instruction: Call them in.
response: [calling offstage] Do you hear, ho?

instruction: If only you were, sir.
response: By this hand, I am.

instruction: Why have you not proclaimed Northumberland and all the rest of the rebels as traitors?
response: We have: whereupon the Earl of Worcester Hath broke his staff, resign'd his stewardship, And all the household servants fled with him To Bolingbroke.

instruction: Could I speak with you a moment, your honor? It is urgent.
response: Near!

instruction: Oh, curse those evil people! It was a person like this who got inside your head and made you suspect that I cheated on you with the Moor.
response: You are a fool.

instruction: Who could say that I'm a villain, when I give free and honest advice that is helpful for Cassio in winning back the Moor's favor? For it really is easy to persuade Desdemona to help you in anything. She gives rise to as many good things as nature itself. And Othello is such a slave to his love for her that he would renounce his baptism and reject all symbols of Christian redemption to win her over. She can do whatever she wants, and whatever she desires he will carry out. How then could I be a villain, when I am advising Cassio to do what is in his best interest? That's Satan's theology! When devils do the worst sins, they first put on the pretense of goodness and innocence, as I am doing now. For while this honest fool begs Desdemona to fix his misfortune and while she pleads on his behalf to the Moor, I'll poison Othello's thoughts by whispering into his ear. I'll say that Desdemona is standing up for Cassio because she is attracted to him. The more that she argues for Cassio, the guiltier she'll seem to the Moor. In this way I'll turn her own virtue into a sort of tar, to entrap herand everyone elsewith her own goodness.
response: How now, Roderigo!

instruction: Sir, I didn't do anything. These gentlemen are my friends and can vouch for me.
response: We can: my royal liege,He is not guilty of her coming hither.

instruction: Anything.
response: Do not desire to see this letter.

instruction: Come on, buddy!
response: Ha, come and bring away the nets!

instruction: Norfolk, there's a worse sentence for you, which I say with some regret: the slow hours will not bring you any closer to ending your banishment, for I order you never to return, upon pain of death.
response: A heavy sentence, my most sovereign liege, And all unlook'd for from your highness' mouth: A dearer merit, not so deep a maim As to be cast forth in the common air, Have I deserved at your highness' hands.

instruction: It looks like food for kings.
response: Doubt not that, if money and the season can yieldit.

instruction: I swear by my own hand, I am. Good fool, bring me some ink, paper, and light, and then deliver the letter I'll write to my lady. You'll be better rewarded for delivering this letter than you've ever been rewarded before.
response: I will help you to t.

instruction: Well, I can cut a caper.
response: And I can cut the mutton to t.

instruction: Groan?! Why, of course not. Just tell me who it is.
response: A sick man in sadness makes his will,A word ill urged to one that is so ill.

instruction: Oh my friends, I wanted to say one thing to you. You, my good lord, I must beg youpleaseto honor me by taking this jewel. Accept it and wear it kindly, my lord.
response: I am so far already in your gifts,

instruction: Now the winter of our troubles has been transformed into glorious summer by the ascension of my brother, King Edward IV, son of the house of York. All the clouds that had descended over our family have now been banished and returned to the sea. Now we wear wreaths of victory on our foreheads, and we've hung up our armor as decoration. We've exchanged the sound of our battle trumpets for the sound of joyful greetings, and our death marches have become stately dances. The grim, warlike expressions on our faces have smoothed. And instead of charging on armored horses to frighten our opponents, we now dance in ladies' chambers to seductive songs on the lute. But as for me, I am not made for such games of love, or to admire myself in a mirror. I was badly made, and I lack the good looks to strut in front of passing girls. Nature has cheated me out of handsome features and proper proportions. I was born deformed, unfinished, and born prematurely. I was barely half-created when I came into the world, and left so lame and misshapen that dogs bark at me as I limp past them. In such delicate times of peace, I have nothing to do. No joys help me pass the time, unless I want to see my own shadow in the sun and make speeches about my deformity. Therefore, since I cannot amuse myself by being a lover during these peaceful days, I am determined to become a villain. I have hatched plots and put dangerous plans into action, using prophecies made while drunk; slander; and stories about dreams in order to set my brother George, Duke of Clarence, against my other brother, the king, so that they hate each other. If King Edward is as true as I am clever, false, and treacherous, then this very day Clarence will be imprisoned because of a prophecy that "G" will murder Edward's children. But, you thoughts, hide yourselves deep down in my soul, for here comes Clarence.
response: Brother, good day.

instruction: Come, sir, you rudely threw it to her, and she wants it to be returned just as rudely. [he throws down the ring] If it's worth stooping to pick up, there it is where you can see it. If not, let whoever finds it first have it.
response: I left no ring with her.

instruction: Let him know, son. There's no reason he would disapprove your choice.
response: Come, come, he must not.Mark our contract.

instruction: He and I have triumphed in the great shower of your gifts and enjoyed it so much!
response: Ay, you are honest men.

instruction: Now, by my Saint George, my garter, and my crown
response: Profaned, dishonored, and the third usurped.

instruction: She's a little purebred hunting hound, and she adores me. What of it?
response: I was adored once too.

instruction: Ive drawn my sword out of its sheath. Fight them! Ill back you up.
response: How?

instruction: So it is. I wonder what it means.
response: Marry, peace it bodes, and love, and quiet life,And awful rule, and right supremacy,And, to be short, what not thats sweet and happy?

instruction: Oh, my mistressa villain has played tricks with love. My husband said she was unfaithful!
response: He, woman.

instruction: Well, sir, my friends praise me and in so doing make a fool of me, while my enemies tell me plainly that I am a fool. Therefore my enemies help me gain knowledge of myself, while my friends deceive me. The same rule applies to both conclusions and kissessince four negatives make two affirmatives, I'm worse because of my friends and better because of my enemies.
response: Why, this is excellent.

instruction: He asked me forhere he is.
response: With all my heart, gentlemen both; and how fare you?

instruction: I don't think he'd have any choice, my lord, believe me.
response: It would seem strange unto him when he waked.

instruction: What now?
response: Please you, my lord, that honourable gentleman, Lord Lucullus, entreats your company to-morrow to hunt with him, and has sent your honour two brace of greyhounds.

instruction: The matter, sir! I think most people can understand the fact that Polixenes is staying here longer.
response: Ha!

instruction: I mean, sir, that by delaying were wasting our torches, which is like wasting the sunshine during the day. Show your good judgment by taking what I say the way I mean it, which is five times more important than literally trusting your five senses.
response: And we mean well in going to this mask,But tis no wit to go.

instruction: What is it?
response: That it would please you leave these sad designs To him that hath more cause to be a mourner, And presently repair to Crosby House, Where, after I have solemnly interred At Chertsey monast'ry this noble king And wet his grave with my repent

instruction: [As VINCENTIO] Help, son! Help, Sir Baptista!
response: Prithee, Kate, lets stand aside and see the end of this controversy.

instruction: Why only a "small group," my Lord of Buckingham?
response: Marry, my lord, lest by a multitude The new-healed wound of malice should break out, Which would be so much the more dangerous By how much the estate is green and yet ungoverned.

instruction: Hes more than just the Prince of Cats. Oh, he does everything according to convention. He fights like you sing printed music, carefully keeping the correct time, distance, and rhythm. He rests when it is proper to rest: one, two, and the third in your heart. Hes a master duelist who can hit any of his opponents buttons that he chooses. Hes a gentleman who learned at the finest fencing school, and hes skilled at identifying insults and slights to his honor so that hes forced to fight. He knows the passadothe forward thrustthe punto reversothe backhand thrustand the haithe thrust for the heart.
response: The what?

instruction: Hurry as fast as you can, and don't go too far inlandthis storm looks bad. Besides, this place is famous for its man-eating animals.
response: Go thou away:I'll follow instantly.

instruction: Are you talking to yourself?
response: I speak not to thee.

instruction: Who takes a friend into consideration when it comes to love?
response: All men but Proteus.

His promises exceed what he has by so much that what he offers is putting him even further in debt. He owes money for every word he gives. He is so kind that now he pays interest for it. His land has been incorporated into their accounts. Well, I wish I were relieved of this job before he is forced to fire me! The man is happier that has no friends to feed than the one who has friends that do him more harm than enemies. I hurt so much for my lord!

instruction: My holy lady, these are two flaws that some alcohol and good advice will fix. If you give the dry fool a drink, then the fool won't be dry anymore. Anything that's mended is only patched up. A virtuous man who does something wrong is only patched with sin, and a sinner who mends his ways is only patched with virtue. If this logical argument will convince you, then good. But if not, what can be done? The only truly betrayed husband is one deserted by luck, and beauty is a lucky flowerso you won't remain alone for long, my lady. But you gave orders to take away the fool. instruction: My Lord of Buckingham, if my weak words can persuade his mother to give up the Duke of York, then you can expect him here soon. But if she resists my mild requests, then God forbid that we should break the holy laws of sanctuary! I would not commit such a terrible sin even in exchange for a kingdom.
response: You are too senseless obstinate, my lord, Too ceremonious and traditional.

instruction: No, sir, I'm worse.
response: How can that be?

instruction: May God protect his Majesty!
response: Long live Gonzalo!

instruction: Well, I'll have to rape her, or she'll ruin all our customers, converting the evil-doers to good.
response: Now, the pox upon her green-sickness for me!

instruction: You've faced many things, haven't you?
response: I have.

instruction: Asses are meant for bearing, and so are you.
response: Women are made to bear, and so are you.

instruction: Im just trying to keep the peace. Put away your sword, or else use it to help me stop this fighting.
response: What, drawn, and talk of peace?

instruction: No, boy, not that; Ill teach you another way. Lavinia, come. Marcus, take care of my house while Im gone; Lucius and I will go make a spectacle of ourselves at court. Yes, indeed we will, sir; and theyll pay attention.
response: O heavens, can you hear a good man groan, And not relent, or not compassion him?

instruction: Madam, Im here. What do you want?
response: This is the matter.Nurse, give leave awhile, We must talk in secret.

instruction: [Picking up the letter] By God, this is my lady's handwritingthese are her C's, her U's, and her T's, and this is how she makes her big P's. It's her handwriting, without question.
response: ( aside ) Her Cs, her Us and her Ts.

instruction: Let's go meet and welcome him.
response: Lo, where he comes!

instruction: [To herself] But love won't be inspired by something it hates.
response: What says she to my face?

instruction: I beg you, dont scold me. The one I love now returns my love. The other did not.
response: Oh, she knew well Thy love did read by rote, that could not spell.

instruction: What must be will be.
response: Thats a certain text.

instruction: Not to his fathers house. I asked Romeos servant.
response: Why, that same pale hard-hearted wench, that Rosaline, Torments him so, that he will sure run mad.

instruction: Be quiet, monster. Madame clothesline, isn't this my jacket? Thank you kindly. Now the jacket is under the line. Now, jacket, you'll probably lose your fur trim and become a bald jacket.
response: Do, do.

instruction: Then I do not lie.
response: Art not a poet?

instruction: Oh, no! You're dying, although I'm the sicker one.
response: I am in health, I breathe, and see thee ill.

instruction: I won't.
response: Should you do so, my lord, My speech should fall into such vile success Which my thoughts aimed not at.

instruction: Monster, use your fingers. Help to carry these clothes to where my barrel of wine is, or Ill throw you out of my kingdom. Get going, carry this.
response: And this.

instruction: The feud is between our masters and us, their servants.
response: Tis all one.

instruction: And you're not a loyal man, as we are.
response: Thy voice is thunder, but thy looks are humble.

instruction: Do something for me before I come to you. I see that Rape and Murder stand by your side; to prove that you really are Revenge, stab them or crush them under the wheels of your chariot. Then Ill come and be your charioteer, and travel with you around the globe. Ill give you two black horses to pull your wagon of revenge as you find the murderers in their guilty caves; and when the cart is loaded with their heads, Ill dismount and trot alongside your wheel like a slavish footman all day long, from when the sun rises in the east until it falls into the sea. And Ill do this hard task every day, if you destroy Rape and Murder there.
response: These are my ministers, and come with me.

instruction: Fair cousin? I must be greater than a kingfor when I was a king, my flatterers were only subjects, but now as a subject, I have a king to flatter me. Since Im so great, I suppose theres no need to beg.
response: Yet ask.

instruction: You are as impetuous as fire to say that she was unfaithful. She was heavenly faithful and honest!
response: Cassio did top her, ask thy husband else.

instruction: But villain, aren't you the messenger?
response: Ay, of my pigeons, sir; nothing else.

instruction: I am your wife, my lord. Your true and loyal wife.
response: Come, swear it, damn thyself.

instruction: Why, what do you mean by "moveable?"
response: A joint stool.

instruction: [Singing] Alas, why is she like this?
response: Fool, I say!

instruction: We want the money Timon owes.
response: Ay, If money were as certain as your waiting, 'Twere sure enough.

instruction: Not since the time of the widow Dido.
response: Widow!

instruction: [Whispering] Oh, if only I had a slingshot, to shoot him in the eye!
response: Calling my officers about me, in my branched velvet gown, having come from a daybed, where I have left Olivia sleeping

instruction: You've spoken your piece, now.
response: Ay, and said nothing but what I protest intendment of doing.

instruction: I did not kill your husband.
response: Why then, he is alive.

instruction: Well, what are you?
response: Your wife, my lord.

instruction: [To soldiers] Give me a goblet of wine. Give me a personal guard. Saddle my white horse Surrey for the battle tomorrow. Make sure that my lances are strong, but not too heavy.
response: My lord.

instruction: I pardon him, as God shall pardon me.
response: O happy vantage of a kneeling knee!

instruction: How many women saw his child?
response: Why, so, brave lords!

instruction: Richmond? The last time I was in Exeter, the mayor politely showed me a castle and called it "Rougemont." The name startled me, for an Irish poet once told me that I wouldn't live long after seeing Richmond.
response: My Lord

instruction: Time to be honest.
response: That time serves still.

instruction: I believe you; the look on his face said it all. Give me your hand: if you lead me out of here, you can continue to work for me as my servant. My ships are ready and my people are, too, because they had expected to leave two days ago. Leontes is jealous of a very special woman and, because she's so special, his jealousy is intense; because he's a powerful king, his jealousy will be violent, too, and because he thinks he's been betrayed by his best friend, his revenge will be horrific. I'm paralyzed with fear. Let's hope we have a safe journey out and that the queen doesn't become a victim, too, of his delusions. Come on, Camillo. I'll love you as much as I love my own father if you can get me out of here alive. Let's go.
response: It is in mine authority to commandThe keys of all the posterns: please your highnessTo take the urgent hour.

instruction: I figured. It never rains but it pours; one struggle gives way to another. It's that way with us. Some nearby country is going to take advantage of our weakness. They've sent all these ships to kick us while we're down, and conquer us in our misery, though it'll hardly be difficult for them to overcome us.
response: That's the least fear; for, by the semblanceOf their white flags display'd, they bring us peace,And come to us as favourers, not as foes.

instruction: Not if you get out of here without saying another word.
response: [as LUCENTIO] Why, sir, I pray, are not the streets as free For me as for you?

instruction: It's like this: Baptista is safely taken care of. He's talking with the pretend father of the pretend son.
response: And what of him?

instruction: That light isnt daylight, I know it. Its some meteor sent from the sun to be a torchbearer, in order to light your way to Mantua. So stay for a bit longer. You dont have to leave.
response: Let me be taen.

instruction: Her eyes almost look like they're moving; this art is too realistic.
response: I'll draw the curtain:My lord's almost so far transported thatHe'll think anon it lives.

instruction: No, listen to me.
response: Nay, but hear me.

instruction: Quiet, please. Let someone who knows what he's talking about speak up. These men are just flattering you, sir, and flattery only fans the fire of sin. When a king's fault is just a spark, flattery is the blast that gives it heat and makes it glow stronger. On the other hand, wise advice is the best tool a king can make use of, since even kings make mistakes sometimes. When Mr. Yes-man over here wishes you good luck, he's flattering you and, really, threatening your life.[He kneels] Forgive me, sir. Hit me if you want. I can't get much lower than here, on my knees.
response: All leave us else; but let your cares o'erlookWhat shipping and what lading's in our haven,And then return to us.

instruction: These events are not natural. They keep getting stranger and stranger.[To BOATSWAIN] Tell me, how did you get here?
response: If I did think, sir, I were well awake, Id strive to tell you.

instruction: The Duke sends his greetings, General. And he orders you to come appear before him immediately, right this very instant.
response: Whats the matter, think you?

instruction: I'm such a fool to cry at the thing that makes me happy.
response: [aside] Fair encounterOf two most rare affections!

instruction: Are you a courtier or not, sir?
response: Whether it like me or no, I am a courtier.

instruction: What?
response: No more of drowning, do you hear?

instruction: Thanks for that joke. Here's some clothes in return. Jokes won't go unrewarded when I'm king of this country. Stealing with a plumb-line and carpenter's level is an excellent little joke. Heres some more clothes as a reward.
response: Monster, come, put some lime upon your fingers, and away with the rest.

instruction: Have you spread the word about her all over the market?
response: I have cried her almost to the number of her hairs;I have drawn her picture with my voice.

instruction: And please, tell me: how do people seem to be reacting, especially the younger ones?
response: 'Faith, they listened to me as they would have hearkened to their father's testament.

instruction: I thank you for that, master.
response: If thou more murmurst, I will rend an oak And peg thee in his knotty entrails till Thou hast howled away twelve winters.

instruction: Tunis used to be Carthage, sir.
response: Carthage?

instruction: Is anyone listening to me?
response: Who is't that goes with me?

instruction: Is the worst well? Very well taken, in truth, very wise.
response: If you be he, sir, I desire some confidence with you.

instruction: Please, sir. Now is not the time to talk about this. Keep your questions until after dinner, then I will tell you why you have not repaid these debts.
response: Do so, my friends.

instruction: Good madam, don't be angry with the child.
response: Pitchers have ears.

instruction: Honest, yes, honest.
response: My lord, for aught I know.

instruction: If you want your eyes scratched out, then come at me. I'll leave on my own, but first I have to do what I came for. The good queen (because she is good) has given birth to your daughter. Here she is, now give her your blessing.
response: Out!A mankind witch!

instruction: [Taking the money] This afternoon, sir? She will be there.
response: And stay, good Nurse.

instruction: I've described her down to every last hair. I've drawn a picture of her with my voice.
response: And I prithee tell me, how dost thou find theinclination of the people, especially of the younger sort?

instruction: God bless you, and fill you with humility, love, charity, obedience, and true duty.
response: [standing] Amen.

instruction: What is she looking for? Lavinia, do you want me to read? This is the tragic story of Philomel, who was raped by Tereusand rape, I fear, was what happened to you.
response: See, brother, see; note how she quotes the leaves.

instruction: Because I would have lost the angry wit I now have if I were a lord. Aren't you a merchant?
response: Ay, Apemantus.

instruction: That's how you've interpreted it: it's your fault then.
response: How dost thou like this jewel, Apemantus?

instruction: Are my master and his wife coming, Grumio?
response: O, ay, Curtis, ay, and therefore fire, fire.

instruction: [To CASSIO] Who are you that's crying out in such pain?
response: Iago?

instruction: Oh, sir!
response: Drew sleep out of mine eyes, blood from my cheeks, Musings into my mind, with thousand doubts How I might stop this tempest ere it came; And finding little comfort to relieve them, I thought it princely charity to grieve them.

instruction: Yes, it's monstrous, monstrous! That's how it is for Rivers, Vaughan, and Grey. And that's how it will be soon for some other men who think they're as safe as you and I arewe who are dear to princely Richard and Buckingham.
response: The princes both make high account of you [aside] For they account his head upon the Bridge.

instruction: Oh, happy outcome from my kneeling! But I am still afraid; say it again. Two pardons is better than one.
response: With all my heartI pardon him.

instruction: Guys, what do you want me to say? The gods hear me when I say that I am as broke as you are.
response: Such a house broke!

instruction: No, but I am resolved on two points.
response: That if one break, the other will hold.

instruction: The gods, through you, amaze us. You've secured your fame forever.
response: She is alive; behold, Her eyelids, cases to those heavenly jewels Which Pericles hath lost, Begin to part their fringes of bright gold; The diamonds of a most praised water Do appear, to make the world twice rich.

instruction: I swear I'll hit you if you strike me again.
response: So may you lose your arms.If you strike me, you are no gentleman;And if no gentleman, why then no arms.

instruction: [Speaking to the door of the tomb] You hateful mouth, you womb of death. Youve feasted on the most precious girl on earth. So now Im going to force open your rotten jaws and cram more food into you. [ROMEO begins to open the tomb with his tools]
response: [Aside] This is that banished haughty Montague, That murdered my loves cousin, with which grief, It is supposed the fair creature died.

instruction: Sweet saint, for goodness's sake, don't be so harsh.
response: Foul devil, for Gods sake, hence, and trouble us not, For thou hast made the happy earth thy hell, Filled it with cursing cries and deep exclaims.

instruction: How are things going, Roderigo?
response: I do follow here in the chase not like a hound that hunts, but one that fills up the cry.

instruction: I'm afraid to know, sir.
response: How!

instruction: Most radiant, exquisite, and unmatchable beautybut please, tell me if you're really the lady of the house, for I've never actually seen her. I would hate to throw away my speech on the wrong person, for it is excellently written and was very hard for me to memorize. Good beauties, please don't scorn me. I'm very sensitive, even to the slightest bit of rudeness.
response: Whence came you, sir?

instruction: Oh villains, vipers, damn them to hell! Dogs, easily won to slobber over any man! Snakes, nurtured in my own blood, that now sting my heart! Three Judases, each one three times worse than Judas! They want peace? Let hell make war on their souls for this!
response: Sweet love, I see, changing his property, Turns to the sourest and most deadly hate: Again uncurse their souls; their peace is made With heads, and not with hands; those whom you curse Have felt the worst of death's destroying wound And lie

instruction: Gentlemen, will you go raise men for battle? I don't know how or which way to order the disorderly affairs that have been thrust into my hands, believe me. Both are of my family: the one is my sovereign, whom both my oath and duty bids me to defend; the other is also my kinsman, who the king has wronged, and conscience and my family bids me to fight for his rights. Well, we have to do something.
response: The wind sits fair for news to go to Ireland, But none returns .

instruction: Why should you be afraid? Doesn't the city have strong defenses?
response: Ay, but the citizens favor Lucius,And will revolt from me to succor him.

instruction: I cannot believe that those outraged at wicked men should still ask for money!
response: Whose womb unmeasurable, and infinite breast, Teems, and feeds all; whose self-same mettle, Whereof thy proud child, arrogant man, is puff'd, Engenders the black toad and adder blue, The gilded newt and eyeless venom'd worm, With all the ab

instruction: Yes, and it's a good marriage. He's married to a woman that surpasses description and exceeds her reputation. Words can't express how great she is, and no artist could capture her natural beauty.
response: How now?

instruction: Sir, I told her not to come near you, and explained that you (and I) would both be angry with her if she did.
response: What, canst not rule her?

instruction: Shes the fairies midwife, and is no bigger than the stone on the ring of a city councilman. She rides her carriage, which is pulled by tiny little creatures, over mens noses as they lie sleeping. The wheel spokes of her carriage are made of spiders legs; its cover is made of grasshopper wings; and its harnesses are made of the smallest spiderwebs. The horse collars are made from moonbeams, while her whip is a single cobweb attached to a cricket bone. Her wagon driver is a tiny gnat wearing a gray coat that is not even half as large as a little round worm that comes from the finger of a lazy young girl. Her carriage is an empty hazelnut, made by a squirrel and an old worm, which have been the fairies carriage-builders for countless years. With this magnificent carriage she rides each night through the brains of lovers, who then dream about love. She rides across courtiers knees, who then dream about bowing and curtsying. She rides over lawyers fingers, who then dream about their fees. She rides over ladies lips, and they immediately dream of kisses. But Queen Mab often puts blisters on their lips because their breath smells of candy, which angers her. Sometimes she rides over a courtiers nose, and he dreams of sniffing out a way to make some money. Sometimes she tickles a priests nose with the tail of pig given as a tithe to the church, and he dreams of getting a high-paid church position. Sometimes she drives over a soldiers neck, and he dreams of cutting the throats of foreigners, of breaking through fortifications, of ambushes, of the finest-quality Spanish swords, and of huge mugs of alcohol before suddenly waking, frightened, by the sound of drums in his ears. Then he says a prayer or two and goes back to sleep. Mab is the one who tangles the hair of horses manes at night and then hardens the tangles in the foul, dirty hairs; tangles which, if you undo them, bring bad luck. Mab is the hag who gives dreams of sex to virgins and teaches them how to bear the weight of a lover and to bear a child. Shes the one
response: Peace, peace, Mercutio, peace!Thou talkst of nothing.

instruction: [To RICHARD] May I weigh down your soul tomorrow! Remember how you stabbed me at Tewkesbury in the prime of my life. So despair, and die!
response: [to RICHARD] When I was mortal, my anointed body By thee was punchèd full of deadly holes.

instruction: You have a strange way of snoring. It sounds like you're speaking actual words.
response: I am more serious than my custom.

instruction: And he also wants to know where you came from, what your name is, and who your parents are.
response: A gentleman of Tyre; my name, Pericles; My education been in arts and arms; Who, looking for adventures in the world, Was by the rough seas reft of ships and men, And after shipwreck driven upon this shore.

instruction: All three of them are desperate. Their guiltlike a poison given time to work in their bodiesnow begins to bite at their consciences. Those who are lively and energetic, I beg you, quickly follow them and stop them from doing whatever this fit of insanity is pushing them to do.
response: Follow, I pray you.

instruction: So, will that be tonight at dinner?
response: No, not tonight.

instruction: [Reading] "With a flared half-circle cape"
response: I confess the cape.

instruction: Catesby, hurry to the Duke of Buckingham.
response: I will, my lord, with all convenient haste.

instruction: Your mother.
response: Madam, I am here.

instruction: Because you're like the peasant who strikes the bell, interrupting my thoughts with your begging. I'm not in the giving mood today.
response: Why then, resolve me whether you will or no.

instruction: Great Ventidius! Well, I am not the type of man to neglect a friend in need. I know that he is a gentleman that deserves assistance, which he will get. I'll pay the debt for his freedom.
response: Your lordship ever binds him.

instruction: Damn it, if I'd known that he was so brave and skilled at fighting, I wouldn't have challenged him in a million years. If he'll forget the whole matter, I'll give him my gray horse Capilet.
response: Ill make the motion.

instruction: Come, bring her here.
response: Where is the gentleman that was with her?

instruction: Iago knows what he is supposed to do. But nonetheless, I will personally look after things.
response: Iago is most honest.

instruction: [To ALONSO] I swear on the Virgin Mary, I cant go any further, sir. My old bones are aching. It's like we're walking in a maze, with some paths straight and some crooked. If it's all right with you, I need to rest.
response: Old lord, I cannot blame thee, Who am myself attached with weariness To th' dulling of my spirits.

instruction: They've fired a shot as a greeting. This ship is also friendly.
response: See for the news.

instruction: But the worst is yet to comechildren who arent even born yet will remember this day as sharp as a thorn to them.
response: You holy clergymen, is there no plotTo rid the realm of this pernicious blot?

instruction: Let's hear it, good Grumio.
response: Lend thine ear.

instruction: Oh, wait a minute![To himself] This is the strangest dream that a poor idiot ever had. This can't be true; my daughter is dead. [To MARINA] Well, where were you born? I'll listen to you again, to the whole story, and won't interrupt you anymore.
response: You scorn: believe me, 'twere best I did give o'er.

instruction: It is my poverty, not my morals, that forces me to agree.
response: I pay thy poverty and not thy will.

instruction: Sir, is she a princess?
response: She is,When once she is my wife.

instruction: Why are you crying, pretty girl?
response: That I am pretty.

instruction: Sir, sir, sir
response: But thou must needs be sure My spirits and my place have in their powerTo make this bitter to thee.

instruction: You're an idiot. Go away.
response: I love thee better now than e'er I did.

instruction: Cassio isn't killed? Then the murder was botched, and sweet revenge hasn't gone as planned.
response: Oh, falsely, falsely murdered!

instruction: And tell us what was so important that it made you late for your wedding, and sent you here dressed so unlike yourself.
response: Tedious it were to tell and harsh to hear.

instruction: If you really love my brother Richard, then don't hate me. I am his brother, and I love him very much. If you're hired to do this for money, then go back again and talk to my brother the Duke of Gloucester. He will reward you better for sparing my life than King Edward will for news of my death.
response: You are deceived.

instruction: Youre still affected by the magic and illusions of this island, which make it hard for you to believe that anything is real. Welcome to all of you, my friends.[To SEBASTIAN and ANTONIO so that only they can hear] But if I wanted to, I could prove that the two of you were traitors. And then you'd face the King's anger. But at the moment I wont say anything.
response: The devil speaks in him.

instruction: Unless I've mistaken his bannerswhich I'm sure I haven'this regiment lies at least half a mile south of the King's mighty army.
response: If without peril it be possible, Sweet Blunt, make some good means to speak with him,And give him from me this most needful note.

instruction: Wait! Ill come with you. If you leave me behind, youll be insulting me.
response: Tut, I have lost myself.

instruction: Confine myself? I'll only confine myself to these clothes I'm wearing. They're good enough to drink in, and these boots are too. And if they aren't, then let them hang themselves by their own straps.
response: That quaffing and drinking will undo you: I heard my lady talk of it yesterday, and of a foolish knight that you brought in one night here to be her wooer.

instruction: Oh, how many cursed and violent days of unrest have my old eyes seen? My husband lost his life to get the crown. And my sons' lives have been tossed up and down for me to rejoice over their gains and weep over their losses. And when one of them gained the throne and got rid of the domestic quarrels, now the conquerors turn on each other, making war among themselvesbrother against brother, blood against blood, self against self. Oh, it's a perversion of the natural order, a frenzied outrage! Let it endor let me dieso I won't have to see any more death.
response: [to YORK] Come, come, my boy.

instruction: As you wish.
response: [Within] My liege, beware; look to thyself;Thou hast a traitor in thy presence there.

instruction: Give me your hand. And, Perdita, give me yours.
response: Soft, swain, awhile, beseech you;Have you a father?

instruction: No, by the Holy Cross, and you know it well. You came to earth to make the earth my hell. Your birth was a painful burden to me. You were fussy and willful as a baby. Your school days were frightening, wild, and angry. As a young man, you were daring, bold, and adventurous. And in your maturity you've grown proud, cunning, sly, and bloodyless wild but more dangerous, flattering in your hatred. Can you name a comfortable hour I've ever had in your company?
response: Faith, none but Humfrey Hower, that called your Grace To breakfast once, forth of my company.

instruction: How are you, my headstrong daughter? Where have you been?
response: Where I have learned me to repent the sin Of disobedient opposition To you and your behests, and am enjoined By holy Lawrence to fall prostrate here To beg your pardon.

instruction: Not really.
response: Why, I'll tell you: this is called Pentapolis, andour king the good Simonides.

instruction: Now Iago is asking Cassio to tell the story again. Go on, well said, well said.
response: She gives it out that you shall marry her.Do you intend it?

instruction: See, here she comes, bringing your willful wives with her as prisoners of her womanly duty. Katherine, that cap of yours doesn't look good. Take off the silly thing and stomp on it.
response: Lord, let me never have a cause to sigh,Till I be brought to such a silly pass!

instruction: If we exchanged vows of love.
response: I gave thee mine before thou didst request it,And yet I would it were to give again.

instruction: And good luck on your journey!
response: Peace, peace, and give experience tongue.

instruction: Now God in heaven forbid!
response: Ah, madam, 'tis too true: and that is worse, The Lord Northumberland, his son young Henry Percy, The Lords of Ross, Beaumond, and Willoughby, With all their powerful friends, are fled to him.

instruction: By heaven, they have already given me a drink.
response: Good faith, a little one, not past a pint, As I am a soldier.

instruction: How is my noble lord doing?
response: Marry, I fare well,For here is cheer enough.

instruction: The ground is actually brown.
response: With an eye of green in t.

instruction: I wish my tongue could rot them off!
response: Away, thou issue of a mangy dog!Choler does kill me that thou art alive;I swound to see thee.

instruction: Ive been too strongly pierced by his arrow to soar. My wounded heart wont let me escape my dull sadness. I am sinking under loves heavy burden.
response: And to sink in it, should you burthen loveToo great oppression for a tender thing.

instruction: Come here, poor baby. I've heard (but haven't believed) stories about spirits of the dead walking the earth. If these things do happen, then your mother appeared to me last night in a dream that was so real, it felt like I was awake. Something walked toward me, moving its head from side to side. I've never seen anything so sad and so completely beautiful. In pure white robes, like a goddess, she walked toward the place where I was sleeping. She bowed three times, gasping as she tried to speak. Crying with rage, she finally burst out, "Antigonus, you have the bad luck to be disposing of my baby far away in Bohemia. Shed a tear as you leave her there. Since she's lost forever, you should call her 'Perdita.' And for what my husband has made you do, you'll never see your wife, Paulina, again." Then, shrieking, she disappeared into thin air. Terrified, it took me a while to collect myself, and I wasn't sure if it was a dream or not. Usually I don't put much stock in dreams, but this one I'd swear by superstitiously. I believe that Hermione died, and that Apollo wants this baby (who must be King Polixenes's daughter) to be laid here on its father's land, to either live or die. [He places the baby on the ground in a basket with a letter and some jewels] Good luck! There you are, and there's the story of your identity. If you make it, these things might help you. The storm is beginning! Poor brat, you're out in the elements thanks to your mother's mistake, and who knows what will happen! I can't cry, but my heart is bleeding and I'm damned for getting tangled up in this. Goodbye! It's getting darker and darker. I'm afraid the lullaby you're about to get will be a little on the rough side; I've never seen the sky so black in the daytime. The thunder, the lightning! I need to get aboard the ship! [Walking away, he sees a bear running toward him] Well, this is it: I'm gone forever.
response: I would there were no age between sixteen and three-and-twenty, or that youth would sleep out the rest; for there is nothing in the between but getting wenches with child, wronging the ancientry, stealing, fighting Hark you now!

instruction: [Singing] Where is the life I used to lead? Where are thoseSit down, Kate, and make yourself welcome.Food, food, food, food!
response: Why, when, I say?Nay, good sweet Kate, be merry.

instruction: I will do so. Sir Fabian, stay with this gentleman until I return.
response: Pray you, sir, do you know of this matter?

instruction: That may be will be, on Thursday, my love.
response: What must be shall be.

instruction: All right, men, take a good look at her. I know what you're thinking: "She's an attractive woman, but it's too bad that she's a liar and a cheater." You can compliment her outer beauty, sureI mean, she deserves that! But then you have to admit that liars use their good looks to manipulate others into thinking they're good people! Your shrugs and your "hmms" show you're hesitant to say "she's honest," right? Everybody believe me; I'm the the real victim. She's having an affair.
response: Should a villain say so,The most replenish'd villain in the world,He were as much more villain: you, my lord,Do but mistake.

instruction: What a monstrous act!
response: Villainy, villainy, villainy!

instruction: You didn't mourn with us when we were left fatherless. Your sadness as a widow will likewise go unmourned by us!
response: G ive me no help in lamentation.

instruction: Yes, but you must at least confine yourself within the limits of order and decency.
response: Confine?

instruction: The weather's fantastic, the air is fresh, the island is lush, and the temple is even more beautiful than everyone says it is.
response: I shall report,For most it caught me, the celestial habits,Methinks I so should term them, and the reverenceOf the grave wearers.

instruction: Yesthere are a dozen, and in fact as many as would populate the whole world that they wagered for. But I think that if wives are unfaithful, it is their husbands' fault. Let's say they stop sleeping with us and give themselves to other women instead, or break out in fits of jealousy and impose restraints on us. Or let's say they hit us, or spitefully cut back on our allowance. Why, we feel resentment, and although we have some grace, we can still have some revenge, too. Let husbands know that their wives have good sense just like them. They see and smell and can taste both sweet and sour, just like their husbands can. What are they doing when they switch us out for other women? Is it for fun? I think so. And does physical attraction lead to it? I think so. Is it a weakness to do this wrong? I think so, too. And don't we have physical attractions, desire for fun, and weakness, just like men? They should treat us well, or else they should know that whatever bad things we do, we are only following their example.
response: Good night, good night.

instruction: You make gold from metal. Here, make gold from this! Get out of here you dogs!
response: It is in vain that you would speak with Timon; For he is set so only to himself That nothing but himself which looks like man Is friendly with him.

instruction: That sounds good to me.Cambio, hurry home and tell Bianca to get ready right away. And, if you want to, tell her what has happened: Lucentio's father has come to Padua, and now she's likely to be Lucentio's wife.
response: I pray the gods she may, with all my heart!

instruction: Well, may peace be with you. Here comes the man Im after.
response: But Ill be hanged, sir, if he wear your livery.Marry, go before to field, hell be your follower.Your worship in that sense may call him man.

instruction: Sir, after having received so many of your gifts, and then hearing you were retired, abandoned by friends so ungrateful that all the whips of heaven are not large enough to punish them. Incredible! To you, whose stellar generosity gave life to them! It drives me mad, and I cannot conceive of any way to describe this level of ingratitude.
response: Let it go naked, men may see't the better:You that are honest, by being what you are,Make them best seen and known.

instruction: Because my name is George.
response: Alack, my lord, that fault is none of yours.

instruction: Go ahead and speak, Othello.
response: Her father loved me, oft invited me, Still questioned me the story of my life From year to year, the battles, sieges, fortunes, That I have passed.

instruction: Perdita, come here. [PERDITA and FLORIZEL move away to talk privately][To CAMILLO] I'll listen to you in a minute.
response: He's irremoveable, Resolved for flight.

instruction: I will, holy lady, but even if I read this letter sanely, I'll still sound crazy. So pay attention, my princess, and listen.
response: [giving the letter to FABIAN] Read it you, sirrah.

instruction: I now have this high seat as King Richard because of your advice and assistance. But will I have these glories for a day only, or will they last long enough for me to enjoy them?
response: Still live they, and forever let them last.

instruction: [To himself] Its that arrogant Montague who was banished. Hes the one who murdered my loves cousin Tybalt, which caused Juliet the grief that they think killed her. And here hes come to do something terrible and shameful to the dead bodies. Ill arrest him.
response: I must indeed, and therefore came I hither.

instruction: He's breathing, my lord. But he couldn't be sleeping so deeply in such a cold place if beer wasn't keeping him warm.
response: O monstrous beast, how like a swine he lies!

instruction: Lord Timon, would you hear me speak?
response: Freely, good father.

instruction: I hope he is, but mothers can have their doubts.
response: Now, by my troth, if I had been remembered,I could have given my uncles grace a flout To touch his growth nearer than he touched mine.

instruction: As in the pink flower.
response: Right.

instruction: These are my agents, and come with me wherever I go.
response: Are these thy ministers?

instruction: It's natural, sir. Wind and rain won't wash it off.
response: 'Tis beauty truly blent, whose red and white Natures own sweet and cunning hand laid on.

instruction: Definitely. Alcibiades says so, and Phrynia and Timandra got gold from him. He also gave the poor soldiers a ton. I also heard he gave his assistant a lot too.
response: Then this breaking of his has been but a try for his friends.

instruction: Tybalt, old Capulets kinsman, has sent a letter to Romeos fathers house.
response: A challenge, on my life.

instruction: Hes been seen at that spot on many mornings, his tears adding to the morning dew and his deep sighs thickening the clouds in the sky. Then, as soon as the happy sun begins to dawn, my unhappy son comes home in order to hide from the light. He keeps to himself in his bedroom, shutting his windows to keep out the daylight so that he can sit in an artificial night. His bad mood is likely to have a bad result, unless someone can give him good advice and remove the cause of his sadness.
response: My noble uncle, do you know the cause?

instruction: Ah, witty Romeo, now youve taken this joke so far that its worn out your pump. With the sole of your pump now worn away, the joke is all that remains.
response: O single-soled jest, solely singular for the singleness.

instruction: Ok, and make sure to take care of them.
response: Pray, draw near.

instruction: Here, my lord, all ready.
response: Our horses!

instruction: You're joking, Tranio! But have you both really given me up?
response: Mistress, we have.

instruction: No, no, living men flatter those that die.
response: Thou, now a-dying, say'st thou flatterest me.

instruction: Heaven, be my witness. I will keep my wish forever.
response: And I mine.

instruction: I'd like to play the pimp, sir, and bring these two lovers together.
response: [giving him money] I understand you, sir.

instruction: To be motivated is to act, while to be valiant is to face a fight. When youre motivated, you just run away.
response: A dog of that house shall move me to stand.

instruction: You idiot, why would you ask if I can "undo it?"
response: O Dionyza, such a piece of slaughterThe sun and moon ne'er look'd upon!

instruction: Uninhabited, and almost inaccessible
response: Yet

instruction: I won't, believe me. I'll visit her like this.
response: But thus, I trust, you will not marry her.

instruction: [To KATHERINE] Say what he wants you to say, or we'll never go.
response: Forward, I pray, since we have come so far, And be it moon, or sun, or what you please.

instruction: Banish me! Banish your old ways! Banish your money-lending! Banish everything that has ruined the senate!
response: If, after two days' shine, Athens contain thee, Attend our weightier judgment.

instruction: I mean they should give her credit.
response: Why, she comes to borrow nothing of them.

instruction: Youve argued well, sirand in return, we arrest you here for capital treason. My Lord of Westminster, keep him under guard until his trial. My lords, may it please you to grant the request from the House of Commons.
response: Fetch hither Richard, that in common view He may surrender; so we shall proceed Without suspicion.

instruction: I'll do it, sir.
response: I will seem friendly, as thou hast advised me.

instruction: Oh, come on. I mean where does he sleep?
response: To tell you where he lodges is to tell you where I lie.

instruction: Do whatever pleases you, within reason.
response: Why should I not, had I the heart to do it, Like to the Egyptian thief at point of death, Kill what I love?

instruction: Thanks, Antiochus, for reminding me of my own mortality. Those frightening things are preparing my body, like theirs, for the worst that could happen: death. When we remember death, it should act like a mirror, reflecting back to us the truth that life is short, and that it's a mistake to put our faith in it. I'll make my will, then, like sick men do when they've experienced the world and, near death, are both sad and resigned to give up the joys experienced on earth. I wish the best to you and to all good men (as every prince should do), and give away all my belongings.
response: Scorning advice, read the conclusion then: Which read and not expounded, 'tis decreed, As these before thee thou thyself shalt bleed.

instruction: [To ANTONIO] The clock strikes one. Count it.
response: When every grief is entertained thats offered,Comes to th' entertainer

instruction: Oh, my dear lady, the sun will set before I've finished the work I've been told to do.
response: If youll sit down,Ill bear your logs the while.

instruction: We'll walk you up to the shore, then we'll give you up to Neptune and pray for the gentlest winds from the skies.
response: I will embrace Your offer.

instruction: No, if our witticisms go on a wild-goose chase, Im done for. You have more wild goose in one of your jokes than I have in five of mine. Was I even close to you in our goose chase?
response: Thou wast never with me for anything when thou wast notthere for the goose.

instruction: I dont know how to tell you who I am by using a name. I hate my name, dear saint, because it is your enemy. If I had it written down, I would tear up the word.
response: My ears have not yet drunk a hundred wordsOf that tongues uttering, yet I know the sound.

instruction: You worked hard to make him stay. As hard as you tried, he insisted he had to get home.
response: Didst note it?

instruction: Your suffering will make them sharp, so they can pierce like mine.
response: Why should calamity be full of words?

instruction: Well follow you. Juliet, Paris is waiting for you.
response: Go, girl, seek happy nights to happy days.

instruction: How are you feeling now?
response: Sweet sir, much better than I was; I can stand andwalk: I will even take my leave of you, and pacesoftly towards my kinsman's.

instruction: Goodbye, then. I have to go buy spices for our sheep-shearing.
response: Prosper you, sweet sir!

instruction: She really is perfect.
response: Well, happiness to their sheets!

instruction: Good gentlemen, give me permission to speak. It is proper for me to obey my husband, but not in this case. Maybe I will never go home, Iago.
response: Oh!

instruction: What does your Highness say to my just request?
response: I do remember me, Henry the Sixth Did prophesy that Richmond should be king, When Richmond was a little peevish boy.

instruction: Go hang yourselves, all of you! You are lazy, shallow creatures. I'm made of better stuff than you. You'll learn more about that, later.
response: Is t possible?

instruction: [To JULIET] I take you at your word. If you call me your love, Ill take a new name. From now on Ill never again be Romeo.
response: What man art thou that, thus bescreened in night,So stumblest on my counsel?

instruction: Oh, why won't you respond to your friends?
response: I have too few to take my leave of you, When the tongue's office should be prodigal To breathe the abundant dolour of the heart.

instruction: Some games are difficult, but the effort they require contributes to the pleasure they give. Some kinds of dishonorable manual labor are undertaken for noble reasons. And many things that bring no money can lead to great wealth in the end. This hard and undignified work would be dull and disgusting to me, but the woman for whom I am doing this makes what is awful seem wonderful. She makes my hard work seem like a pleasure. Oh, shes ten times more kind than her father is nasty, and hes completely nasty. Hes issued a severe command that I have to move thousands of these logs and put them in a stack. My sweet lady cries when she sees me work, and tells me that such lowly work has never been done by such a noble person. These sweet thoughts refresh me and make me forget that I am working, especially when I am working the hardest.
response: Alas now, pray you, Work not so hard.

instruction: I don't think so, my lord.
response: Dear lad, believe it.

instruction: Yes, so what?
response: Thats not so good now.

instruction: Have you heard anything about the old man having a son, sir? If it please you, sir?
response: He has a son, who shall be flayed alive; then 'nointed over with honey, set on the head of a wasp's nest; then stand till he be three quarters and a dram dead; then recovered again with aqua-vitae or some other hot infusion; then, raw as he

instruction: Oh, good sir. My master instructed me to deliver a ring to Madam Silvia, which I forgot to do.
response: Where is that ring, boy?

instruction: Alas, he is fainting! Oh, Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!
response: Gentlemen all, I do suspect this trash To be a party in this injury.

instruction: Lead on, monster. Well follow. I wish I could see this drummer. He's very good.
response: Wilt come?

instruction: What's your news then?
response: Lord Rivers and Lord Grey are sent to Pomfret,And, with them, Sir Thomas Vaughan, prisoners.

instruction: Certainly, for you can see that it won't curl naturally.
response: But it becomes me well enough, does t not?

instruction: You sound like a doctor, Helicanus, but what you're prescribing me is something you'd hardly do yourself. You see, I went to Antioch where, as you know, I faced death for the chance to win a famously beautiful woman. I had hoped we would get married and have children together, heirs for my throne that would strengthen my rule in this country and delight my subjects. I thought she was beautiful in person, but listen: they were committing incest. Once I figured it out, her sinful father didn't lash out; he suddenly became very smooth. As you well know, it's time to be afraid when tyrants kiss you. I ran away in the dark of night and, once I got here, thought I was safe. I know Antiochus is a tyrant, and that he's probably getting increasingly paranoid about what I know. And if he suspects that I've told the world how he killed all of those princes, and slept with his own daughter, then there's no doubt that he'll invade our country on the pretense of me having offended him. Then the country will be plunged into war for my socalled offense, and many innocent people will die, and everyone I love, yourself included, will blame me for it
response: Alas, sir!

instruction: Good Lord, they look a lot like the empresss sons! And you look like the empress! But we mortal men have miserable, mad eyes that are easy to deceive. Oh, sweet Revenge, now Ill come to you; and, if you can be happy with a one-armed embrace, Ill embrace you soon.
response: This closing with him fits his lunacy Whate'er I forge to feed his brain-sick fits, Do you uphold and maintain in your speeches, For now he firmly takes me for Revenge; And, being credulous in this mad thought, I'll make him send for Lucius

instruction: I'll try to live up to that, sir, to the best of my ability.
response: Ay, by any means prove a tall fellow: if I do not wonder how thou darest venture to be drunk, not being a tall fellow, trust me not.

instruction: But, my lord, believe this: one of his men went to the Lord Lucullus to ask for that much. Really, he begged desperately for it, showing just how much he really needed it, and still he was rejected.
response: How!

instruction: Oh, oh, Petruchio! Now Tranio hits you with a good one.
response: I thank thee for that gird, good Tranio.

instruction: These challenges will stand until Norfolk comes back: although hes my enemy, Ill repeal his banishment and restore his lands and dukedom to him again. When hes returned, hell fight with Aumerle.
response: That honourable day shall ne'er be seen.

instruction: And the news you spread led to the murder.
response: Nay, stare not, masters, it is true, indeed.

instruction: What, my respectable old master? Yes, of course, sir. There he is, looking out the window.
response: Is t so, indeed.

instruction: I only asked.
response: But crave!

instruction: I don't care what she's worth; I wish she had never come here.
response: Fie, fie upon her!

instruction: It was only by chance that you yourself were saved.
response: O, my poor brother!

instruction: Well, I'll go even though I don't want to.
response: Come, come, I know 'tis good for you.Walk half an hour, Leonine, at the least:Remember what I have said.

instruction: And I say that this house is as dark as ignorance, and ignorance is as dark as hell. And I say that no man has ever been abused like I've been. I'm no more crazy than you are. Ask me any question and I'll prove my sanity.
response: What is the opinion of Pythagoras concerning wildfowl?

instruction: I come here exhausted, like a dog bringing up the rear of the pack during a hunt. I've spent almost all my money, have been thoroughly beaten up tonight, and all I have for all this is some painful life experience. So, I'm going to return to Venice a little wiser and a lot poorer.
response: How poor are they that have not patience!

instruction: Farewell, brave Moor. Be good to Desdemona.
response: Look to her, Moor, if thou hast eyes to see.She has deceived her father, and may thee.

instruction: The general should know about this. Perhaps he doesn't see this, or he only sees the virtues in Cassio and is blind to his faults. What do you think?
response: [aside] How now, Roderigo?I pray you, after the lieutenant, go!

instruction: Three or four thousand gold coins is all we need to retire quietly and give up the business.
response: Why to give over, I pray you?

instruction: Twenty crowns? I'd bet that much on my hawk or my hound, but I'd bet twenty times that on my wife.
response: A hundred then.

instruction: Good morning, good Lieutenant. I am sorry for what has happened to you, but I'm sure everything will turn out okay. The general and his wife are talking about the situation, and Desdemona is speaking up for you. Othello says that the man you hurt is well-known and well-liked in Cyprus, and that he has no choice but to refuse your appeal. But Othello insists that he still loves you, and doesn't need any persuading to put you back in your position when he gets the opportunity.
response: Yet I beseech you, If you think fit, or that it may be done, Give me advantage of some brief discourse With Desdemona alone.

instruction: Sir, you'll hardly believe this, but you have to because the one who sent me is about to arrive: Polixenes sends you his greetings. He asks that you hold his son hereyou see, his son ran away from his father and his responsibilities with a shepherd's daughter.
response: Where's Bohemia?

instruction: [Whispering] Out of here, you scab!
response: ( aside ) Nay, patience, or we break the sinews of our plot.

instruction: Mistress, how are you?
response: Faith, as cold as can be.

instruction: You are the captain of all fools.
response: Would thou wert clean enough to spit upon!

instruction: It's not bad.
response: Admirable: how this grace Speaks his own standing!

instruction: [To GONZALO] With his magic, my master could see the danger that you, his friend, are in. He sent me to keep you all aliveor else his plans would die along with you. [Singing in GONZALOs ear] While you lie here snoring, Cold-blooded conspirators Are about to seize their chance. If you want to live, Wake up and beware! Wake up! Wake up!
response: Then let us both be sudden.

instruction: Oh, that memory is still so vivid to me! He did indeed die on the day my sister turned thirteen.
response: If nothing lets to make us happy both But this my masculine usurped attire, Do not embrace me till each circumstance Of place, time, fortune, do cohere and jump That I am Viola.

instruction: Sir, it's true that there are tricksters out there, so it's always smart to be aware.
response: Fear not thou, man, thou shalt lose nothing here.

instruction: True. Except anything you could actually use to live.
response: Of that theres none, or little.

instruction: We did respect the time, sir, in the beat of our songs. So go hang yourself!
response: Sir Toby, I must be round with you.

instruction: [To QUEEN ELIZABETH] Madam, you're not exempt from this.
response: There, Hastings, I will never more rememberOur former hatred, so thrive I and mine.

instruction: At Ely House.
response: Now put it, God, in the physician's mind To help him to his grave immediately!

instruction: That was always the job of a villain or a fool. Do you like it?
response: Ay.

instruction: Please, listen to me speak.
response: You speak too bitterly.

instruction: Hello, Lord Stanley, what's the news?
response: Know, my loving lord,The marquess Dorset, as I hear, is fled To Richmond, in the parts where he abides.

instruction: No, madam. Weve selected the things that would be best for me to wear at the ceremony tomorrow. So, if its all right with you, please leave me alone now. Let the Nurse stay up tonight with you. Im sure your hands are full getting ready for this sudden marriage celebration.
response: Good night.Get thee to bed and rest, for thou hast need.

instruction: Get away, you son of a bitch! Your life makes me angry enough to die. I swoon just looking at you!
response: Would thou wouldst burst!

instruction: Poor Romeo! He is already dead: stabbed by the black eye of a fair-skinned girl, cut through the ear by a love song. The very core of his heart has been split by blind Cupids arrow. Is he really man enough to fight Tybalt?
response: Why, what is Tybalt?

instruction: Very clever, really, very clever. Well, go along now. If only Sir Toby would stop drinking, you'd be a woman who was as funny as any person in Illyria.
response: Peace, you rogue, no more o' that.

instruction: You'll be my husband, then?
response: Ay, with a heart as willingAs bondage e'er of freedom.

instruction: Send for the Count. Tell him about this. Well move the wedding to tomorrow morning.
response: I met the youthful lord at Lawrence cell,And gave him what becomèd love I might, Not stepping oer the bounds of modesty.

instruction: Things for the cook, sir. But I dont know what exactly.
response: Make haste, make haste, sirrah.

instruction: You haven't seen anything, then?
response: Nor ever heard, nor ever did suspect.

instruction: Stop, you who bear that corpse, and set down your load.
response: What black magician conjures up this fiend To stop devoted charitable deeds?

instruction: Me, my lord?
response: Ay, you did wish that I would make her turn.

instruction: I heard that news, my lord.
response: Stanley, he is your wifes son.

instruction: The Turks are heading for Cyprus with a strong fleet. Othello, you know the strengths of the place the best. And although we have someone stationed there who is very skilled, everyone seems to think that you would be better in that position. So, you must tinge the happiness of your recent marriage with this difficult mission.
response: The tyrant custom, most grave senators, Hath made the flinty and steel couch of war My thrice-driven bed of down.

instruction: You wouldnt dare, coward.
response: Now by my soul, I would it were this hour.

instruction: I could stand here forever, too, just looking.
response: Either forbear, Quit presently the chapel, or resolve you For more amazement.

instruction: What are you doing, Lavinia? Marcus, what does this mean? She wants to see one of these books. Which book? Open them, boy. [To LAVINIA] Youre a better reader than mecome and take any book from my library, and so distract yourself from your sorrow until the heavens reveal who did this to you. Why does she lift her arms up twice?
response: I think she means that there was more than oneConfederate in the fact: ay, more there was;Or else to heaven she heaves them for revenge.

instruction: If we're friends, let's do it. I am dog at singing catches.
response: By 'r lady, sir, and some dogs will catch well.

instruction: So will I, Sir Gremio. But wait, let me have a word with you first, please. Though we've always been opponents, never allies, when you think about it, it's now important to us both that we regain access to our fair mistress, so that we can once again be friendly rivals competing for Bianca's love. But first we have to work to achieve one thing.
response: Whats that, I pray?

instruction: How is it going now? Othello looks gentler than before.
response: He says he will return incontinent,And hath commanded me to go to bedAnd bid me to dismiss you.

instruction: Did you intend to do something wrong, or did you already do it? If its the first, no matter how bad it is, Ill forgive you to make you love me from now on.
response: Then give me leave that I may turn the key,That no man enter till my tale be done.

instruction: Come, we'll get him into a madhouse soon enough. My niece already thinks that he's crazy. We can take it as far as we want, punishing him and having fun, until we're tired and out of breath from laughing so hard, and then we can have mercy on him and reveal the joke, and crown you, Maria, the prank's mastermind. Come on, come on!
response: More matter for a May morning.

instruction: No, sweet Romeo, you have to dance.
response: Not I, believe me.

instruction: Oh, it's too true.
response: But see what heaven can do!

instruction: Hortensio, what's all this talk about?
response: [To TRANIO] Sir, let me be so bold as ask you,Did you yet ever see Baptistas daughter?

instruction: This wretched man has confessed to some of his evil doings. Did you and he conspire to kill Cassio?
response: Ay.

instruction: When will he be here?
response: When he stands where I am and sees you there.

instruction: What was your dream?
response: That dreamers often lie.

instruction: I think you do. And it's precisely because I know you are full of love and honesty and think carefully before you speak that I'm even more worried about the way you're hesitating. In some disloyal liar, it wouldn't mean anything, but in an honest man like you, these kinds of reactions are indications of thoughts that come from the heart which cannot be clouded by emotion.
response: For Michael Cassio, I dare be sworn, I think, that he is honest.

instruction: And your goal is our goal.
response: Lucius' Servant And Sir Philotus too!

instruction: You have to understand that our grievances have piled up to the point of overflowing.
response: Your griefs!

instruction: If you think it's best. Poor queen!
response: Here she lies, sir.

instruction: No, come and sit down. Now go on.
response: Dwelt by a churchyard: I will tell it softly;Yond crickets shall not hear it.

instruction: What, my lord?
response: That he hath usèd thee.

instruction: Yes, and it seemed like thirty years to me, as I've been banished from your bed this whole time.
response: 'Tis much.Servants, leave me and her alone.Madam, undress you and come now to bed.

instruction: And will you learn from me?
response: Madam, with all my heart.

instruction: Good day.
response: Welcome, good brother.What do you think the hour?

instruction: [To himself] Is she a Capulet? Oh, what a price Ive paid! My life is now owned by my enemy.
response: [To ROMEO] Away, begone.

instruction: [Offstage] Madam!
response: I come, anon.But if thou meanst not well,I do beseech thee

instruction: I've heard that it means that. Oh these men, these men! Tell me, Emilia: do you think that there are women who deceive and cheat on their husbands as badly as men do to women?
response: There be some such, no question.

instruction: [To the SHEPHERD] He seems to have a lot of power. Let's make friends with him and give him a little money. You can control even power with money; give him a few coins and see how easy everything becomes. Remember he said we're condemned to be "stoned to death" and "skinned alive!"
response: An't please you, sir, to undertake the business forus, here is that gold I have: I'll make it as muchmore and leave this young man in pawn till I bring it you.

instruction: As much as I could gather, he accuses the duke because he thinks he poses a threat to your highness, not for personal reasons.
response: Then call them to our presence; face to face, And frowning brow to brow, ourselves will hear The accuser and the accused freely speak : High-stomach'd are they both, and full of ire, In rage deaf as the sea, hasty as fire.

instruction: I say, I wouldn't do that in this company. Is that really what you meant by "accost her?"
response: Fare you well, gentlemen.

instruction: What? Is it because my legs are too long?
response: No; that it is too little.

instruction: Well, I dont know what to say.
response: Oh, I cry you mercy, you are the singer.

instruction: Oh, my! Time goes by slowly when youre sad. Was that my father who just rushed away?
response: It was.

instruction: Definitely.
response: There's never a one of you but trusts a knave,That mightily deceives you.

instruction: Well, so be it, then. [The JAILER leaves] [To herself] This is a lot of hullabaloo to make an innocent woman look guilty. [The JAILER comes back in with EMILIA][To EMILIA] How's Hermione doing?
response: As well as one so great and so forlornMay hold together: on her frights and griefs,Which never tender lady hath born greater,She is something before her time deliver'd.

instruction: My lord, I had forgot to tell your lordship. Today, on way here, I stopped therebut I will grieve you to report the rest.

We are all made of the stuff of dreams, and our small lifespans stretch from the sleep before birth to the sleep after death. Sir, Im upset. Please put up with this weakness of mine.
