response: 'Twill make me think the world is full of rubs,And that my fortune rubs against the bias.

instruction: If I'm a wasp, then you'd better beware my stinger.
response: My remedy is then to pluck it out.

instruction: [As CAMBIO] Well, let him sprint ahead for now. He's not likely to finish the race.
response: Hortensio, to what end are all these words?

instruction: So Timon
response: Well, sir, I will; therefore, I will, sir; thus: If Alcibiades kill my countrymen, Let Alcibiades know this of Timon, That Timon cares not.

instruction: Tranio, let's go. One more thing still has to be done, and it's up to you to arrange it. You have to become another suitor to Bianca. Don't ask me whyjust trust that I have a good reason for doing this.
response: My lord, you nod.

instruction: Was that my handkerchief?
response: Yours by this hand.

instruction: Tranio, I saw her coral-pink lips move, and her breath perfume the air. Everything I saw in her was holy and sweet.
response: [aside] Nay, then, tis time to stir him from his trance.

instruction: What do you mean by that, Malvolio?
response: Some are born great

instruction: Oh, but they say people are more likely to listen to the last words of dying men: when words are few, they rarely miss their mark, for those who speak when they're close to death are always truthful. The person who will soon have nothing to say is listened to more than the young, who tend to ramble on and waste words; the death of a man is more notable than his life before. Like the setting sun or the final note of a piece of music, what comes last is sweetest and most memorable. So although Richard would rather not hear my advice, the sad story of my death may make him listen to me.
response: No; it is stopp'd with other flattering sounds, As praises, of whose taste the wise are fond, Lascivious metres, to whose venom sound The open ear of youth doth always listen; Report of fashions in proud Italy, Whose manners still our tardy

instruction: I scolded you for obsessing, not for loving, my student.
response: And badest me bury love.

instruction: I flew over these walls on the wings of love. No stone wall can keep love out. Whatever a man in love can do, love will make him attempt to do it. Therefore your relatives cant stop me.
response: If they do see thee they will murder thee.

instruction: Just tell me the important part. I'll excuse you for skipping the praise.
response: Alas, I took great pains to study it, and tis poetical.

instruction: Sir, she's from Libya.
response: Where the warlike Smalus,That noble honour'd lord, is fear'd and loved?

instruction: He knew that she was unfaithful in her marriage?
response: Ay, with Cassio.

instruction: My lord, I dont know and I cant guess. Unless shes suffering from some fit or madness, for Ive often heard my grandfather say that extreme grief makes people mad, and Ive read that Hecuba of Troy went mad from sorrow. That made me afraidalthough, my lord, I know my noble aunt loves me as dearly as my mother ever did, and would only in madness have ever frightened meand I threw down my books and ran, but perhaps for no reason. Forgive me, sweet aunt; and madam, if my uncle Marcus comes with us, Ill gladly go with you.
response: Lucius, I will.

instruction: We haven't yet set the date for the triumphant coronation day. In my opinion, tomorrow is too sudden, for I myself am not as well prepared as I would be if a later date were set.
response: Where is my lord the duke of Gloucester?I have sent for these strawberries.

instruction: Who is that, my lord?
response: Her husband, knave.

instruction: Do your best, then.
response: Sir, you shall understand what hath befall'n, Which, as I think, you know not.

instruction: He's wearing armor; oh, and he looks worried! Uncle, for God's sake, speak comforting words.
response: Should I do so, I should belie my thoughts: Comfort's in heaven; and we are on the earth, Where nothing lives but crosses, cares and grief.

instruction: Oh, look: the precious passengers of the ship have come on shore. You, men of Cyprus, kneel down. Hail, lady, and may the grace of God be all around you.
response: I thank you, valiant Cassio.What tidings can you tell me of my lord?

instruction: God bless you, Timon?
response: Now, thieves?

instruction: A giving hand. It used to be that people's hearts controlled whether they gave someone their hand in marriage. But now people give away their hands without consulting their hearts.
response: I cannot speak of this.

instruction: Truthfully, I'm glad about that.
response: Indeed!

instruction: Her husband, fool. Are you going to tell on me?
response: I do beseech your Grace to pardon me, and withal Forbear your conference with the noble duke.

instruction: Sir, you've been generous here in Ephesus. Thousands of people have been cured by you and are loyal to you. Not only your knowledge and your personal effort, but also your charity, Lord Cerimon, have built a reputation that will last forever.
response: So; lift there.

instruction: And, Norfolk, throw down his.
response: When, Harry, when?Obedience bids I should not bid again.

instruction: Uncle Marcus, since my father wants me to come back to Rome, Ill do it.
response: And ours with thine, befall what fortune will.

instruction: I dont dare, sir. My master thinks Ive gone from here. He threatened to kill me if I stayed to watch his actions.
response: Stay, then.

instruction: The darkness of night will hide me from their eyes. And if you dont love me, then let them find me. Id rather they killed me in hatred than experience the prolonged death of life without your love.
response: By whose direction foundst thou out this place?

instruction: Two thousand gold coins a year from his land!
response: [as LUCENTIO] Gremio, tis known my father hath no less Than three great argosies, besides two galliasses, And twelve tight galleys.

instruction: Hey, cut that out!
response: Not a word, a word; we stand upon our manners.Come, strike up!

instruction: And, ma'am, I'll have to stay in the room to monitor your conversation.
response: Well, be't so, prithee.

instruction: Well, come on then, my Kate. We'll just go on to your father's house dressed in our plain, respectable clothes. Our purses will be proud and our clothes will be poor. It's the mind that makes the body rich, after all, and just as the sun breaks through the darkest clouds, so honor can be seen through even the lowliest attire. What, is the jay more precious than the lark because his feathers are more beautiful? Or is the poisonous snake better than the eel because his patterned scales please the eye? Certainly not, good Kate. Therefore you aren't any less precious because of your poor clothes and lowly attire. If you consider it shameful, then lay the shame on me. So cheer up! We will go now to feast and party at your father's house.
response: I dare assure you, sir, tis almost two,And twill be supper time ere you come there.

instruction: Uncle, you say the queen is at your house; for God's sake, treat her fairly. Tell her I send her my kind regards; take special care that my greetings are delivered.
response: A gentleman of mine I have dispatch'dWith letters of your love to her at large.

instruction: Yes, and you and everyone else will find that out when he comes home. But why am I talking about this? Call in Nathaniel, Joseph, Nicholas, Philip, Walter, Sugarsop, and all the rest. Make sure their hair is slicked down and combed, their blue coats are brushed, and their garters are normal-looking and matching. Have them do an elaborate greeting and not dare to touch a hair of my master's horse's tail until they've kissed their hands. Are they all ready?
response: They are.

instruction: And I swear as well to abide by all these conditions.
response: No, Bolingbroke: if ever I were traitor, My name be blotted from the book of life, And I from heaven banish'd as from hence!

instruction: You lie.
response: Art not one?

instruction: I fear were going to arrive too early. I have a feeling this party tonight is fated to set in motion some awful destiny that will result in my own untimely death. But whoevers in charge of my fate can steer me where they want. Lets go, my lusty friends!
response: Strike, drum.

instruction: I did this because you asked me to with your own words, my lord.
response: They love not poison that do poison need, Nor do I thee: though I did wish him dead, I hate the murderer, love him murdered.

instruction: Oh, you gods! Why do you give us good things that we love and then take them away? Those of us on earth hardly know what to do.
response: Patience, good sir,Even for this charge.

instruction: Really?
response: I remember a mass of things, but nothing distinctly.

instruction: Go bring them here. If they refuse to come, give them a beating on my behalf to get them out here to their husbands. Go on, I say, and bring them here right away.
response: Here is a wonder, if you talk of a wonder.

instruction: What is his name?
response: His name, my lord, is Tyrrel.

instruction: Yes, madam. He wants to reconcile Richard with your brothers, and your brothers with Lord Hastings. He has just summoned them all to his royal presence.
response: Would all were wellbut that will never be.I fear our happiness is at the height.

instruction: Oh, Iago!
response: And did you see the handkerchief?

instruction: And how are you, daughter Katherine? Are you sad?
response: Call you me daughter?

instruction: I think one of them is around here, and cannot run away.
response: Oh, treacherous villains!

instruction: What kind of woman is she?
response: Of your complexion.

instruction: Very well then, sir.
response: [Aside to SAMPSON] Say better.

instruction: "Satisfy!" "Satisfy" my wife's invitation! That says it all. I've trusted you, Camillo, with my darkest secrets. I've confessed my soul to you as if you were a priest, and you've cleared my conscience and helped me to be a better man. But now I see I was wrong about you. I thought you were a good man, but you're not!
response: Be it forbid, my lord!

instruction: No, I'm telling you, put on this robe and beard. Make him believe that you're Sir Topas the priest. Do it quickly. I'll call Sir Toby while you're getting dressed.
response: Well, Ill put it on, and I will dissemble myself in t, and I would I were the first that ever dissembled insuch a gown.

instruction: Ive never done you harm. In fact, I love you more than youll be able to understand until you know the reason behind my love. And so, good Capuletwhich is a name I love as dearly as my ownbe satisfied.
response: O calm dishonourable, vile submission!Alla stoccata carries it away.

instruction: I can't think about what I was before; I can only think about what I am now, which is cold. I'm freezing down to my veins and barely have enough life left in me to warm my tongue up to ask you for help. Please help me, or at least, when I'm dead, make sure I get a proper burial.
response: Die quoth-a?

instruction: He must be a stranger, since he showed up with such a strange outfit.
response: And on set purpose let his armour rustUntil this day, to scour it in the dust.

instruction: My lord, he hasbut you can be sure that he'll deny it.
response: What hath he said?

instruction: Wearing royal clothes, scented with perfumes and spices! With a passport, too! Apollo, help me read what this says. [He picks up a scroll and reads from it] "To whoever's reading this, if this coffin ever comes to land: I, King Pericles, have lost my beloved wife. If you've found her, please give her a proper burial. She was the daughter of the king. Take this gold as payment for your service. May the gods bless you!"[To the absent Pericles] Pericles, if you're alive, I feel sorry for you. She must have died tonight.
response: Most likely, sir.

instruction: I will say this. If Alcibiades wants to kill my fellow citizens, let Alcibiades know that Timon does not care. But if he wants to pillage Athens, grabbing old men by the beards and sacrificing holy virgins to the horrors of war, then let him know that even as I pity the old and the young, I cannot help but say still that I do not care if he does his worst. Their blades do not care that your throats suffer the consequences of their actions. And as for me, I put the smallest switchblade in their rebel barracks before the most honored throat in all of Athens. I leave you to the protection of the gods, the way I might leave thieves to their jailers.
response: Stay not, all's in vain.

instruction: Does he know about this?
response: He neither does nor shall.

instruction: So his bankruptcy has just been a test for his friends.
response: Nothing else: you shall see him a palm in Athens again, and flourish with the highest.

instruction: No, not a penny. Forget about it, Saint Jeronimy. Run off to bed now and play with yourself.
response: I know my remedy.

instruction: [Outside] Open this locked door, foolish king: will you make me speak in this treasonous way to you when I'm trying to protect you? Open the door, or I will break it open.
response: What is the matter, uncle?

instruction: May heaven restore your sanity!
response: Remember who commended thy yellow stockings

instruction: Then you must have killed many of his men?
response: The offence is not of such a bloody nature; Albeit the quality of the time and quarrel Might well have given us bloody argument.

instruction: My lord, Cassio has killed a young Venetian named Roderigo.
response: Roderigo killed?

instruction: What are the chances of his recovery, lords?
response: Madam, good hope.

instruction: Let it be, let it be. I wish I were dead. Except . . . I think . . . already . . . who made this? [To POLIXENES] Look, doesn't it look like it's breathing? Doesn't it look like those veins have blood running through them?
response: Masterly done:The very life seems warm upon her lip.

instruction: No, my girl! It eats and sleeps and has the same senses as we do. The gentleman you see was in the shipwreck. And, even though hes marked by griefwhich always spoils beautyyou could describe him as handsome. Hes lost his friends and is wandering around trying to find them.
response: I might call himA thing divine, for nothing naturalI ever saw so noble.

instruction: [To herself] God slept when my holy husband Henry died, and my sweet son Edward.
response: [sitting down] Dead life, blind sight, poor mortal living ghost, Woes scene, worlds shame, graves due by life usurped, Brief abstract and record of tedious days, Rest thy unrest on Englands lawful earth, Unlawfully made drunk with innocent

instruction: Go on; I'll be right behind you.
response: I am glad at heartTo be so rid o' the business.

instruction: This is fairy gold, boy, you'll see! Hold on to it tight. Let's get on home now. We are lucky, boy, and to hold on to our luck we need to keep this under wraps. Let the sheep go. Let's get on home now, boy!
response: Go you the next way with your findings.

instruction: Sir, it is the Moor.
response: Down with him, thief!

instruction: True. The dogs love you because you only have enough means to keep a dog.
response: What things in the world canst thou nearest compareto thy flatterers?

instruction: Whats that letter you have? Why do you look so pale? Let me see it.
response: My lord, 'tis nothing.

instruction: It seemed like you were going to try to expose us for lying, but you've just revealed that you're the liar.
response: Are you a courtier, an't like you, sir?

instruction: Drink when I tell you to, servant-monster. Your eyes look sunk into your head.
response: Where should they be set else?

instruction: May the gods strike those you war against, and after you win, you as well!
response: Why me, Timon?

instruction: Ive been waiting for you for a long time. Welcome to my sad house, dreaded Fury; Rape and Murder, youre welcome here, too. You look so much like the empress and her sons! You would look even more like them if you had a Moor with youcouldnt you find such a devil in hell? For I know that the empress doesnt go anywhere without a Moor, and if youre trying to look like her, it would be convenient to have a devil like that. But youre welcome just as you are. What should we do?
response: What wouldst thou have us do, Andronicus?

instruction: Have you forgotten the torture from which I freed you?
response: No.

instruction: I beg your pardon, lords and gentlemen who stayed awake and alertyou've caught me sleeping late.
response: How have you slept, my lord?

instruction: Go and fill another room in hell.
response: That hand shall burn in never-quenching fire That staggers thus my person.

instruction: Oh, it was loud enough to frighten a monster, or to cause an earthquake! Surely, it must have been the roar of an entire herd of lions.
response: Heard you this, Gonzalo?

instruction: Have you thought about where you'll go?
response: Not any yet:But as the unthought-on accident is guiltyTo what we wildly do, so we professOurselves to be the slaves of chance and fliesOf every wind that blows.

instruction: The loss of such a husband includes all kinds of harm.
response: The heavens have blessed you with a goodly son To be your comforter when he is gone.

instruction: Now Dorset, hug Hastings. Hastings, befriend Lord Marquess of Dorset.
response: This interchange of love, I here protest,Upon my part shall be inviolable.

instruction: Yes, my legs are strong, and they don't look bad in brown stockings. Should we have a little dance?
response: What shall we do else?

instruction: You should have kept one for yourself, because I have no intention of giving you one.
response: Hang thyself!

instruction: Oh, she was foul! I barely knew you, Uncle Gratiano, but there lies your niece, whose life I have just recently stopped with these very hands. I know this act seems horrible and grim.
response: Poor Desdemon!

instruction: I must obey. [To VIOLA] This happened because I was looking for you, but there's nothing to be done now. I'll answer for what I've done. But what will you do, now that I am forced to ask for my purse back? I feel worse about not being able to help you than I do about what's going to happen to me. You look confused, but don't worry about me.
response: Come, sir, away.

instruction: Whats going on here?
response: Whiles we stood here securing your repose, Even now, we heard a hollow burst of bellowing Like bulls, or rather lions.

instruction: Neither.
response: What, neither?

instruction: Sir Topas, no man has ever been as badly treated as I have been. Good Sir Topas, don't believe that I'm mad. They've left me here in this horrible darkness.
response: Fie, thou dishonest Satan!

instruction: Oh, yes, Curtis, yes, so they need a fire, a fire. And leave out the water.
response: Is she so hot a shrew as shes reported?

instruction: Hanged! By our Lady, then I've come to a good end.
response: Despiteful and intolerable wrongs!

instruction: Speak plainly, my son. Be clear. A confusing confession will result only in confused absolution.
response: Then plainly know my hearts dear love is set On the fair daughter of rich Capulet.

instruction: For there it is, cracked in a hundred pieces. See, silent king, what I mean by this: my sorrow has destroyed my face.
response: The shadow of your sorrow hath destroy'dThe shadow of your face.

instruction: Get her, Kate!
response: To her, widow!

instruction: Not yet, I beseech you: I'll stay on my knees forever and never have a happy day in my life, until you give me joy again by pardoning Rutland, my son, who has offended you.
response: Unto my mother's prayers I bend my knee.

instruction: I beg you, Father.
response: Hence!

instruction: [To ANTONIO so that only he can hear] Agreed. Tonight it is. Now be quiet.
response: What harmony is this?

instruction: I saw them while I was hiding behind a cluster of pine trees. I never saw men hurry away so quickly. I watched them go all the way to their ships.
response: How blest am I In my just censure, in my true opinion!

instruction: She's not worthy of you, then. How old is she?
response: About your years, my lord.

instruction: What, what, what, what? Insane logic! What is this? How can you say proud and I thank you and no thank you and not proud? You spoiled brat, dont give me these thank you no thank yous and proud not prouds. Just get yourself together for Thursday when youll be going with Paris to Saint Peters Church. And if you refuse to go, Ill drag you there. My god, you sick corpse! You worthless bit of baggage! You pale face!
response: Fie, fie!

instruction: Well, lords, the Duke of Lancaster is dead.
response: And living too; for now his son is duke.

instruction: Certainly we will, if we can. But if you hunt these bear cubs, then beware; their mother will wake, and if she sees you once, shell set the lion on youfor she lulls him to sleep while she plays on her back, and while he sleeps she'll do what she wants. Youre not much of a huntsman, Marcus; leave it alone. And come, Ill go get a sheet of brass, and with a steel pen Ill write these words and lay it aside: the angry northern wind will blow these sands through the air like Sibyls leaves.[To YOUNG LUCIUS] And what do you have to say for yourself, boy?
response: I say, my lord, that if I were a man,Their mother's bed-chamber should not be safeFor these bad bondmen to the yoke of Rome.

instruction: Psh! Have you seen my hat?
response: I have lost my gown.

instruction: [To herself] I've sent for him. He says he'll come. What food should I give him? What gifts? For it's better to buy something than beg for it or borrow itand it's the same with youth and love. But I'm speaking too loud. [To MARIA] Where's Malvolio? He is very serious and solemn, which is appropriate for someone in mourning like I am. Where is Malvolio?
response: Hes coming, madam; but in very strange manner.

instruction: It is. Can it be done?
response: Not possible.

instruction: Emilia, come with me. Act however you want, Othello. Whatever you do, I'll be obedient to you.
response: Excellent wretch!

instruction: Madam, I will.
response: Oh, say so, and so be!

instruction: I banished your son after taking advice from good counselors, including you. Why do you complain about the justice we have done?
response: Things sweet to taste prove in digestion sour.

instruction: Why are you talking in fits in startsand so impulsively, too?
response: Is t lost?

instruction: Im begging you, good Mercutio, lets go home. Its hot, and the Capulets are all over the place. If we should meet up with them, well end up fighting them. Hot days like today get people all worked up and angry.
response: Thou art like one of those fellows that, when he enters the confines of a tavern, claps me his sword uponthe table and says God send me no need of thee!

instruction: In fact, marriage is exactly what I came here to discuss. Tell me, Juliet, my daughterwhat do you think about getting married?
response: It is an honor that I dream not of.

instruction: Alas, what is this gentleman talking about? How are you doing, madam? My good lady, are you okay?
response: Faith, half asleep.

instruction: [As LUCENTIO] But in ladies' eyes, it's youth that flourishes.
response: Content you, gentlemen.

instruction: Well, how are you, Stephano?
response: O, touch me not.

instruction: Iago.
response: What sayst thou, noble heart?

instruction: Leave it to me, sir.
response: Sirrah, hast thou a knife?

instruction: [To PERICLES] Sir, the king, my father, just drank a toast to you.
response: I thank him.

instruction: By his voice I know that this man is a Montague.
response: Why, how now, kinsman?

instruction: It was no trouble, sir. I take pleasure in singing, sir.
response: Ill pay thy pleasure then.

instruction: What do you have to say for yourself, Cesario?My lord, a moment
response: My lord would speak.

instruction: How?
response: Out of their saddles into the dirt, and thereby hangs atale.

instruction: Why, whats up with Tybalt?
response: More than Prince of Cats.

instruction: Wickedness, wickedness, wickedness! I think about it, and I think I can smell it, oh wickedness! I suspected it earlier. I could kill myself out of grief. Oh, wickedness, wickedness!
response: What, are you mad?

instruction: At the sad place, my lord, where people threw dust and garbage on King Richards head from the windows.
response: Then, as I said, the duke, great Bolingbroke, Mounted upon a hot and fiery steed Which his aspiring rider seem'd to know, With slow but stately pace kept on his course, Whilst all tongues cried 'God save thee, Bolingbroke!' You would have t

instruction: [Whispering] By God, I'd like to beat him up!
response: ( aside ) Peace, I say.

instruction: Sir, I hear.
response: Most heavenly music!It nips me unto listening, and thick slumberHangs upon mine eyes: let me rest.

instruction: Tybalt, I love you for a reason that allows me to ignore the rage I would normally feel in response to such a greeting. Im not a villain. Therefore, goodbye. I can see that you dont know me at all.
response: Boy, this shall not excuse the injuriesThat thou hast done me.

instruction: Sir, I'd planned to stay quiet until you'd pushed him to the point of swearing not to stay. You're too hard on him. Tell him everything in Bohemia's finewe heard good news yesterday. If you tell him that, he's lost his best reason for leaving.
response: Well said, Hermione.

instruction: You have news that's both new and old? How can that be?
response: Why, is it not news to hear of Petruchios coming?

instruction: To be poor but content is actually to be quite rich. But you can have endless riches and still be as poor as anyone if you are always afraid of losing your riches. Good heaven, defend us all from jealousy!
response: Why, why is this?

instruction: Yes, you must tell us your reason, Sir Andrew.
response: Marry, I saw your niece do more favors to the Counts servingman than ever she bestowed upon me.

instruction: I know his walk. It's him. Villain, time for you to die!
response: That thrust had been mine enemy indeed But that my coat is better than thou knowstI will make proof of thine.

instruction: [To ROMEO] Lets go, lets go, now while everything is still perfect.
response: Ay, so I fear.

instruction: Who's the second knight?
response: A prince of Macedon, my royal father; And the device he bears upon his shield Is an arm'd knight that's conquer'd by a lady; The motto thus, in Spanish, 'Piu por dulzura que por fuerza.'

instruction: [To LUCENTIO] In time I may believe you, but I'm still doubtful.
response: Mistrust it not, for sure AeacidesWas Ajax, called so from his grandfather.

instruction: Get bit! You aren't even good enough to curse.
response: All villains that do stand by thee are pure.

instruction: you can have a little taste.
response: I may so.

instruction: But wait, seeor rather, dont seemy fair rose wither. Yet still look at him, so that you can cry in pity and wash him fresh again with true loves tears. Ah, you, youre the grave where Troy once stood, the map of honor: the tomb of King Richard, not King Richard himself. You, most beautiful innwhy should sadness stay with you, while triumph rejoices in the alehouse?
response: Join not with grief, fair woman, do not so, To make my end too sudden: learn, good soul, To think our former state a happy dream; From which awaked, the truth of what we are Shows us but this: I am sworn brother, sweet, To grim Necessity, a

instruction: I am waiting on the general here, and I don't think it would be very good for him to see me with a woman.
response: Why, I pray you?

instruction: Go talk to him with your own voice, and tell me how he's feeling. I want this foolishness to be over soon. If we can conveniently let him go, I want to do it, for I'm now in so much trouble with my niece that I can't safely pursue this prank to its conclusion. Come to my room in a while.
response: [sings in his own voice] Hey, Robin, jolly Robin, Tell me how thy lady does.

instruction: You would not have been with me for anything if you werent there for the goose.
response: I will bite thee by the ear for that jest.

instruction: [Whispering] Bloody hell!
response: ( aside ) O, peace, peace!

instruction: Is whispering nothing? Leaning against each other, touching cheeks? Rubbing noses? French-kissing? Laughing until you can't breathe? Here's one you can't ignoreplaying footsie? Hiding in corners? Counting down the minutes and hours until midnight, when, while all eyes but theirs are closed in sleep, they might be wicked in secret? Is all that nothing? Well, then, the world and everything in it is nothing, the universe is nothing, Bohemia is nothing, my wife is nothing, and everything I'm saying is nothing, if this is "nothing."
response: Good my lord, be curedOf this diseased opinion, and betimes;For 'tis most dangerous.

instruction: How dare you say so! He plays the violin, and speaks three or four languages word for word from memory. He has all of nature's good gifts.
response: He hath indeed, almost natural, for besides that hes afool, hes a great quarreler, and but that he hath the gift of a coward to allay the gust he hath in quarreling, tis thought among the prudent he would quickly have the gift of a grave.

instruction: Nothing; he's said all he can. His tongue is now a stringless instrument; his words and his life are finished.
response: Be York the next that must be bankrupt so!Though death be poor, it ends a mortal woe.

instruction: Let me say just one prayer!
response: It is too late.

instruction: Where will we meet in the morning?
response: At my lodging.

instruction: Get away from me, fond woman! If he were twenty times my son, I would still turn him in.
response: Hadst thou groan'd for him As I have done, thou wouldst be more pitiful.

instruction: Look, an angel is walking on earthhere comes the Countess. But as for you, fellow, your words are madness: this youth has worked for me for three months. But more of that later. [To an officer] Take him away.
response: What would my lord, but that he may not have, Wherein Olivia may seem serviceable?

instruction: You'd dare to call me daughter? I swear, you've certainly shown a father's tender care in trying to marry me off to a lunatic, a crazed villain and a swearing fool, who thinks that he can force his way through with enough cursing!
response: Father, tis thus: yourself and all the world That talked of her have talked amiss of her.

instruction: Oh, I have been unjustly murdered!
response: Alas, what cry is that?

instruction: Good morning to you, my noble lord.

instruction: All three of you hide in the hedge. Malvolio's coming this way down the path. He's been over there practicing his elegant manner for the past half hour. Watch him closely, if you love mockery, because I know that this letter will turn him into a starry-eyed fool. Now hide, if you love jokes!

instruction: Villain, I say, knock for me here.

instruction: No question, there are some.

instruction: Well, my uncle Clarence's angry ghost. My grandmother told me he was murdered there.

instruction: A prize, a prize, a prize!
response: Forbear, forbear, I say!

instruction: Is that true? Then Othello and Desdemona are returning to Venice.

instruction: To save her life, I'll say she isn't.
response: Her life is safest only in her birth.

instruction: If you forgive him, whoever prays against it, bad things will come of it. If you cut off this diseased limb, the rest of the body will live; but if you leave it, it will poison you.

instruction: Give me my veil. Come, throw it over my face. [OLIVIA puts on a veil] Let's hear Orsino's offer once more.

instruction: I can't tell if any of this is real or not.

instruction: Let me be your servant and go with youif you won't return my devotion, you'll be killing me.

instruction: Friar, don't tell me that youve heard all this unless you can tell me how I can prevent it. If with all your wisdom even you cant help, then you must agree that my resolution to die is wise. And this knife will help me do it. [Revealing a knife] God joined my heart to Romeos, and you joined our hands. Before my hand or heartwhich are bound to Romeoare given to another man, Ill use this knife to kill myself. So either use your long experience and education to give me some advice about what to do, or watch as I use this knife like a judge to honorably resolve the extreme situation in which Im caught. Dont wait long to speak. I want to die if what you say isnt a solution.
response: Hold, daughter.

instruction: I only learned my rudeness from the way I was received here. Who I am and what I want are as secret as a girl's virginity. I have a holy message for your ears only. It would be blasphemy for anyone else to hear it.
response: Give us the place alone.

instruction: First, who are you?
response: I am the governor of this place you lie before.

instruction: Probably the Pandar. Or the Bawd.

instruction: You must be mistaken, sir. I'm sure no man has any reason to quarrel with me. I can't remember ever offending anyone.

instruction: And judgment and logic have been wise jury members since the time of Noah's ark.
response: She did show favor to the youth in your sight only to exasperate you, to awake your dormouse valor, to put fire in your heart and brimstone in your liver.

instruction: Be prepared to learn a lot now, for a fool is reciting the words of a madman. [Reading] "By God, madam,"
response: How now?

instruction: Go on; go on. It's impossible for you to say too much. I deserve the most bitter words anyone can offer.

instruction: Ill bite you on the ear for that joke.

instruction: Aha, a riddle! Neither good nor bad. Why do you need to run in such wide circles when you can get straight to the point with your story? I'll ask you again: what's the news?

instruction: Madam, I've come on his behalf to improve your feelings towards him.
response: O, by your leave, I pray you, I bade you never speak again of him.

instruction: That's me, sir.

instruction: Thank Lord Cerimon, dear, this man through whom the gods have shown their power. He can tell you everything from beginning to end.

instruction: Am I not wise?

instruction: Sir, she doesn't care about stuff like that. The gifts she expects from me are the ones that come from the heart, and I've given those to her already, though I haven't delivered them. You must have had some experience with love, sir, at your age . . . let me explain how much I love her. Watch me take her handher soft, pure white hand. [He holds PERDITA's hand]

instruction: I pity you.

instruction: He'll release him.

instruction: Go to sleep, and we'll laugh.

instruction: Where do you sleep here Timon?

instruction: Because of the way love has oppressed your heart.

instruction: She has an inviting eye, and yet I think she's very modest.

instruction: It was. What sadness is making Romeo's hours so long?

instruction: Aw, please buy some! I love a printed ballad, since if they're printed they must be true.

instruction: I can't decide if I should leave in silence or bitterly scold you. I don't know which response is more appropriate to my rank and your social position. If I say nothing, you might think that my silence means consent, and you'll assume that I agree to bear the golden burden of responsibility that you're foolishly trying to impose on me. But if I scold you for this request just after you've proven your faithful love for me, then I would be guilty of rebuking my friends. Therefore I will speak, and so avoid the first possibility, but with my words I will avoid the second. So this is my answer, once and for all: I thank you for your love, but I don't deserve to be king. So I must turn down your noble request. Even if all obstacles were removed and my path led straight to the crownmy proper birthrightmy poverty of spirit and my many other flaws would still make me prefer to hide from my greatness, rather than be swallowed up by it and be smothered in glory. I am only a small boat, unprepared for the stormy sea of kingship. But, thank God, there is no need for me to rule. The royal tree has left us royal fruit, which, with time, will fit the throne well, and make us all happy as our king. I lay on him the responsibility you want to lay on me, as it is his birthright and his happy destiny. God forbid that I should steal the crown from him.
response: My lord, this argues conscience in your Grace, But the respects thereof are nice and trivial, All circumstances well considerèd.

instruction: [As VINCENTIO] Swear, if you dare.
response: Nay, I dare not swear it.

instruction: I don't know.
response: May you a better feast never behold, You knot of mouth-friends I smoke and lukewarm water Is your perfection.

instruction: Oh, insatiable and lustful woman!

instruction: Well, your imprisonment won't be for long. I'll free you, or else go to prison in your place. In the meantime, have patience.

instruction: You need to have faith. Everyone stand still. And anyone who thinks I'm doing something I shouldn't can leave.
response: Proceed:No foot shall stir.

instruction: [Returning] His name is Romeo. Hes a Montague. Hes the only son of your greatest enemy.
response: [Aside] My only love sprung from my only hate!

response: Blessed figs-end!

instruction: Yeah, him. He wanted to do it as soon as he heard the proclamation, but then groaned and swore he would see her tomorrow.

instruction: He's well-spoken.
response: I know a lady in Venice would have walked barefoot to Palestine for a touch of his nether lip.

instruction: Yes. It looks rotten like you.
response: An thou hadst hated meddlers sooner, thou shouldsthave loved thyself better now.

instruction: You will be a tutor and offer to teach the girl. Is that your plan?

instruction: Sign your divorce, sir[He takes off his disguise] I can hardly call you my son now; I wouldn't stoop down to your level. Look at you, a prince, dressed up with a shepherd's staff! [To the shepherd] You old traitor, it's too bad that by hanging you I won't be shortening your life that much.[To PERDITA] And you, you witch, as if you don't know that you're meddling with a prince.

instruction: I guarantee hell never drown, not even if the ship were as fragile as a nutshell and as leaky as a menstruating woman.

instruction: And turning the sun into shadow. Alas, alas, like my son, who is now in the shadow of death. Oh God, witness this injustice and don't let it go unpunished! As the Yorks won the crown through bloodshed, let them also lose it in the same way.

instruction: Sir, it's the governor of Mytilene. He heard how melancholy you were and came to see you.

instruction: Come, cousin, can you shake and turn pale, and stop speaking suddenly, and then begin again, and then stop againas if you were driven crazy from terror?
response: Tut, I can counterfeit the deep tragedian, Speak, and look back, and pry on every side, Tremble and start at wagging of a straw, Intending deep suspicion.

instruction: What is the matter with our cousin now?

instruction: Saints dont move, though they do grant prayers.

response: Ply Desdemona well, and you are sure on t.

response: 'Tis not a year or two shows us a man.

instruction: Which of my people is delaying him right now?

instruction: [Sitting down beside her] Ah, if only the earth could provide me with a grave instead of just a sad seat, then I would bury my bones, instead of simply resting them here. Oh, who has any right to mourn except for us?

instruction: You will be there, I know.

instruction: Will it always be like this with you? You ungrateful wretch, you are only fit to live in the mountains and caves far from civilization, where good manners are unnecessary! Get out of my sight![To SEBASTIAN] Don't be offended, dear Cesario.[To TOBY]Go away, you brute!
response: I prithee, gentle friend, Let thy fair wisdom, not thy passion, sway In this uncivil and unjust extent Against thy peace.

instruction: I hope you're right.

instruction: Uncle, even in the mirrors of your eyes, I see the reflection of your grief. Based on your sad expression, I will reduce your son's banishment by four years.
response: Six frozen winter spent,Return with welcome home from banishment.

instruction: Welcome, Iago. We must go be on the lookout.

instruction: Well, they say that my uncle grew so fast that he could gnaw a crust of bread at two hours old. For me, it took two full years before I could get a single tooth. Grandmother, this would have been a biting joke.

instruction: First, mighty King, tell me what your Highness wants, so I can deliver your message to him.

instruction: In Algiers, sir.

instruction: Well, something's standing up and making it so I can hardly wait that long. But I would hate to fall back into my dreams. I'll wait, despite my flesh and blood.

instruction: Well, let her disapprove of meI disapprove of her.

instruction: No you cannot even live on animals like birds and fish yourselves. You must eat men. Though I ought to thank you for at least being honest thieves who do not hide behind some more respectable disguise, for there is thievery in other professions as well. Here's some gold, you dirty thieves. Go now and drink all the wine you can until you catch a deadly fever that makes your blood foam. Do not trust the doctor, though, because his cures are poisonous and he kills men even more often than you rob them, taking both money and lives. Wreak havoc as your occupation dictates, and like one being instructed in his occupation, I'll give you good examples of thieves. The sun is a thief for robbing water from the vast sea; the moon is a thief for snatching light off the sun; the sea is a thief as its tides surge forth, dissolve the moon into salty tears; the earth is a thief as it steals and feeds off the manure of animals. Everything is a thief, from the laws to its enforcement, which use their unlimited power to steal. And do not make yourselves the exception, go away and rob one another. Here's some more gold. Go cut some throats, because everyone you meet is a thief. Go to Athens, pillage shops, because nothing you steal will not come from a thief's pocket. Do not steal any less because I'm giving you this, more gold, which I hope may curse you! Amen.
response: Has almost charmed me from my profession, bypersuading me to it.

instruction: How are you, my dear Othello? The islanders you invited to dinner are waiting for you.

instruction: My lord
response: No lord of thine, thou haught insulting man, Nor no man's lord; I have no name, no title, No, not that name was given me at the font, But 'tis usurp'd: alack the heavy day, That I have worn so many winters out, And know not now what name to

response: [to SEBASTIAN] Fie, what a spendthrift is he of his tongue!

instruction: Come, sir, let's go.
response: [t o VIOLA ] I must entreat of you some of that money.

instruction: My Lord of Gloucester, in those busy days, we were just following our lord, our rightful kingwhich you now bring up to prove that we're your enemies. And we would follow you in just the same way, if you were our king.
response: If I should be?

instruction: Oh, sir, calm yourself. I'm following him only so I can turn on him later. Maybe we can't all be leaders, but not all leaders can have loyal followers. All the time you see dutiful servants kneeling to their masters and working like mules for nothing but food. And when they get old, they're fired. These honest fools deserve to be whipped! There are others who take the appearance of duty and loyalty, but stay focused on their own interests. They put on a good show of serving their lords, and thrive in their subservient positions. But once they get enough money, they serve only themselves. These are the guys who really have some soul. That's the kind of servant I am. Believe me, as sure as your name is Roderigo: if I were the Moor, I would not want Iago as my servant. In following him, I'm really just following myself. God may judge me. I swear I'm not serving Othello out of love and duty, but merely appearing to, for my own purposes. If my outward appearance showed what my real intentions are, It would be like wearing my heart on my sleeve for birds to peck at. I am not what I seem to be.
response: What a full fortune does the Thick-lips oweIf he can carryt thus!

instruction: True. Im talking about dreams, which are produced by a brain thats doing nothing. Dreams are born of no more than empty fantasy, which lack substance like air, and are more unpredictable than the wind, which can blow on the frozen north and then suddenly get angry and blow south.

instruction: [To HORTENSIO] Look at that, sir, he is very straightforward with his intentions. Why, if you give him enough gold he'll marry a puppet, a doll, or an old prostitute with a dozen diseases and not a tooth in her head. Why, nothing can bother him, as long as money comes with it.

instruction: Forget the things that have happened to you, which we are very sorry for. The senators unanimously agreed to ask you to come back to Athens. There are many honors there, totally ready for you to take up.
response: They confess Toward thee forgetfulness too general, gross: Which now the public body, which doth seldom Play the recanter, feeling in itself A lack of Timon's aid, hath sense withal Of its own fail, restraining aid to Timon; And send forth

instruction: What should you be afraid? Its nothing but some receipt for his clothes on the tournament day.

instruction: Do you see the fright in her eyes? Stay here, good gentlemen. Do you look a little pale, mistress? Keep watching her; we'll hear more about what happened soon. Watch her carefully. I beg you, look at her. Do you see, gentlemen? Guiltiness speaks, even when the guilty person holds his or her tongue.

instruction: I'll be glad to get this over with.

instruction: To please the king I did, but to please myself I cannot do it. Yet I don't know why I welcome such a guest as grief, except because I had to say goodbye to so sweet a guest as my sweet Richard. And yet again, I feel as if some unborn sorrow, ready to be birthed by fortune, is coming towards me, and my soul is afraid of something; it grieves at something more than just my parting from the king.
response: Each substance of a grief hath twenty shadows, Which shows like grief itself, but is not so; For sorrow's eye, glazed with blinding tears, Divides one thing entire to many objects; Like perspectives, which rightly gazed upon Show nothing bu

instruction: Oh, noble prince, I can explain everything about the unfortunate events that led to this deadly fight. There lies Tybalt, the man who killed your relative, brave Mercutio. Tybalt was then killed by young Romeo.

instruction: Oh, Lucius, that was a charitable deed compared to what you'll hear from me soon. It was her sons that murdered Bassianus, and they were the ones who raped your sister, cut out her tongue, and cut her hands and trimmed her as you saw.

instruction: Then, gentlemen, bear witness to his promise.
response: You tempt him over-much.

instruction: My my, the knight's very good at playing the fool.

instruction: Give me some music. [Music plays] Now, good morning, friends. [To VIOLA] Now, good Cesario, have them play that old-fashioned song we heard last night. It helped ease my passion and made me feel better, more than the silly songs and memorized words of these fast-paced modern times. Come, have them sing just one verse at least.
response: He is not here, so please your lordship, that should sing it.

instruction: Nurse, hes a gentleman who loves to hear himself talk. He says more in one minute than he will stand behind in a month.
response: An he speak any thing against me, Ill take him down, an he were lustier than he is, and twenty such Jacks.

instruction: I swear, I hardly know where I'm going myself. Have you heard the news going around?

instruction: Come along with us and you'll see the truth for yourself, if our initial joke has made you suspicious.

instruction: Descend and do what you have promised.

instruction: It's taken a long time, but at last we've all been reconciled. Now that the raging war is over, it's time to smile at our past dangers and adventures. My fair Bianca, welcome my father, while I with equal kindness welcome yours. Brother Petruchio, Sister Katherina, and you, Hortensio, with your loving widow, feast with the best of them, and welcome to my house. This dessert is to close up our stomachsand any hard feelingsafter our great feast. Please, sit down, for now we sit to chat as well as to eat.

instruction: Madam, his Majesty asks for youand for you, Duke of Gloucesterand for you, my gracious lords.

response: Is not this man jealous?

instruction: Get on with it, please.

instruction: I remember everything in a big haze. I can't recall the particulars. I remember the fight, but not the reason for it. Oh, why do men drink their enemy, which robs them of their senses! Why do we celebrate by willingly turning ourselves into beasts?

instruction: OrsinoI have heard my father mention him. He was a bachelor back then.
response: And so is now, or was so very late.

instruction: And I missed your help, too. Your Grace, pardon me. It is neither my official position nor anything I heard about business that has gotten me out of bed. And it is not the general problem of war that brought me here. Rather, my own particular trouble is so great that it is overwhelming, and takes precedence over other problems.

instruction: Who's calling me?

instruction: Do you intend to sleep here tonight?

response: To satisfy my lady.

instruction: Yes. I can read my fortune in my misery.
response: Perhaps you have learned it without book.

instruction: All right. But I'm not happy that we lost our wine bottles in the pond
response: There is not only disgrace and dishonor in that, monster, but an infinite loss.

instruction: I dreamed a dream last night.
response: And so did I.

instruction: When you're the last man on earth, you'll be welcome here. I would rather be a beggar's dog than you.
response: Thou art the cap of all the fools alive.

instruction: Will you dine with me, Apemantus?
response: No; I eat not lords.

instruction: I'm ready.
response: No, I will rob Tellus of her weed, To strew thy green with flowers: the yellows, blues, The purple violets, and marigolds, Shall as a carpet hang upon thy grave, While summer-days do last.

instruction: Don't worry, I'm not afraid of him.
response: You are very sensible, and yet you miss my sense:I mean, Hortensio is afeard of you.

instruction: I'll pay you for your pleasure, then.
response: Truly, sir, and pleasure will be paid, one time or another.

instruction: Now let me see if I can translate it. Hic ibat Simois, I don't know you, hic est Sigeia tellus, I don't trust you, Hic steterat Priami, make sure he doesn't hear us, regia, don't presume anything, celsa senis, don't give up.
response: [as LITIO] Madam, tis now in tune.

instruction: For a full half hour.
response: Go with me to the vault.

instruction: Longer, longer. Lucentios son is older than that, sir. Hes thirty.
response: Will you tell me that?His son was but a ward two years ago.

instruction: You tell a sad tale too well, too well. Where is the Earl of Wiltshire? Where is Bagot? How have Bushy and Green let the dangerous enemy come into this country without meeting any opposition? If we survive this, they'll pay for it with their heads: I bet they've made peace with Bolingbroke.
response: Peace have they made with him indeed, my lord.

instruction: I'm doing well, my good lady. [To himself] Oh, it's so hard to pretend I'm fine! [To DESDEMONA] How are you, Desdemona?
response: Well, my good lord.

instruction: This knight is a beloved puppet to you, Sir Toby.
response: I have been dear to him, lad, some two thousand strong,or so.

instruction: A fool that wears nice clothes, not unlike you. He can change appearances. Sometimes he looks like a lord, and sometimes he looks like lawyer. Sometimes, he looks like a philosopher with two testicles to add to the stone he uses for alchemy. A lot of times he looks like a knight, but generally he sticks to the appearances men take between the ages of 13 and 80.
response: Thou art not altogether a fool.

instruction: Oh, horrible villain! You call that trimming?
response: Why, she was wash'd and cut and trimm'd, and 'twasTrim sport for them that had the doing of it.

instruction: They are like two virtuous supports for a Christian prince, to prevent him from the downfall of vanity. And see, he has a prayer book in his hand. These are the accessories of a holy man.
response: My lord, there needs no such apology.

instruction: Do you know her?
response: Almost as well as I do know myself:To think upon her woes I do protestThat I have wept a hundred several times.

instruction: There's plenty of time for that and to tell all our stories. Go on, all of you lucky people! Go to the feast. Meanwhile, I'll find some lonely place to mourn my husband until I die.
response: O, peace, Paulina!

instruction: What? Have I said the right thing twice? When was the first time? Please tell me. Butter me up with praise 'til I'm as fat as a pig for the slaughter. If you don't compliment a good deed, you'll stop that person from doing a thousand more good things that person might have done. Your compliments are my reward. For a single kiss, you can ride me for a mile before you'd have to kick me with your spurs. Back to the point: if my most recent accomplishment was convincing him to stay, what was the first one? This accomplishment must have a sister, unless I misunderstood you. If only her name were "Grace!" There was another time I said something good? What was it? Please tell me; I'm dying to know.
response: Why, that was when Three crabbed months had sour'd themselves to death, Ere I could make thee open thy white hand And clap thyself my love: then didst thou utter 'I am yours for ever.'

instruction: Hermione, are you tongue-tied? Say something!
response: I had thought, sir, to have held my peace until You have drawn oaths from him not to stay.

instruction: For the last time, get her out of here!
response: A most unworthy and unnatural lordCan do no more.

instruction: What, you can't even stand my presence? Now I see that she is your treasure. She must have a husband, while I must dance barefoot on her wedding day and lead apes in hell, all because you love her most. Don't speak to me, I will go cry and wait until I can get my revenge.
response: Was ever gentleman thus grieved as I?But who comes here?

instruction: And then?
response: The old priest at Saint Lukes Church is at your command at all hours.

instruction: We don't have any silent songs, sir.
response: Then put up your pipes in your bag, for Ill away.

instruction: I think I am a prophet, newly inspired, and as I die I make this prediction. His bad behavior cannot last, for violent fires soon burn themselves out; small rain showers last long, but sudden storms are short; he who rides too fast will soon exhaust himself; he who eats too quickly will choke; vanity is like an insatiable vulture that feeds on itself. This royal throne of kings, this crowned island, this land of majesty, this seat of war, this other Edenalmost paradisethis fortress built by Nature as her home against disease and invaders, this happy race of men, this little world, this precious stone set in the silver sea (which acts as a wall or a moat that defends a castle against the jealousy of less happy nations), this blessed plot of land, this earth, this realm, this England, this nurse, this birthplace of royal kings who are feared and respected for their ancestry, as famous for their deeds of Christian service and true chivalry as is the tomb of Jesus! This land of such dear souls, this dear dear land, beloved for her reputation through the worldis now rented out, I die pronouncing it, like a tenement or a paltry little farm. England, surrounded by the triumphant sea, with a rocky shore that beats back the jealousy of the sea god Neptune, is now fenced in by its own shame, sealed with ink blots and rotten legal documents. The England that used to conquer others has made a shameful conquest of itself. Ah, if the scandal ended with my life, I could die happy!
response: The king is come: deal mildly with his youth; For young hot colts being raged do rage the more.

instruction: Old man, you're out of luck.
response: Why, sir?

instruction: Then you must have a horrible message to deliver, since you're so afraid to get to the point. Speak your business.
response: It alone concerns your ear.

instruction: How can you say that? His son was still a minor two years ago.
response: [To a SERVINGMAN] What lady is that which doth enrich the handOf yonder knight?

instruction: They lie in bed while dreaming about true things.
response: Oh, then, I see Queen Mab hath been with you.

instruction: Am I a lord? Do I have such a lady? Or am I dreaming? Or have I been dreaming until now? I'm not asleep: I can see, and hear, and speak. I can smell sweet aromas and feel soft things. I swear, I must be a lord indeed! I'm not a tinker, and I'm not Christopher Sly. Well, bring my lady here before me, and I'll ask again, bring me a mug of the cheapest beer.
response: Will t please your Mightiness to wash your hands?

instruction: My lord, will you eat?
response: Taste of it first, as thou art wont to do.

instruction: I defy your threats. Im arresting you as a criminal.
response: Wilt thou provoke me?

instruction: But
response: He could not miss t.

instruction: [As VINCENTIO] Keep your hundred pounds to yourself. He won't need anything as long as I'm alive.
response: [To VINCENTIO] Nay, I told you your son was well beloved in Padua.

instruction: If this is just another of the illusions produced by this island, then Ill lose my dear son twice.
response: A most high miracle!

instruction: [To herself] Oh, look how beautiful he is even in his anger and contempt! A murderer's guilt is easier to hide than feelings of love. Midday is like nighttime for lovethat's how brightly passion shines. [To VIOLA] Cesario, I swear by the roses of spring, by virginity, by honor, by truth, and by everything, that I love you. I love you so much that neither my wit nor my reason can hide my passion, despite your pride. Don't draw the wrong conclusions from this, thoughjust because I'm wooing you doesn't mean you shouldn't woo me. Use your better logic and see that love asked for is good, but love freely given is better.
response: By innocence I swear, and by my youth I have one heart, one bosom, and one truth, And that no woman has, nor never none Shall mistress be of it, save I alone.

instruction: If they see you theyll murder you.
response: Alack, there lies more peril in thine eyeThan twenty of their swords.

instruction: Tell me again, where did you leave those villains?
response: I told you, sir, they were red-hot with drinking, So full of valor that they smote the air For breathing in their faces, beat the ground For kissing of their feet; yet always bending Towards their project.

instruction: Well, God give her a good rest afterwards! What sort of child has he given her?
response: A devil.

instruction: [To the shepherd, but without him hearing] You poor father, you'll have more of this funny business to deal with after the festival.[To CAMILLO] Has it gone too far? We need to separate them. Florizel is an idiot and is about to give himself away.[To FLORIZEL] Hello there, handsome shepherd! You're distracted by love and not too focused on this party, huh? I'll tell you, when I was your age, I was a sucker for buying gifts for my girlfriend. I would have bought every piece of silk from the traveling salesman if it would have won her over, but you've let him go without buying a single thing. If your girlfriend interpreted this as a lack of love on your part, you'd be hard-pressed to convince her that you really care.
response: Old sir, I know She prizes not such trifles as these are: The gifts she looks from me are pack'd and lock'd Up in my heart; which I have given already, But not deliver'd.

instruction: Here, kiss the Bible.[STEPHANO gives the bottle to TRINCULO] Though you can swim like a duck, you look like a silly goose.
response: O Stephano, hast any more of this?

instruction: And where is that poisonous snake? Bring the villain forward.
response: I look down towards his feet, but thats a fable.If that thou best a devil, I cannot kill thee.

instruction: You cry so they can drink, Timon.
response: Joy had the like conception in our eyesAnd at that instant like a babe sprung up.

instruction: I'm not worthy to be her teacher.
response: She thinks not so; peruse this writing else.

instruction: [Whispering] Yes, and if you had an "I" in the back of your head, you might see more trouble behind you than good luck before you.
response: M.O.A.I.

instruction: All right then, sir. We all pay for our pleasures eventually.
response: Give me now leave to leave thee.

instruction: Go on, Camillo.
response: I am appointed him to murder you.

instruction: What's that?
response: My nieces chambermaid.

instruction: That's it, I promise.
response: Hark, how these instruments summon to supper.

instruction: Get out of my way, unruly woman!
response: After, Aumerle!

instruction: I thought you were sure about this.
response: So I amto let him live.

instruction: Run after that irritating messenger who just left, the duke's man. He left this ring behind, whether I wanted it or not. Tell him I want nothing to do with it. [OLIVIA hands him a ring] Tell him not to encourage Orsino, or get his hopes up. I am not for him. And tell that youth that if he'll come by tomorrow, I'll give him reasons why. Now hurry up, Malvolio.
response: Madam, I will.

instruction: Come here, I tell you! Theres other work for you to do. Come here, you slow turtle! Come on!
response: Fine apparition!

instruction: I've practically fainted, to tell the truth.
response: Good madam, whats the matter with my lord?

instruction: Then he's a rogue, and I hate a drunken rogue. He spins and sways like he's doing a slow dance.
response: Away with him!

instruction: I have sent someone to tell Cassio to come speak to you.
response: I have a salt and sorry rheum offends me.Lend me thy handkerchief.

instruction: No, she doesn't talk that much!
response: In faith, too much.

instruction: Sir, it might be better if someone else popped the cherry before you
response: What, prithee?

instruction: God for his mercy! What a tide of woes comes rushing on this sad land at once! I don't know what to do: I wish to God, provided I hadn't done anything disloyal, the king had cut off my head with my brother's. What, are there no messages sent to Ireland? How will we have money for these wars?
response: Gentlemen, will you go muster men?

instruction: That's true, when someone who has avoided God's grace is controlling that destiny. My children would have been destined to better deaths if you had been blessed with a more virtuous life.
response: You speak as if that I had slain my cousins.

instruction: Please, my king, be quiet. Do you see this? It's the door to his hut. Be silent and enter. Commit the good crime that will make this island yours forever. And I, your Caliban, will always be your worshipful foot-licker.
response: Give me thy hand.

instruction: You are most welcome, your Honor.
response: Will you walk, sir?O Desdemona

instruction: What are you doing away from home? How are you, my most beautiful Bianca? I was actually just on my way to your house, my sweet love.
response: And I was going to your lodging, Cassio.

instruction: Too true, too true, sir. No woman alive compares to the woman you killed.
response: I think so.

instruction: My shame and guilt overcome me. Forgive me, Valentine. If hearty sorrow can be enough to make up for my offense, I offer it here. I do suffer for the wrongs I've committed.
response: Then I am paid; And once again I do receive thee honest.

instruction: I can't do much good at all for him, unless you call it good to pity him for having lost his inheritance.
response: Now, afore God, 'tis shame such wrongs are borne In him, a royal prince, and many more Of noble blood in this declining land.

instruction: Then go, goodbye. Get enough money together in your wallet.
response: Ill sell all my land.

instruction: [To himself] Now I've seen them go into the church together. May God give them a good marriage! But who's this here? My old master Vincentio! Now everything's ruined! It was all for nothing.
response: [To BIONDELLO] Come hither, crack-hemp.

instruction: Vices, yes, that's what I meant. I know this guy well: he was an odd-jobs guy, then a police officer, then he wasted all his money for a while, and then he married a handyman's wife about a mile away from where I live now. He's tried his hand at several questionable professions and has now settled on being a criminal. Some call him Autolycus.
response: Out upon him!

instruction: So could I.
response: And ask no other dowry with her but such another jest.

instruction: God be with you, sir; I will.
response: Come, Marcus, let us go.

instruction: Well, sir, now it begins.
response: Gentlemen, forward to the bridal dinner.I see a woman may be made a foolIf she had not a spirit to resist.

instruction: Listen, these trumpets announce that dinner is ready. The messenger from Venice is waiting on the food. Go inside, and don't cry. Everything will be okay.
response: How now, Roderigo!

instruction: [To himself] Now, by the gods, I have to applaud his bravery.
response: My actions are as noble as my thoughts, That never relish'd of a base descent.

instruction: I wish that I had never seen him, though!
response: Go, girl.

instruction: How does Gremio like these quick-witted folks?
response: Believe me, sir, they butt together well.

instruction: I'll bet you're a happy fellow, without a care in the world.
response: Not so, sir, I do care for something.

instruction: [Taking his hand] Now, sir, everyone has a right to their opinions. Please, take your hand to the dairy and let it drink.
response: Wherefore, sweetheart?

instruction: She says it's pale.
response: Nay then, the wanton lies; my face is black.

instruction: "M"Malvolio. "M"why, that's the first letter of my name.
response: [aside] Did not I say he would work it out?

instruction: For shame, what a devious and perverse course the queen is taking!
response: My Lord of Buckingham, if my weak oratory Can from his mother win the duke of York, Anon expect him here; but if she be obdurate To mild entreaties, God in heaven forbid We should infringe the holy privilege Of blessèd sanctuary!

instruction: My Lord Aumerle, is Harry Hereford ready for battle?
response: Yea, at all points; and longs to enter in.

instruction: I'm strong-willed. My conscience won't overcome me.
response: Spoke like a tall man that respects thy reputation.

instruction: Fellow soldiers and loving friends, all who have suffered under the burden of Richard's tyrannywe have marched this far without obstacles, all the way to the center of England. And here we receive news of encouragement and comfort from my stepfather Stanley. He says this: the wretched, violent, and usurping boar, that ruined your fields and vineyards; drinks your warm blood like water; and uses your disemboweled stomachs as his feeding troughthis foul swine is right now in the center of the country, near the town of Leicester. It's only a day's march from Tamworth, where we are now. In God's name, let's continue with cheerful spirits, my courageous friends, to reap the harvest of eternal peace from this one bloody trial of war.
response: Every mans conscience is a thousand men,To fight against this guilty homicide.

instruction: And his opponent, the youth, doesn't seem to have much aggression in his face either.
response: Look where the youngest wren of nine comes.

instruction: I will get free from you!
response: What wouldst thou now?

instruction: Who's coming with me? Begging your pardon, Leontes, but I need some women to come with me on account of the pregnancy. [To her servants] Don't cry; there's no reason to cry. You can cry if and when you find out that I actually deserve to be in prison. What's happening here is only a chance for me to demonstrate grace. [To LEONTES] Goodbye, sir. I never hoped to see you regret something; now I'm sure I will.[To her servants] Ladies, come on, you have permission.
response: Go, do our bidding; hence!

instruction: Welcome them and guide them to us.
response: You must needs dine with me: go not you henceTill I have thank'd you: when dinner's done,Show me this piece.

instruction: Please, good Grumio, tell me, how are things out in the world?
response: A cold world, Curtis, in every office but thine, and therefore fire!

instruction: Weak fool! Shallow, fickle woman!
response: How now, what news?

instruction: Well, they've seen me more or less, or they never saw me at allhere's Aaron. What do you want with him?
response: O gentle Aaron, we are all undone!Now help, or woe betide thee evermore!

instruction: Three rolls of the dice is lucky, sir, and the old saying goes "the third time's the charm." Triple-time is a good beat for dancing, and the bells of Saint Bennet's church chimeone, two, three.
response: You can fool no more money out of me at this throw.

instruction: Oh, my heart!
response: I'll have thy beauty scratch'd with briers, and made More homely than thy state.

instruction: Where is the duke my father with his army?
response: No matter where; of comfort no man speak: Let's talk of graves, of worms, and epitaphs; Make dust our paper and with rainy eyes Write sorrow on the bosom of the earth, Let's choose executors and talk of wills: And yet not so, for what can w

instruction: So, Green, you are the midwife to my sadness, and Bolingbroke is the child of my sorrow: now my soul has brought forth her offspring, and I, a gasping new mother, have joined my unborn sorrow with a real one.
response: Despair not, madam.

instruction: Then forgive me for speaking like a military man, my lords. Why do good people fight and not patiently bear the insults of their enemies? Why do they not patiently let those same enemies murder them in their sleep? If there is such honor in patience, what do we make of our wars abroad, and why are women not considered more valiant for staying at home? Why do we not deem the donkey superior to the lion, or the prisoner to the judge, if there is such wisdom in suffering? You are great men, be compassionate. Who would not sentence a man for violent aggression? You are right, murder is the greatest sin, but when it is done for self-defense it is fair. Anger is wicked, but who has not been angry before? Think about this as you judge the crime before you.
response: You breathe in vain.

instruction: I'm happy to do as you say.
response: My best Camillo!

instruction: [As VINCENTIO] Away with you, mad fool! His name is Lucentio, my only son, and heir to all the lands owned by me, Vincentio.
response: Lucentio!

instruction: Oh, blood, blood, blood!
response: Patience, I say.

instruction: [To the baby] May you have an easy life! No baby has ever had such a chaotic birth, but you seem to be quiet and gentle! This is the worst welcome to the world that any princess has ever had. It can only go up from here! This is the roughest start for a newborn that fire, water, earth, and heaven could put together as you came out of the wombyou've lost everything before you had anything at all. May the gods take note of this and bless your future!
response: What courage, sir?

instruction: Sir, there are three wagon-makers, three shepherds, three cowboys, and three pig-herders outside dressed up as satyrs. They call themselves "The Wits" and say they have a dance to perform, but the girls are saying its a load of garbage. But the men say that, if people aren't easily offended, they'll enjoy the performance.
response: Away!

instruction: We will attend you, your Grace.
response: I do the wrong, and first begin to brawl.

instruction: How long a time lies in one little word! Four long winters and four fresh springs end in a word: such is the power of a king's wishes.
response: I thank my liege, that in regard of me He shortens four years of my son's exile: But little vantage shall I reap thereby; For, ere the six years that he hath to spend Can change their moons and bring their times about My oil-dried lamp and

instruction: Yes, Timon, and for a good reason.
response: The gods confound them all in thy conquest;And thee after, when thou hast conquer'd!

instruction: But we can, grandmother, for my good uncle Richard told me. He said that the king was provoked by the queen to make up accusations against my father that would get him arrested. When my uncle told me about this he wept, and pitied me, and kindly kissed my cheek. He told me that I could rely on him as if he were my father, and that he would love me as dearly as if I were his child.
response: Ah, that deceit should steal such gentle shape, And with a virtuous visor hide deep vice.

instruction: Sound the trumpets, and combatants, come forward.
response: Stay, the king hath thrown his warder down.

instruction: [Singing] My lady is unkind indeed.
response: Fool!

instruction: Before you can say Come and Go"and breathe twice and shout So, so!"each one of your servants, leaping on their toes, will arrive here with their gestures and silly faces. Do you love me, master? No?
response: Dearly my delicate Ariel.

instruction: You're not a complete fool.
response: Nor thou altogether a wise man: as much foolery asI have, so much wit thou lackest.

instruction: Who cares where; let no man talk of comfort. Let's talk of graves, of worms, and epitaphs; dust is our paper, and with our tears we'll write "sorrow" on the ground. Let's choose executors and talk of willsbut no, for what can we leave behind after we're dead, except our deposed body to the grave? Our lands, our lives and everything we have are Bolingbroke's; we have nothing to call our own but death, and the earth covering our coffin. For God's sake, let us sit on the ground and tell sad stories of the death of kings: how some have been deposed; some killed in war; some haunted by the ghosts of the kings they deposed; some poisoned by their wives: some killed while they sleptall murdered. For within the hollow crown that sits on the king's mortal head, Death keeps his court, and sits amusing himself, grinning at his power, allowing the king a breath, a little time, to be a monarch, be feared and kill with looks, feeling vain and self-satisfied, as if this thin wall of flesh were impenetrable brass. But Death comes and with a little pin breaks through his castle wall, and: farewell king! Cover your heads; such signs of respect now are just a mockery, when you know that I'm flesh and blood. Throw away respect, tradition, all forms of royal ceremony and duty, for you have been mistaken all this while: I live by bread like you, feel want, taste grief, need friends. Subjected like this, how can you say to me that I am a king?
response: My lord, wise men ne'er sit and wail their woes, But presently prevent the ways to wail.

instruction: [Singing]Oh my mistress, where are you roaming?Oh, stay and listen! Your true love's coming:He can sing both high and low.Travel no more, my pretty sweetheart.Journeys end when lovers meet,As every wise man's son should know.
response: Excellent good, i' faith.

instruction: Oh, forgive me for all my sins!
response: He that dies pays all debts.I defy thee!Mercy upon us!

instruction: What handkerchief?
response: What handkerchief?Why, that the Moor first gave to Desdemona,That which so often you did bid me steal.

instruction: I don't know a single woman, or even seen a womans faceexcept my own in the mirror. Ive also never met any other men than you, my friend, and my dear father. I have no knowledge of what people look like in other places. But I swear by my virginitythe most precious thing that I can givethat Id never want to be with anyone in the world but you. I cant even imagine that I might like any other shape besides your own. But listen to me babbling on and on, forgetting that my father told me not to.
response: I am in my condition A prince, MirandaI do think, a king; I would, not so!and would no more endure This wooden slavery than to suffer The flesh-fly blow my mouth.

instruction: Oh, God forgive us!
response: I cry you mercy, then, I took you for that cunning whore of Venice That married with Othello.

instruction: My lord, the enemy has passed the marsh. Let George Stanley die after the battle is over.
response: A thousand hearts are great within my bosom.

instruction: Are you really leaving tonight?
response: I must away today, before night come.

instruction: If your speech could ever please me, it would be these observations. The state of Athens has become a forest of beasts.
response: How has the ass broke the wall, that thou art out of the city?

instruction: If youre braver with a man of your own rank, heres my gage, Aumerle: by the sun that shines on us, I hear you sayand you said it boastinglythat you were responsible for noble Gloucester's death. Even if you deny it twenty times, youre still a liar; and Ill stab you in your lying heart.
response: Thou darest not, coward, live to see that day.

instruction: Tell me what a drunk man is like, fool.
response: Like a drowned man, a fool and a madman.

instruction: Is she really such a splendid girl?
response: Ay, lord.

instruction: Where, good Mistress Mary?
response: In the wars.

instruction: Madam, not now. I don't have a good feeling about this, and don't think it's the right time.
response: Well, do your discretion.

instruction: He was? Why, then! What will be will be! The nobles are fled; the common people are cold and will, I fear, join Hereford's side.
response: My lord, I had forgot to tell your lordship,To-day, as I came by, I called there;But I shall grieve you to report the rest.

instruction: Like a nice dream or an empty fantasy. So take him inside and start setting up the prank. Carry him gently to my finest room, and hang all my erotic paintings on the walls. Bathe his filthy head with warm, clean water, and burn fragrant wood to make the room smell sweet. Find some musicians to be ready for when he wakes, so they can make sweet and heavenly sounds for him. If he happens to speak, be ready right awaybow low and say obediently, "What does your Honor command us to do?" Let one servant wait on him with a silver bowl full of rosewater and flowers. Have another servant carry the pitcher, and a third carry a towel, and say, "Would it please your Lordship to cool your hands?" Have someone ready with expensive clothing, and ask him what he wants to wear. Have another servant tell him about his dogs and his horse, and explain that his wife has been grieving over his illness. Convince him he's been out of his mind, and when he says that he's insane now, tell him that he's just mistaken, for he is really a mighty lord. Do all this, and do it convincingly, gentle sirs. If this can be managed subtly, it will be some excellent entertainment for us.
response: My lord, I warrant you we will play our partAs he shall think by our true diligenceHe is no less than what we say he is.
