instruction: Bonos dies, Sir Toby. As the old hermit of Prague, who never learned to read or write, said very wittily to a niece of King Gorboduc, "That which is, is." So if I'm Mr. Priest, then I'm Mr. Priest. For doesn't "that" just mean "that," and isn't "is" just "is?"
response: To him, Sir Topas.

instruction: The same way men do on land: the big ones eat the little ones. Whales are like rich men, they play and tumble, pushing all the little fish in front of them, then eat them up all in one gulp. I've heard of whales like that on land, who won't stop until they've swallowed the whole parish, church, steeple, bells, and everything else.
response: [Aside] A pretty moral.

instruction: Well, let's go to the king. The stuff in this bag will give him something to think about.
response: [Aside] I know not what impediment this complaintmay be to the flight of my master.

instruction: I swear on my own honor.
response: Humbly I thank your lordship: never mayThe state or fortune fall into my keeping,Which is not owed to you!

instruction: [To himself] Despite everything I just said, Ill hide nearby. The look on his face makes me nervous, and I have doubts about his story of what he plans to do.
response: Thou detestable maw, thou womb of death, Gorged with the dearest morsel of the earth, Thus I enforce thy rotten jaws to open, And in despite Ill cram thee with more food!

instruction: Pale trembling coward, there I throw my gage [throws glove on the ground], abandoning here my royal bloodit's fear, not respect, that makes you refuse to challenge me because I'm the king's cousin. If guilty fear has left you enough strength, pick it up: by that and all the code of knighthood, I'll take up arms to prove that you're guilty of all I've accused you of, or worse.
response: I take it up; and by that sword I swear Which gently laid my knighthood on my shoulder, I'll answer thee in any fair degree, Or chivalrous design of knightly trial: And when I mount, alive may I not light, If I be traitor or unjustly fight!

instruction: Say what you have to say: if I'm pleased with what you say, your child will live and I'll see it taken care of.
response: An if it please thee!

instruction: I am no whore. I am as chaste as you who accuse me.
response: As I!

instruction: As good as any man in Illyria, as long as he isn't better than I am. And yet I'm not as good as an experienced dancer.
response: What is thy excellence in a galliard, knight?

instruction: We can help you with that. We'll make sure you get a pair, and I'll bring you to court myself.
response: Then honour be but a goal to my will,This day I'll rise, or else add ill to ill.

instruction: Its nearly six o'clock, my lord, which is when you said our work would be done.
response: I did say so When first I raised the tempest.

instruction: Yes, that's the point. At the risk of being too honest, it was against her nature not to like so many suitors of her own country, complexion, and social rank, since those who share such similarities are naturally drawn to each other. Ugh! You can practically smell a gross desire in excessive proportion and foul thoughts in such a person. But forgive me, I am talking generally and don't mean her in particular, although I do fear that she may return to her better judgment, prefer her own countrymen to you, and take back her love for you.
response: Farewell, farewell.If more thou dost perceive, let me know more.

instruction: Indeed, the judges have sent for us.
response: And so was I.

instruction: Yes, and you come from Isidore for the same?
response: It is so.

instruction: I hope he proves himself so; then I can respect him.
response: Next, he's the governor of this country, and a manwhom I am bound to.

instruction: "Some achieve greatness"
response: What sayest thou?

instruction: Yesthe two points where your suspenders are buttoned on. If one breaks, the other will hold. But if both break, your pants will fall.
response: Apt, in good faith, very apt.

instruction: I wish that all were wellbut that will never be. I fear that our good fortune has reached its peak.
response: They do me wrong, and I will not endure it!

instruction: you see before you a beautiful woman. You can look, but don't touch! She's dangerous. Her beauty might lure you in, but if you're not deserving, you'll be killed just for trying to get a closer look.[He points to a pile of skeletons] Those former princes, like you, were drawn here by the rumors. They were looking for adventure, too. As you can see by their silence (and their bare bones), they're all casualties of love with no grave to speak of, except the stars above. Take a hint from their corpses and turn back now before it's too late.
response: Antiochus, I thank thee, who hath taught My frail mortality to know itself, And by those fearful objects to prepare This body, like to them, to what I must; For death remember'd should be like a mirror, Who tells us life's but breath, to tr

instruction: You must be afraid of his moodiness or my faults, if you think there's any chance that he'll stop liking me. Is he usually fickle in his moods and favors?
response: No, believe me.

instruction: [To ALONSO] Sir, we were discussing that our clothes seem just as clean as they did when we were in Tunis at the wedding of your daughter, whos now queen.
response: And the rarest that e'er came there.

instruction: I could be "Count Malvolio!"
response: ( aside ) Ah, rogue!

instruction: Five thousand.
response: 'Tis much deep: and it should seem by the sun,Your master's confidence was above mine;Else, surely, his had equall'd.

instruction: He is a rascal that continuously makes me ashamed! Sebastian, I have taken you into service, partly because I need such a young boy who can carry out my business with discretion. There's no point in trusting that foolish man over there. But I have mostly employed you because of your face and your manners, whichif my prediction is correctare evidence of a good upbringing, fortune, and truth. Therefore, you should know that I have taken you for these reasons. Go at once and take this ring with you. Deliver it to Madam Silvia. The girl who gave it to me loved me well.
response: It seems you loved not her, to leave her token.She is dead, belike?

instruction: Let him get his mercy from a noose, and let devils in hell gnaw on his bones! Why should Othello call Desdemona a whore? Who does she sleep with? Where? When? How? What proof is there? The Moor has been tricked by some absolutely villainous lowlifesome base, well-known fool, some vile man. Oh God, if only you would reveal the evil people in the world and give every honest person a whip to lash the rascals with as they run naked east to west across the whole globe!
response: Speak within door.

instruction: [To himself] And for dinner too, though you don't know it yet.
response: Ill wait upon your Lordship.

instruction: Cant you hear him shouting commands? Youre interfering with our work. Stay in your cabins. Youre helping the storm.
response: Nay, good, be patient.

instruction: Admit it, admit, didn't that one hit close to home?
response: He has a little galled me, I confess.And, as the jest did glance away from me,'Tis ten to one it maimed you two outright.

instruction: He couldnt not say it.
response: It must needs be of subtle, tender, and delicate temperance.

instruction: I didn't know that, but I saw Cassio use such a handkerchiefI'm sure it was your wife'sto wipe his beard earlier today.
response: If it be that

instruction: Say you want to hunt rabbits. Your greyhounds are as swift as healthy stags, yes, and quicker than young deer.
response: Dost thou love pictures?

instruction: I will not hold my tongue. I must speak. My mistress lies here murdered in her bed
response: Oh, heavens forfend!

instruction: [As Sir Topas] Don't try to talk to him, good fellow. [In his own voice] Who, me, sir? Not me, sir. God be with you, goodbye Sir Topas. [As Sir Topas] Amen. [In his own voice] Yes, sir, yes.
response: Fool, fool, fool, I say!

instruction: Enough to get a whore to retire, as well as enough to turn women into whores too. Stop bothering me and holding your skirts up, you sluts. You are not trustworthy, though I do know you will swear shaking with supposed divinity onto the immortal gods. Spare your prayers, and I'll trust your characters. Keep whoring, and the man that tries to tell you to do otherwise, be sure to stay true to your profession, seduce him, and infect him with your venereal diseases. Let that hidden fire overpower his piety, and do not betray your craft so that you may keep laboring. Cover your heads with wigs plucked from the hairs of the deadeven if they were hanged. Wear them and sin with them. Keep whoring around, with that thick makeup hiding all your wrinkles!
response: Well, more gold: what then?Believe't, that we'll do any thing for gold.

instruction: My Lord of Norfolk
response: Here, most gracious liege.

instruction: Let's shake hands. [They shake hands] I'll swear to the prince that you're as honest and loyal as any man in Bohemia.
response: You may say it, but not swear it.

instruction: Better, now that your Lordship was kind enough to ask.
response: I tell thee, man, tis better with me now Than when thou metst me last where now we meet.

instruction: I met the youthful lord at Lawrences cell. I treated him with all the love I could give without breaking the proper rules of modesty.
response: Why, I am glad on t.

instruction: Advancing them up to some scaffold, to lose their heads.
response: Unto the dignity and height of fortune, The high imperial type of this earths glory.

instruction: One of Timon's servants is coming
response: Flaminius!

instruction: Oh, he's drunk, Sir Toby, since an hour ago. He was cross eyed at eight in the morning.
response: Then hes a rogue, and a passy-measures pavin.

instruction: Foul shame on youI've already lost my patience with you all.
response: Were you well served, you would be taught your duty.

instruction: I heard he hasn't though. They say that my son of York has almost passed him in height.
response: Ay, mother, but I would not have it so.

instruction: What?
response: I say, my lords, he has done fair service, And slain in fight many of your enemies: How full of valour did he bear himself In the last conflict, and made plenteous wounds!

instruction: Madam, I will.
response: I do I know not what and fear to find Mine eye too great a flatterer for my mind.

instruction: Now, fellows, you are welcome here.
response: We thank your Honor.

instruction: By no means, good Ventidius. I helped you out of love and gave everything to you freely. No one can actually say that he gives if he receives something in return. The politicians play those kind of crafty games, and we must not do the same. If rich people ought to have faults, let them be good faults.
response: A noble spirit!

instruction: No, though Im bound more tightly than any mental patient is. Im locked in a prison without food. Im whipped, tortured.
response: God i good een.

instruction: Good Sir Toby!
response: Cousin, cousin, how have you come so early by this lethargy?

instruction: No, no, sir.
response: It is; you lie, you lie: I say thou liest, Camillo, and I hate thee, Pronounce thee a gross lout, a mindless slave, Or else a hovering temporizer, that Canst with thine eyes at once see good and evil, Inclining to them both: were my wife's

instruction: Feste the jester, my lord, a fool that Olivia's father used to like. He's somewhere in the house.
response: Seek him out, and play the tune the while.

instruction: What do you want, man? And how did you get here?
response: I would speak with Clarence, and I came hither on my legs.

instruction: Why bother asking that? I have forgotten all men. If you agree that you are indeed a man, then I have forgotten you too.
response: An honest poor servant of yours.

instruction: Oh, yes, and she feels sorry for them.
response: Wherefore?

instruction: Here is Lucentio, the real son of the real Vincentio. I've made your daughter mine by marriage while you were tricked by false appearances.
response: Heres packing, with a witness, to deceive us all!

instruction: What's the matter with you now?
response: O my good lord, yonders foul murders done!

instruction: This is the place. There, where that torch is burning.
response: The ground is bloody.Search about the churchyard.Go, some of you.

instruction: Be calm, my liegeremember who you are.
response: I had forgot myself; am I not king?

instruction: There will be no rest in any bedroom where you lie!
response: So will it, madam till I lie with you.

instruction: Well, forward, forward then! This is how things should go, smooth and straight. But wait! Someone's coming.
response: [To VINCENTIO] Good morrow, gentle mistress, where away?

instruction: No; I'll go to Ireland to his majesty. Goodbye: if the heart can predict the future, the three of us will never meet again.
response: That's as York thrives to beat back Bolingbroke.

instruction: Camillo had the power to open themhe's done it many times at your command.
response: I know't too well.Give me the boy: I am glad you did not nurse him:Though he does bear some signs of me, yet youHave too much blood in him.

instruction: Aren't you sorry for these horrible crimes?
response: Ay, that I had not done a thousand more.

instruction: I wonder why. He usually wakes up at seven.
response: Ay, but the days are wax'd shorter with him: You must consider that a prodigal course Is like the sun's; but not, like his, recoverable.

instruction: The woman who was beautiful but not too proud, who was eloquent but not too loud, who never lacked gold but never dressed too extravagantly, who held back her desires even when she could fulfill them, the woman who, when angry and able to get revenge nonetheless endured her misfortune and turned the other cheek, who was wise enough not to make foolish decisions, who could think and not share her thoughts, who could see men pursuing her but not pay them any attention . . . that's the sort of woman
response: To do what?

instruction: Cassio has been attacked here in the dark by Roderigo and some men who have run away. Cassio was almost killed, and Roderigo is dead.
response: Alas, good gentleman!

instruction: Bushy, what's the news?
response: Old John of Gaunt is grievous sick, my lord, Suddenly taken; and hath sent post haste To entreat your majesty to visit him.

instruction: Tell me what business you have there, and with whom. Tell me what's in that bag, where you live, your names, your ages, how much money you have, who your parents are, and anything else that I should know.
response: We are but plain fellows, sir.

instruction: What, must we drown in the cold water?
response: The king and prince at prayers.

instruction: Please, for honor's sake, no more. If you love Prince Pericles, you'll stop. I'll do as you wish: I'll set sail to find him, as dangerous as it is out there on the seas. Let me ask you to stand the absence of the king for another year. If I can't find the Prince within that time, I'll patiently accept your appointment. If you can't wait, go and look for him; show how loyal you are by your diligent searching. Then, if you find him and bring him back, he will reward you generously.
response: To wisdom he's a fool that will not yield;And since Lord Helicane enjoineth us,We with our travels will endeavour us.

instruction: My Lord Fitzwater, I remember the time you and Aumerle talked of these matters.
response: 'Tis very true: you were in presence then;And you can witness with me this is true.

instruction: Ha, ha, ha!
response: Do ye triumph, Roman?

instruction: Oh, you've come, Iago? You've done really well, since other men credit you for their murders .
response: What is the matter?

instruction: Jesus, what a rush you're in! Cant you wait for awhile? Dont you see that Im out of breath?
response: How art thou out of breath when thou hast breath To say to me that thou art out of breath?

instruction: Sir, the king, the king!
response: What is the business?

instruction: What! "She's busy, and she cannot come!" Is that her answer?
response: Ay, and a kind one too.Pray God, sir, your wife send you not a worse.

instruction: I am Pericles of Tyre, but tell me my drowned wife's name. Everything you've said has been completely perfect. If you get this right, you're the heir to two kingdoms and to me, your father, Pericles.
response: Is it no more to be your daughter than To say my mother's name was Thaisa?

instruction: In Orsino's heart.
response: In his bosom?

instruction: This warrant commands me to deliver the noble Duke of Clarence into your hands. I won't ask what this means, for I'd rather not know about something that might make me guilty later. There's the duke, sleeping, and here are the keys. [He hands them the keys] I'll go to the king and tell him that I've handed over my prisoner to you.
response: You may, sir.

instruction: If I saw a Montague rascal, Id face him. Id walk on the side of the street closer to the wall, and so force the Montague into the gutter.
response: That shows thee a weak slave, for the weakest goes to the wall.

instruction: Oh, man, carefully! I think I've broken my shoulder blade.
response: How now!

instruction: Think about your sins.
response: They are loves I bear to you.

instruction: Where was I?
response: At that sad stop, my lord, Where rude misgovern'd hands from windows' tops Threw dust and rubbish on King Richard's head.

instruction: I don't care. In that case, the heretic would be the one making the fire, not the one burning in it! I'll stop short of calling you a tyrant, but this cruel treatment of your queen on the basis of nothing more than your unsupported fantasy definitely tastes like tyranny. The world will see you as horrible and scandalous from here on out.
response: On your allegiance,Out of the chamber with her!

instruction: We are, my lord. We've come to get the warrant so we can be admitted into Clarence's cell.
response: Well thought upon.

instruction: [To RODERIGO so that only he can hear] Go away, I tell you. Run off and shout out that there's a brawl.
response: Nay, good lieutenant!

instruction: Remember the reward we'll get when the deed is done.
response: Zounds, he dies!

instruction: Saddle my horse. God have mercy, what treachery is here!
response: Why, what is it, my lord?

instruction: What, are you crying? Come closer. I do love you, now, because these tears show you to be a woman. You give up your manhood, because no man's eyes ever did tear up, except for lust or laughter. Pity may as well be asleep, for these are strange times, in which people weep for laughter and not in sadness.
response: I beg of you to know me, good my lord,To accept my grief and whilst this poor wealth lastsTo entertain me as your steward still.

instruction: [To QUEEN ELIZABETH] Yes, before you were queen, or your husband was king, I was a beast of burden for his great affairs. I weeded out his proud enemies and generously rewarded his friends. I spent my own blood to make his blood royal.
response: [aside] Ay, and much better blood than his or thine.

instruction: [To GONZALO] My good lord, please dont be angry.
response: No, I warrant you.

instruction: Wait, I'll win the bet even more completely, and show more signs of her obedience, her newly-created virtue and obedience.
response: See where she comes and brings your froward wives As prisoners to her womanly persuasion.

instruction: Well, he's been cast down already, so it seems likely that he'll be deposed: letters came last night to a dear friend of the good Duke of York's, telling bad news.
response: O, I am press'd to death through want of speaking!

instruction: His name is Tyrrel, my lord.
response: I partly know the man.

instruction: Sirs, shut him up, and don't let him say anything else.
response: My lord, there is a messenger from RomeDesires to be admitted to your presence.

instruction: Was the Duke of Milan thrown out of Milan so that his descendants could become kings of Naples? Oh, we should celebrate this extraordinary joy, and commemorate it in gold letters, etching them into columns that will last forever. In just one journey, Claribel found a husband in Tunis; Ferdinand, her brother, found a wife in the place where he was shipwrecked; Prospero found his dukedom on a deserted island; and all of us found ourselves when we could not control our own minds.
response: [to FERDINAND and MIRANDA] Give me your hands.Let grief and sorrow still embrace his heartThat doth not wish you joy.

instruction: Tybalt is lying right there.
response: [To TYBALT] Up, sir, go with me.I charge thee in the Princes name, obey.

instruction: Traitor?
response: Ay, traitor.

instruction: You're one of those men who want him to marry again.
response: If you would not so, You pity not the state, nor the remembrance Of his most sovereign name; consider little What dangers, by his highness' fail of issue, May drop upon his kingdom and devour Incertain lookers on.

instruction: My good Lord Stanley, the countess Richmond would hardly agree and say "amen" to you prayer. But even though she's your wife and doesn't like me, you can be assured, good lord, that I don't hate you for her proud arrogance.
response: I do beseech you either not believe The envious slanders of her false accusers, Or if she be accused in true report, Bear with her weakness, which I think proceeds From wayward sickness and no grounded malice.

instruction: And Julia herself gave it to me. And Julia herself has brought it here.
response: How!

instruction: Yes, and tell us where she's been living, or how she's come back from the dead.
response: That she is living, Were it but told you, should be hooted at Like an old tale: but it appears she lives, Though yet she speak not.

instruction: Yes, to see idiots fill up on meat and fools get drunk on wine.
response: Fare thee well, fare thee well.

instruction: Here he comes.
response: So soon as dinner's done, we'll forth again,My Alcibiades.

instruction: Come on, then. Kneel down and swear.
response: I shall laugh myself to death at this puppy-headed monster.A most scurvy monster.

instruction: No, there's something more going on. Please, tell me what you're thinking to yourself, and speak even the worst thoughts you are thinking.
response: Good my lord, pardon me, Though I am bound to every act of duty I am not bound to that all slaves are free to.

instruction: Ah!
response: Why dost thou cry 'alas'?

instruction: [To himself] That's a nice moral.
response: But, master, if I had been the sexton, I would havebeen that day in the belfry.

instruction: Oh, Romeo, Romeo, why must you be Romeo? Deny your father and give up your name. Or, if you wont change your name, just swear your love to me and Ill give up being a Capulet.
response: [Aside] Shall I hear more, or shall I speak at this?

instruction: Gentlemen, have your instruments been in Naples? Is that why they have that strange nasal sound?
response: How, sir?

instruction: Here I am, sir. What do you need?
response: Good, speak to th' mariners.

instruction: I know no one like this.
response: Nor I.

instruction: Slave!
response: Toad!

instruction: Well, go on. You've tamed a terrible shrew.
response: 'Tis a wonder, by your leave, she will be tamed so.

instruction: Then may black night overshadow your day, and death take your life.
response: Curse not thyself, fair creature; thou art both.

instruction: My name is Roderigo.
response: The worser welcome.

instruction: My lord of Salisbury, we have waited ten days, and hardly kept our countrymen together, and yet we hear nothing from the king. Therefore we will disperse the army: farewell.
response: Stay yet another day, thou trusty Welshman:The king reposeth all his confidence in thee.

instruction: If he governs the country, you are definitely bound to serve him. It's unclear how honorable he is in the act of governing, though.
response: Pray you, without any more virginal fencing, willyou use him kindly?

instruction: Please, is that true?
response: I am a very villain else.

instruction: [Looking up to heaven] God bless you, daughter. Tell me, sweetheart: how did you escape? Where did you live? How did you get back to your father's court? You should know: Paulina told me that the oracle gave us hope that you were still alive. I kept myself going just to see you.
response: There's time enough for that; Lest they desire upon this push to trouble Your joys with like relation.

instruction: Quiet, please. My soul is full of sorrow.
response: I will not rise unless your Highness hear me.

instruction: And also tell him we want to know where he came from and who his parents are.
response: The king my father, sir, has drunk to you.

instruction: Lucius, which book is she searching through so frantically?
response: Grandsire, 'tis Ovid's Metamorphoses;My mother gave it me.

instruction: Name him.
response: Plantagenet.

instruction: Youd take back your vow? Why, my love?
response: But to be frank, and give it thee again.

instruction: This scene now looks less like a serious thing, and more like "The Beggar and the King." My dangerous cousin, let your mother in: I know she's come to pray that I forgive you for your crime.
response: If thou do pardon, whosoever pray, More sins for this forgiveness prosper may.

instruction: Why would say that? Do you think I would make jealousy my whole life, and with every change in the moon find new suspicions? No! To doubt once is to make up your mind. I'd rather turn into a goat than devote all my time to such overblown suspicions, like the sort of jealous man you're describing. It wouldn't make me jealous for you to say that my wife is pretty, eats well, enjoys the company of others, speaks her mind, sings, plays music, and dances. When a woman is virtuous, these traits are virtuous as well. And I will not worry or fear that she may be unfaithful because I am not very desirable. She knew who she was marrying. No, Iago, I won't doubt Desdemona until I see something, and if I doubt her I'll see if I can prove it. If I get proof, there's only one thing to do: get rid of either my love or my jealousy.
response: I am glad of this, for now I shall have reason To show the love and duty that I bear you With franker spirit.

instruction: Oh, what a monstrous beast, lying there like a pig! Grim death, how foul and hateful your twinsleepis! Gentlemen, I will play a trick on this drunken man. What do you think: if he were carried to bed, dressed in fresh clothes, had rings put on his fingers, a delicious feast laid out by his bed, and had finely dressed servants near him when he woke upwouldn't the beggar be confused then?
response: Believe me, lord, I think he cannot choose.

instruction: For shame, get Juliet out here. Her bridegroom has arrived.
response: Shes dead, deceased, shes dead.

instruction: Advise us what we should do, Aaron, and we'll take your advice. Save the child so that we can all be safe.
response: Then sit we down, and let us all consult.My son and I will have the wind of you:Keep there: now talk at pleasure of your safety.

instruction: Right now I swear by Saint Peters Church and Peter too that he will not make me a joyful bride. Im confused by this sudden hurry. Why would I marry this would-be husband before hes even come to court me? I beg you, tell my father, madam, I wont marry yet. And when I do marry, I swear, Id marry Romeo, whom you know I hate, before Id marry Paris. Now that would be some news!
response: Here comes your father.

instruction: It's really sealed up tight! Did it come out of the sea?
response: I never saw so huge a billow, sir,As toss'd it upon shore.

instruction: Thats him, that villain Romeo.
response: Content thee, gentle coz.

instruction: Why, an Englishman could easily drink a Dane under the table, and wouldn't sweat out-drinking a German. And if a Dutchman tried to go drink for drink with an Englishman, the Dutchman would end up vomiting before they could even refill his cup.
response: To the health of our general!

instruction: What a good guess for such a boy!
response: Now, by Saint George, I am too young for you.

instruction: We have always known you to be a holy man. Where is Romeos servant? What does he say about all this?
response: I brought my master news of Juliets death, And then in post he came from Mantua To this same place, to this same monument.

instruction: Come, tailor, let's see what you have. Lay out the gown.
response: What news with you, sir?

instruction: My noble uncle, do you know whats causing his mood?
response: I neither know it nor can learn of him.

instruction: My own father wouldn't recognize me now.
response: Nay, you shall have no hat.

instruction: [To QUEEN ELIZABETH] You poor imitation of a queen, you meaningless decoration on my throne: why do you give sugar to this swollen spider when he's already ensnared you in his deadly web? Fool, fool, you're sharpening the knife that will kill you. The day will come when you'll wish that I could help you curse this poisonous, hunchbacked toad.
response: False-boding woman, end thy frantic curse,Lest to thy harm thou move our patience.

instruction: Here, fill your cup up to the brim. Here's a toast to your love for Thaisa and to all your health.
response: We thank your grace.

instruction: You're right, sir. What a wonder this modern age is! A sentence is like a supple glove for good witit can be turned inside out so quickly!
response: Nay, thats certain.

instruction: Sir, I told them to take you away.
response: Misprision in the highest degree!

instruction: God help me.
response: Say you?

instruction: Oh Tranio, I never thought it possible or likely until it happened to me. But see, while I stood here watching this unfold, I suddenly found myself struck with love. You are as trustworthy and dear to me as Anna was to Dido, Queen of Carthage, so I must plainly confess to you, Tranio: I'm on fire, I'm burning, I'm filled with longing. TranioI'll die if I can't win this modest young girl for myself. Advise me, Tranio, for I know you can. Help me, Tranio, for I know you will.
response: Master, it is no time to chide you now.

instruction: Can't you guess what she wants from you?
response: My lord, I know not, I, nor can I guess, Unless some fit or frenzy do possess her: For I have heard my grandsire say full oft, Extremity of griefs would make men mad; And I have read that Hecuba of Troy Ran mad through sorrow: that made me

instruction: Why, she already has a face of her own.
response: Who knows not that?

instruction: What, that they kissed in private?
response: An unauthorized kiss!

instruction: This is as rude as it is strange. I beg you, please do me the favor of asking the knight how I've offended him. It must be something I've done without knowing it, not on purpose.
response: I will do so.

instruction: Me too; let's go there together.
response: Or thou goest to the orange or mill.

instruction: What does Lord Stanley say? Will he bring his army?
response: My lord, he doth deny to come.

instruction: That's a step towards love.
response: No, not a grize.

instruction: I thank you for saying that. I know he loves me well. But I haven't asked him out about the coronation, and he hasn't told me his preferences about it. But you can name a time, my honorable lords. And I'll give my vote on the duke's behalf. I'm sure he won't mind.
response: In happy time here comes the duke himself.

instruction: [Whispering] What, what?
response: You must amend your drunkenness.

instruction: Now, your gown? Why, yes. Come, tailor, let us see it. God have mercy! What is this costume? What's this, a sleeve? It's more like a cannon. What, you've carved it like an apple tart all over? A snip here and a nip there, a cut here and a slash thereit's like a sieve! What in the hell do you call this, tailor?
response: [aside] I see shes like to have neither cap nor gown.

instruction: [To herself] And may her joy be even less than that, God! Elizabeth's honor, rank, and throne all rightly belong to me.
response: [to QUEEN ELIZABETH] What, threat you me with telling of the king?

instruction: Could we have the pleasure, my lord Timon, of serving you in some way? That way we could express our great enthusiasm for you, and be forever happy.
response: O, no doubt, my good friends, but the gods themselves have provided that I shall have much help from you: how had you been my friends else?

instruction: [To MIRANDA] Wake up, my dear, wake up! You have slept well. Wake up.
response: [waking] The strangeness of your story putHeaviness in me.

instruction: Uh oh, look who's coming. Will we be mocked?
response: We'll bear, with your lordship.

instruction: Let me weep for such a terrible loss.
response: So shall you feel the loss, but not the friendWhich you weep for.

instruction: Tybalt is dead. Romeo has been banished. It was Romeo who killed Tybalt, which is why he was banished.
response: O God, did Romeos hand shed Tybalts blood?

instruction: Oh, I'll die if I don't reply!
response: Thou, old Adam's likeness, set to dress this garden, How dares thy harsh rude tongue sound this unpleasing news?

instruction: Now I will question Cassio about Bianca, a loose girl that makes a living by selling herself to men. The whore loves Cassio, and it's her bad luck to attract many men but be attracted to just one. When he is asked about her, he can't help but laugh. Here he comes.
response: As he shall smile, Othello shall go mad.

instruction: [Whispering] Oh, yes, notice that. The trail's gone cold for him.
response: [aside] Sowter will cry upon t for all this, though it be as rank as a fox.

instruction: I have no more sons of royal blood for you to murder. And as for my daughters, Richard, they'll become praying nuns, not weeping queens. So don't aim to destroy their lives.
response: You have a daughter called Elizabeth, Virtuous and fair, royal and gracious.

instruction: Of course, sir, if you like.
response: Give me thy hand: I will swear to the prince thouart as honest a true fellow as any is in Bohemia.

instruction: Timon
response: What if it should be so?

instruction: Here comes your father. Tell him so yourself, and see how he takes it from you.
response: When the sun sets the air doth drizzle dew, But for the sunset of my brothers son It rains downright.

instruction: The mighty dukes of Gloucester and Buckingham.
response: For what offence?

instruction: Who is her mother?
response: Marry, bachelor, Her mother is the lady of the house, And a good lady, and a wise and virtuous.

instruction: Did you see my master winking and laughing at you?
response: Biondello, what of that?

instruction: She is indebted to you, gentle boy. Ah, poor lady, abandoned and left behind! I cry just thinking about your words. Here, boy, take my purse. I give you this for the sake of your sweet mistress, because you love her. Goodbye.
response: And she shall thank you for't, if e'er you know her.

instruction: If I don't, never trust me againinterpret that how you want to.
response: Come, come, Ill go burn some sack.

instruction: Ill get my bottle of wine back, even if it means I have to go down into that pond so the water is over my ears.
response: Prithee, my king, be quiet.

instruction: Sir Paris, Ill make a desperate present of my childs love. I think shell do whatever I tell her to do. No, Im sure she will. Wife, go to see her before you go to bed. Explain to her how my son Paris loves her. And tell her, listen to me, on WednesdayWaitWhat day is today?
response: Monday, my lord.

instruction: Wherever you want, as long as I'm out of your sight.
response: Go, some of you convey him to the Tower.

instruction: [Speaking of LUCILIUS] This man is honest.
response: Therefore he will be, Timon:His honesty rewards him in itself;It must not bear my daughter.

instruction: Oh, horrible plot! Oh, loyal father of a treacherous soon! Youre a clear fountain and hes the stream that muddies your water. But your overflow of goodness will redeem your son, even though hes committed a crime punishable by death.
response: So shall my virtue be his vice's bawd; And he shall spend mine honour with his shame, As thriftless sons their scraping fathers' gold.

instruction: Indeed I did. But if you remember, I didn't tell you to make it a mockery of the current fashions. Go on, hop on home, for you must hop without my money, sir. I want nothing to do with this. Get out of here, and do whatever you want with it.
response: I never saw a better-fashioned gown,More quaint, more pleasing, nor more commendable.Belike you mean to make a puppet of me.

instruction: My noble lord
response: If thou dost slander her and torture me, Never pray more.

instruction: If you are going to slander Desdemona and torture me, you can give up on praying, and showing any remorse, because it won't help you. Go ahead and pile more sins on top of the ones you've already committed, do things so horrible they'll make heaven cry and astound everyone on earth. For nothing you could do would add more to your damnation than if you should slander Desdemona more.
response: Oh, grace!

instruction: But as it is, we cant manage without him. He builds our fires, gathers our firewood, and performs useful work. Hey there! Caliban! You pile of dirt, you! Answer me.
response: [within] Theres wood enough within.

instruction: Why?
response: My worthy friends, will you draw near?

instruction: Yes, it is as I said.[To the POET] And as for your fiction, the lines swell with material so fine and smooth that your art comes to equal nature. But in spite of all this, my truthful friends, I must say that you do have one vice. It's not such a bad thing, and you shouldn't try too hard to fix it.
response: Beseech your honourTo make it known to us.

instruction: You are both honest men and have heard that I have gold. I am sure that you have. Tell me the truth, honest men.
response: So it is said, my noble lord; but thereforeCame not my friend nor I.

instruction: You're not even good enough to come with me. You are the fool.
response: Where's the fool now?

instruction: I will not stay, if it offends you.
response: Truly, an obedient lady.I do beseech your lordship, call her back.

instruction: What the hell was that?
response: Know you the quality of Lord Timon's fury?

instruction: What in the world do you mean, boy?
response: I would you did but see how it chafes, how it rages, how it takes up the shore!

instruction: What a ridiculous monster, to see a poor drunk man and think him a miracle.
response: [to STEPHANO] I prithee, let me bring thee where crabs grow.

instruction: I didn't.
response: Nor I.

instruction: What then?
response: Why then tis hers, my lord, and, being hers,She may, I think, bestow t on any man.

instruction: Bring that little chest here.
response: Yes, my lord.

instruction: I'll bring him.
response: Lords, you that here are under our arrest, Procure your sureties for your days of answer.

instruction: We are blessed to have met this man. Very blessed.
response: Let's before as he bids us: he was provided to do us good.

instruction: If you have any songs that are silent, feel free to keep playing those. But, you know, the general doesn't care much for music.
response: We have none such, sir.

instruction: This man, Lord Timon, this dependent of yours, comes by my house at night. I am a man who has been thrifty from the start, and my estate deserves an heir of better rank than this lowly waiter here.
response: Well; what further?

instruction: If you make us sing, youll hear us.
response: Pray you, put up your dagger and put out your wit.

instruction: You haven't gone to bed, then?
response: Why, no.

instruction: No, you don't need a hat. [He gives the hat to PERDITA] Come on, Perdita. [To AUTOLYCUS] Goodbye, friend.
response: Adieu, sir.

instruction: Don't ask him anymore, my lord Northumberland.
response: The commons will not then be satisfied.

instruction: What, everyone's leaving? From now on, let there never be a feast where such villains are not welcome. Burn down the house! Destroy all of Athens! Timon will from now on hate all of humanity!
response: How now, my lords!

instruction: Were I the king of the whole world, I would do anything to undo this. Poor Marina! She was not only a princess by blood, she was a virtuous person, the equal of any single princess on the earth by comparison! Curse you, Leonine. And you've poisoned him, too, haven't you? If you'd poisoned yourself, it would have been the punishment you deserved. What are you going to say to Pericles when he comes looking for his child?
response: That she is dead.

instruction: I have, my liege.
response: Tell me, moreover, hast thou sounded him, If he appeal the duke on ancient malice; Or worthily, as a good subject should, On some known ground of treachery in him?

instruction: Its no longer fashionable to talk that much. Were not going to announce our entrance with some guy blindfolded, dressed up as Cupid, and carrying a toy bow in order to frighten the ladies like some scarecrow. Nor will we introduce ourselves with a memorized speech. They can judge us however they want. Well dance for one dance, and then get out of there.
response: Give me a torch.

instruction: Two or three people are groaning. It's the middle of the nightthey might be trying to trick us. Let's not rush in unsafely by ourselves, without any other help.
response: Nobody come?

instruction: My lord, if you hadn't shown up when you did, Lord Hastings would have taken your part. He was going to cast a vote on your behalf in deciding about the coronation of the king.
response: Than my Lord Hastings no man might be bolder.

instruction: You're still keeping on the safe side of the law. Good.
response: [reads] Fare thee well, and God have mercy upon one of our souls.

instruction: You cannot make terrible sins look innocent. Valor is patience, not revenge.
response: My lords, then, under favour, pardon me, If I speak like a captain.

instruction: If only you could see how the water is roiling and raging all the way up the beachbut that's not the point! The pitiful cries of people who are doomed! I could see 'em, and then I couldn't as the ship went up and down, to and fro, pushed around in the waves like you'd push a cork into a keg of beer. And then on land, if you'd seen how the bear tore his arm out of its socket, and heard how he cried to me for help and said his name was Antigonus, a gentleman. But back to the ship: if you'd seen how the sea gobbled them up, and the people screamed, and the sea laughed at them, and how the poor man screamed and the bear laughed at him, both screaming louder than the sea or the storm.
response: Name of mercy, when was this, boy?

instruction: How poor are those who don't have any patience! Every wound must heal gradually. You know that our plan is based on cleverness and not magic, and cleverness needs time to work. Aren't things actually going well? Cassio has beaten you up, yes. But because of this he's been fired from his position as lieutenant. The fruits that blossom first are the first to ripen, and before long, we'll reap the fruits of our labors. Be patient a while longer. It's already morning, in fact. Excitement and action make time fly. Go back to your room and get some sleep. Go, I tell you. I'll fill you in more later. Now, get going.
response: Two things are to be done: My wife must move for Cassio to her mistress.

instruction: Youre asking me to stop my tale before its finished.
response: Thou wouldst else have made thy tale large.

instruction: A false conclusion. I hate your logic like I hate an empty wine goblet. To stay up past midnight means going to bed in the early morning, so therefore to stay up past midnight is to go to bed early. Doesn't life consist of the four elementsfire, water, earth, and air?
response: Faith, so they say, but I think it rather consists of eating and drinking.

instruction: If you're still not satisfiedsince he didn't go with your permissionI'll tell you why he left. When he was at Antioch
response: [Aside] What from Antioch?

instruction: What do you say for yourself, shepherd? Speak or you die.
response: I cannot speak, nor think Nor dare to know that which I know.

instruction: Well, she's escaped me. Sir Tranio, you also aimed at that bird, though you didn't hit her.So here's a toast to all who have shot and missed.
response: Oh, sir, Lucentio slipped me like his greyhound,Which runs himself and catches for his master.

instruction: Sin from my lips? Oh, how you urge me on to another crime. Give me back my sin.
response: You kiss by th book.

instruction: That would be hard to bring about, because she won't allow anyone in to see her, not even the duke's men.
response: There is a fair behavior in thee, captain, And though that nature with a beauteous wall Doth oft close in pollution, yet of thee I will believe thou hast a mind that suits With this thy fair and outward character.

instruction: Are they from Athens?
response: Yes.

instruction: Even tyrants wept when they heard about it.
response: No man but prophesied revenge for it.

instruction: I bless you on your mother's behalf. She prays continually for you. But enough of that. The silent hours keep passing, and dawn is breaking in the east. To be briefas the situation requiresyou should prepare your army early in the morning. Let bloody fighting and deadly war be the judges of your destiny. I can't help you in this battle as much as I'd like to, but I'll do the best I can without Richard finding out. If I act too boldly on your behalf and Richard notices, then your stepbrother, young George, will be executed in front of me. Farewell. The danger and urgency of the current situation must keep us from the long greetings and happy catching-up that friends like us, who have been separated for so long, should have. But may God grant us time for all that soon! Once more, farewell. Be brave, and do well.
response: Good lords, conduct him to his regiment: Ill strive with troubled thoughts to take a nap, Lest leaden slumber peise me down tomorrow, When I should mount with wings of victory.

instruction: No, my good lord, for that would be to forget what I never remembered; to my knowledge, I've never seen him in my life.
response: Then learn to know him now; this is the duke.

instruction: Really!
response: My lord?

instruction: What? The highest-ranking? What would happen to you if the King of Naples heard you say that?
response: A single thing, as I am now, that wonders To hear thee speak of Naples.

instruction: If you want to have a laughing fit, and really laugh until you split your sides, then follow me. That gullible Malvolio must have renounced Christianity, for no Christian who intends to go to heaven by his faith could ever believe the absurd, exaggerated things like we put in that letter. He's wearing yellow stockings.
response: And cross-gartered?

instruction: What? Should I cry out the name in a groan of sadness?
response: Groan!

instruction: I will interrogate all the world about him, and make everyone answer my questions.
response: Seek him, bid him come hither.

instruction: [To herself] You devil! I remember those efforts all too well: you killed my husband Henry in the Tower, and my poor son Edward at Tewkesbury.
response: [to QUEEN ELIZABETH] Ere you were queen, ay, or your husband king, I was a packhorse in his great affairs, A weeder-out of his proud adversaries, A liberal rewarder of his friends.

instruction: You are courageous gentlemen. Youd give the moon a helpful push if it got stuck in the same spot of its orbit for five weeks.
response: We would so, and then go a-batfowling.

instruction: Oh, was she really? Ill have to tell the story again every month, since you seem to forget it. This damned witch Sycorax was thrown out of Algiers for committing so many crimes and performing magic too terrible to even describe. There was just one reason why they didnt kill her. Isnt that true?
response: Ay, sir.

instruction: You'd better be sure of what you're doing, sir, or what you think is "justice" will devolve into violence that only causes you, your queen, and your son to suffer.
response: For her, my lord,I dare my life lay down and will do't, sir,Please you to accept it, that the queen is spotlessI' the eyes of heaven and to you; I mean,In this which you accuse her.

instruction: "Should be?" Keep on buzzing, bee!
response: Well ta'en, and like a buzzard.

instruction: I couldn't have imagined you could speak so well; I couldn't have dreamed it. If I had had a dirty mind, your speech would have changed it. Here, take this coin. Keep going on this virtuous path, and may the gods bless you!
response: The good gods preserve you!

instruction: Well, that's an problem.
response: Whereby hangs a tale, sir?

instruction: I do hope that dog dies.
response: How dost, fool?

instruction: I can't stay any longer.
response: One seven-night longer.

instruction: [So only LUCENTIO can hear] Keep quiet master, here's some entertainment for us. That girl is either insane or incredibly disobedient.
response: [aside to TRANIO ] But in the others silence do I seeMaids mild behavior and sobriety.Peace, Tranio.

instruction: It is silliness to live when life is torture? When death is the only remedy, then the best prescription is to die.
response: Oh, villainous!

instruction: Did your boss tell you who I am?
response: Who is my principal?

instruction: May God grant both of you a nice day.
response: As much to you, good sister.

instruction: Get away you dumb peasant! It's sad I have to waste a stone on you.
response: Beast!

instruction: Who do you mean?
response: Why, your lieutenant, Cassio.

instruction: I'll carry your purse then, and leave you for an hour.
response: To the Elephant.

instruction: He was right, and so indeed it is.
response: Tell the clock there.

instruction: Oh no, oh no! My child, my reason for being, come back! Look up, or Ill die with you! Help, help! Call for help.
response: For shame, bring Juliet forth.

instruction: You both have honorable reputations. Its a pity youve been enemies for so long. But, now, my lord: how do you respond to my request?
response: But saying oer what I have said before.

instruction: What, you?
response: Even so.

instruction: What is it, Biondello?
response: You saw my master wink and laugh upon you?

instruction: Yes, I am.
response: Then heavenHave mercy on me!

instruction: What? Yourself?
response: Ay.

instruction: What did the philosopher Pythagoras believe about wild birds?
response: That the soul of our grandam might haply inhabit a bird.

instruction: The one my lord called me.
response: He called her whore.

instruction: By my foot, I couldnt care less.
response: Follow me close, for I will speak to them.

instruction: And my letters say a hundred and forty.
response: And mine, two hundred.

instruction: Yes, hand from hand, my love, and heart from heart.
response: Banish us both and send the king with me.

instruction: May he live a long and wealthy life! Shall we go in?
response: I'll keep you company.

instruction: It's unbelievable!
response: [looking at VIOLA] Do I stand there?

instruction: I didn't want to trouble you, but you seem to take pleasure in enduring suffering, so I won't scold you about it anymore.
response: I could not stay behind you.

instruction: It seems our masters should probably give up on getting their money back. Now that Timon's mad, these debts are junk.
response: They have e'en put my breath from me, the slaves.Creditors?

instruction: Believe me, you've already sold us on this guy. Is he selling anything else?
response: He hath ribbons of an the colours i' the rainbow; points more than all the lawyers in Bohemia can learnedly handle, though they come to him by the gross: inkles, caddisses, cambrics, lawns: why, he sings 'em over as they were gods or goddes

instruction: Is this the same noble Moor that our whole senate thinks so highly of? Is this the person who supposedly could not be shaken by passion? The man whose solid virtue was invulnerable to anything chance or fortune could throw at it?
response: He is much changed.

instruction: What is the matter, my lord?
response: Ho!

instruction: Oh, for God's sake!
response: May not one speak?

instruction: Well, you have made a foolish choice. You dont know how to choose a man. Romeo? No, not him, even though his face is more handsome than any other mans, his legs are prettier. His hands and feet and body arent much to speak of, and yet theyre beyond compare. He isnt the most courteous man, but, Id swear that hes as gentle as a lamb. So do what you want, girl. Be good. Hey, have you already eaten lunch?
response: No, no.

instruction: Let's hope he's at the palace.
response: [Aside] Though I am not naturally honest, I am sosometimes by chance: let me pocket up my pedlar's excrement.

instruction: Yes, like a black dog, as the saying goes.
response: Art thou not sorry for these heinous deeds?

instruction: What excuse will we make? Or should we enter without apology?
response: The date is out of such prolixity.

instruction: I hold you all and your many visits so dear to my heart, there is not enough to give. I could deal kingdoms to my friends, and never tire of it. Alcibiades, you are a soldier, and therefore will never be rich. To give to you would be genuine charity, because you live among the dead, and all the lands you have are in the battlefield.
response: Ay, defiled land, my lord.

instruction: Oh, that crazy girl. But I'll be damned if don't love her! The world will end before I stop loving her.
response: My noble lord

instruction: Thank you. I know you mean that. You really do love my husband. You've known him for a long time, and you can be sure that he is only keeping his distance from you for political reasons.
response: Ay, but, lady, That policy may either last so long, Or feed upon such nice and waterish diet, Or breed itself so out of circumstances, That, I being absent and my place supplied, My general will forget my love and service.

instruction: You have already given me so many gifts.
response: So are we all.

instruction: Are your doors locked?
response: Why, wherefore ask you this?

instruction: I guess we can put our pipes away and leave.
response: Honest good fellows, ah, put up, put up,For, well you know, this is a pitiful case.

instruction: You speak with authority, but you look like a common man.
response: My voice is now the kings, my looks mine own.

instruction: You'll grant me, you hedgehog? Then let God grant me my wish that you'll be damned for that wicked deed. Oh, Henry was gentle, mild, and virtuous.
response: The better for the King of heaven that hath him.

instruction: God forbid!
response: I say she's dead; I'll swear't.

instruction: Its all the same. Ill be the Montagues master. After fighting with the men, Ill be nice to the maidsIll cut off their heads.
response: The heads of the maids?

instruction: The parties we throw might not be much to be proud of, but we make up for it with heart! Seriously
response: Beseech you

instruction: You've had a terrible experience giving birth, my dear. No light, no warmth, and a storm. And I don't even have time to bury you; I have to throw you into the sea without a coffin, straight into the depths. Instead of a tombstone and lighted lamps, you'll have whales, flowing water, and simple shells.[To LYCHORIDA] Lychorida, have Nestor bring in some spices, ink, and paper, a casket, and my jewels. And ask Nicander to bring me that fancy box. Lay the baby on that pillow, there, and go, while I say goodbye to my wife. Hurry!
response: Sir, we have a chest beneath the hatches, caulkedand bitumed ready.

instruction: I'll close the curtain. The king is so carried away, next he'll think that it lives.
response: O sweet Paulina,Make me to think so twenty years together!No settled senses of the world can matchThe pleasure of that madness.

instruction: I do. What of him?
response: Most noble Timon, call the man before thee.

instruction: Take her away. Her heart is just a little strained; she'll recover. I put too much stock in my own suspicions. Please, take care of her, get her some medicine. [PAULINA and the female servants carry HERMIONE out]Apollo, please forgive my blasphemy against your oracle! I'll make up with Polixenes, win my wife over again, bring Camillo back since I know now that he's a good guy. I was too carried away with my jealousy and got caught up with bloody thoughts of revenge. I told Camillo to poison my friend Polixenes, which would have happened if Camillo hadn't questioned my command (even though I threatened him with death if he didn't obey). He admirably told Polixenes what I had planned, then gave up his comfortable position here to help Polixenes get away. He risked everything to do what was right. His goodness glitters through my dark intentions, making my actions look even more dark by contrast!
response: Woe the while!O, cut my lace, lest my heart, cracking it,Break too.

instruction: Why would you say that? Either you're the most ignorant old man I've ever met or you were born an idiot. The fact that Camillo ran away, on top of Hermione and Polixenes' disgusting hook-ups (even if we didn't see them, we have all the evidence except the visual proof), on top of everything else, makes putting Hermione on trial absolutely necessary. It would be wrong to go about something this serious haphazardly, so I've sent my servants Cleomenes and Dion (you know them; they're good guys) to Delphos, to Apollo's temple. They'll bring back a prophecy from the oracle that will settle everything, for good or bad. How did I do?
response: Well done, my lord.

instruction: Oh, that joke is made of leather so thin it has been stretched from an inch wide to a full fat yard.
response: I stretch it out for that word broad, which, added to the goose, proves thee far and wide a broad goose.

instruction: Do it, knight. I'll write a letter challenging him on your behalf. Or I'll tell him your insults myself.
response: Sweet Sir Toby, be patient for tonight.

instruction: In the next half an hour hell be asleep. Will you kill him then?
response: Ay, on mine honor.

instruction: [Coming up with an idea] But what if...
response: My lord,

instruction: If you are Prospero, tell us the details of how you survived, and how you met us here when just three hours ago we were shipwrecked and I lost my dear son Ferdinand. How sharp the pain of this memory is!
response: I am woe for t, sir.

instruction: Lead me on.
response: Methinks his words do from such passion fly, That he believes himself.

instruction: A curse, a curse on all tired, worthless horses, on all crazy masters, and on all bad roads! Was ever a man beaten so much as me? Was ever a man so weary? I've been sent ahead to make a fire, and they're coming afterward to warm themselves up. It's a good thing I can keep myself hot with my quick temper, or else my lips might freeze to my teeth, my tongue to the roof of my mouth, and my heart to my belly before I could find a fire to thaw myself out. But I'll keep stoking my anger to stay warm. In weather like this, a better man than I am would catch cold.Hey, hello! Curtis!
response: Who is that calls so coldly?

instruction: How cruel! He would have died in battle if he did not have certain good qualities. And even though his sword-arm has bought him a longer life, in which he owes nothing to anyone, take this as encouragement to change your ruling. Think of what's mine as his, and because I know you all love money, I'll give to you all that I have won at war in return for his safety. If he owes his life for this crime, let it at least be had at war with the army. War can punish the way the law does.
response: We are for law: he dies; urge it no more,On height of our displeasure: friend or brother,He forfeits his own blood that spills another.

instruction: This is the time that Madam Silvia told me to come and talk to her. There's something she wants me to do. [To SILVIA] Madam, madam!
response: Who calls?

instruction: So he rode on Barbary? Tell me, kind friend, how did the horse take to him?
response: So proudly as if he disdain'd the ground.

instruction: These banished men that I have lived with have some valuable qualities. Forgive them for what they have done here, and let them return home from their exile. They are reformed, civil, full of goodness, and ready to do you great service, noble Lord.
response: Thou hast prevail'd; I pardon them and thee: Dispose of them as thou know'st their deserts.

instruction: What are you studying, teacher? First answer me that.
response: [as CAMBIO] I read that I profess, The Art to Love.

instruction: No, you were provoked by your own bloody mind, which never thinks about anything but butchery. Did you kill this king?
response: I grant you.

instruction: Yes, sir, and I'm afraid we've arrived at a bad time. The skies look dark, which means it's about to storm. In my opinion, the gods are angry at us and are punishing us.
response: Their sacred wills be done!

instruction: [As LUCENTIO] And I am a man that loves Bianca more than words can express, or your thoughts can guess.
response: Youngling, thou canst not love so dear as I.

instruction: So does everyone here. How much money did he ask you for?
response: A thousand pieces.

instruction: Yes, she did.
response: Why, go to then.

instruction: I'll sell all my land.
response: Thus do I ever make my fool my purse.

instruction: I would build a little cabin outside your gates, and from there I'd call out to you, my soul, in your house. I would write loyal songs about unrequited love and sing them loudly even in the dead of night. I would shout your name to the hills and make their echoes cry out "Olivia!" Oh, you wouldn't be able to go anywhere under the sun without pitying me.
response: You might do much.What is your parentage?

A thousand flatters sit within your crown, which is no larger than your head: and yet despite its small size, there is a sickness there that might encompass the whole country. response: A lunatic lean-witted fool, Presuming on an ague's privilege, Darest with thy frozen admonition Make pale our cheek, chasing the royal blood With fury from his native residence.

This food for thought is equal to the food you offer, no doubt. Men who attend feasts are too proud to give thanks to the gods.[APERMANTUS gives his own toast] Immortal gods, I do not want money; I pray for no one other than myself. Please grant that I never become so dumb as to trust a man on his oath or promise; or a whore, when she weeps; or a dog, that seems to sleep; or a jailer with my freedom; or my friends if I ever need them. Amen. So let's get to eating: rich men will sin while I eat my root.

Rise, beautiful sun, and kill the jealous moon, which is already sick and pale with grief because Juliet, her maid, is more beautiful than she is. Dont be her maid, since shes jealous. The moons virginity makes her look sick and green, and only fools hold on to their virginity. Throw it off. It is my lady. Oh, it is my love. Oh, I wish she knew I loved her. Shes talking, but isnt saying anything. Why is that? Her eyes are speaking. Ill respondno, I am too bold. Its not to me she speaks. Two of the most beautiful stars in the sky had to go off on some business, and begged her eyes to twinkle in their place until they return. If her eyes were in the sky and the stars were in her head the brightness of her cheeks would overwhelm the stars, just as daylight outshines a lamp. And her eyes in the night sky would shine so brightly that birds would start singing, thinking it was day. Look how she leans her cheek against her hand. I wish I were a glove on that hand, so I could touch her cheek.

That is my command, and if you respect me, youll stop with all these frowns, which is no way to behave at a party.

You're advising the king to go against the gods' will.[To LEONTES] Don't worry about having children; you'll find someone to inherit the throne. Alexander the Great didn't have children, so he left his to whoever was most worthy. That worked out fine for him.

Can't a plain man live, wishing no harm on anyone, without his words being twisted like this by slick, sly, slithering lowlifes?

instruction: Ah, yes. Where is my conscience? If a conscience were a blister on my heel, I'd put my slippers on. But I don't feel this "conscience" in my chest. Here lies your sleeping brother, who'd be of no more value than the ground he's lying on if he were in fact what he now looks likedead, that is. And I, with just three inches of this sword, could put him to rest forever; while you, doing the same, could give ancient Gonzalo a permanent sleep to ensure that he wouldn't stand against us. response: Gramercy, lovely Lucius: what's the news?

instruction: [As VINCENTIO] Quiet, son.Sir, if I mayhaving come to Padua to collect some debts, my son Lucentio made me aware of the deep love between your daughter and himself. Because of the good reports I've heard about you, and for the sake of the love between your daughter and my son, I won't delayI am glad to have him matched. And if you also approve of the marriage, then you'll find me ready and willing to consent to your daughter's betrothal. I won't be fussy about details with you, Sir Baptista, for I respect you.
response: Sir, pardon me in what I have to say.

instruction: She doesn't like it when you talk about violence.
response: But well, when I discourse of love and peace?

instruction: I hope that all men live in hope.
response: Vouchsafe to wear this ring.

instruction: Mamillius, go play. That's a good boy. [MAMILLIUS leaves]Camillo, this all-important man has decided to stay longer.
response: You had much ado to make his anchor hold:When you cast out, it still came home.

instruction: The king has ordered that the queen appear at court in person. Silence!
response: Read the indictment.

instruction: Who was it that you were chasing after with your sword? What did he do to you?
response: I know not.

instruction: Why are you looking at me like that? I'm sorry this happened, but I'm not afraid. This delays me, but doesn't change me. I am who I was before. This setback makes me want to marry Perdita even more.
response: Gracious my lord, You know your father's temper: at this time He will allow no speech, which I do guess You do not purpose to him; and as hardly Will he endure your sight as yet, I fear: Then, till the fury of his highness settle, Come not

instruction: Well, some do, some don't. But, mistress, since it's me that bought her
response: Thou mayst cut a morsel off the spit.

instruction: Monster, losing those bottles of wine was a loss much worse than disgrace or dishonor.
response: Thats more to me than my wetting.

instruction: How but well, sir? How but well? It would be impossible to go any other way.
response: Why, how now, daughter Katherine?

instruction: Oh, my!
response: [Aside] She speaks.

instruction: If I were king? I would rather be a peddler. Far be it for me to ever think of being king.
response: As little joy, my lord, as you suppose You should enjoy were you this countrys king, As little joy may you suppose in me That I enjoy, being the queen thereof.

instruction: The king tried to make peace among all of us, and I hope he succeeded. For me, at least, those vows of friendship were firm and true.
response: And so in me, and so, I think, in all.

instruction: Come, come! I know it's best for you. Walk half an hour, Leonine, at least. Remember what I said.
response: I warrant you, madam.

instruction: The house will be a calmer place for it.
response: Come, well have him in a dark room and bound.

instruction: It's news that grieves me to report, my lord.
response: How doth the prince?

instruction: Alas, what is the matter? What is the matter, husband?
response: Cassio hath here been set on in the dark By Roderigo and fellows that are scaped.

instruction: Since she's not actually part of your family, your family hasn't offended the king, and your family can't be punished by him. Show him the things you found with herall the things that you kept secret all these years (except for whatever she took with her). Then, the law can have nothing to do with us, I promise you.
response: I will tell the king all, every word, yea, and his son's pranks too; who, I may say, is no honest man, neither to his father nor to me, to go about to make me the king's brother-in-law.

instruction: Fool, I say!
response: (sings) She loves anotherWho calls, ha?

instruction: My mother was the daughter of a king, and she died as soon as I was born. My nurse, Lychorida, told me the story many times, crying.
response: O, stop there a little!

instruction: Come, Kate, come. Don't look so sour.
response: It is my fashion, when I see a crab.

instruction: Now go. Good night. And remember that everything depends on you being out of Verona before the night watch takes its position, or that you disguise yourself and leave after daybreak. Stay a while in Mantua. Ill find your servant, and every once in a while Ill send you news through him about every good thing that occurs for you here. Give me your hand. Its late. Farewell. Good night.
response: But that a joy past joy calls out on me, It were a grief so brief to part with thee.

instruction: May God keep you safe here! I'm afraid of the consequences; you've been sheltered enough to not know what fear is. I'm terrified of what would happen if your dad showed up here by chance the way that you did. Oh, just imagine! What would he think of his royal son being engaged to someone like me? What would he say? And how would I, in this ridiculous outfit, respond to his anger?
response: Apprehend Nothing but jollity.

instruction: It is true, and because you do not have a dog which I could imitate so as to flatter you, I hope you catch a disease!
response: This is in thee a nature but infected; A poor unmanly melancholy sprung From change of fortune.

instruction: Good uncle, take this barbaric Moor as your prisonerhe's a hungry tiger, a cursed devil. Dont feed him, but keep him in chains until hes brought before the empress, to prove what shes done. And make sure our army is close by; Im afraid the emperor plans to betray us.
response: Some devil whisper curses in mine ear,And prompt me, that my tongue may utter forthThe venomous malice of my swelling heart!

instruction: Is it possible?
response: If this were played upon a stage now, I could condemn it as an improbable fiction.

instruction: Tell me, are these wind instruments?
response: Ay, marry, are they, sir.

instruction: [Singing]Your father lies thirty feet below the sea,His bones are made of coral now.His eyes have turned to pearls.Every part of him that is impermanent,Has changed completely in the seaTo become something rich and strange.Sea nymphs ring his death bell hourly.
response: [within] Ding-dong.

instruction: Antonio, oh my dear Antonio! How time has tortured me ever since I lost you!
response: Sebastian are you?

instruction: Oh, he has a son. He'll be skinned alive, drizzled in honey, thrown into a wasp's nest, and forced to stay there until he's nearly dead. Then they'll wake him up with a shot of whisky and stand him, raw flesh and all, on top of a brick wall to be baked in the sun and eaten by flies. But why are we talking about these backstabbing traitors? We should be thankful they're going to be put to death for their crimes! Since you seem to be humble peasants, tell me what you're bringing to the king. If it's worth his attention, I'll bring you aboard his ship and introduce you to him with a kind recommendation. If there's anyone besides the king who can help you, it's me.
response: He seems to be of great authority: close with him, give him gold; and though authority be a stubborn bear, yet he is oft led by the nose with gold: show the inside of your purse to the outside of his hand, and no more ado.

instruction: Here comes my noble fool-catcher.
response: Wilt thou set thy foot o' my neck?

instruction: Who is it who calls so coldly?
response: A piece of ice.

instruction: [As LUCENTIO] Maybe I mean the father and the daughter, sir. What is it to you?
response: Not her that chides, sir, at any hand, I pray.

instruction: Toad!
response: Rogue, rogue, rogue!

instruction: And meet me at the Elephant.
response: I do remember.

instruction: Weren't you banished on pain of death?
response: I was, but I do find more pain in banishment Than death can yield me here by my abode.

instruction: Well, sir, since you know I've served your father well, it follows that I would serve just as well the person he loves the most (that is, you). Hear me out: if you encounter any difficulties on your journey, I can tell you where to go, where to take Perdita (since it's clear you don't want to be separated from her, unless some sort of catastrophe got in your way), and where to marry her. And, while you're gone, I can try to win your father over for you.
response: How, Camillo,May this, almost a miracle, be done?That I may call thee something more than manAnd after that trust to thee.

instruction: Are you okay, Malvolio?
response: At your request!

instruction: It's so strange how all of them suddenly got so tired!
response: It is the quality o' th' climate.

instruction: "And some have greatness thrust upon them."
response: Heaven restore thee!

instruction: Amen.
response: Tomorrow will it please you to be crowned?

instruction: To be honest, they deserve to keep their heads more than the people who've accused them deserve to keep their duke's caps. But come, my lord, let's go.
response: Go on before.

instruction: You've said enough.[To DUKE OF AUMERLE] I hate you, cousin, for leading me out of that sweet way to despair! What do you have to say now? What comfort do we have now? By heaven, I'll hate him forever that tells me to "be of comfort" anymore. I'll go to Flint castle: there I'll waste away; a king, sorrow's slave, shall obey his sorrow. The men that I have, let them go, to plow the earth that still has some hope to give, for I have none. Let no men try to argue with me, for advice is no use.
response: My liege, one word.

instruction: And I was on my way to yours, Cassio. Why have you been away for a week? Seven days and nights? One hundred and sixty-eight hours? And hours that lovers spend apart pass eight times more slowly than normal. How tiresome to count the hours going by!
response: Pardon me, Bianca, I have this while with leaden thoughts been pressed, But I shall, in a more continuate time, Strike off this score of absence.

instruction: Then say that you'll accept me.
response: That shall you know hereafter.

instruction: No, we'll talk to him first.
response: Where art thou, keeper?

instruction: I know both of them. The other one is a jeweler.
response: O, 'tis a worthy lord.

instruction: I don't know her, but I know her father, and he knew my father well when he was alive. I won't sleep until I see her, Hortensio, so I hope you'll pardon me for cutting off this first meeting of oursunless you want to come with me.
response: [To HORTENSIO] I pray you, sir, let him go while the humor lasts.

instruction: Take him away! Who has caused all this trouble?
response: Ill help you, Sir Toby, because well be dressed together.

instruction: Paulina, you keep Hermione's memory alive. I wish I would have listened to you before! If I had, I might be looking into my queen's eyes at this very moment. I might be kissing her precious lips
response: And left themMore rich for what they yielded.

instruction: Do you think he really means it? Look at his face; he's not crying, his prayers are false; his words come from his mouth, but ours from our hearts. He begs weakly and would rather that you not grant his request; we pray with heart and soul and everything else. His tired joints would rather rise, I know; our knees will kneel to the ground until they take root there. His prayers are full of false hypocrisy; ours are full of true emotion and deep honesty. Our prayers out-pray hisso let us have the mercy which true prayer should receive.
response: Good aunt, stand up.

instruction: And you as well.
response: Lucius!What, do we meet together?

instruction: It's an honor that I dont think about at all.
response: An honor!

instruction: Sir, I swear that I did hear a strange humming sound, which woke me up. I shook you, sir, and cried out. When I opened my eyes, I saw their raised swords. There was a noise, thats true. It would be best if we either set a constant guard here, or left this place entirely. Lets take out our own swords too.
response: Lead off this ground, and lets make further searchFor my poor son.

instruction: I guarantee you that my man is as trustworthy as steel.
response: Well, sir, my mistress is the sweetest lady.Lord, Lord!

instruction: Please, Camillo, don't pester me. Though it's hard to deny you anything, it would be the death of you if I said "yes."
response: It is fifteen years since I saw my country: though I have for the most part been aired abroad, I desire to lay my bones there.

instruction: Not money, I swear. But Ill insult you, and call you rogues.
response: Then I will give you the serving creature.

instruction: Most excellent accomplished lady, may the heavens rain odors upon you!
response: ( aside ) That youths a rare courtier.

instruction: No, definitely tonight, look how fresh she looks! They shouldn't have thrown her in the sea. Build a fire inside, and bring all the boxes from my closet.
response: Death may usurp on nature many hours, And yet the fire of life kindle again The o'erpress'd spirits.

instruction: I have no choice in the matter. Farewell.
response: Go tread the path that thou shalt ne'er return.

instruction: I will tell her, sir, that you protest to her, which I think is a gentlemanly offer.
response: Bid her devise Some means to come to shrift this afternoon.

instruction: How dare plants grow up toward the sky, from which they receive rain and sun?
response: Thou know'st I have powerTo take thy life from thee.

instruction: Hit him on the head with the hilt of your sword, and then throw him in the wine barrel in the next room.
response: O excellent device and make a sop of him.

instruction: Honestly, honestly, that saying certainly didn't hold true for Richard! He was a terrible child, and took such a long time to grow up that if that rule were true, he should be a very gracious adult.
response: And so no doubt he is, my gracious madam.

instruction: Do you want me to come with you?
response: No, good-faced sir; no, sweet sir.

instruction: A widow never suffered so great a loss.
response: Were never orphans had so dear a loss.

instruction: Farewell then. Remain in the darkness. I won't declare you sane until you agree with Pythagoras, and fear to kill a pigeon because it might have the soul of your grandmother. Farewell.
response: Sir Topas, Sir Topas!

instruction: I wish poison would go wherever my mind sent it!
response: Where wouldst thou send it?

instruction: I have been to a place where I learned to repent for the sin of being disobedient to my father and his commands. I am instructed by holy Friar Lawrence to kneel down and beg your forgiveness. [She kneels] Forgive me, I beg you. From now on Ill do what you tell me to.
response: Send for the county.

instruction: Ladies, there is a small banquet here for you. Please enjoy yourselves.
response: Most thankfully, my lord.
