instruction: See where his Grace is standingbetween two clergymen.
response: Two props of virtue for a Christian prince, To stay him from the fall of vanity; And, see, a book of prayer in his hand, True ornaments to know a holy man.

instruction: [To himself] Come on, wit, give me something good to say now! Those people who think they're witty often prove to be fools. And I'm sure that I'm not witty, so I might pass for a wise man. For what did the philosopher Quinapalus say? "Better a witty fool, than a foolish wit."
response: God bless thee, lady!

instruction: Are you Sebastian, then?
response: Fearst thou that, Antonio?

instruction: Sir, I'll use all the skills I have to help him, as long as no one but me and my maid are allowed to come near him.
response: Come, let us leave her;And the gods make her prosperous!

instruction: Please tell me, clever York, who told you this about him?
response: Grandam, his nurse.

instruction: The best part was the blast of the oracle's ear-defeaning voice; it was like thunder! I was scared senseless. I felt tiny and insignificant.
response: If the event o' the journeyProve as successful to the queen,O be't so!As it hath been to us rare, pleasant, speedy,The time is worth the use on't.

instruction: Ha ha ha! He thinks so? He's a very nice guy, but he has spent too much money. I came over several times for dinner and told him to be more thrifty, but he would never listen or heed my warnings. No one is perfect, and his vice is generosity. I told him so, but never could change his ways.
response: Please your lordship, here is the wine.

instruction: I'll swear to that.
response: This is the prettiest low-born lass that everRan on the green-sward: nothing she does or seemsBut smacks of something greater than herself,Too noble for this place.

instruction: I wish my spit were deadly poison.
response: Never came poison from so sweet a place.

instruction: The curse my noble father laid on you when you set a paper crown on his head, and drew rivers of tears from his eyes with your scorn, and then, to dry them, you gave him a handkerchief soaked in innocent Rutland's bloodthe curses he laid on you then, when his bitter soul condemned you, have now come to pass. God, not us, is punishing you for your bloody deeds.
response: So just is God to right the innocent.

instruction: My lord, if you'll take into consideration what you've just seen and heard, I hope that you'll accept me as a sister-in-law instead of a wife. We can have the two weddings on the same day, if you want, here at my house, and I'll pay for everything.
response: Madam, I am most apt to embrace your offer.

instruction: I am already hunting a hart, but it's also my heart being hunted. Oh, when I first saw Olivia, it seemed to me that she purified the air with her very presence. In that instant I was transformed into a hart, and ever since then my desire for her has pursued me like a pack of cruel hunting hounds.
response: How now!

instruction: Tear me apart and take me away, and may the gods take their revenge upon you!
response: 'Faith, I perceive our masters may throw their capsat their money: these debts may well be calleddesperate ones, for a madman owes 'em.

instruction: She was here just now. She follows me everywhere. The other day I was talking along the shore with some Venetians, and the silly girl came to me andI swearshe hangs around my neck like this
response: Crying O dear Cassio!

instruction: The mayor is on his way and nearly here. Pretend to be afraid, and don't let yourself be spoken to until we plead with you. And get a prayer book in your hand and stand between two priests, my good lord. I'll use that to improvise an argument for your holiness. But don't be easily won over by our requests to be king. Be like a coy virgin: refuse for a long time, and then finally accept.
response: I go.

instruction: Dear boy, believe me. Anyone who says that you're a man is denying you the happy years of your youth. Your lips are as smooth and ruby-red as the goddess Diana's. Your small voice is like a girl's, high and clear, and the rest of you is feminine as well. I know you have been predestined to do this job. [To CURIO and attendants] Four or five of you go with him. All of you can go if you want to, for I feel my best when I'm away from people. [To VIOLA] If you succeed in this you will live as well as I do, and share in all my fortune.
response: Ill do my best To woo your lady [aside] Yet, a barful strife Whoe'er I woo, myself would be his wife.

instruction: May God end this foolish fantasy in your Honor's mind! Alas, that a mighty man of such noble birth, with so much wealth and such a good reputation, should be infected with such a terrible illness!
response: What, would you make me mad?

instruction: If we find you in Athens two days from now, you will face the most severe punishment. And even though it displeases us, your friend will be executed now.
response: Now the gods keep you old enough; that you may live Only in bone, that none may look on you!

instruction: Oh, the widow Dido? Of course, the widow Dido.
response: Is not, sir, my doublet as fresh as the first day I wore it?

instruction: Hold on, everyoneboth those supporting me, and the rest of you. If this were the time to fight, I'd know it without anyone telling me. So where do you want me to go to answer this accusation of yours?
response: To prison, till fit timeOf law and course of direct sessionCall thee to answer.

instruction: Oh, forgive me sir. I have made a mistake. This is the ring you sent to Silvia.
response: But how camest thou by this ring?

instruction: [As LUCENTIO] And if I am, sir, is it a problem?
response: No, if without more words you will get you hence.

instruction: [To ARIEL so that only he can hear] Magnificently done, my hard-working spirit. Youll get your freedom.
response: This is as strange a maze as e'er men trod, And there is in this business more than nature Was ever conduct of.

instruction: [To himself] As much as an apple looks like an oyster, but that's no matter.
response: [as LUCENTIO] To save your life in this extremity, This favor will I do you for his sake And think it not the worst of all your fortunes That you are like to Sir Vincentio His name and credit shall you undertake, And in my house you shall b

instruction: That may be true, since my face is not my own.
response: My leisure serves me, pensive daughter, now.My lord, we must entreat the time alone.

instruction: Agreed.
response: A match!

instruction: Oh, you malicious wretch! Cassio, how did you come across my wife's handkerchief?
response: I found it in my chamber, And he himself confessed but even now That there he dropped it for a special purpose Which wrought to his desire.

instruction: My hair stands on end when I hear her curses.
response: And so doth mine.

instruction: What is the matter?
response: (to IAGO) Disprove this villain, if thou best a man.

instruction: I do trust you, but what if Antiochus attacks while I'm gone?
response: We'll mingle our bloods together in the earth,From whence we had our being and our birth.

instruction: You poor thing! In that case, you need clothes to be buried in, not for what's left of your clothes to be taken away.
response: O sir, the loathsomeness of them offends me morethan the stripes I have received, which are mightyones and millions.

instruction: Oh come on. You decided she was beautiful when no one else was around and there was no one to compare her to except herself. But if instead you compare her to some other beautiful woman who Ill point out to you at this feast, youll see that shes far from the best.
response: I'll go along, no such sight to be shown, But to rejoice in splendor of mine own.

instruction: [To TITUS] Why, sir, this is the perfect messenger for your speech. Let him take the pigeons to the emperor from you.
response: Tell me, can you deliver an oration to the emperorwith a grace?

instruction: Yes, leave, and take these notes of the debt with you, and make sure to show him that the time has already passed to pay me back.
response: I will, sir.

instruction: I don't know, mighty king. I can only guess.
response: Well, as you guess?

instruction: He has wounded me a little, I confess. But since the taunt grazed me and kept flying, it's ten to one that it hit you two straight on.
response: Now, in good sadness, son Petruchio, I think thou hast the veriest shrew of all.

instruction: Its torture, not mercy. Heaven is in Verona because this is where Juliet lives. Every cat and dog and little mouse, every unworthy creature, that lives in Verona lives in heaven because it can see her. But I wont be able to. Carrion-eating flies will have more vitality, a more blessed existence, and more romance than I will. They can touch Juliets white hand and can steal kisses from her sweet lips, whichthough she is a pure virginblush when they touch each other because they think its a sin. But Romeo cant touch her hand or kiss her. Flies can kiss her, but I must fly from the city. Flies are free, but Ive been banished. Do you still argue that exile isnt death? You didnt have some poison, a sharpened knife, or some other weapon that you could have used to kill me quickly, nothing so disgraceful, other than banishment? Oh Friar, damned souls use the word banishment to describe hell. They howl the word. How, as a priest, confessor, and my friend, can you have the heart to say to me the word banished?
response: Thou fond mad man, hear me a little speak.

instruction: Which makes it even worse that I escaped Leonine's hands, where I might have died.
response: Ay, and you shall live in pleasure.

instruction: I do.
response: Then hie you hence to Friar Lawrences cell.

instruction: Only your name is my enemy. Youd be yourself even if you ceased to be a Montague. Whats a Montague, after all? Its not a hand, foot, arm, face, or any other body part. Oh, change your name! Whats the significance of a name? The thing we call a rose would smell as sweet even if we called it by some other name. So even if Romeo had some other name, he would still be perfect. Romeo, take off your namewhich really has no connection to who you areand take all of me instead.
response: I take thee at thy word.

instruction: [To himself] Well, then, it's time to wake him up from his trance.
response: Ah, Tranio, what a cruel fathers he!

instruction: What do you want with her? Pretend that I'm her.
response: If you be she, I do entreat your patienceTo hear me speak the message I am sent on.

instruction: The fifth knight's shield shows a hand emerging from clouds, holding pure gold. His motto is, "Faith should be valued this way."
response: And what'sThe sixth and last, the which the knight himselfWith such a graceful courtesy deliver'd?

instruction: Yes, my lord, that's him. How are you, Malvolio?
response: Madam, you have done me wrong,Notorious wrong.

instruction: And then to have an expression of great authority, and to gravely survey the room and then tell them that I know my place, and I'd like them to know theirs. I'd ask for my cousin Toby
response: ( aside ) Bolts and shackles!

instruction: "Think, my lord?" Come on, you're repeating everything I say like a strange monster in your mind that you're afraid is to hideous to show. You're hinting at something. You just said earlier that you didn't like how Cassio left my wife's side. What about it didn't you like? And when I told you that Cassio advised me the whole time I was courting Desdemona, you said, "Oh really?" And you raised your eyebrows like you had some secret thought about it. If you care about me at all, tell me what you're thinking.
response: My lord, you know I love you.

instruction: She said so. I must tell the truth.
response: Shes like a liar gone to burning hell.'Twas I that killed her.

instruction: No. When he wakes up he'll say that we killed him like cowards.
response: Why, he shall never wake until the great Judgment Day.

instruction: That's a lie! You're rough and hairy. Don't lie to me. Only business people lie. But, since we soldiers pay them with money instead of pulling out our swords, they don't expose us for lying.
response: Your worship had like to have given us one, if youhad not taken yourself with the manner.

instruction: Iago, naked in bed and not meaning any harm? That would be like tricking the devil. If they were acting this way but had virtuous intentions, they were tempted by the devil and they were tempting God to damn them.
response: So they do nothing, tis a venial slip.

instruction: Boult!
response: Sir?

instruction: That can't be true!
response: They answer, in a joint and corporate voice, That now they are at fall, want treasure, cannot Do what they would; are sorryyou are honourable, But yet they could have wish'dthey know not Something hath been amiss a noble nature May catch a

instruction: Come closer to me Flaminius. Your lord is a generous man, but you are smart and know as well as anybody, even though you've come to me, that now is not the time to lend money, especially to friends, without some kind of insurance. Here are three coins. This way you can say that you never visited me and I did not reject your request for a loan. Goodbye.
response: Is't possible the world should so much differ,And we alive that lived?

instruction: I thank you, my good lord, and thank you all. But I thought my mother and my brother York would have met us on our way long before now. And it's shameful what a slug Hastings is, that he hasn't even come to tell us whether or not they're coming!
response: And in good time here comes the sweating lord.

instruction: Lets make sure the law is on our side by getting them to start the fight.
response: I will frown as I pass by, and let them take it as they list.

instruction: [To LEONTES] Sir, you had a lot to grieve for, but sixteen years should have helped ease that pain. Few joys last that long, and any other sorrow would have fizzled out long before now.
response: Dear my brother,Let him that was the cause of this have powerTo take off so much grief from you as heWill piece up in himself.

instruction: Hello, my friend Cassio!
response: What make you from home?

instruction: Welcome to you!How's it going to you?Hey to you!My friend to you!And that's enough greetings. Now, my dapper companions, is everything neat and ready?
response: All things is ready.

instruction: [To himself] Well, I guess I won't be hanged now (though I almost was). He's gone, but the king should be happy anyway, since Pericles will probably die at sea. I'll come out of hiding.[To HELICANUS and the LORDS] Greetings, lords of Tyre!
response: Lord Thaliard from Antiochus is welcome.

instruction: What report would you like me to bring Athens for you?
response: Thee thither in a whirlwind.

instruction: This man is very honest and knows human interactions very well. If I find proof that Desdemona is unfaithful, I'll let her go like I'm getting rid of a pet, even if the leash is my own heartstrings. Maybe since I am black and don't have the smooth conversational skills of gallant men, or maybe since I'm getting oldbut no, none of that's important. She's gone, I am betrayed, and my only recourse must be to hate her. Oh, this is the curse of marriage, that we can have control over our delicate wives, but not their desires. I'd rather be a toad who survives off the mold in a dungeon than to share the thing I love with others. But that's what you get for being a powerful man, as this happens more often to noblemen than to commoners. It's an inescapable part of fate, like death. From the moment we're born we are fated to wear the horns. Look, here she comes.
response: If she be false, heaven mocked itself.Ill not believe t.

instruction: Shut your mouth, girl. I think I'll have to do something about you. You're young and naive and you'll have to be broken as I would have you.
response: The gods defend me!

instruction: Don't go see your bride in these disrespectful clothes. Go to my room and put on some of my clothes.
response: Not I, believe me.

instruction: We're near Tarsus.
response: Thither, gentle mariner.Alter thy course for Tyre.

instruction: I swear by the holy mother of our Lordthe citizens didn't say a word.
response: Touched you the bastardy of Edwards children?

instruction: Who am I, sir! No, who are you, sir? By the immortal gods! Oh, you complete villain! A silken jacket, velvet hose, a scarlet cloak, and a tall hat! Oh, I'm ruined, I'm ruined! While I played the thrifty father at home, my son and my servant have spent all my money at university.
response: [as LUCENTIO] How now, whats the matter?

instruction: May God, in his next shipment of hair, send you a beard!
response: By my troth, Ill tell thee, I am almost sick for one, (aside] though I would not have it grow on my chin.

instruction: How would you go about wooing her?
response: That would I learn of you,As one being best acquainted with her humor.

instruction: Come on, come on. Youre an impertinent boy. Is that really how you think it is? This silliness is likely to come back to harm you. I know what Im doing, but you feel the need to contradict me. Well, Ill show you a thing or two.
response: Patience perforce with willful choler meeting Makes my flesh tremble in their different greeting.

instruction: How does that work?
response: Marry, sir, tis an ill cook that cannot lick his own fingers.

instruction: [To VIOLA] I must ask you for some of that money.
response: What money, sir?

instruction: We're simple people, sir.
response: A lie; you are rough and hairy.

instruction: Come on, in God's name, let's continue on to your father's house. Good Lord, the moon is so bright and beautiful tonight!
response: The moon?

instruction: Yes, and for that I thank God, my father, and yourself.
response: Then patiently hear my impatience.

instruction: [Offstage] My lord, my lord! What is going on? My lord, my lord!
response: What noise is this?Not dead?

instruction: Yes, and he'll tame her.
response: He says so, Tranio?

instruction: This is my niece's chambermaid.
response: Good Mistress Accost, I desire better acquaintance.

instruction: I want to speak with Clarence, and I came here on my legs.
response: What, so brief?

instruction: I can't say the name, or I'll offend you.
response: I cannot be offended with my trade.

instruction: May honor, riches, marriage, blessings, Long life, and ever increasing, Constant joy be always with you. Juno sings her blessings to you.
response: Earths increase, foison plenty, Barns and garners never empty, Vines and clustering bunches growing, Plants with goodly burden bowing Spring come to you at the farthest In the very end of harvest.

instruction: Lady, you don't know the rules of charity, which transforms evil into good, and curses into blessings.
response: Villain, thou knowst not law of God nor man.No beast so fierce but knows some touch of pity.

instruction: Spoken like a good worker! Here's to you, boy!
response: How likes Gremio these quick-witted folks?

instruction: Why are you saying this to me? I never hurt you. You drew your sword against me without a good reason, but I spoke politely to you and didn't hurt you.
response: If a bloody coxcomb be a hurt, you have hurt me.

instruction: [To LANCE] What's this? You bastard peasant! Where have you been these past two days?
response: Marry, sir, I carried Mistress Silvia the dog you bade me.

instruction: Hello?
response: I will dispatch you severally; you to Lord Lucius; to Lord Lucullus you: I hunted with his honour to-day: you, to Sempronius: commend me to their loves, and, I am proud, say, that my occasions have found time to use 'em toward a supply of m

instruction: I am their father's mother. I will see them.
response: Their aunt I am in law, in love their mother.Then bring me to their sights.

instruction: Not Romeo, Prince. He was Mercutios friend. His crime was justice, because it took the life of Tybalt.
response: And for that offense Immediately we do exile him hence.

instruction: So, this is Tyre, and this is the court. I'm supposed to kill King Pericles here and, if I don't do it, I'll be hanged back home. It's dangerous. Well, now I see that a man would be wise if, being told to ask for whatever he wanted from the king, said he didn't want to know any of the king's secrets. Now I see his reason for it: I mean, if a king tells you to be a villain, you're bound by your promise to him to be one. Quiet! Here come the lords of Tyre.
response: You shall not need, my fellow peers of Tyre, Further to question me of your king's departure: His seal'd commission, left in trust with me, Doth speak sufficiently he's gone to travel.

instruction: Did you say "die"? May the gods forbid! I have a coat here, come on, put it on, get warm. Now come with me, handsome man! You can come home with me. We'll have meat on holidays, fish on fasting days, and plenty of desserts and pancakes, and you're welcome to it all.
response: I thank you, sir.

instruction: I will, sir.
response: Mark and perform it, see'st thou!

instruction: I'm done. Yet, if you do intend to marry, sir, and won't be stopped, give me the right to choose your new queen. She won't be as young as your first one, but she'll be someone that Hermione's ghost would be happy to see you with.
response: My true Paulina,We shall not marry till thou bid'st us.

instruction: All of us kneeled down in front of you and begged you not to do this, and the beautiful girl herself was forced to choose whether to follow her own disgust at the marriage or her duty to obey you. Now weve lost your son forever too, I fear. This marriage and subsequent shipwreck has created more widows in Milan and Naples than we have survivors to bring home to comfort them. All of this is your fault.
response: So is the dearest o' th' loss.

instruction: And I'm proud of the fact that I was never a wasteful man like you.
response: I, that I am one now: Were all the wealth I have shut up in thee, I'ld give thee leave to hang it.

instruction: Though he'd be the king of this land with no kingship.
response: The latter end of his commonwealth forgets the beginning.

instruction: Listen to a little more, and Ill tell you everything up to our current situation, which is the entire reason why its necessary for me to tell you this story at all.
response: Wherefore did they notThat hour destroy us?

instruction: Can't we see her, sir?
response: 'Faith, by no means; she has so strictly tied Her to her chamber, that 'tis impossible.

instruction: To be a peacemaker is a fitting role for me, at my age: my son, throw down the Duke of Norfolk's gage.
response: And, Norfolk, throw down his.

instruction: I recognize that voice! You're, you'reoh, Pericles!
response: What means the nun?

instruction: Oh Romeo, Romeo, brave Mercutio is dead! His noble spirit has gone to heaven, but it was too early for him to leave this life.
response: This days black fate on more days doth depend.This but begins the woe others must end.

instruction: Fair enough.
response: But I much marvel that your lordship, having Rich tire about you, should at these early hours Shake off the golden slumber of repose.

instruction: Such a worthy man, this lord.
response: Nay, that's most fix'd.

instruction: Sir, I'll answer for anything I've done. But, I beg you. if you're okay with the fact that your fair daughter, at this late hour of the night, is handed over to the gross hands of a lustful Moor with no guard but a common servant for hire, a gondolier evenif you know all this, and you allow it (which I think is the case), well then I admit we have insolently done you wrong. But if you're not aware of all this, then my own good manners suggest that you're wrong to scold us. Don't think that I would just play around with such a serious matter, contrary to any good manners. I repeat: if you haven't given your daughter permission, then she has seriously rebelled against your authority. She's giving all her obedience, beauty, wit, and wealth to some extravagant, wandering foreigner, who seems to have roots just about everywhere. Go now and see for yourself. If she's in her room, or even in your house, sue me and let the government punish me for lying to you like this.
response: Strike on the tinder, ho!

instruction: I hope the gods give them what they deserve! But calm down, those old cronies have ingratitude in their DNA. Their blood is thick and runs slow and cold. They do not have the warmth to be kind. And they must act as their nature dictates, dull and heavy.
response: Go to Ventidius.

instruction: I think so too.
response: Men should be what they seem,Or those that be not, would they might seem none!

instruction: [To GROOM] If you love me, it's time for you to go.
response: What my tongue dares not, that my heart shall say.

instruction: Queen Mab? Whos she?
response: She is the fairies midwife, and she comes In shape no bigger than an agate stone On the forefinger of an alderman, Drawn with a team of little atomi Over mens noses as they lie asleep.

instruction: So you won't admit it?
response: More than mistress of Which comes to me in name of fault, I must not At all acknowledge.

instruction: What is it you want, Timon?
response: Promise me friendship, but perform none: if thou wilt not promise, the gods plague thee, for thou art a man!

instruction: And here he comes.
response: Kind Tyrrel, am I happy in thy news?

instruction: Why, man?
response: Because he should have swallowed me too: and when I had been in his belly, I would have kept such a jangling of the bells, that he should never have left, till he cast bells, steeple, church, and parish up again.

instruction: Let me stay at your own risk, Timon. I come only to observe and am giving you fair warning abo that.
response: I take no heed of thee; thou'rt an Athenian,therefore welcome: I myself would have no power;prithee, let my meat make thee silent.

instruction: [As LUCENTIO] I have no love for scolders, sir. Biondello, let's go.
response: [aside] Well begun, Tranio.

instruction: Did you see the gloomy Lord Northumberland?
response: Thomas the earl of Surrey and himself,Much about cockshut time, from troop to troopWent through the army cheering up the soldiers.

instruction: Oh, you deserve: they deserve who know the strongest and best way to get what they want. [To York] Uncle, give me your hands: no, dry your eyes; tears show their love, but won't fix anything. [To Bolingbroke] Cousin, I am too young to be your father, though you are old enough to be my heir. What you want, I'll give you willingly, for we must do what force compels us to do. We'll go to London, cousin, isn't that so?
response: Yea, my good lord.

instruction: Well, should I stab him as he sleeps?
response: No.

instruction: You cant talk about something you dont feel. If you were as young as I am, in love with Juliet, married to her for just an hour, and had murdered Tybalt...If you loved her as I do and were banished as I am, then you could talk about it. Though instead you might tear out your hair and fall to the ground the way I do right now [He falls on the ground] in order to measure out your grave.
response: Arise.

instruction: Quiet, you mumbling fool! Save your wisdom for your gossiping buddies. We dont need it here.
response: You are too hot.

instruction: I have to deflower you; otherwise you'll have to be killed. Come with me. We can't have any more gentleman driven away. Come with me, I said!
response: How now!

instruction: He called me Sebastian. I have seen my brother when I look in my mirror. My brother looked like me, and now I'm dressed as he used to dress, in the same fashion, colors, and with the same accessoriesbecause I imitated him in my disguise. Oh, if it's true, then storms are kind and the ocean is full of love!
response: A very dishonest paltry boy, and more a coward than a hare.

instruction: Sir, listen to some more of the poem. All of those men who were his equals, some of an even better rank, immediately follow him, so that his rooms are suddenly filled with attendants who shower his ears with whispers of their sacrificial devotion to him, and make sacred even his mounting of a horse, as if it were only because of him that they could breathe.
response: Ay, marry, what of these?

instruction: Spirit, we must prepare to deal with Caliban.
response: Ay, my commander.

instruction: Your mother was good and honest, and she said you were my daughter. And your father was Duke of Milan, and you were his heir, a princess of the same noble birth as her parents.
response: Oh, the heavens!

instruction: Come on, missy, come with me.
response: Whither wilt thou have me?

instruction: Yes, yes! Pains flare up and wither your tender joints! That there can be so much disdain amongst these villains, who act with such politeness! All this politeness! The human species has bred itself into baboons and monkeys.
response: Sir, you have saved my longing, and I feedMost hungerly on your sight.

instruction: When I say your name. I'll beat you up, if only touching you wouldn't infect my hands!
response: I would my tongue could rot them off!

instruction: Not me, believe me. Youve got on dancing shoes with nimble soles. But my soul is made of lead so heavy that it anchors me to the ground and I cant move.
response: You are a lover.

instruction: Do you hear, my honest friend?
response: No, I hear not your honest friend, I hear you.

instruction: Whos bothering me? Are you trying to make me open the door, so that Ill lose my resolve and all my work will come to nothing? Youre wrong if you think that will happenfor Ive written my plan on this paper in blood, and what is written will be done.
response: Titus, I am come to talk with thee.

instruction: Take care of that boy.
response: Why, boy!

instruction: I think our clothes are as fresh now as they were when we put them on in Africa to attend the marriage of the kings beautiful daughter Claribel to the King of Tunis.
response: 'Twas a sweet marriage, and we prosper well in our return.

instruction: Good day, gentlewoman! I beg you to take me where I can speak with Madam Silvia.
response: What would you with her, if that I be she?

instruction: Oh monstrous arrogance! You lie, you thread, you thimble, you puny measurement! You flea, you louse egg, you winter cricket! Defied in my own house by a spool of thread? Away with you, you rag, you fragment, you remnant, or I'll use your own yardstick against you until you think twice about talking again for the rest of your life! I tell you that you've ruined her gown.
response: Your Worship is deceived.

instruction: No, not a bit. I find you exceedingly gentle. I was told that you were rough, scornful, and sullen, but now I see that those rumors are lies. You are pleasant, amusing, polite, not sharp-tongued, and as sweet as springtime flowers. Even if you tried, you couldn't frown, glare scornfully, or bite your lip as angry women do, and you take no pleasure in arguments. Instead you entertain your suitors with mild and gentle conversation, and are quiet and friendly. So why does the world report that Kate limps along? What a slanderous world! Kate is like a hazel-twig, straight and slender, her hair is as brown as hazelnuts, and she herself is sweeter than the hazelnut kernels. Oh, let me see you walk, Kate! You don't limp at all!
response: Go, fool, and whom thou keepst command.

instruction: I would bet my life on her honesty! Honest Iago, I must leave Desdemona with you. Please, have your wife look after her, and bring them along after me when you get the chance. Come with me, Desdemona. I have only an hour to spend with you in love, and to teach you some worldly things. We can't be late.
response: Iago.

instruction: I gave him no order. I gave him the material.
response: But how did you desire it should be made?

instruction: [So only GRUMIO can hear] Quiet, boy.
response: [aside] Grumio, mum!

instruction: [To FABIAN and MARIA] Come on, come on! Quiet, quiet. We must be gentle with him. Let me deal with this. [To MALVOLIO] How are you, Malvolio? How are you feeling? Come on, man, renounce the devil! Remember, he's the enemy of mankind.
response: Do you know what you say?

instruction: What are you doing, Aaron? Why did you do this?
response: O Lord, sir, 'tis a deed of policy: Shall she live to betray this guilt of ours, A long-tongued babbling gossip?

instruction: Let the devil and his wife follow you around! Why did you give me that handkerchief just recently? I was an idiot to accept it. You want me to copy the embroidery? What a likely story, that you found it in your room and didn't know who left it there! This is a gift from some woman, and you want me to copy out the embroidery? There, give it back to your new mistress. Wherever you got it from, I'm not copying any of it.
response: How now, my sweet Bianca!

instruction: If you are her, then I ask you to patiently hear the message I am sent here to deliver.
response: From whom?

instruction: Curse those men shouting below decks! Theyre louder than the storm and distracting us from our duties.
response: Yet again?

instruction: I have Clarence's son locked up, and Clarence's daughter married off to a poor fellow. Edward's sons are sleeping in heaven, and my wife Anne has bid this world goodnight. But I know that Richmond aims to marry young Elizabethmy brother Edward's daughterand win the crown through that match. So now I go to her: a jolly, lively wooer.
response: My lord!

instruction: But did your sister die of her love, my boy?
response: I am all the daughters of my fathers house, And all the brothers tooand yet I know not.

instruction: As long as I'm alive.
response: Will he woo her?

instruction: Sir, don't worry. As you know, I have a lot of connections there. I can make sure you're provided for, as surely as if I were there myself. For example, sirif I can ease your mind, talk with me for a moment.
response: Ha, ha!

instruction: How are you, my husband? I have been talking here with a man who, sadly, you are displeased with.
response: Who is t you mean?

instruction: Most noble sir, do you recognize my voice?
response: Not I.

instruction: I am glad to see you.
response: How do you, Cassio?Oh, a chair, a chair!

instruction: They're busy inside. You'd better knock louder.
response: [as VINCENTIO] Whats he that knocks as he would beat down the gate?

instruction: He is.
response: Go you before, and I will follow you.

instruction: [To QUEEN ELIZABETH] What, are you threatening me that you'll tell the king? Go ahead and tell him, and don't spare any details. Look, I will repeat what I have said here in the presence of the king. I'll even risk being sent to the Tower for it. It seems that all my efforts on Edward's behalf have been forgotten.
response: [aside] Out, devil!

instruction: No, I'll have nothing from you. Besides, if I were bribed like all the others, there wouldn't be anyone left to criticize you, and then you would fall even faster than you do now. You give so much I worry that you will yourself away In IOUs shortly: why do you have these feasts, celebrations, and vanities?
response: Nay, an you begin to rail on society once, I amsworn not to give regard to you.

instruction: I beg your pardon, your Graces. His Majesty the king has strictly ordered that no one can speak privately with your brother Clarence, no matter their social rank.
response: Even so.

instruction: Our great master!
response: Have I once lived to see two honest men?

instruction: Call up my brotheroh, if only you had married her! [To members of the search party] Some of you go one way, some go another way. [To RODERIGO] Do you know where we might find her and the Moor?
response: I think I can discover him, if you please To get good guard and go along with me.

instruction: Here comes a messenger.
response: Such news, my lord, as grieves me to report.

instruction: [To PROSPERO so that only he can hear] Was the job well done?
response: [aside to ARIEL] Bravely, my diligence.

instruction: I beg your pardon. Here's some money to cure that blow I gave you. [He gives money] Has any quick-thinking friend of mine offered a reward to whoever brings that traitor in?
response: Such proclamation hath been made, my lord.

instruction: May God and our own innocence defend us!
response: Be patient.

instruction: Go then and get your men, but leave behind your son, George Stanley. Make sure your loyalty stays firm, or else he has a good chance of losing his head.
response: So deal with him as I prove true to you.

instruction: The wind that scatters young men throughout the world to seek their fortunes away from home, where there are few new experiences to be had. But to be brief, Sir Hortensio, this is how it stands: Antonio, my father, is dead, and I have now thrown myself into the wide world to try and marry and thrive as best I can. I have money in my purse and property at home, so I've set off to see the world.
response: Petruchio, shall I then come roundly to thee And wish thee to a shrewd, ill-favored wife?

instruction: The king and the prince are praying. Lets pray with them, since we share their situation.
response: Im out of patience.

instruction: Do it! Shout as loud and as seriously as when someone cries "Fire!" in a crowded city at night.
response: What, ho, Brabantio!

instruction: You did, it seems, since you told them to "countenance" her.
response: I call them forth to credit her.

instruction: Anything. Call me an honorable murderer, if you wish, since I didn't do anything out of hate but instead out of a sense of honor.
response: This wretch hath part confessed his villainy.Did you and he consent in Cassios death?

instruction: But you, who are dying, say that you flatter me.
response: O, no!

instruction: Please leave these burial ceremonies for me to finish, as I have more reason to mourn than you do. Go immediately to my estate at Crosby House. After I have solemnly buried this noble king at Chertsey Abbey, and wet his grave with my repentant tears, I will hurry to meet you there. Please do this for me, I beg you. My reasons must remain secret for now.
response: With all my heart, and much it joys me tooTo see you are become so penitent.Tressel and Berkeley, go along with me.

instruction: You're a smart man. Let us eat and drink then. Maria, I say! Bring us a big mug of wine!
response: Here comes the fool, i' faith.

instruction: Wherever seems best for your royal self. If I can advise you, though, you should stay a day or two in the Tower. After that you can stay wherever you like, and wherever seems best for your health and pleasure.
response: I do not like the Tower, of any place.Did Julius Caesar build that place, my lord?

instruction: You're waging war on Athens?
response: Ay, Timon, and have cause.

instruction: Farewell, old lady. Farewell, lady, lady, lady.
response: I pray you, sir, what saucy merchant was this that was so full of his ropery?

instruction: A boy?
response: A daughter, and a goodly babe,Lusty and like to live: the queen receivesMuch comfort in't; says 'My poor prisoner,I am innocent as you.'

instruction: Yes, my lord.
response: If you bethink yourself of any crimeUnreconciled as yet to heaven and grace, Solicit for it straight.

instruction: Good Peter, to hide her face, please give her the fan. Her fan is prettier than her face.
response: God ye good morrow, gentlemen.

instruction: We know each other's faces. But as for our hearts, he doesn't know mine any more than I know yours or his, or you know mine.
response: I thank his Grace.

instruction: Oh, that wretched villain!
response: Two or three groan.

instruction: Are you begging, Brother?
response: Of my kind uncle, that I know will give,And being but a toy, which is no grief to give.

instruction: He has. But see, here he comes with the mayor.
response: Lord Mayor

instruction: Ratcliffe, come here. Ride quickly to Salisbury. When you get there
response: First, mighty liege, tell me your Highness' pleasure,What from your Grace I shall deliver to him.

instruction: Yes, sir.
response: Go play, Mamillius; thou'rt an honest man.

instruction: Ma'am, he hasn't slept tonight, and he demanded that no one be allowed into his room.
response: Not so hot, good sir: I come to bring him sleep.

instruction: My lord, we have always said the same.
response: Ho, ho, confess'd it!

instruction: His name is Doricles. He says he owns a prosperous farm, and I believe it, considering how handsome and well-dressed he is. He says he's in love with my daughter, and I think it's true. To be blunt, the way he stares at her completely gives it away! You'd be hard pressed to say which one loves the other more.
response: She dances featly.

instruction: Sir, there are secrets in this bag and this box which are for the king alone. If I get the chance to speak to him, he'll know within the hour.
response: Age, thou hast lost thy labour.

instruction: Let her be hanged! I'm just calling her what she is now. Such a skilled sewer, such an admirable musician. Oh, she could sing so well she'd charm a savage bear to gentleness! She's so clever and intelligent!
response: Shes the worse for all this.

instruction: Petruchio, should I speak plainly then and offer you a shrewish, unpleasant wife? I don't think you'd thank me for my suggestion, but I promise you she's rich, yes, very rich. But you are my friend, so I won't wish her on you.
response: Signior Hortensio, twixt such friends as we Few words suffice.

instruction: Yes, if you approve.
response: It pleaseth me so well, that I will see you wed;And then with what haste you can get you to bed.

instruction: The man is going mad. Take him away. Come on, come on, sir.
response: Lead me on.

instruction: [To himself] Short summers often have an early spring, as they say. Those who die young are usually precocious.
response: Now in good time here comes the duke of York.

instruction: Oh Tybalt, Tybalt, the best friend I ever had! Oh, well-mannered, honorable Tybalt! If only I had not lived long enough to see him die.
response: What storm is this that blows so contrary?

instruction: I have made your bed with the sheets from your wedding night, as you asked.
response: Alls one.

instruction: I'll do it, and return soon.
response: Now will I hence about thy business,And take my ministers along with me.

instruction: What? Alcibiades is banished?
response: 'Tis so, be sure of it.

instruction: [To CAPULET] Shame on you! What, are you crazy?
response: Good Father, I beseech you on my knees,Hear me with patience but to speak a word.

instruction: He's coming, madam, but in a very strange manner. He seems crazy, madam.
response: Why, whats the matter?

instruction: At least let me know where you're headed to.
response: No, sooth, sir.

instruction: What support did we have besides Clarence? And he's dead.
response: What stays had I but they?

instruction: No. I'll never set foot in a place like this again, if she's not there.
response: But to have divinity preached there!

instruction: Here, improve your feast.
response: First mend my company, take away thyself.

instruction: Heaven knows the truth: that you are false as hell.
response: To whom, my lord?

instruction: How could we do anything else in your royal presence?
response: Here, with a cup that's stored unto the brim, As you do love, fill to your mistress' lips, We drink this health to you.

instruction: [To herself] The one man I love is the son of the one man I hate! I saw him before I knew who he was, and learned who he was too late! What a monster love is to make me love my worst enemy.
response: Whats this?

instruction: I'll follow this good priest, and go with you; and once I've sworn to be faithful, I'll be faithful forever.
response: Then lead the way, good father; and heavens so shine That they may fairly note this act of mine.

instruction: All right, break it up. Thanks, gentleman, and everyone. You all did well. [To PERICLES] But you were the best.[To ALL] Servants, bring lamps and take these knights to their rooms![To PERICLES] We've asked for you to have the best room, right next to mine.
response: I am at your grace's pleasure.

instruction: I can't tell. Those who teach young children do it in a gentle way with easy tasks. He should have scolded me in this kind of a gentle way, for I am truly like a child who has been scolded.
response: What is the matter, lady?

instruction: Roderigo from Venice?
response: Even he, sir.

instruction: Madam?
response: Gracious Olivia

instruction: [To himself] I wish I didnt know the reason why it should be slowed down.
response: Happily met, my lady and my wife.

instruction: We have one here, sir, if she would . . . but we've never had anyone like her in Mytilene.
response: If she'ld do the deed of darkness, thou wouldst say.

instruction: If you know this place is a brothel, why did you come in? I've heard that you're honorable, and that you're the governor of this place.
response: Why, hath your principal made known unto you who I am?

instruction: [As LUCENTIO] Yes, but your goods were just gathering dust and annoying you. Now they'll either bring you a profit or be lost at sea.
response: The gain I seek is quiet in the match.

instruction: Well, let it strike ten then.
response: Why let it strike?

instruction: Ventidius just held his father's funeral, who died and left him heir to an enormous fortune. When he was poor and had no one to turn to, I gave him five talents. Go to him for me and ask that his friend needs him right now, and hopes that he remembers those five talents.
response: That had, give't these fellowsTo whom 'tis instant due.

instruction: He'll have to do better than this to prove himself. His rusty armor looks less like a knight's and more like it came from a junk shop.
response: He well may be a stranger, for he comesTo an honour'd triumph strangely furnished.

instruction: You speak of the famous Alcibiades?
response: Will 't hold?

instruction: I will be mild and gentle in my words.
response: And brief, good mother, for I am in haste.

instruction: If they had actually gotten married and you were his brother-in-law by now, he'd hate you even more, and the price on your head would be even higher.
response: [Aside] Very wisely, puppies!

instruction: Unfortunately, yes.
response: Mark, how strange it shows, Timon in this should pay more than he owes: And e'en as if your lord should wear rich jewels, And send for money for 'em.

instruction: Calm down, please! It was an accident.
response: A whoreson, beetle-headed, flap-eared knave!

instruction: What is this supposed to mean?
response: I know not.

instruction: Are you so impatient? God knows I waited for you, in torment and in agony, when I was giving birth to you.
response: And came I not at last to comfort you?

instruction: [To SEBASTIAN so that only he can hear] Im very glad hes lost all hope. Dont give up on the plan we agreed to carry out just because we failed in our first attempt.
response: [aside to ANTONIO] The next advantageWill we take throughly.

instruction: Crossed laces?
response: Go to, thou art made, if thou desirest to be so

instruction: I swear it is, or else I'm a villain.
response: Have you scored me?

instruction: I go.
response: Son, Ill be your half Bianca comes.

instruction: You worthless, worthless man! I am sick of this lying world and will not love anything but the most basic necessities. So, Timon, prepare your own grave, lie down here where the light foam of the sea might lap against your grave stone every single day. Make your own epitaph, so my death will laugh at the lives of others.
response: O thou sweet king-killer, and dear divorce 'Twixt natural son and sire!

instruction: But how long will that "ever" last?
response: Sweetly in force unto her fair lifes end.

instruction: Oh, she teaches the torches to burn bright! She glows in the darkness like a jewel in the ear of an African. Her beauty is too good to be used and worn, too precious for this world. Like a white dove in a flock of crows, she surpasses all the other women. When this dance ends, Ill note where she stands, and then Ill touch her hand and thereby bless my ugly one. Did I ever love anyone before this moment? Renounce that love, my eyes! I never saw true beauty until this night.
response: This, by his voice, should be a Montague.

instruction: What's the news from outside the country?
response: No news so bad abroad as this at home:The king is sickly, weak and melancholy,And his physicians fear him mightily.

instruction: It's not a good idea for me, certainly. Wait, sir, here's my purse. [Giving SEBASTIAN some money] The best place to stay is an inn called the Elephant. It's in the suburbs to the south. I'll order our meals while you spend your time pleasantly and educate yourself by exploring the town. You can find me back at the Elephant.
response: Why I your purse?

instruction: Are the knights ready to begin the contest?
response: They are, my liege;And stay your coming to present themselves.

instruction: [To SIR TOBY BELCH] Oh my, the demon speaks so loudly from within him. Didn't I tell you? Sir Toby, my lady asks you to take care of him.
response: Aha!

instruction: He's a devil, a devil from the moment he was born. His nature can never be changed, no matter how much care he receives. All my work for himall done with sincere care for himhad no effect, absolutely no effect. As he grows older, his body grows uglier, and his mind becomes more evil. Ill put them all in agony until they roar in pain.
response: Come, hang them on this line.

instruction: Your forehead looks wrinkled with thought. Are you upset, my love?
response: No, in good earnest.

instruction: Please, be quiet.
response: [to ANTONIO] He receives comfort like cold porridge.

instruction: I'll stab the tadpole with the point of my blade; nurse, give it to me. My sword will soon get rid of it.
response: Sooner this sword shall plough thy bowels up.

instruction: Never, except once.
response: What!

instruction: Go, take it away and let your master use it however he wants.
response: Villain, not for thy life!

instruction: The man with the two pretty daughtersis that who you mean?
response: [as LUCENTIO] Even he, Biondello.

instruction: What do you want us to do?
response: Know you these two?

instruction: I ask for your forgiveness. This here is Cassio, hurt by some villains.
response: Cassio!

instruction: To your plates.
response: The middle of humanity thou never knewest, but the extremity of both ends: when thou wast in thy gilt and thy perfume, they mocked thee for too much curiosity; in thy rags thou knowest none, but art despised for the contrary.

instruction: Have courage, man. The injury cant be so bad.
response: No, tis not so deep as a well nor so wide as a church-door, but tis enough, twill serve.

instruction: What kind of man is he?
response: Why, of mankind.

instruction: I'll deliver the message as well as I can.
response: Now will I to that old Andronicus; And temper him with all the art I have, To pluck proud Lucius from the warlike Goths.

instruction: Madam.
response: Nurse?

instruction: Get her out of here!
response: Let him that makes but trifles of his eyesFirst hand me: on mine own accord I'll off;But first I'll do my errand.

instruction: I hit hard, when Im motivated.
response: But thou art not quickly moved to strike.

instruction: Goodness gracious! There's my little chickadee. Is that some dirt on your nose? They say it looks just like mine. Come on, buddy, we should be part of the same herd. Did you know that a bull, a cow, and a calf are called a herd? [Looking toward POLIXENES and HERMIONE] Still holding his hand! [To MAMILLIUS] Well, my silly little calf. Are you my calf?
response: Yes, if you will, my lord.

instruction: Why do you spit at me?
response: Would it were mortal poison for thy sake.

instruction: Ill be calm when the sea is. Get out of here! These waves dont care that someone here is a king. Get to your cabins and be quiet! Stop bothering us.
response: Good, yet remember whom thou hast aboard.

instruction: Didn't I tell you how I was tricked and lost all my money?
response: And indeed, sir, there are cozeners abroad;therefore it behoves men to be wary.

instruction: What are you going to tell her, Nurse? Youre not understanding me.
response: I will tell her, sir, that you do protest, which, as I take it, is a gentlemanlike offer.

instruction: [To DESDEMONA] I kissed you before I killed you. Now that I am killing myself, I must die with a kiss.
response: This did I fear, but thought he had no weapon,For he was great of heart.

instruction: Look, look! Oh, what an awful day!
response: O me, O me!

instruction: I'll take every flower Mother Earth has to offer, to decorate your grave with yellows, blues, purple violets, marigoldsall these will cover you as long as summer lasts. Poor me! When I was born (in a storm), my mother died; my whole life has been a continuous storm blowing me away from my friends.
response: How now, Marina!

instruction: What can I swear? You don't believe in any gods; if that's true, then how can you believe an oath?
response: What if I do not?

instruction: Sir, he may still live. I saw him swim over the waves and ride upon their backs. He treaded water, withstanding all their rage, and fought through even the biggest waves that came at him. He bravely kept his head above the rough waves. And with his powerful arms and strong strokes he swam toward the shore, which seemed almost to lean forward to help him from the water. I have no doubt that he got to the shore alive.
response: No, no, hes gone.

instruction: What did that nun say? Is she dead? Help her, gentlemen!
response: Noble sir,If you have told Diana's altar true,This is your wife.

instruction: Alas, he was a good gentleman! And alas, poor Cassio!
response: This is the fruits of whoring.

instruction: And I wouldn't want to stay at my father's house, either, as my presence would irritate him. Most gracious Duke, listen to my proposal, and please voice your support for my simple idea.
response: What would you, Desdemona?

instruction: To me he's one in a million.
response: Yon king's to me like to my father's picture, Which tells me in that glory once he was; Had princes sit, like stars, about his throne, And he the sun, for them to reverence; None that beheld him, but, like lesser lights, Did vail their crow

instruction: At least tell him we are waiting for him.
response: I need not tell him that; he knows you are too diligent.

instruction: Believe me, sister, out of all the men alive I've never yet seen that special face that I could love more than any other.
response: Minion, thou liest.

instruction: It doesn't appear that way.
response: I grant indeed it hath not appeared, and your suspicionis not without wit and judgment.

instruction: Bad news, by the Virgin Mary. The news is always bad, and likely to get worse. I fear that the world will go crazy.
response: Neighbors, God speed.

instruction: You sad-looking men, people, and sons of Rometorn apart by conflict, scattered like a flock of birds in the windwe'll show you how to put this broken body back together again, how to put the scattered corn back into its sheaf. If we don't, Rome will be a curse to herself. The empire that once defeated many mighty kingdoms will, like a pitiful and desperate person shipwrecked on an island, collapse. But if white hair and wrinkles (the signs of experience) can't convince you to listen to me[To LUCIUS] then speak, Rome's good friend. Speak as eloquently as Aeneas when he told lovesick Dido about the fall of Troythat destructive, burning night when the Greeks surprised King Priam's city. Tell us what Sinon has betrayed us, or who brought in the Trojan horse that has caused civil war in Rome. My heart isn't made of flint or steel, and I can't talk about all our suffering without cryingso I'll have to stop talking, even when you should listen most closely to what I have to say. Here's your captain: let him explain everything. Your hearts will throb and cry when you hear him.
response: Then, noble auditory, be it known to you, That cursed Chiron and Demetrius Were they that murdered our emperor's brother; And they it were that ravished our sister: For their fell faults our brothers were beheaded; Our father's tears despis

instruction: Tunis has never before had such a perfect beauty for a queen.
response: Not since widow Didos time.

instruction: Petruchio, since the conversation has gone this far already, I'll continue with what I meant only as a joke. I can help you find a wife, Petruchio, who's rich, young, beautiful, and brought up as a noble gentlewoman. Her only flaw, and it's certainly a big one, is that she is an unbearable shrew, disagreeable and willful, and so much so that even if I was broke I wouldn't marry her for a goldmine.
response: Hortensio, peace.

instruction: [To MIRANDA, who is about to speak] Quiet for now, darling. Juno and Ceres are whispering about something serious. Theres something else they must do. Be quiet and don't speak, or else my spell will be broken.
response: You nymphs, called Naiads of the windring brooks, With your sedged crowns and ever-harmless looks, Leave your crisp channels and on this green land Answer your summons, Juno does command.

instruction: [To PERDITA] I'll have your beautiful face scratched with thorns until you're uglier than your ugly poverty. [To FLORIZEL] And you, lover boy, if you so much as sigh over not seeing this slut again, you'll never inherit the throne and, what's more, I'll disown you as my son. You'll be out of the family forever, mark my words. Follow me back to court.[To the SHEPHERD] This time you're off the hook, though I am not at all pleased. [To PERDITA] And you, you witch! Your tricks might be good enough for a shepherd, but not for my son. If you ever let him through your gates again, or lay a hand on him, I'll think up the cruelest, most painful possible death for you.
response: Even here undone!

instruction: Dear Apollo, help it all go well! I don't like these accusations against Hermione one bit.
response: The violent carriage of it Will clear or end the business: when the oracle, Thus by Apollo's great divine seal'd up, Shall the contents discover, something rare Even then will rush to knowledge.

instruction: If I were as quick to get into fights as you are, my life insurance rates would be immense.
response: The fee simple?

instruction: A dollar.
response: Dolor comes to him, indeed.

instruction: You go, Malvolio. If this visitor is a messenger from the duke, then tell him that I'm sick, or not at home. Do whatever you have to to make him go away.
response: Now you see, sir, how your fooling grows old, and people dislike it.

instruction: Her brothers died because of that same "safety."
response: Lo, at their births good stars were opposite.

instruction: Hello, sir! Why are you shaking? Don't be afraid; no one's going to hurt you.
response: I am a poor fellow, sir.

instruction: Just some dry humor, sir.
response: Are you full of them?

instruction: Since you won't listen to my advice, you'll have to face the consequences: if you read the riddle and can't answer it, you'll be killed like the others before you.
response: Of all say'd yet, mayst thou prove prosperous!Of all say'd yet, I wish thee happiness!

instruction: If he says anything against me, Ill teach him a lesson, even if he were tougher than he isand twenty wise-asses like him. And if I couldnt take him down myself, Ill find someone who can. That rotten scoundrel! Im not one of his flirty girls. Im not one of his low-life scheming friends.
response: I saw no man use you at his pleasure.

instruction: I wouldn't have missed this entertainment for a pension of thousands, to be paid by the Shah of Persia.
response: I could marry this wench for this device.

instruction: Are you going to weep forever about your cousins death? Do you think you can wash him out of his grave with tears? Even if you could, you couldnt bring him back to life. So stop crying. Some grief shows a lot of love. But too much grief makes you look silly.
response: Yet let me weep for such a feeling loss.

instruction: Easily, my good lady.
response: Make your proof.

instruction: It's all mortgaged, and some of it already sold. What's left won't even come close to paying off everyone. And what are we going to do about the even greater number of creditors that will approach us soon? What can we do in the long run?
response: To Lacedaemon did my land extend.

instruction: I can't sleep. I'm pale and sick. I can't stop thinking about it, can't stop trying to come up with ways to stop this storm before it happens. And since there's no solution, I'm just letting myself be sad about it.
response: Well, my lord, since you have given me leave to speak.

instruction: Bring me my boots; I'm going to the king.
response: Strike him, Aumerle.

instruction: Is Clarence dead? The death sentence had been reversed.
response: But he, poor man, by your first order died, And that a wingèd Mercury did bear.

instruction: If I can get him to have just one drink, together with what he's already had to drink, he'll be as belligerent and testy as a badly trained as a young girl's pet dog. Now my fool Roderigowhom love has practically turned inside out, has drunk whole pots full of wine in toasts to Desdemonaand he's on guard duty. I've gotten three men from Cyprus drunk as well, noble men who are worried about maintaining their honor (which is important in this warlike island), and they are also on guard duty. Now among this flock of drunkards, I will put Cassio, and I'll have him do something to offend the men of Cyprus. But here they come. If things turn out as I want them to, I've got smooth sailing ahead.
response: 'Fore heaven, they have given me a rouse already.

instruction: We say Amen to that! We will be witnesses.
response: Father, and wife, and gentlemen, adieu.

instruction: Hmph!
response: And yet I fear you, for youre fatal then When your eyes roll so.

instruction: Everyone else leave. But take care to see what ships are coming in and out of the harbor and report back to me.[The LORDS leave]Helicanus, you've got my attention. How do I look?
response: An angry brow, dread lord.

instruction: Ah, well done, the chair! Some good man carry him away carefully. I'll go get the general's doctor. [To BIANCA] As for you, mistress, don't bother trying to help. Cassio, the man who lies murdered here was my dear friend. What bad blood was there between the two of you?
response: None in the world, nor do I know the man.

instruction: Yes, by stabbing them in their hearts, grandfather.
response: No, boy, not so; I'll teach thee another course.

instruction: With all my heart. I remember this fellow herehe once played the part of a farmer's eldest son. That was the play in which you courted the gentlewoman so successfully. I've forgotten your name, but you were well suited for that role, and played it realistically.
response: I think twas Soto that your Honor means.

instruction: Continue, continue, or Ill proclaim victory.
response: Nay, if our wits run the wild-goose chase, I am done, for thou hast more of the wild-goose in one of thy wits than, I am sure, I have in my whole five.

instruction: My brother-in-law of Gloucester, you're mistaken. It was the king himself, unprovoked by anyone, who noticed your hatred for my children, my brothers, and myselfan inner hatred that expresses itself in your outward actions. He summoned people to ask them about your dislike of us, so that he might discover the reasons behind it and do something about it.
response: I cannot tell.

instruction: Some people in the street are crying Romeo. Others cry Juliet, and still others Paris. Theyre all running and screaming towards our tomb.
response: What fear is this which startles in our ears?

instruction: He would not say that.
response: No, his mouth is stopped.

instruction: If you so much as touch the princess in response to his disgusting words, your hands will be cursed forever.
response: So I would you did; then 'twere past all doubtYou'ld call your children yours.

instruction: May Mercurythat god of deceptionmake you a skilled liar, to reward you for speaking so highly of fools!
response: Madam, there is at the gate a young gentleman much desires to speak with you.

instruction: Are the English really so good at drinking?
response: Why, he drinks you with facility your Dane dead drunk; he sweats not to overthrow your Almain.

instruction: That handkerchief that I loved so much and gave to you, you gave to Cassio.
response: No, by my life and soul!Send for the man and ask him.

instruction: Oh, Sir, things are what they are. What a man can't get, he can trade for (like his wife's soul).
response: Help, master, help!

instruction: Don't you hear a cry?
response: Here, here!

instruction: Good day, brother. Why do you have all these armed guards accompanying you, your Grace?
response: His majesty,Tend'ring my persons safety, hath appointed This conduct to convey me to the Tower.

instruction: May you live in misery and love it too.
response: Long live so, and so die.

instruction: The king is here: be gentle to this youth, since young horses only get angrier when shouted at.
response: How fares our noble uncle, Lancaster?

instruction: I am very sorry, sir, for all the wrong I've done you, sir. Please report good things about me to the prince my master.
response: Prithee, son, do; for we must be gentle, now we aregentlemen.

instruction: Please, heaven, stop your wrath! Wind, rain and thunder: remember that earthly men can only yield to you and recognize that I, as an earthly man, do obey you. The sea has tossed me onto the rocks, washed me from shore to shore, and left me sure of nothing but that my end is near. Please, let it be enough for your great powers that I, a prince, have lost everything. Since you've thrown me out of your watery grave, all I ask is to die here in peace.
response: What, ho, Pilch!

instruction: He was just here, and he is certainly strangely bothered.
response: Can he be angry?

instruction: Look at all the people following the lord!
response: The senators of Athens: happy man!

instruction: I'm a virgin, sir, and though I've never asked for anyone's attention, I've had a lot of people stare at me (as though I were a shooting star)! I'm speaking to you, sir, because I think I may have experienced grief that, if we compared, might equal yours. Though I've been unlucky to end up where I am now, I'm descended from ancestors who were the equivalent of powerful kings. I've been robbed of my inheritance from my parents, and over the course of time have been forced to serve the world and its uncomfortable institutions. [To herself] I should stop. But there's something that warms my cheek, a little voice inside me telling me, "Keep going until he says something."
response: My fortunesparentagegood parentageTo equal mine!was it not thus?

instruction: Listen, Escanes: Antiochus was committing incest, and the most high gods couldn't contain their vengeance any longer against this most horrible of crimes. He was at the height of his glory, riding in his expensive chariot with his daughter when lightening struck from heaven, shriveling up their bodies to a disgusting, stinking mess. It was so horrible that no one who formerly adored them would stoop low enough to bury them.
response: 'Twas very strange.

instruction: Magni Dominator poli, Tam lentus audis scelera? tam lentus vides?
response: O, calm thee, gentle lord; although I know There is enough written upon this earth To stir a mutiny in the mildest thoughts And arm the minds of infants to exclaims.

instruction: She has been more beautiful than she is now, madam. When she thought that my master loved her, I think she was as beautiful as you. But since she stopped looking in the mirror and threw her mask away, the air has starved the rosy blush on her cheeks, and eroded the lily-white color of her face, so now she has become as black as I.
response: How tall was she?

instruction: No.
response: Yes, indeed shall you, and taste gentlemen of allfashions: you shall fare well; you shall have thedifference of all complexions.

instruction: Whatever he gives courteously, I accept gratefully.
response: Ha' you done?

instruction: Well, now you missed the target. She wont be hit by Cupids arrow. Shes like Diana, protected by the armor of chastity. She is immune to the weak and childish arrows of love. She ignores words of love, refuses to even let you look at her with loving eyes, or open her lap to receive golden gifts that would even tempt a saint. Oh, shes rich in beauty. But shes also poor, because when she dies her beauty will die along with her.
response: Then she hath sworn that she will still live chaste?

instruction: Hail, royal prince!
response: Thanks, noble peer; The cheapest of us is ten groats too dear.

instruction: Im no lord of yours, you haughty insulting man, nor no mans lord; I have no name, no titleno, not even the name that was given to me when I was baptizedthat isnt usurped. How can I have lived so many winters and dont know now what name to call myself? Oh, that I were a mockery, a king of snow, that would melt away in water-drops, standing before the sun of Bolingbroke! [To Bolingbroke] Good king, great kingand yet not greatly goodif my word still counts for something in England, ask that someone bring a mirror here, so that I can see what I look like now that Im no longer king.
response: Go some of you and fetch a looking-glass.

instruction: Yes, but why?
response: To satisfy your highness and the entreatiesOf our most gracious mistress.

instruction: Open it, and read it.
response: Look then to be well edified when the fool delivers themadman.

instruction: Otherwise, would they be happy to die?
response: Yes; if there were no other excuse why they shoulddesire to live.

instruction: The tyrannous and bloody act is done. It was the worst, most horrible massacre of which this land has ever been guilty. Dighton and Forrestwhom I hired to do this piece of ruthless butcheryare experienced villains. They are like bloody hunting dogs. But even they melted with tenderness and compassion, and wept like children when they told the sad story of what they'd done. "The gentle children lay like this," Dighton said. "Like this," said Forrest, "embracing each other with their white innocent arms. Their lips were touching, like four red roses on a stalk. And a prayer book lay on their pillow," said Forrest, "which almost made me change my mind. But oh, the devil" And there the villain stopped talking, and Dighton continued the tale: "We smothered the most perfect, sweet work that nature ever created." Both men were crushed with remorse, so that they couldn't speak any more. I left them both to bring this news to the bloody king.
response: And here he comes.All health, my sovereign lord.

instruction: So now the Yorks' prosperity has ripened and rotted, falling into the mouth of death. I've been lurking in the shadows here to watch my enemies come to ruin, and it's a terrible scene I've witnessedan ominous prologue to what I hope will be a bitter, dark, and tragic conclusion. I'll head to France. But hide now, wretched Margaret. Who's coming?
response: Ah, my poor princes!

instruction: [To himself] Joking makes their work fun!
response: Hark you, sir, do you know where ye are?

instruction: When I'm at home I spend all my time playing, laughing, and working with him. He's my friend and my enemy, my shadow, my soldier, my little king-in-training. He makes the days fly by and his crazy antics keep me from taking myself too seriously.
response: So stands this squire Officed with me: we two will walk, my lord, And leave you to your graver steps.

instruction: Yes, because I am young and haven't experienced any sorrow.
response: This argues fruitfulness and liberal heart.

instruction: My heart will show what I can't tell you with words.
response: My lord, will't please you to fall to?

instruction: Silver. Follow them, Silver!
response: Fury, Fury!

instruction: Yes, Timon.
response: A beastly ambition, which the gods grant thee t' attain to!

instruction: We should kill him before he harasses us.
response: A plague upon him, dog!

instruction: Master, I'm thinking of the poor men that were shipwrecked before us even now.
response: Alas, poor souls, it grieved my heart to hear whatpitiful cries they made to us to help them, when,well-a-day, we could scarce help ourselves.

instruction: Oh, why would nature create such a foul place, unless the gods take delight in our suffering?
response: Give signs, sweet girl, for here are none but friends, What Roman lord it was durst do the deed: Or slunk not Saturnine, as Tarquin erst, That left the camp to sin in Lucrece' bed?

instruction: I know it's the sun that shines so bright.
response: Now, by my mothers son, and thats myself, It shall be moon, or star, or what I list, Or e'er I journey to your fathers house.

instruction: Yes, but the citizens prefer Lucius, and will rebel against me to support him.
response: King, be thy thoughts imperious, like thy name.

instruction: You can rely on me, your Ladyship. Have a good morning, gentle lady.
response: Good morrow, kind Sir Eglamour.

instruction: [To ALONSO] In the name of all that is holy, sir, why do you stand there staring strangely around?
response: Oh, it is monstrous, monstrous.

instruction: It may be so; and yet my inward soul tells me it's not. For whatever reason, I can't help but be sad: so extremely sad that, even if I'm not thinking of anything in particular, I feel exhausted and frightened by this heavy nothing weighing on me.
response: 'Tis nothing but conceit, my gracious lady.

instruction: Well, then on Judgment Day he'll say that we stabbed him in his sleep.
response: The urging of that word judgment hath bred a kind of remorse in me.

instruction: Oh, but they're our friends. Just one drink. I'll even drink it for you.
response: I have drunk but one cup tonight, and that was craftilyqualified too, and behold what innovation it makes here.

instruction: My lady, I humbly thank you.
response: Save you, friend Cassio!

instruction: May the god of melancholy watch over you, and may a tailor make you a jacket of opal, for your mind changes like the colors of an opal. Men as changeable as you should be put out to sea, where they can make everything their business and scatter their ideas everywhere, drifting about on the changeable wavesthat's how you make a good voyage out of nothing. Farewell.
response: Let all the rest give place.

instruction: And in saying so, you'll only be telling the truth.
response: Then I salute you with this royal title: Long live Richard, Englands worthy king!

instruction: [Reading] "Jack of Norfolk, don't be too bold, for Dick your master's been bought and sold." Some plot of the enemy's. Go, gentlemen, every man to his position. Don't let our babbling dreams frighten our souls. "Conscience" is just a word that cowards use to keep down the strong. Our strength will make us right; our swords will be the law. March on. Meet the enemy bravely. Let's go down fightingif not to heaven, then hand in hand to hell.
response: Hark!

instruction: Dance with Mopsa . . . though you might need some strong stuff to cover her bad breath!
response: Now, in good time!

instruction: [To SIR TOBY BELCH] Let me go.
response: Come, sir, I will not let you go.

instruction: Knock on the door? Oh God! Didn't you clearly say the words "Man, knock me here, pound here, and knock me well?" And now you're claiming it was "knocking on the door?"
response: Sirrah, begone or talk not, I advise you.

instruction: [Opening the door] Welcome, then.
response: O holy Friar, O, tell me, holy Friar,Where is my ladys lord?

instruction: [To ANTONIO] We'll continue this later.
response: [t o ANDREW ] Pray, sir, put your sword up, if you please.

instruction: I think I do.
response: And how does your contentTender your own good fortune?

instruction: Oh no, the storm is returning! The best thing for me would be to crawl under his cloak. Theres no other shelter nearby. When times are tough, youll end up close to the strangest people. Ill cover myself up here until the last of the storm passes. [He crawls under the cloak]
response: [sings] I shall no more to sea, to sea, Here shall I die ashore This is a very scurvy tune to sing at a mans funeral.

instruction: And is worth more than our labor to find you.
response: Evermore thanks, the exchequer of the poor; Which, till my infant fortune comes to years, Stands for my bounty.

instruction: Is that all you saw? Didn't you notice how her sister began to scold and cause such a ruckus that human ears could hardly endure the noise?
response: Tranio, I saw her coral lips to moveAnd with her breath she did perfume the air.

instruction: Like the moon, which falls as it loses its light to give. But I cannot renew myself and start again like the moon. There are no suns out there to borrow light from.
response: Noble Timon,What friendship may I do thee?

instruction: The castle is royally defended against your entrance, my lord.
response: Royally!Why, it contains no king?

instruction: What are you talking to me about with "robbing?" This is the city of Venice. My house isn't some unprotected barn.
response: Most grave Brabantio,In simple and pure soul I come to you

instruction: I thank you, gentle Percy; and be sure that I count myself lucky for nothing so much as my good friends. And as my fortune improves with your love, I'll reward you well: my heart promises this, and a handshake seals it.
response: How far is it to Berkeley?

instruction: You want a single word with one of us? Combine it with something else. Make it a word and a punch.
response: You shall find me apt enough to that, sir, an you will give me occasion.

instruction: Go, fellow, go. Return to your lord. Tell him not to worry about the two separate meetings. He and I will be at one meeting, and my good friend Catesby will be at the other. Nothing important can happen at the secret meeting without us hearing about it. Tell your lord that his fears are shadows without evidence. And as for his dreams, I'm surprised that he's so foolish as to trust the imaginings of restless sleep. To flee the boar before he even pursues us would make the boar angry, and incite him to chase us even if he never intended to in the first place. Go tell your master to get up and meet me, and we'll go together to the Tower. There he'll see that the boar will treat us kindly.
response: Ill go, my lord, and tell him what you say.

instruction: Who's blocking my path?
response: O, she that might have intercepted thee,By strangling thee in her accursèd womb,From all the slaughters, wretch, that thou hast done.

instruction: Not in my house, Lucentio, for you know that I have many servants who might eavesdrop, and "little pitchers have big ears," as they say. Besides, old Gremio is always hanging around and listening, so we might be interrupted.
response: [as LUCENTIO] Then at my lodging, an it like you.

instruction: Good morning to you both. What do you mean I tricked you?
response: The slip, sir, the slip.

instruction: What is your idea, Desdemona?
response: That I did love the Moor to live with him, My downright violence and storm of fortunes May trumpet to the world.

instruction: I don't want your food. It would choke me because it is offered to flatterers, and I would never flatter you.
