Oh you gods, what number of men eat Timon's meat, and he doesn't even notice. It makes me sad to see so many dip their meat into the blood of one man, and the crazy thing about it all is that he encourages them to do it! I wonder how men dare to trust other men. They should be cautious of letting them bring their knives to such a feast. It would keep them from eating so much, and probably save their lives too! There are many examples of it: the man sitting next to him now, breaks bread with him, and shares his germs as he drinks from the same glassthat is the man most ready to kill him. It is certain. If I were a man of higher rank, I would fear drinking at my meals, because they might be able to see my neck's tenderest spots while I tilted my head back. Great men should drink with armor on their throats.
response: My lord, in heart; and let the health go round.

instruction: Well, that's comforting. [Enter CAMILLO] Hey, Camillo, is that you?
response: Ay, my good lord.

instruction: Treason! Foul treason! Villain! Traitor! Slave!
response: What is the matter, my lord?

instruction: [As LUCENTIO] That "only" came just in time.
response: Two thousand ducats by the year of land!

instruction: Brabantio, wake up! Thieves! Thieves! Check on your house, check on your daughter, check on your money bags! Thieves! Thieves!
response: What is the reason of this terrible summons?What is the matter there?

instruction: Now you see, sir, how your jokes grow stale, and people dislike them.
response: Thou hast spoke for us, madonna, as if thy eldest son should be a fool, whose skull Jove cram with brains, forhere he comesone of thy kin has a most weak pia mater.

instruction: What's going on, woman? How dare you!Bianca, step away from her.The poor girl, she's weeping! [To BIANCA] Go do some sewing, and don't talk to her.[To KATHERINE] For shame, you vicious creature, you devil! Why would you hurt her when she's never done you any harm? When did she ever speak a single cruel word to you?
response: Her silence flouts me, and Ill be revenged.

instruction: Why are you dressed like that, Andronicus?
response: Because I would be sure to have all well,To entertain your highness and your empress.

instruction: I'll leave you for a while, dear. Mind you, walk slowly and don't get too worked up! What? I have to take care of you!
response: My thanks, sweet madam.

instruction: Help, help, help!
response: How now!

instruction: Is he here?
response: Why, no, sir.

instruction: Return, good Catesby, to the gracious duke. Tell him that I, the mayor, and some citizens have come to confer with his Grace about matters of great importance, which concern the good of all.
response: Ill signify so much unto him straight.

instruction: You are banished from Verona. Be patient, the world is big and anything can happen.
response: There is no world without Verona walls But purgatory, torture, hell itself.

instruction: I don't beg to stand; I only ask for pardon.
response: I pardon him, as God shall pardon me.

instruction: Please, that's enough of your jokes. Here's a little gold for you. If the woman who takes care of the general's wife is awake, tell her that a man named Cassio begs the she give him a chance to speak with her. Will you do this?
response: She is stirring, sir.

instruction: Here, at your lordship's service.
response: This fellow here, Lord Timon, this thy creature, By night frequents my house.

instruction: Get out of here; I have to goSomewhere you can't follow.
response: Whither?

instruction: He's still only in the second degree, my lady, so the fool will take care of the madman.
response: Madam, yond young fellow swears he will speak with you.I told him you were sick.

instruction: The devil may take me if I should ever do such a wrong for the whole world.
response: Why the wrong is but a wrong i' th' world, and having the world for your labor, tis a wrong in your own world, and you might quickly make it right.

instruction: Enough, you owls! All I hear are songs of death. [He strikes the THIRD MESSENGER] There, take that until you bring me better news.
response: The news I have to tell your Majesty Is that by sudden floods and fall of waters Buckinghams army is dispersed and scattered, And he himself wandered away alone, No man knows whither.

instruction: It doesn't matter, since they left their food behind, and we have hungry stomachs. Would you like to taste some of the food?
response: Not I.

instruction: Indeed, I do mean to keep myself warm, sweet Katherine, in your bed. But enough chatter. Let's speak plainly: your father has consented that you will be my wife. Your dowry is agreed upon, and whether you want it or not, I will marry you. Now, Kate, I'm the only husband for you. I swear by this light, which lets me see your beautyyour beauty that makes me love youthat you must be married to no man but me. I was born to tame you, Kate, and change you from a wildcat Kate into a Kate as obedient as other domesticated Kates.
response: Here comes your father.

instruction: Neither, girl: for happy stories remind me of my sorrow, and sad stories add more sorrow to my already sad life. I already know I'm sad, and there's no point in complaining about my lack of happiness.
response: Madam, I'll sing.

instruction: You speak honestly. Have a nice day.
response: Stay, fellow.

instruction: If I were like you I'd throw myself away.
response: Thou hast cast away thyself, being like thyself; A madman so long, now a fool.

instruction: My message can't be told to anyone, my lady. It's only for your own willing and receptive ears.
response: [aside] Odors, pregnant, and vouchsafed.

instruction: Come here, son; come, come, and show us how to cry. Your grandfather loved you very much. He would often bounce you on his knee, or sing to you until you fell asleep on his chest; he told you many things that were fit for you to know when you were a child. Like a loving child, then, shed some tears, since kind nature requires it. Friends should be together in times of grief and sorrow. Say goodbye before we bury him. Do that kindness, and then leave him in peace.
response: O grandsire, grandsire!

instruction: Come here, little man. Will you play with me?
response: No, I'll none of you.

instruction: Verona in the summertime has no flower as fine as him.
response: Nay, hes a flower.

instruction: But how? How will you be satisfied, my lord? Would you, like a voyeur, inappropriately watch and look on as she is having sex?
response: Death and damnation!

instruction: A rhyme I learned just now from somebody I danced with.
response: Anon, anon.

instruction: Go to your chairs as hungrily as you might kiss the lips of your mistress. There are no assigned seats, when the food gets cold before people find out where they sit. Sit, sit, and thank the gods. I thank you for the gifts you have given, and hope you will keep enough for yourselves so that you can still be so charitable in the future. You should have given enough that no man will have to give his own money to another, because even gods would not be successful in applying for a loan nowadays. Enjoy the meat more than you enjoy the man who provides you with it. Make sure also that twenty out of twenty men are villains, as you might let twelve women at a table be as they are. As for the rest, the senators and the commoners, destroy the worst parts of them.[Gesturing to the people around him] My friends here, they mean nothing to me, so bless them with nothing. Here they are welcome to nothing. Uncover the dishes so the dogs may lick up the water.
response: What does his lordship mean?

instruction: Am I only three inches? Why, your cuckold's horn is a foot long, and I'm at least that tall. But are you going to make a fire, or will I have to complain about you to our mistress? Now that she's at hand, you'll soon feel her hand, and you'll find it cold comfort if you're slow in warming us up.
response: I prithee, good Grumio, tell me, how goes the world?

instruction: So we hear you're the governor? Don't be so surprised by all our ships and men. We've heard about your suffering all the way in Tyre, and we've seen the destruction in your streets. We came to help, not to make things worse. These ships might look like the Trojan horse (which had Greek soldiers hidden inside, bloodthirsty and ready to attack), but they're filled with grain to make bread, to bring all your starving people back to life.
response: The gods of Greece protect you!And we'll pray for you.

instruction: [To the PAGE] Lead on, boy. Which way?
response: Yea, noise?

instruction: See, no one has private access to Pericles except for Helicanus.
response: It shall no longer grieve without reproof.

instruction: Yes, but the mustard's a little too hot.
response: Why then, the beef, and let the mustard rest.

instruction: You silly madman, listen to me for a second.
response: Oh, thou wilt speak again of banishment.

instruction: Now knock when I tell you to, you idiot peasant.
response: How now, whats the matter?

instruction: Praise Diana! I'm doing what you asked: I'll tell the whole story here. I'm the king of Tyre. I left my country because I was afraid for my life, and married Thaisa in Pentapolis. She died giving birth to our daughter, Marina, at sea. Marina is still a virgin like you, Diana! Cleon took care of her in Tarsus, but when she was fourteen years old he tried to murder her. Luckily, she came to Mytilene, where, when I arrived, by good fortune she was brought aboard my ship and, by recounting her story, she made it clear she was my daughter.
response: Voice and favour!You are, you areO royal Pericles!

instruction: Oh, Pomfret, Pomfret! Oh, you bloody prison, fatal to noblemen! King Richard II was hacked to death within your guilty walls. And nowto bring greater shame to your ominous namewe must offer up our innocent lives here.
response: Now Margarets curse is fall'n upon our heads,When she exclaimed on Hastings, you, and I, For standing by when Richard stabbed her son.

instruction: I approve so wholeheartedly that I'd like to have the wedding immediately and get you off to bed!
response: Now sleep y-slaked hath the rout; No din but snores the house about, Made louder by the o'er-fed breast Of this most pompous marriage-feast.

instruction: [Singing] On the twelfth day of December
response: For the love o' God, peace!

instruction: It's no surprise that it frightened you, my lord. I'm afraid just hearing you tell it.
response: Ah keeper, keeper, I have done those things, That now give evidence against my soul, For Edwards sake, and see how he requites me.

instruction: A curse on these wild, pompous fellows who are always spouting exotic foreign phrases. These fellows, who say things like: By Jesus, this is a very good blade! A very brave man! A very good whore. Isnt it a sad thing, good man, that we are forced to interact with these foreign flies, these fashionmongers, these fellows who say pardon me and care so deeply about good manners that they cant relax on a bench without groaning, Oh, my aching bones!
response: Here comes Romeo, here comes Romeo.

instruction: Im crying at my cowardice for not daring to give you what I want to give you, much less take what Im dying to have. But that's nothing. And the more I try to hide my feelings, the larger they get. So stop being so shy and indirect, Miranda, and let your innocent directness guide you! Ill be your wife if you will marry me. If you won't, Ill die a virgin, having never loved another man. You can refuse to make me your wife, but Ill be your servant whether you want me to or not.
response: My mistress, dearest, and I thus humble ever.

instruction: Here you've seen a king commit incest with his daughter. Pericles will turn out to be a much more powerful prince and a better ruler, strong in both word and deed. But now he has to keep his mouth shut, until enough time has passed. I'll show you how much trouble he had to deal with; once he got over the molehill, he ran into a mountain. That good man whom I bless, Pericles, is still at Tarsus, where everyone is singing his praises and the city is erecting a statue of him to remember him byeverything seems happy. But what you're about to see contradicts that, so what can I say?
response: Good Helicane, that stay'd at home, Not to eat honey like a drone From others' labours; for though he strive To killen bad, keep good alive; And to fulfil his prince' desire, Sends word of all that haps in Tyre: How Thaliard came full bent

instruction: My mistress is my mistress; this child is me, the picture of how I was a child. I prefer this to all the world, and despite everything I will keep it safeor all Rome will burn.
response: By this our mother is forever shamed.

instruction: Can I ask you to stay?
response: I am content.

instruction: Greetings, sir! May the gods bless you!
response: And you, sir, to outlive the age I am,And die as I would do.

instruction: By God's eyelid, I'll go after him again and fight him.
response: Do, cuff him soundly, but never draw thy sword.

instruction: Oh, help, hey! Bring some light! I need a doctor!
response: 'Tis he.

instruction: If Mamillius had lived to see this day, he'd be Florizel's age. They were born about a month apart.
response: Prithee, no more; cease; thou know'st He dies to me again when talk'd of: sure, When I shall see this gentleman, thy speeches Will bring me to consider that which may Unfurnish me of reason.

instruction: Haha, you've confessed it? And been hanged for the sin, have you not?
response: O, Apemantus, you are welcome.

instruction: Him? I recognize him.
response: Save thee, Timon.

instruction: How's it going, my golden one?
response: Get you all three into the boxtree.

instruction: Look, here comes the smallest bird of all.
response: If you desire the spleen, and will laugh yourself into stitches, follow me.

instruction: Wasn't that Cassio who was just talking to my wife?
response: Cassio, my lord?

instruction: My comfort is that heaven will take our souls, and that the unjust people who do this to us will suffer in hell.
response: My Lord Northumberland, see them dispatch'd.

instruction: Will you really deny that you know me now? Is it possible that all I've done for you can't persuade you to help me? Don't make my misery even worse, or make me so angry that I list out all the kind things I've done for you.
response: I know of none, Nor know I you by voice or any feature.

instruction: Every day new taxes are invented, such as blanks, benevolences, and I know not what: but what, in God's name, will come of this?
response: Wars have not wasted it, for warr'd he hath not, But basely yielded upon compromise That which his noble ancestors achieved with blows: More hath he spent in peace than they in wars.

instruction: Go on, now. Bye. Now are you listening to me?
response: What say you?

instruction: [To FERDINAND] Who is this young woman with whom you were playing chess? You cant have known her for more than three hours. Is she the goddess that separated us and then brought us back together?
response: Sir, she is mortal.

instruction: Yes, a thousand times. Peter!
response: Anon!

instruction: If just one of the pockets on his clothes could speak, wouldnt it say that hes a liar?
response: Ay, or very falsely pocket up his report.

instruction: Sir, I beg you: don't trouble yourself any further.
response: Oh, pardon me, twill do me good to walk.

instruction: I give it out of sincere kindness and affection for you.
response: I think it freely, and betimes in the morning I will beseech the virtuous Desdemona to undertake for me.

instruction: You lie, you evil thing! Have you forgotten the awful witch Sycorax, who was so old and filled with anger that she was so stooped over? Have you forgotten her?
response: No, sir.

instruction: And wasn't that lucky! Please, don't finish your story. Next you're going to say that your queen and I are devils. Actually, keep goingwe'll admit to being the cause of your sin as long as you admit you sinned with us for the first time and swear you haven't sinned with anyone else since.
response: Is he won yet?

instruction: I'll buy that.
response: Do not you fear: upon mine honour,I will stand betwixt you and danger.

instruction: No, in its tongue.
response: Whose tongue?

instruction: Your face is mine, and you have slandered it.
response: It may be so, for it is not mine own.Are you at leisure, holy Father, now,Or shall I come to you at evening mass?

instruction: The Duke and Senators of Venice send their greetings.
response: I kiss the instrument of their pleasures.

instruction: A daughter? Oh God, I wish that they were both living in Naples, as king and queen of the country! To make that happen, Id sacrifice my own life and lie in the muddy bed beneath the ocean. When did you lose your daughter?
response: In this last tempest.

instruction: Honestly, when I ran into this holy man, I did think of those men you mention. So, are you going to the Tower?
response: I do, my lord, but long I shall not stay there.

instruction: What? Just now?
response: But now, my lord.

instruction: Give my regards to Lord Hastings. Tell him, Catesby, that the dangerous enemies who have plagued him for years will be executed tomorrow at Pomfret Castle. And to celebrate this good news, tell him to give Miss Shore an extra kiss.
response: Good Catesby, go effect this business soundly.

instruction: Stop that. You're drunk.
response: Drunk?

instruction: Go, girl. I can't blame you for weeping now. Such an insult would offend even a saint, let alone an impatient shrew like you.
response: Master, master!

instruction: What did he say?
response: Why, that he didI know not what he did.

instruction: To horse, to horse! Encourage those who are afraid.
response: Hold out my horse, and I will first be there.

instruction: We cant be both here and there at once! Be cheerful, boys. Be quick for a while, and may the longest lived take everything.
response: Welcome, gentlemen!

instruction: A rogue is going to tell me what to do? I'll beat the scoundrel to a pulp.
response: Beat me?

instruction: Good aunt, stand up.
response: Nay, do not say, 'stand up;' Say, 'pardon' first, and afterwards 'stand up.' And if I were thy nurse, thy tongue to teach, 'Pardon' should be the first word of thy speech.

instruction: I tell you, Kate, it was burnt and dried up. I'm expressly forbidden from eating meat like that, for it creates choler and makes me angry. It's probably better that we should go hungry, since we're both hotheaded and temperamental, than that we should eat such overcooked meat. Be patientit'll get fixed tomorrow. For tonight we'll just go without food. Come, I'll bring you to your bridal bedroom.
response: Peter, didst ever see the like?

instruction: Very proudly, as if he had contempt for the ground beneath his feet.
response: So proud that Bolingbroke was on his back!

instruction: No, gentlemen, dont leave now. We have a bit of dessert arriving any moment. [They whisper something to him] Is that so? Then, I thank you. I thank you, honest gentlemen. Good night. Bring more torches over here! Come on, lets all get to bed.
response: Come hither, Nurse.

instruction: Romeo will answer it.
response: Any man that can write may answer a letter.

instruction: Well, he is gone, and these thoughts should go with him. Now as for the situation in Irelandwe must do something to manage the rebels, my liege. If we wait too long theyll use the extra time to their advantage against us.
response: We will ourself in person to this war: And, for our coffers, with too great a court And liberal largess, are grown somewhat light, We are inforced to farm our royal realm; The revenue whereof shall furnish us For our affairs in hand: if tha

instruction: [To VIOLA] Come here, boy. If you ever fall in love, remember me when you feel its bittersweet pangs. Because the way I am now is the way all true lovers aremoody and fickle in every emotion, constant only in imagining the face of the person they love. How do you like this song?
response: It gives a very echo to the seatWhere Love is throned.

instruction: [To RICHARD] When I was alive, you stabbed my kingly body full of deadly holes. Remember the Tower, and remember me. Despair, and die! Henry the Sixth tells you to despair and die!
response: [to RICHARD] Let me sit heavy in thy soul tomorrow, I, that was washed to death with fulsome wine, Poor Clarence, by thy guile betrayed to death.

instruction: Very good.
response: What trumpet is that same?

instruction: If you sink in love, then youre burdening it. Youre putting too much weight on such a tender thing.
response: Is love a tender thing?

instruction: That is true. I can show you a thousand paintings of moral lessons that demonstrate Fortune's sudden victims more effectively than words ever could. But you'd do well nevertheless to show the Lord Timon that even we commoners can see that he is falling.
response: Imprison'd is he, say you?

instruction: You idiot, that doesn't mean anything! Those that seem to be the most kind are the most deceitful. But let them do what they will and what they can, why should we be afraid? Our lives couldn't be more miserable than they are now; we're halfway to the ground. Go, tell their general he can meet us here to announce why and from where he comes, and what he wants.
response: I go, my lord.

instruction: That's a compelling sales pitch.
response: No, my good lord; he speaks the common tongue,Which all men speak with him.

instruction: Don't preach to me. I have not done a single bad thing in giving these gifts, for they were imprudently, not dishonorably, given. Why are you so upset? Can't you see that I have all the friends in the world? Don't worry, because if I could appeal to those who have received so much from me in love and work to inspire their sympathy, other men and their fortunes will prove themselves available to me. One word and someone will lend to me.
response: Assurance bless your thoughts!

instruction: My lord, I care about my life as much as you care about yours, and I swear I care about it as much now as I ever have. Do you think I would be as confident as I am if I wasn't certain of our safety?
response: The lords at Pomfret, when they rode from London, Were jocund and supposed their states were sure, And they indeed had no cause to mistrust; But yet you see how soon the day o'ercast.

instruction: To supper. To our house.
response: Whose house?

instruction: My gracious lord, I come only for what belongs to me.
response: Your own is yours, and I am yours, and all.

instruction: That's what I conceive of Petruchio.
response: Conceives by me?

instruction: Indeed, I will. This is the wisest course.
response: Ancient damnation!

instruction: Young budding virgin, fair and fresh and sweet, where are you off to, and where is your home? Happy are the parents of such a fair child. And happier the man whose destiny is to share your bed!
response: Why, how now, Kate!

instruction: What I say is the truth: and if I had you in the right place, I'd prove it to you.
response: I am for thee straight.

instruction: Was I completely senseless during the hours she was cheating on me? I didn't see anything, and I didn't suspect anything. So, it didn't do me any harm. I slept well after, ate well, and was happy and carefree. I didn't see Cassio's kisses on her lips. If a man is ever robbed but doesn't realize what has been stolen, let him not know he's been robbed. And then it's as if the robbery never happened.
response: I am sorry to hear this.

instruction: Sir, a special order has come from Venice to put Cassio in charge here, in Othello's place.
response: Is that true?

instruction: Was that him who just left?
response: Ay, sooth, so humbledThat he hath left part of his grief with me To suffer with him.

instruction: My lord, there are some senators who have just arrived and come to visit you.
response: They are fairly welcome.

instruction: Did he write this?
response: Ay, madam.

instruction: The sun won't come out today. The sky frowns and scowls at our army. I wish there wasn't all this dew on the ground. So the sun won't shine today? Why, that shouldn't matter any more to me than it does to Richmond. The same heaven that frowns on me also looks sadly on him.
response: Arm, arm, my lord.

instruction: If you'll allow it, no. My luck is bad, and my doomed fate might disturb your own destiny. Therefore I will say farewell, and face the evils of my fate alone. It would be a bad way of thanking you if I burdened you with any of my troubles.
response: Let me yet know of you whither you are bound.

instruction: Come on, come on. You women are the picture of perfection out in public, but annoying as ringing bells in your parlors and like wild-cats in your kitchens. When you've been hurt, you act like saints, but when you're offended you act like devils. You all fool around when you should be doing your housewife duties, and you are hussies in bed.
response: Oh, fie upon thee, slanderer!

instruction: Give signs, sweet girl, for everyone here is your friend: what Roman lord is responsible? Was it Saturninelike Tarquin, who left the camp to attack Lucrece?
response: Sit down, sweet niece: brother, sit down by me.

instruction: Oh, what misery!
response: Poor and content is rich, and rich enough, But riches fineless is as poor as winter To him that ever fears he shall be poor.

instruction: My gracious uncle
response: Tut, tut!

instruction: You shapeless plague of a man, please allow me to curse your cursed self for the crimes I know you've committed.
response: Fairer than tongue can name thee, let me haveSome patient leisure to excuse myself.

instruction: Okay.
response: Sir, hes rash and very sudden in choler, and haply maystrike at you.

instruction: Sometimes getting hanged saves a man from getting into a bad marriage, and as for getting kicked out, it's summer, so being homeless won't be so bad.
response: You are resolute, then?

instruction: The air here is like a fresh, sweet breath.
response: As if it had lungs, and rotten ones.

instruction: Cassio slept with her; you can ask your husband. I would be damned to hell if I didn't seek out just punishment to this end. Your husband knew all about this.
response: My husband!

instruction: My noble general, Timon is dead. His grave lies on the shore, and on that tombstone there is this epitaph, which I brought here on wax which will show you what I cannot in ignorance.
response: [Reads the epitaph] 'Here lies a wretched corse, of wretched soul bereft: Seek not my name: a plague consume you wicked caitiffs left!

instruction: Neither did I.
response: Saw you my daughter?

instruction: And you, sir. May you live longer than me and die an old man.
response: You wish me well.

instruction: Here comes the lady. Oh, a footstep as light as hers will never endure the rocky road of life. Lovers are so light that they can walk upon a spiderweb floating on a summer breeze, and still not fall. Thats how flimsy and unreal pleasure is.
response: Good even to my ghostly confessor.

instruction: Will you really?
response: Doubt it not, worthy lord.

instruction: What's the matter, my sweet Bianca? What's the matter?
response: By heaven, that should be my handkerchief!

instruction: Damn her, that lusty flirt! Oh damn her, damn her! Come on, come leave with me. I will go to figure out some quick way to kill the beautiful devil. Now you are my lieutenant.
response: I am your own for ever.

instruction: You both feel the same way?
response: Yes, if it please your majesty.

instruction: My lord, it's nothing.
response: No matter, then, who see it;I will be satisfied; let me see the writing.

instruction: Is your name Tyrrel?
response: James Tyrrel, and your most obedient subject.

instruction: My gracious uncle, tell me what I've done wrong: what law have I broken and when?
response: Even in condition of the worst degree, In gross rebellion and detested treason: Thou art a banish'd man, and here art come Before the expiration of thy time, In braving arms against thy sovereign.

instruction: "Farewell." And, since I hated to say goodbye without meaning it, I pretended to be so sorry for him that I couldn't even speak. Indeed, if the word "farewell" could lengthen hours and add years to his short banishment, I would have said volumes of "farewells." But since it would not, he got no goodbye from me.
response: He is our cousin, cousin; but 'tis doubt, When time shall call him home from banishment, Whether our kinsman come to see his friends.

instruction: Oh, Cassio, where did you get this from? This is some gift from another woman! Now I see why you haven't come to see me. Has it come to this? Well, well, well.
response: Go to, woman, Throw your vile guesses in the devils teeth From whence you have them.

instruction: Never?
response: Never, but once.

instruction: What's the matter here?
response: I bleed still,I am hurt to the death.

instruction: She was a lady who many people said looked just like me, but she was also considered beautiful. But though I can't believe all that was said about her beauty, I will publicly declare this much about her: she had a beautiful mind. Even people who were jealous of her would have to admit that. She has already been drowned in the salt water of the sea, sir, and now I seem to be drowning her memory with the salt water of my tears.
response: Pardon me, sir, your bad entertainment.

instruction: Here comes the youth with your niece. Stay away until he leaves her, and then confront him.
response: I will meditate the while upon some horrid message for a challenge.

instruction: Youre on. What does the winner get?
response: A laughter.

instruction: Did Michael Cassio know about your love for Desdemona when you were courting her?
response: He did, from first to last.Why dost thou ask?

instruction: Only if my enemies are bleeding to death, my lord, there's no food like that. I would wish such a feast on my best friend.
response: Would all those fatterers were thine enemies then,that then thou mightst kill 'em and bid me to 'em!

instruction: [To OTHELLO] What can you say about this on your own behalf?
response: Nothing, but this is so.

instruction: Did you mention that Edward's children are bastards?
response: I did, with his contract with Lady Lucy And his contract by deputy in France; Th' unsatiate greediness of his desire And his enforcement of the city wives; His tyranny for trifles; his own bastardy, As being got, your father then in France,

instruction: [He gives ROMEO poison] Put this in any kind of liquid you want, and drink it. Even if you had the strength of twenty men, it would kill you quickly.
response: [Giving money] There is they goldworse poison to men'ssouls, Doing more murder in this loathsome world, Than these poor compounds that thou mayst not sell.

instruction: Bagot, wait; dont pick it up.
response: Excepting one, I would he were the bestIn all this presence that hath moved me so.

instruction: Did you call, sir?
response: Gentlemen, there's some of worth would come aboard;I pray ye, greet them fairly.

instruction: Your Honor, the Ottomites have steered their fleet of ships toward the island of Rhodes, and added a second fleet to that one.
response: Ay, so I thought.

instruction: A king of beasts, indeed; if they had been nothing but beasts, I would still be a happy king of men. Good old queen, prepare to go to France: imagine that Im dead, and that here youre saying goodbye to me on my deathbed. During long winter nights, sit by the fire with good old people and let them tell you sad stories from long ago. And before you say goodnight, tell them my sad story, and send them crying to their beds: the logs themselves will weep and extinguish the fire, and some will cry in ashes, when they hear about the deposing of a rightful king.
response: My lord, the mind of Bolingbroke is changed:You must to Pomfret, not unto the Tower.And, madam, there is order ta'en for you;With all swift speed you must away to France.

instruction: Why "let it strike?"
response: Because that, like a jack, thou keepst the strokeBetwixt thy begging and my meditation.I am not in the giving vein today.

instruction: [To himself] I don't know how we'll afford to.
response: May it please your honour, Lord Lucius,Out of his free love, hath presented to youFour milk-white horses, trapp'd in silver.

instruction: Get out! You manly witch! Take her away, out the door! That damn busybody!
response: Not so:I am as ignorant in that as youIn so entitling me, and no less honestThan you are mad; which is enough, I'll warrant,As this world goes, to pass for honest.

instruction: I can't swear it, now that I'm a gentleman? If the peasants and the middle class can swear, I can swear, too.
response: How if it be false, son?

instruction: I'm healthy, I breathe, and I see that you're sick.
response: Now He that made me knows I see thee ill; Ill in myself to see, and in thee seeing ill.

instruction: It was the lark, who sings to greet the dawn, not the nightingale. My love, look at the streaks illuminating the clouds parting in the east. Night is over. Day is creeping over the mountain tops. I must leave in order to live. If I stay, Ill die.
response: Yon light is not daylight, I know it, I.

instruction: I'll help you. But tell me the truth, are you really not crazy? Or are you just acting?
response: Believe me, I am not.

instruction: Sweet prince, you are young and innocent, and haven't experienced the deceitfulness of the world yet. You can't perceive the truth about a man except for what he shows on the outsidewhich, God knows, hardly ever corresponds with his heart. Those uncles you wish for were dangerous. You heard their sugary words, but you couldn't see the poison in their hearts, your Grace. May God protect you from them, and from all such false friends!
response: God keep me from false friends, but they were none.

instruction: [To himself] If I do this right, I'll catch him.
response: I cannot do't without counters.

instruction: Christ, you're not listening to me! I never even dreamed of such a thing. If I did, you'd have every right to hate me.
response: Thou toldst meThou didst hold him in thy hate.

instruction: Poor Hermione! But what am I supposed to do? If I do my job of serving Leontes, then I have to poison Polixenes (who's innocent). Leontes is messed up in the head and wants everyone else to be miserable, too. If I do this, he'll promote me. But, waiteven if I could look through the history books and find thousands of men who'd killed kings and done well afterward, I still wouldn't do it. And, in fact, since not a single record would tell you such a story, it's obvious how wrong this is in every way. I have to get out of here. Whether I do it or not, I'll be hanged. Man, I could use some luck right about now! Here comes Polixenes.
response: This is strange: methinksMy favour here begins to warp.

instruction: And I know that she loves music, playing her instruments, and poetry, so I'll keep tutors in my house to instruct her. If either of you, Hortensio and Sir Gremio, know of any good tutors, then recommend them to me. I'll pay well for good teachers, and won't spare anything in giving my children a good education. So farewell.Katherine, you may stay. I have more to talk about with Bianca.
response: Why, and I trust I may go too, may I not?

instruction: You don't have to pay us back for anything; everything we give is a gift.
response: Believe me, I speak as my understanding instructs meand as mine honesty puts it to utterance.

instruction: Would you really do such a thing for all the world?
response: The worlds a huge thing.

instruction: I know his soul is in heaven, fool.
response: The more fool, madonna, to mourn for your brothers soul being in heaven.

instruction: And I love Hastings with all my heart.
response: [to QUEEN ELIZABETH] Madam, yourself is not exempt in this, Nor you, son Dorset, Buckingham, nor you.

instruction: I am a spirit indeed, as I have a soul. But my spirit wears the same earthly form that I've had since I was born. If you were only a womansince everything else about you fitsI would cry and hug you, and say "Welcome, welcome drowned Viola!"
response: My father had a mole upon his brow.

instruction: Yes, the hostess's maid.
response: Why, sir, you know no house nor no such maid, Nor no such men as you have reckoned up, As Stephen Sly and old John Naps of Greece, And Peter Turph and Henry Pimpernell, And twenty more such names and men as these, Which never were, nor no m

instruction: That's what the world is like, and every flatterer is the same. What is a friend who takes so much? Timon was so good to Lucilius, and kept him afloat with his own money. It's Timon who paid for his servants, and he never enjoys anything that does not owe itself to him. But how monstrous he looks for being so ungrateful! He denies him what rich men would give to beggars.
response: Religion groans at it.

instruction: Really? Is this true?
response: Most veritable, therefore look to t well.

instruction: That our grandmother's soul could end up inhabiting a bird.
response: What thinkest thou of his opinion?

instruction: I'm coming, don't worry. If I miss the tiniest bit of this joke, may I get boiled to death.
response: Wouldst thou not be glad to have the niggardly rascallysheep-biter come by some notable shame?

instruction: And what else?
response: Then certifies your Lordship that this night He dreamt the boar had razèd his helm.

instruction: No, sir, I live by the church.
response: Art thou a churchman?

instruction: And you're not suited for any place but hell.
response: Yes, one place else, if you will hear me name it.

instruction: You've come into my hands now, where you're likely to live.
response: The more my faultTo scape his hands where I was like to die.

instruction: You won't like it.
response: Most thankfully, my lord.

instruction: Madam, go whenever you want; leave us here.
response: Farewell, Andronicus: Revenge now goesTo lay a complot to betray thy foes.

instruction: Oh, dear lady, don't put me on the spot. I'm nothing if not overly critical.
response: Come on, assay.

instruction: My lord, no one in Venice would believe you just did thateven if I swore that I saw it with my own eyes. This is no small matter. Apologize to her. She's crying.
response: Oh, devil, devil!

instruction: Sweet Sir Andrew.
response: [To MARIA] Bless you, fair shrew.

instruction: Its the maids you rape or kill or who will have to sense it.
response: Me they shall feel while I am able to stand, andtis known I am a pretty piece of flesh.

instruction: What's the point of calling yourself a sun?
response: Rome's emperor, and nephew, break the parle; These quarrels must be quietly debated.

instruction: Here come the Lords of Ross and Willoughby, their horses bloody from spurring them on and their faces red from hurrying here.
response: Welcome, my lords.

instruction: I'll answer you by walking in. But we've been anticipated.
response: Most excellent accomplished lady, the heavens rain odors on you!

instruction: [To ANTONIO] He insists on talking.
response: Which, of he or Adrian, for a good wager, first begins to crow?

instruction: Who ordered you, Camillo?
response: By the king.

instruction: I can't get her for a cent less than a thousand gold coins.
response: Well, follow me, my masters, you shall have your money presently.

instruction: Nothing at all. The waters are rough, and I can't see a single sail between the sky and the ocean.
response: Methinks the wind hath spoke aloud at land, A fuller blast ne'er shook our battlements.

instruction: I cannot.
response: Let me entreat you.

instruction: Then you have good aim! And the woman I love is beautiful.
response: A right fair mark, fair coz, is soonest hit.

instruction: It's as you said, Timon is poor. And someone who is denied once does not have much hope of prospering.
response: Do you observe this, Hostilius?

instruction: Oh God!
response: Come, sir, I pray you, go.

instruction: As if the air was perfumed by a swamp.
response: Here is everything advantageous to life.

instruction: An hour before I came, the duchess died.
response: God for his mercy!

instruction: Here at the door. Please, call them in.
response: Ill do t, but it dislikes me.

instruction: She will invite him to dinner.
response: A bawd, a bawd, a bawd!

instruction: Oh, you cottage housewife, you. Go to bed, my God. Youll be sick tomorrow from staying up all night.
response: No, not a whit, what.

instruction: Go, Sir Andrew. Look for him in the corner of the garden as if you were a bounty hunter. As soon as you see him, draw your sword, and swear horribly as you draw it. It's often the case that a terrible swear word uttered with an arrogant tone can increase your reputation for courage better than actually fighting would. Now go!
response: Nay, let me alone for swearing.

instruction: Ill tell you before you ask me again. Ive been at a party with my enemy, where suddenly someone wounded me and was in turn wounded by me. But both of us can be cured by your holy power. I hold no hatred, blessed father, because my request will also help my enemy.
response: Be plain, good son, and homely in thy drift.Riddling confession finds but riddling shrift.

instruction: And you, fellow, go find my page, Bartholomew, and dress him up like a lady in great detail. When that's done, bring him to the drunkard's room, address him as "madam," and bow to him and treat him as if he were the lady of the house. Tell Bartholomew I said this: if he wants to please me, he will conduct himself properly, copying the way he's seen noble ladies act towards their husbands. Let him attend to the drunkard like that: speaking softly, acting humble and polite, and saying things like, "What does your Honor command your lady and humble wife to do, that she might show her devotion and love?" And then with kind embraces, tempting kisses, and his head resting on the drunkard's breast, Bartholomew should weep as if he's overjoyed to see his noble husband restored to health after believing for the last seven years that he was no better than a poor, disgusting beggar. And if the boy lacks a woman's gift for crying on command, an onion will serve the same purpose. Hide one in a handkerchief and put it close to his face, and that will certainly make his eyes water. Get this taken care of as quickly as you can, and soon I'll give you more instructions.
response: I know the boy will well usurp the grace, Voice, gait, and action of a gentlewoman.

instruction: Don't worry about that. With Emilia here as my witness, I guarantee that you will have your place back as lieutenant. I assure you, when I promise to do something out of friendship, I deliver. My husband won't have a moment of rest because I'll keep him awake all night to talk his ear off about this. I'll lecture him until our bed feels like a school room and his table a confessional. I'll mention your case no matter what he's doing. So cheer up, Cassio. I'd rather die than fail on your behalf.
response: Madam, here comes my lord.

instruction: Here, my lord.
response: That which I gave you.

instruction: Where are you taking him, my lord?Cesario, my husband, stay.
response: Husband?

instruction: [To VIOLA] And you will be my sister!
response: Is this the madman?

instruction: Her father loved me and often invited me to his house, where he would ask about the story of my life, about the battles and sieges I've fought in, and the good and bad fortune I've had. I told him everything, even from when I was a boy, and spoke about disastrous turns of events, moving events on land and on sea, and about times I barely escaped imminent death by a hair's breadth. I told him about how I was taken prisoner by my enemy and sold into slavery, about how I was ransomed back and how I traveled around through vast caverns and empty deserts, through rough, rocky quarries and hills so high they touch heaven itself. I told him about the cannibals that eat other humans, called the Anthropophagi, and about strange men whose heads grow beneath their shoulders. Desdemona was always fascinated by these stories, but household chores would call her away. She did her chores quickly so she could come back and listen voraciously to my stories again. When I had some spare time, she asked me to expand on the story of my travels and fill her in on what she had only heard parts of. I agreed, and my tales often brought her to tears. When I finished my stories, she would sigh. She would always say things like, "That was strange, very strange," or "That was pitiful, so pitiful." She wished she hadn't heard the moving stories, but also wished that God had made her that kind of a man. She thanked me and told me that if I knew anyone who loved her, all he would have to do to woo her was to tell her my stories. Picking up on her hint, I spoke to her. She loved me for the dangers I had endured, and I loved her because she pitied me for having endured them. This is the only witchcraft I have used. Here comes the woman herself. Let her testify.
response: I think this tale would win my daughter too.

instruction: I think you're right. Killed? The woman I killed? It's true, but it hurts to hear you say that. It hurts to think that. Please, don't say it often.
response: Not at all, good lady:You might have spoken a thousand things that wouldHave done the time more benefit and gracedYour kindness better.

instruction: Oh, Lord, sir, for strategy. Should this babbling gossip live to tell the tale? No, lords, noand now let me tell you my full plan. One of my countrymen, Muli, lives not too far from here. Yesterday night his wife gave birth to a child like her, as fair-skinned as you. Go to him, give the mother money, and tell them the situation: if they give us their child, it shall become the emperor's heir and take the place of mine, to calm this storm in the court and let the emperor have his son. Listen, lords, you see I have given her medicine
response: And you must needs bestow her funeral; The fields are near, and you are gallant grooms: This done, see that you take no longer days, But send the midwife presently to me.

instruction: It's fine, but it's just a painting.
response: Wrought he not well that painted it?

instruction: If a bloody head is an injury, then you've hurt me. I don't think you care at all about a bloody head.
response: Here comes Sir Toby halting.

instruction: God's greetings to you, my lady!
response: Take the fool away.

instruction: Give me evidence, or at least prove it beyond an ounce of doubtor else you'll regret it!
response: My noble lord

instruction: Are you flesh and blood? Is your heart beating? You're not a ghost? You're alive! Well, keep talking. Where were you born? And why were you called Marina?
response: Call'd MarinaFor I was born at sea.

instruction: Oh, please let me not cry if Mowbray stabs me. I'll fight with him as confident as a falcon against a defenseless little bird. My loving lord, I say goodbye to you and to my noble cousin, Lord Aumerle. I may die, but I'm not sick. No, I'm young, vigorous, and still cheerfully drawing breath. And just as I leave the best for last at the dinner table, so do I turn to you, father, whose youthful spirit lives on in me and gives me strength in the fight to come. With your blessings on my lance, may it defeat Mowbray and add new glory to the name of John of Gaunt by the deeds of his son.
response: God in thy good cause make thee prosperous!

instruction: Oh ha, oh ha! I wish Id done it! You stopped me. If you hadnt, I would have filled this island with a horde of little Calibans.
response: Abhorrèd slave, Which any print of goodness wilt not take, Being capable of all ill!

instruction: Why are you still here?
response: Which way ran he that killed Mercutio?

instruction: Your Highness just told me that I should hurry there.
response: My mind is changed.

instruction: [To himself] Very smart, boys!
response: Well, let us to the king: there is that in thisfardel will make him scratch his beard.

instruction: Ill groan twice for every step, since my journey is short, and go with a heavy heart. Lets be brief in wooing sorrow, since it will be a long marriage. One kiss shall stop our mouths, and well leave in silence; I'll give you mine [kisses her] and leave with your heart.
response: Give me mine own again; 'twere no good part To take on me to keep and kill thy heart.

instruction: Oh, they eat lords; that's how they get pregnant.
response: That's a lascivious apprehension.

instruction: Are you my son?
response: Ay, I thank God, my father, and yourself.

instruction: By the world, part of me thinks my wife is honest, and another part of me thinks she isn't. Part of me thinks you're trustworthy, and another part of me thinks you're not. I need some proof. Her reputation, which was as pure and fair as Diana's, is now besmirched and black as my face. If I can find any ropes, knives, poison, fire, or streams you can drown in, I won't endure this dishonor. If only I could be satisfied in this!
response: I see, sir, you are eaten up with passion.I do repent me that I put it to you.You would be satisfied?

instruction: Yes, I swear on my life. And he hopes that you'll join his side and help him. For that reason he sends you this good news: that this very day your enemiesthe queen's relativeswill die at Pomfret Castle.
response: Indeed, I am no mourner for that news, Because they have been still my adversaries.

instruction: Oh, then you probably prefer money. You'll choose Gremio who will keep you dressed up in fine clothes and jewelry.
response: Is it for him you do envy me so?

instruction: Lord, I have such a headache! Its pounding as if its about to break into twenty pieces. And on my other side my back is achingah, my back! Curse your heart for sending me out and about. I could get sick and die from all this journeying around!
response: I faith, I am sorry that thou art not well.Sweet, sweet, sweet Nurse, tell me, what says my love?

instruction: [Mimicking TRINCULO's voice] You lie.
response: [to TRINCULO] Thou liest, thou jesting monkey, thou!

instruction: Alas, the poor girl, I think she really does love me.
response: Now he denies it faintly, and laughs it out.

instruction: Just one more week?
response: Very sooth, to-morrow.

instruction: Oh, help!
response: Hark!

instruction: Not the daughter who scolds, anyway, I hope.
response: [as LUCENTIO] I love no chiders, sir.

instruction: [Reading]"I may command the one I love,But silence, like a knife,Cuts my heart with a bloodless wound.M.O.A.I. rules my life."
response: ( aside ) A fustian riddle!

instruction: I wish we could go straight from sixteen to twenty-three, or that we could put our lives on pause in between those ages. Ya don't get up to much at that age except knocking girls up, embarrassing your old folks, stealing, fighting[Seeing the basket on the ground] Well, whadaya know! Only no-good youngsters would be out in this weather! They've scared away two of my best sheep, and I'll be darned if the wolves don't find them before I do. If they're anywhere to be found, it's down by the sea, grazing on some weeds . . . [He looks into the basket] Lord have mercy, it's a baby, a very pretty little baby! Is it a boy or a girl, I wonder? Ah, it's a pretty one, you're a very pretty one, aren't you, with a pretty face. I may not be all that smart, but I can tell from your face your mama's a high-class lady. This has been some back-room, behind-closed-doors, under-the-covers business, huh, by two people who were hotter and heavier than you are now! You poor thing, come here. [He picks up the basket] I'll hold on 'til my son comes; I thought I heard him just nowHey there!
response: Hilloa, loa!

instruction: Sir, I'm capable of doing that, and I wouldn't use any fast-acting poison. I'd use something slow, that'd drift him off the sleep so that he wouldn't feel a thing. But I can't believe Hermione would do this; she's always been so good. I've been loyal to you
response: Make that thy question, and go rot!

instruction: Give me a torch. I dont feel like dancing. Since Im sad, I might as well carry the light.
response: Nay, gentle Romeo, we must have you dance.

instruction: Listen, theyre roaring in pain.
response: Let them be hunted soundly.

instruction: And you have mercy, too! I never did anything to offend you in my life. I never loved Cassio except in a general way, as a friend. I never gave him a token of my affection.
response: By heaven, I saw my handkerchief in s hand.

instruction: It is true. There's magic in the sewing. A prophetess who lived to the age of two hundred sewed the handkerchief while she was in a trance. The worms that made the silk were magical, and it was tinted in dye extracted from embalmed virgins' hearts.
response: Indeed?

instruction: Has it come to this?
response: Make me to see t, or at the least so prove it That the probation bear no hinge nor loopTo hang a doubt on, or woe upon thy life!

instruction: Won't King Richard let me speak with him?
response: No, my good lord.

instruction: Uncle, that is a Montagueour rival. Hes a rogue whos come here out of spite to scorn our celebration.
response: Young Romeo is it?

instruction: Hey, monster, that spiritwho you said is harmlesshas done nothing but play prank after prank on us.
response: Monster, I do smell all horse piss, at which my nose isin great indignation.

instruction: Oh, the gibbet-maker! He says that he has taken the gibbets down again, for the man wont be hanged until next week.
response: But what says Jupiter, I ask thee?

instruction: I'm a poor fellow, sir.[To himself] I know exactly who you are.
response: Nay, prithee, dispatch: the gentleman is halfflayed already.

instruction: I think your Honor means the character "Soto."
response: 'Tis very true.

instruction: I promise I'll excite those dirty-minded men as much as I can. I'll bring some home tonight.
response: Come your ways; follow me.

instruction: Shes not yet fourteen.
response: Ill lay fourteen of my teethand yet, to my teen be itspoken, I have but fourshe is not fourteen.

instruction: Come, let's go see what will happen.
response: I dare lay any money twill be nothing yet.

instruction: Sort of, sir. Even though my share is small, I hope I won't be skinned out of it.
response: O, that's the case of the shepherd's son: hang him,he'll be made an example.

instruction: He really has been badly treated.
response: Pursue him and entreat him to a peace.

instruction: I am Thaisa, who you thought was dead and drowned.
response: Immortal Dian!

instruction: He is as he is. I can't say a bad word about what he might be like. If he is not what he has the potential to be, then I wish to heaven he was!
response: What?

instruction: What was that about? Why did he hit his wife?
response: 'Faith, that was not so well.

instruction: Come on, Marcus, come; kinsmen, this is the way.[To Young LUCIUS] Sir boy, now let me see your archery; make sure you draw home and shoot straight. Terras Astraea reliquit: remember it. Marcus, justice is gone, she ran away. Sirs, pick up your weapons. You, cousins, will go around the ocean and cast your nets; perhaps you can catch her in the sea. But theres just as little justice there as on landso never mind. No, Publius and Sempronius, you must do it; dig with a fork and spade until you get to the center of the Earth. Then, when you get to Plutos underworld, give him this petition. Tell him I ask for justice and for help, and that it comes from old Andronicus, who suffers in ungrateful Rome. Oh, Rome! Well, I made you miserable when I threw the peoples votes on the tyrant Saturninus. Go, go away; and be careful everyone, and don't let a ship get by without searching it. This wicked emperor may have had her shipped her away. And then, kinsmen, we're searching for justice in vain.
response: O Publius, is not this a heavy case,To see thy noble uncle thus distract?

instruction: Don't you have anything more to say? He was your brotheris there any fire left in your old blood? You're one of Edward's seven sons: those sons were like seven vials of his blood or seven branches springing from one root. Some of these seven died naturally, some by fate; but Thomas, my dear lord, my life, my Gloucester, one vial full of Edward's sacred blood, one fine branch of the royal root, is broken and all the precious liquid spilled, hacked down and his summer leaves all faded by the hand of envy and the bloody ax of murder. Ah, Gaunt, his blood was yours! You were born from the same blood, the same womb; the same metal that molded you made him a man too! And although you live and breathe, you are dead in him. You have allowed your father's death, by seeing your poor brother die, who so strongly resembled his father. Don't fool yourself by saying this is patience, Gaunt: it's despair. In allowing your brother to be slaughtered, you've shown them how to kill you: what in poor men we call patience is just cold cowardice in noblemen. What more can I say? The best way to save yourself is to avenge my Gloucester's death.
response: God's is the quarrel; for God's substitute, His deputy anointed in His sight, Hath caused his death: the which if wrongfully, Let heaven revenge; for I may never lift An angry arm against His minister.

instruction: The king's grown bankrupt, like a broken man.
response: Reproach and dissolution hangeth over him.

instruction: And didn't I come at last to comfort you?
response: No, by the Holy Rood, thou knowst it well.

instruction: Indeed, I should have asked you that earlier.
response: Now Ill tell you without asking.

instruction: No, by the light of heaven!
response: Nor I neither, by this heavenly light.I might do t as well i' th' dark.

instruction: Romeo, get away from here. The citizens are coming, and Tybalt is dead. Dont just stand there staring. If youre caught, the Prince will execute you. Get out of here!
response: Oh, I am fortunes fool!

instruction: Ladies! What do they want?
response: There comes with them a forerunner, my lord, whichbears that office, to signify their pleasures.

instruction: Do you love me?
response: O heaven, O earth, bear witness to this sound And crown what I profess with kind event If I speak true!

instruction: We were laughing at you.
response: Who in this kind of merry fooling am nothing to you.

instruction: Then I'm not your jailer; I'm your kind hostess. Come on, I'll ask you all about your and my husband's shenanigans back when you were kids. You were cute little kings-to-be back then, weren't you?

instruction: Forgive me, madam: I am sad to say it, but what I say is true. King Richard is imprisoned by the powerful Bolingbroke. If you send a letter to London to ask for news, you'll hear the same; I'm only saying what everyone already knows.

instruction: "M.O.A.I." The hidden meaning of this part isn't like the other one, but if I force it a little, it too could refer to mefor every one of these letters is in my name. Wait, there's some more prose now.[Reading]"If this should fall into your hands, consider it well. By birth I am ranked above you, but don't be afraid of my greatness. Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon them. Your fate welcomes you. Accept it with your body and spirit. And, to prepare yourself for the upper-class life you will have soon, cast aside your lowly outer self and become a new, fresh person. Be rude to your companions, and be mean to servants. Talk loudly and often about politics, and make a habit of being unique and eccentric. The woman who sighs with love for you advises you to do this. Remember who it was who complimented your yellow stockings, and asked to see you always wearing crossed laces going up your legs. Remember her, I say. Now go. You are assured of becoming a gentleman, if you want to be. If not, just keep acting like a steward, a companion of servants, and not worthy to grasp the greatness before you. Farewell. Signed, one who would switch places with you and be your servant,The Fortunate Unfortunate"Daylight in an open field couldn't be clearer than this. This is obvious. I will act proud, I will study politics, I will insult Sir Toby, I will rid myself of lower-class acquaintances, and I will act exactly as she asked me to. I'm not fooling myself now, or letting my imagination trick mereason points to the inevitable conclusion that my lady Olivia loves me. She did compliment my yellow stockings lately, and she did praise my crossed laces, and in this she has proven that she loves me. I thank my lucky stars. I'm so happy. I will act just as she wantedI'll be proud and aloof, and put on my yellow stockings and crossed laces as quickly as I can. May God and my lucky stars be praised! And here's more, a postscript.[Reading]"You have probably figured out who I am. If you accept my love, then let me know by smiling. Your smiles look good on you. So please smile whenever you're in my presence, my dear sweetheart."Thank you God! I will smile for her. I'll do everything she wants me to.

instruction: No, no, my dream continued after I died. Oh, then the real storm of my soul began! I passed over the river of death with the help of Charon, the ferryman of the underworld, and I entered the kingdom of perpetual night. The first soul to greet me there was my great father-in-law, the Earl of Warwick, who cried aloud, "What terrible punishment for oath-breaking can this dark kingdom inflict on that false Clarence?" And then he vanished. Next a shadow like an angel came wandering by, with its bright hair spattered with blood, and it shrieked aloud, "Clarence is herefalse, fickle, lying Clarence, who stabbed me in the field at Tewkesbury. Seize him, avenging devils. Take him and torture him." With that it seemed like a legion of foul demons surrounded me and howled in my ears, and their cries were so loud and horrible that I woke up trembling. And for a long time afterward I still believed that I was in hellthat was how terrible an impression this dream made on me.
response: No marvel, lord, though it affrighted you.

instruction: The more I suffer, the angrier he seems to get. What, did he marry me to starve me? Even beggars who come to my father's door get money when they ask for it. If not, they find charity elsewhere. But I, who never learned how to beg and never needed to beg, am starved for food and dizzy with lack of sleep, kept awake by curses and fed only with arguing. And what puzzles me more than all these troubles is that he does it all under the pretense of perfect love. He acts as if I would get sick and die right away if I were to sleep or eat. Please, go and get me some food. I don't care what it is, as long as it's filling.

instruction: This behavior is a symptom of your infected nature, which has caught an unmanly melancholy due to bad luck. Why this shovel? In this place? In these tattered clothes? With these sad looks? Those who flattered you still wear silk, drink wine, and lie down on soft beds. They hug their perfumed, diseased women, and have totally forgotten that Timon even existed. Do not curse these woods by becoming a cynic. Be a flatterer and look to live off what once undid you. Bow your knee and heed every word of the men you would flatter as genius. Praise the worst parts of a man and call them excellent. That is what you used to be told. You once gave your ears to men like bartenders give their ears to the worst villains and rascals. It is only fair that you become a rascal. If you had your money again, rascals would have it. Do not act as I did to you, act like them!
response: Were I like thee, I'ld throw away myself.

instruction: [To the nuns] Take care of the lady, she's just overexcited. [To PERICLES] Early one morning, this woman washed up on shore. I opened the coffin, found some expensive jewels inside, revived her, and made her a nun here in Diana's temple.
