instruction: What does "pourquoi" mean? Does it mean to do or not do? I wish I had spent more time learning languages instead of fencing, dancing, and bear-baiting. Oh, if I'd only studied more!
response: Then hadst thou had an excellent head of hair.

instruction: Hush, Gremio. Even though you and I don't have the patience to put up with her loud cries, why, man, there are good fellows in this world, if we could only find them, who would take her with all her faultsand enough money.
response: I cannot tell.

instruction: Beautiful lady, don't curse yourself, since you are both my day and my life.
response: I would I were, to be revenged on thee.

instruction: Calm down, now.
response: Oh, blood, blood, blood!

instruction: Though I have far more reason to curse you, I don't have her energy. I'll just say "amen" to everything she said.
response: Stay, madam.

instruction: Yes, too gentle.
response: Nay, thats certain.

instruction: Let me go, sir, or I'll strike you on your head.
response: Come, come, you're drunk.

instruction: [He takes out his sword] Break it up, fools! Sheathe your swords. You dont know what youre doing.
response: What, art thou drawn among these heartless hinds?Turn thee, Benvolio.

instruction: Calm down.
response: One Varro's servant, my good lord,

instruction: Yes, with Cassio, mistress. Now come on, hold your tongue.
response: I will not charm my tongue, I am bound to speak.My mistress here lies murdered in her bed

instruction: I remember that you overthrew and replaced your brother Prospero.
response: True.

instruction: [She picks up DESDEMONA's handkerchief] I am glad I have found this handkerchief. This was Desdemona's first gift from the Moor. My stubborn husband has asked me to steal it a hundred times, but she loves it so much (for Othello asked her never to lose it) that she always keeps it with her to kiss and talk to. I'll have the embroidered pattern copied and give it to Iago. God knows what he will do with it. God only knows. I certainly don't. I just like to make him happy.
response: How now!

instruction: My father-in-law Capulet wants it that way, and Im not at all interested in slowing him down.
response: You say you do not know the ladys mind.

instruction: Ah, for our father, for our dear lord Clarence!
response: Alas for both, both mine, Edward and Clarence!

instruction: Should I go and get your nightgown?
response: No, unpin me here.This Lodovico is a proper man.

instruction: Sir Topas the priest, who is here to visit Malvolio the lunatic.
response: Sir Topas, Sir Topas, good Sir Topas, go to my lady

instruction: Why do you think so, mighty lord?
response: Because the girl should not survive her shame,And by her presence still renew his sorrows.

instruction: A blessed good evening to you. Excuse me, sir, do you know how to read?
response: Ay, mine own fortune in my misery.

instruction: Let's get going and do what he says. God sent him to help us.
response: If I had a mind to be honest, I see Fortune would not suffer me: she drops booties in my mouth.

instruction: The furious Tybalt has returned.
response: Alive in triumphand Mercutio slain!

instruction: The evil thing you warned me of is all too true. She is gone. And all that's left of my life, which I now hate, is bitterness. Now, Roderigo, where did you see her? Oh, unhappy girl! Did you say she was with the Moor? Who would want to be a father in such a situation as this? How did you know it was her? Oh, she has tricked me beyond anything I could have thought possible. What did she say to you? Get more torches, and wake up my whole family. Do you think they've gotten married?
response: Truly, I think they are.

instruction: [To TRANIO] Sir, if I may be so bold as to ask you, have you even seen Baptista's daughter yet?
response: [as LUCENTIO] No, sir, but hear I do that he hath two, The one as famous for a scolding tongueAs is the other for beauteous modesty.

instruction: [To himself] Is this one of Timon's servants? Great! I dreamt last night of expensive gifts. [To FLAMINIUS] Welcome, Flaminius. [To the SERVANT] Go get some wine for us.
response: And how does that honourable, complete, free-heartedgentleman of Athens, thy very bountiful good lordand master?

instruction: Oh comforting friar! Where is my husband? I remember well where I should be, and here I am. Where is my Romeo?
response: I hear some noise.

instruction: It's important to be healthy. What do you have under your cloak, Flaminius?
response: 'Faith, nothing but an empty box, sir; which, in my lord's behalf, I come to entreat your honour to supply; who, having great and instant occasion to use fifty talents, hath sent to your lordship to furnish him, nothing doubting your presen

instruction: Now, noble peers, we are meeting today to come to a decision about the coronation. In God's name, speak. When will the royal day be?
response: Is all things ready for the royal time?

instruction: Alas, how sad! I cant remember crying then, but now Ill cry about it all over again. This story wrings tears from my eyes.
response: Hear a little further And then Ill bring thee to the present business Which now s upon s, without the which this story Were most impertinent.

instruction: I always long to serve you, my lord.
response: You had rather be at a breakfast of enemies than adinner of friends.

instruction: The quickness and boldness with which I have taken control of my future clearly show that I married the Moor so that I could live with him. My heart is completely under his control. I saw Othello's true nature in his mind, and dedicated my soul and all my fortune to his honor and bravery. So, my dear lords, if I am left behind while he goes off to war, I will be deprived of seeing the very things I married him for. And I will have a horrible time here without him. Let me go with him.
response: Let her have your voice.

instruction: "Madam Alice," or "Madam Joan?" What's her first name?
response: Madam, and nothing else.

instruction: My lord, I promise
response: O, do not swear!Hold little faith, though thou hast too much fear.

instruction: You'll have plenty of wine soon enough, my lord.
response: In Gods name, what art thou?

instruction: Is it really possible that such bad men can exist when there are good ones too? You and your money sicken me.
response: Ha!

instruction: Either be patient and treat me with courtesy or I'll drown you out with the noisy music of war.
response: Art thou my son?

instruction: Ask me nothing. You know what you know. From now on I will never speak again.
response: What, not to pray?

instruction: Oh, dear father, dont be too harsh with him. Hes a gentleman, and not a coward.
response: What, I say?

instruction: There's no other way. She must be the one to do it. And what luck, here she is! Go and ask her.
response: How now, good Cassio, whats the news with you?

instruction: Why shouldn't Iif I had the heart to do itkill what I love, like that Egyptian thief Thyamis who murdered the woman he loved just before he died? That kind of savage jealousy sometimes seems noble. But listen to me now: since you keep denying my faithful love, and since I can guess who has forced me from my rightful place in your heart, you can go on being a cold-hearted tyrant as long as you likebut I'm going to take your darling Cesario from you. I know that you love him, and I swear that I care deeply for him as well, but I must tear him away from you because his place in your heart humiliates me.
response: And I, most jocund, apt, and willingly,To do you rest, a thousand deaths would die.

instruction: Did you call me, sir?
response: Get fire and meat for these poor men:'T has been a turbulent and stormy night.

instruction: I see that your name is Lucentio. Where are you from?
response: [as LUCENTIO] Of Pisa, sir, son to Vincentio.

instruction: I did. I brought up his earlier engagementsto Lady Lucy, who bore him a child, and Lady Bona in France. And I described the insatiable greediness of his lust, and his rape of citizens' wives. I reminded them of his harsh punishments for trivial offenses, and said that he was nothing like the duke your father, as the duke was away in France when Edward was conceived. Then I brought up your own appearance and suggested that you were the spitting image of your father, both in your looks and in your noble mind. I described all your victories in Scotland, your discipline in battle, your wisdom in peacetime, your generosity, your virtue, and your noble humility. Indeed, I didn't leave out anything that might have helped your case at all. And then when my speech came to an end, I asked those who loved their country to cry, "God save Richard, England's royal king!"
response: And did they so?

instruction: Well I wouldn't do it by light either. I might do it in the dark, though.
response: Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world?

instruction: My lord, stand back and let the coffin pass.
response: Unmannered dog, stand thou when I command!

instruction: No, you certainly won't. Now that you've gotten started, be ready for a sharp joke or two!
response: Am I your bird?

instruction: As long as heaven and nature lengthen it.
response: As long as hell and Richard likes of it.

instruction: If there's anything I didn't do correctly, know that I meant to do it better. You've repaid me for everything, and now you, Polixenes, Perdita, and Florizel have come to visit my little house. It's extremely gracious for you to be here, and I can never thank you enough.
response: O Paulina, We honour you with trouble: but we came To see the statue of our queen: your gallery Have we pass'd through, not without much content In many singularities; but we saw not That which my daughter came to look upon, The statue of h

instruction: Raise an army, my lordRome has never been under attack like this before. The Goths have arrived with an army of soldiers intent on sacking the city. They come here under the command of Lucius, old Andronicus's son, who threatens to take as much revenge as Coriolanus ever did.
response: Is warlike Lucius general of the Goths?

instruction: Master, I'm not sure if he's a merchant or a schoolmaster, but he's well-dressed and looks old and respectable enough to be Lucentio's father.
response: And what of him, Tranio?

instruction: I hope my noble lord thinks I am honest.
response: Oh, ay, as summer flies are in the shambles, That quicken even with blowing.

instruction: Come, come! I love you and your father as if I were his own subject rather than a foreigner. We expect him to visit any day now, and when he does, what will he say when he finds our little princess in poor health? He'll wish he hadn't come so far, and he'll blame my husband and me for not taking care of you like we promised to do. Go, please. Walk, be happy, bring back those rosy cheeks we all love so much! Don't worry about me; I can go home alone.
response: Well, I will go;But yet I have no desire to it.

instruction: [To LUCILIUS] Do you love this young woman?
response: Ay, my good lord, and she accepts of it.

instruction: [Offstage] Who's knocking?
response: One from the Lord Stanley.

instruction: Whos that calling so loudly?
response: Come hither, man.

instruction: I will go find him. Cassio, stay around here. If I find him in a good mood, I'll plead your case and try my hardest to get you your job back.
response: I humbly thank your ladyship.

instruction: Oh sir, such a life with such a wife will be strange! But if you have the stomach for it, then godspeedand you'll have my help in everything you need. But will you really woo this wildcat?
response: Will I live?

instruction: Get out of town! What kind of man are you?
response: One, gentlewoman, that God hath made, himself to mar.

instruction: Oh, your husband's an honest fellow. Cassio, do not doubt that I will soon have you and my husband as close as you were before.
response: Bounteous madam,Whatever shall become of Michael Cassio,Hes never anything but your true servant.

instruction: I say a devil. Do you really think, Hortensio, that any man is foolish enough to marry hell itselfeven if her father is very rich?
response: Tush, Gremio.

instruction: Don't ask to see this letter.
response: This is, to give a dog and in recompense desire my dogagain.

instruction: Thanks.
response: Here's my lord.

instruction: No, I think she is alive.
response: Alas!

instruction: It did, it did. Unfortunately, it did.
response: O serpent heart hid with a flowering face!

instruction: Huh. I don't like the looks of that.
response: What dost thou say?

instruction: See how they kiss and flirt! Sir Lucentio, take my hand. I firmly vow to stop wooing her forever. I reject her as a woman unworthy of all the time and money I have so foolishly flattered her with.
response: And here I take the like unfeignèd oathNever to marry with her, though she would entreat.Fie on her!

instruction: For shame! What kind of foolish "obedience" do you call this?
response: I would your duty were as foolish too.The wisdom of your duty, fair Bianca,Hath cost me an hundred crowns since suppertime.

instruction: Yes, I heard, but who is he?
response: Let him be the devil, an he will, I care not.

instruction: No, my good lord. My friends are in the north.
response: Cold friends to me.

instruction: No, he said such insulting, rude things against your sense of honor that it took all the goodness in me to hold back from hurting him. But I beg you to tell me, sir: are you safely married? Because you can be sure that Senator Barbantio is well-liked in the city, and has twice as much influence as the Duke. He will divorce you two, or at least subject you to whatever restraint and punishment he has the power to inflict.
response: Let him do his spite.

instruction: Trinculo, if you interrupt his story again, I swear by my hand, Ill knock out some of your teeth.
response: Why, I said nothing.

instruction: Well, that's from staying up too late. It will go away soon. Let me just tie this handkerchief tight around your head and it will feel better within an hour. [She pulls out a handkerchief]
response: Your napkin is too little,Let it alone.

instruction: May blisters cover your tongue for making a wish like that! Romeo was not born to have anything to do with shame. Shame could never be connected to him, because he is destined only to experience great and total honor. Oh, I was such a beast to condemn him.
response: Will you speak well of him that killed your cousin?

instruction: Give me a torch to carry. Let those with light hearts dance. Theres an old proverb that fits me perfectly: Ill hold a torch and watch. The game looks like fun, but Im done with it.
response: Tut, duns the mouse, the constables own word.

instruction: [To himself] She speaks. Speak again, bright angel. For tonight you are as glorious as an angel, shining above my head like a winged messenger from heaven; one who makes mortals fall onto their backs to gaze up in awe as the angel strides across the clouds and sails through the air.
response: O Romeo, Romeo!

instruction: If I have to do something, it must be something brave, for I hate politics. I'd rather be a heretic than a politician.
response: Why, then, build me thy fortunes upon the basis of valor.

instruction: Amen.
response: I thank thee.

instruction: Whether I like it or not, I'm a courtier. Can't you see my courtly clothes? Don't I walk like a courtier? Smell like one? Look down my nose at you like one? Just because I'm asking you questions, you think I'm not a courtier? I'm a courtier from head to toe and I have the power to help you to court or to stop you right there. For that reason I command you to tell me everything.
response: My business, sir, is to the king.

instruction: My freedom.
response: Before the time be out?

instruction: She hangs on me like this and cries on my shoulder and shakes and pulls me like this! Ha, ha, ha!
response: Now he tells how she plucked him to my chamber.

instruction: Go to Ventidius.
response: Prithee, be not sad,Thou art true and honest; ingeniously I speak.No blame belongs to thee.

instruction: [To the gentlemen and guards] What, do you tremble at the sight of him? Are you all afraid? Alas, I don't blame you, for you're only mortal, and mortal eyes can't stand to look at the devil.
response: Sweet saint, for charity, be not so curst.

instruction: [To CALIBAN] Now, kiss my feet.
response: But that the poor monsters in drink.

instruction: If I told you my story, you would think I was lying.
response: Prithee, speak: Falseness cannot come from thee; for thou look'st Modest as Justice, and thou seem'st a palace For the crown'd Truth to dwell in: I will believe thee, And make my senses credit thy relation To points that seem impossible; fo

instruction: Do you doubt that, Antonio?
response: How have you made division of yourself?

instruction: Foolishness, sir, wanders about the earth like the sun. It's everywhere. I'd be sorry if your master was less acquainted with foolishness than my mistress is. I think I saw you there, you wise man.
response: Nay, an thou pass upon me, Ill no more with thee.

instruction: Whos calling? My mother? Why is she up so late, or so early? What could possibly be her reason for coming to see me?
response: Why, how now, Juliet?

instruction: I pray to God that he keeps his promise!
response: I do assure you, tis against my will.

instruction: I'm an honest man who takes things literally, so I thought you had been seriously wounded. That would be worse than losing your reputation. Reputation is an empty, stupid idea. Often people get good reputations when they don't deserve it, and people lose their reputations unfairly. You haven't lost your reputation unless you consider yourself to have lost it. Come on, man, there are ways to gain back the general's favor. He's just in a bad mood, and he punished you because he had to in front of the men of Cyprus, not because he dislikes you. It's like someone beating their dog in front of a strong lion, when the dog did nothing wrong, just to show the lion that he's powerful. Ask Othello's pardon, and he'll be your friend again.
response: I will rather sue to be despised than to deceive so good a commander with so slight, so drunken, and so indiscreet an officer.

instruction: Yes, madam.
response: I am not merry, but I do beguileThe thing I am by seeming otherwise.Come, how wouldst thou praise me?

instruction: Yes, boy, Im ready.
response: You are looked for and called for, asked for and sought for, in the great chamber.

instruction: A burning torch turned upside down, with the motto, "That which lights me snuffs me out."
response: Which shows that beauty hath his power and will,Which can as well inflame as it can kill.

instruction: Did she see you at the time though, old boy? Tell me that.
response: As plain as I see you now.

instruction: If you'll sit down, Ill carry your logs for a while. Please, give them to me. Ill carry it to the pile.
response: No, precious creature.

instruction: I wish you had my bones, and I had your news. I beg you, speak. Good, good Nurse, tell me!
response: Jesu, what haste!

instruction: If love is rough with you, be rough with love. Prick love when it pricks you, and youll beat love down. Give me a mask to put over my face. A mask to cover that mask I call my face. What do I care if someone sees my flaws? Let the this mask, with its dark eyebrows, blush for me.
response: Come, knock and enter.

instruction: Iago, I realize that your affection for Cassio makes you downplay what he has done. Cassio, I love you, but you are no longer one of my officers.
response: Look, if my gentle love be not raised up!Ill make thee an example.

instruction: Yes.
response: Be a whore still: they love thee not that use thee; Give them diseases, leaving with thee their lust.

instruction: Please tell me, what is the proper punishment for someone who conspires to kill me with wicked plots and witchcraftand who has already plagued my body with hellish magic?
response: The tender love I bear your Grace, my lord, Makes me most forward in this princely presence To doom th' offenders, whosoe'er they be.

instruction: What is going on?
response: Please you, my lord, there are certainladies most desirous of admittance.

instruction: Good father, Im on my knees, begging you, please be patient and let me say just one thing.
response: Hang thee, young baggage!

instruction: [To DORSET] You go to Richmond, and may good fortune go with you.
response: Stay, yet look back with me unto the Tower.

instruction: Fool!
response: (sings) Alas, why is she so?

instruction: [Outside]Are you there, my liege? For Gods sake, let me in.
response: What shrill-voiced suppliant makes this eager cry?

instruction: Very few people, and most of them are peasants.
response: His princess, say you, with him?

instruction: May the best happiness, honor, and fortune be yours, Lord Timon!
response: Ready for his friends.

instruction: Quiet, for shame! Your outcries are no cure for confusion. Both you and heaven played a part in giving you your child. Now heaven has her, and she is better off. The part of her that came from you could not stop her from dying, but the part she got from heaven gives her eternal life. The most you could hope for her was that she marry well. Your idea of heaven for her was that she move up the social ladder. Yet now you weep, even though she has risen up above the clouds, all the way to heaven itself? Oh, by mourning her death you love your child so poorly, going crazy even though she is well and in heaven. It is better for a girl to die young while her marriage is still fresh and loving than to be married for a long time. Dry your tears, and place your rosemary on this beautiful corpse. And, as is the custom, put her in her finest clothes and carry her to church. Its human nature to shed tears, but reason says that we should be joyful.
response: All things that we ordained festival Turn from their office to black funeral.

instruction: Are you in love?
response: Out.

instruction: Here she is, sir.
response: A terrible childbed hast thou had, my dear; No light, no fire: the unfriendly elements Forgot thee utterly: nor have I time To give thee hallow'd to thy grave, but straight Must cast thee, scarcely coffin'd, in the ooze; Where, for a monume

instruction: The ship that saw all this is now docking here. It came from Verona, bringing Michael Cassio, the lieutenant of the warlike Moor Othello. The Moor himself is still at sea, having been ordered to come here to Cyprus.
response: I am glad on t.

instruction: Musicians, oh, musicians! Play Hearts Ease, Hearts Ease. Oh, if you want me to live, play Hearts Ease.
response: Why Hearts ease?

instruction: We're grateful to you, Andronicus.
response: An if your highness knew my heart, you were.

instruction: So shes sworn to live her life a virgin?
response: She hath, and in that sparing makes huge waste, For beauty, starved with her severity, Cuts beauty off from all posterity.

instruction: Is it true? Then I defy you, fate! [To BALTHASAR] You know where Im staying. Go there and get me some ink and paper, and hire some horses. I will leave here tonight.
response: I do beseech you, sir, have patience.Your looks are pale and wild, and do importSome misadventure.

instruction: Why, Belman is just as good, my lord. He was the only one to howl when the scent was lost completely, and twice today he picked it up when it was weakest. Trust me, I think he's the better dog.
response: Thou art a fool.

instruction: [To himself] That we've found you out, that's the news, and know that you're rapists.[To CHIRON and DEMETRIUS] With all respect, my grandfather has sent me to bring you the best weapons from his armory to amuse your honorable youth, for you are the hope of Rome. He told me to tell you that, and so I do. And I present you these gifts, your lordships, so that you can always be armed whenever you need toand with that, I'll go. [To himself] Armed like murderous villains, that is.
response: What's here?

instruction: Did you find him? His servants? Was Camillo with him?
response: Behind the tuft of pines I met them; neverSaw I men scour so on their way: I eyed themEven to their ships.

instruction: Why, there they go: God give joy to his lordship!
response: News, news from heaven!

instruction: In truth, I think I should do it, and then undo it after. Really, I wouldn't do such a thing for a ring, or for fine linen, or for gowns and petticoats, or for caps, or for any little gift. But for the whole world? Why, who would not cheat on her husband in order to make him king of the world? I'd risk being punished in purgatory for it.
response: Beshrew me, if I would do such a wrongFor the whole world.

instruction: To whom?
response: Marry, to

instruction: Well, sir, since you've given me permission to speak, I will. You're right to be afraid of Antiochus, since he'll either wage a public war or kill you privately. So, I recommend that you get away and don't come back until he either gets over his anger or dies. You can trust me to rule the country while you're gone; I'll be as faithful as day is to the sun.
response: I do not doubt thy faith;But should he wrong my liberties in my absence?

instruction: I forgot about Calibans evil conspiracy with his companions to kill me. The time for them to act on their plot is almost here.[To the spirits] Well done. Now leave, no more!
response: [to MIRANDA] This is strange.

instruction: I wish your obedience was just as foolish. The wisdom of your obedience, fair Bianca, has cost me a hundred crowns since dinnertime.
response: The more fool you for laying on my duty.

instruction: My legs are yellow, but I don't feel blue. The letter came to me, and its commands must be obeyed. I think I recognized the fancy Italian handwriting.
response: Wilt thou go to bed, Malvolio?

instruction: Why do you call them villains? You don't even know them.
response: Are they not Athenians?

instruction: We are amazed; and have waited a long time for you to kneel to us, because we thought ourself your lawful king.
response: The king of heaven forbid our lord the king Should so with civil and uncivil arms Be rush'd upon!

instruction: Of course, ma'am.
response: I'll leave you, my sweet lady, for a while:Pray, walk softly, do not heat your blood:What!

instruction: Will you be loyal to me, if I need your help?
response: Thou art sure of me.

instruction: What're you doing up here? If you wanna see the darnedest thing you ever did see, get yourself over here! What's the matter with you, boy?
response: I have seen two such sights, by sea and by land!but I am not to say it is a sea, for it is now thesky: betwixt the firmament and it you cannot thrusta bodkin's point.

instruction: Once again, goodbye.
response: This fellows of exceeding honesty And knows all quantities, with a learnèd spirit, Of human dealings.

instruction: Camillo, haven't you seen (but you must have, unless your glasses are as thick as a cuckold's horn) or heard (since something so obvious must have started rumors) or thought (for only someone incapable of thinking wouldn't have thought of this) that my wife is unfaithful? Unless you're planning to say "no" or you're willing to claim that you're blind, deaf, and dumb, admit that my wife's a slut who deserves every name you'd call a corner prostitute. Just say it and swear by it.
response: I would not be a stander-by to hear My sovereign mistress clouded so, without My present vengeance taken: 'shrew my heart, You never spoke what did become you less Than this; which to reiterate were sin As deep as that, though true.

instruction: [As LUCENTIO] No, sir, but I hear that he has two, the one as famous for her scolding tongue as the other is for her beauty and modesty.
response: Sir, sir, the firsts for me; let her go by.

instruction: My land extended all the way to Sparta.
response: O my good lord, the world is but a word:Were it all yours to give it in a breath,How quickly were it gone!

instruction: Come now. You can be as hot-blooded as any man in Italy. You get angry at the smallest thing, and when youre in the mood to get angry you always find something to get angry about.
response: And what to?

instruction: You said you would believe me. I won't bother you anymore; I'll stop there.
response: But are you flesh and blood?

instruction: Let's get out of here.
response: Lord Timon's mad.

instruction: What is that trumpet?
response: I warrant something from Venice.

instruction: It's not good to contradict him; let him go on.
response: Rarest sounds!

instruction: Lord Lucius and princes of the Goths, the Roman emperor sends his greetings. He understands that you are here with an army, and asks to meet with you at your father's houseif you ask for hostages to ensure your safety, they'll be immediately sent to you.
response: What says our general?

instruction: I'd prefer not to believe you, sir, on this issue. I'd rather see Hermione defended, no matter how you might be blamed for starting things.
response: Why, what need we Commune with you of this, but rather follow Our forceful instigation?

instruction: We'll go for a little walk in the garden, and then to dinner. Please, know that you are all very welcome here and make yourselves at home.
response: Signior Baptista, my business asketh haste, And every day I cannot come to woo.

instruction: Then both, or one, or anything you want.
response: Why then, the mustard without the beef.

instruction: Take that, and that. [He stabs CLARENCE] If all this won't do the job, then I'll drown you in that wine barrel.
response: A bloody deed, and desperately dispatched.

instruction: Wow, she's warm! If this is from your magic spell, your magic should be considered an art as natural as eating.
response: She embraces him.

instruction: One face, one voice, one manner of dressing, but two people! An optical illusionit both is and is not!
response: Antonio, O my dear Antonio!How have the hours racked and tortured meSince I have lost thee!

instruction: Cursed, unhappy, wretched, hateful day! The most miserable hour that ever existed in all of time. I had just one child livingone poor child, one poor and loving child. Just one thing to rejoice and find comfort in. Now cruel Death has stolen her from my sight!
response: O woe!

instruction: Who's this first knight?

instruction: Welcome, Lord Thaliard of Antioch.

instruction: Yes.
response: Then I lie not.

instruction: Welcome, my lord. Well, is my mother coming?

instruction: It's a strange truth.
response: Oh, monstrous act!

instruction: When I was banished, I was banished as Hereford; but as I come, I come for Lancaster. And, noble uncle, I ask you to be indulgent with me: you are my father, for I think in you I see old Gaunt alive. Oh, then, my father, will you allow me to stand condemned as a wandering beggar, my rights and income taken from me by force and given away to upstart spendthrifts? Why was I born? If my cousin is King of England, it must be that I am Duke of Lancaster. You have a son, Aumerle, my noble cousin; if you had died first, and he was treated this way, he would have found in his uncle Gaunt a father to fight for him. I am refused the right to wear the colors of the dukedom of Lancaster here, although I have the legal right to do so; my father's good are all liquidated and sold, and these and everything he owned are put to ill ends. What do you want me to do? I am a subject, and I challenge the law: I am denied attorneys, and therefore I've come here to claim my inheritance in person.
response: The noble duke hath been too much abused.

instruction: I've killed the girl who made my eyes blind with tears. I am as miserable as Virginius, and have a thousand times more cause than him to do this horrible thing. And now it's done.
response: What, was she ravish'd?

instruction: It was, Andronicus.
response: Your reason, mighty lord?

instruction: Oh, please! I've been around for twenty-eight years, and ever since I've known the difference between a good thing and a bad thing, I've never yet found a man who knew what was good for him. I'd trade in my humanity to become a baboon before I'd ever say that I'd drown myself for the love of some hen.
response: What should I do?

instruction: I'm sure you will also confess that you love me.

instruction: I have.
response: Face not me.

instruction: How does he love me?
response: With adorations, fertile tears, With groans that thunder love, with sighs of fire.

instruction: Most mighty king, you have no reason to doubt my friendship. I never have been false, and never will be.
response: Go then and muster men, but leave behindYour son George Stanley.

instruction: It's burnt, and so is all the rest of the meat. These servant dogs! Where is the rascal cook? You villains, how dare you bring me this meat when you know I don't like it overcooked? There, take it back, plates, cups, and all!
response: I pray you, husband, be not so disquiet.

instruction: Is it on record that he built the Tower, or is it just reported by word of mouth from generation to generation?

instruction: Its almost morning. I want to force you to go. Yet I would not let you move any further than a spoiled child would let his pet bird go. The child so loves the bird that he will not let the bird hop any more than a small distance from his hand before pulling it back by a silk thread.
response: I would I were thy bird.

instruction: Fierce warrior Lucius is general of the Goths? This news nips me like a flower covered in frost or grass beaten down with storms. Yes, now our sorrow comes; the common people love him. instruction: Should I kiss your feet?

response: Sir, at the farthest for a week or two,But then up farther, and as far as Rome,And so to Tripoli, if God lend me life.

instruction: Again, we'll sail over miles of miles of ocean as if it were nothing, hopping from country to country and region to region, by the power of your imagination. Forgive us for using the same language in all these different places where our scenes are set for the sake of simplicity. Now let me fill you in on what happens next, in the gaps between the parts of our story: Pericles takes to the unruly sea once again, along with many courtiers. He's coming to see his daughter, the light of his life. Old Escanes, Helicanus's friend whom he left in charge, is governing while he's gone. Keep that in mind, since Helicanus is going along with Pericles. With a sturdy ship and a good wind at his back, Pericles arrives in Tarsus. Just imagine his ship and all its cargo, arriving here to take Marina home, who's gone. Watch them move like ghosts and shadows for a while, and then I'll explain in words what you've just seen.
response: See how belief may suffer by foul show!

instruction: If it weren't for the fact that my fellow tutor was watching Bianca so closely, I'd think it would be good to just elope in secret. Once the ceremony was performed, it wouldn't matter if the whole world disapprovedI'd keep my wife, despite what anyone might say.

instruction: Nature would produce everything people needed, and all of it would be shared equally by all. Thered be no treason, crimes, swords, spears, knives, guns, or need for any other weapon. Without any human help, nature would grow bountiful harvests to feed my innocent people.

instruction: How great a house gone bankrupt! How great a master fallen! Everything's gone! And there's not a single friend to help him in this unfortunate time and accompany him!

instruction: Oh, heaven, how did she get out of the house? Oh, she has committed treason against her own blood! All you fathers, from now on do not trust your daughters' minds based on how you see them act. Aren't there magic charms out there that can trick and violate young maidens? Roderigo, have you read about such things?
response: Yes, sir, I have indeed.

instruction: When I wore it at your daughters wedding.
response: You cram these words into mine ears against The stomach of my sense.

instruction: I'm glad that your highness is so prepared to handle my sad news. Bolingbroke covers your fearful land with bright steel and hearts as hard as swords, like a stormy day that makes the rivers overflow and drown their shores. Old men have put on helmets to cover their thin and hairless scalps; boys with women's voices try to sound like tough men; your own archers turn their bows against you; even washer-women are taking up rusty pikes against your throne: both young and old rebel, and everything goes worse than I have power to tell.
response: Too well, too well thou tell'st a tale so ill.

instruction: Your life insurance? Youre a fool!
response: By my head, here comes the Capulets.

instruction: Aumerle, you lie; he is as honest and honorable as you are unjust. And to prove it, here I throw my gage [throws down gage] to prove it in battle: pick it up, if you dare.
response: An if I do not, may my hands rot offAnd never brandish more revengeful steelOver the glittering helmet of my foe!

instruction: Here it is.
response: Here lies my gown.

instruction: To continue this metaphorin the first chapter of his heart.

instruction: What happens if I obey you? How would the Duke like that, when he has just sent messengers here to bring me to him on urgent business of the city?

instruction: Let's at least wait until the war is over. There is no worse time to be honest than a war.

response: If to have done the thing you gave in chargeBeget your happiness, be happy then,For it is done.

response: I think thou dost.

instruction: Uncle, uncle, it's so early in the dayhow are you already so sick?

instruction: Don't mistake me, my lord; I didn't mean to erase one of your titles. To you, my lord, I come, whatever lord you are, from the most gracious regent of this land, the Duke of York, to ask why you take advantage of the king's absence to frighten our natural peace with your army.
response: I shall not need transport my words by you;Here comes his grace in person.

instruction: What, by God, may she do? She may marry a king, a bachelor, a handsome young man. Certainly, your grandmother had a worse match.

instruction: Yes and I'm still proud that I am a wasteful man still. I would still give all the wealth I havenothingto you. Get away from me.[Gesturing to a root] I wish all of Athens were in this! I would eat it!

instruction: Thank you, sir.
response: Hark you, my friend; you said you could not beg.

instruction: You wanted to be king of the island, sir?

instruction: Plant syphilis into the hollow bones of men. Kick their shins and cripple them. Steal the voice of the lawyer, so he will never ever defend a false case or voice his small disagreements. Give diseases to the priest who scolds against carnal pleasures, but doesn't behave himself. Make it so his nose rots off, so that for his private pleasures he loses the scent of public welfare. Make curly-haired scoundrels bald, and have the silly macho men in the army finally feel some pain from you. Give diseases to everyone, so that in your profession you defeat all of men's power. Here's some more gold, so that you damn even more. But let it damn you, too, and send you to your graves!
response: More counsel with more money, bounteous Timon.

instruction: [To RICHARD] Remember Grey, and let your soul despair!
response: [to RICHARD] Think upon Vaughan, and with guilty fearLet fall thy lance.

instruction: Only asked! Maybe I'll become a beggar too, and talk my way out of a whipping.

response: Richard!

instruction: Say that I did all those things out of love for her.

instruction: Tyrrel, come back to me soon after dessert, and tell me the details of their deaths. In the meantime, think about how I can reward you with whatever you desire. Farewell until then.

instruction: Its not as deep as a well or as wide as a church door, but its enough. Ask for me tomorrow, and youll find me a grave man. My time in this world is done, I believe. May a plague strike both your families. God! That dog, that rat, that mouse, that cat has scratched me to death! That braggart, that scoundrel, that villain who fights as if he learned it all from some manual!
response: I thought all for the best.

instruction: I don't need any help in mourning. I am full of sorrows to complain about. May all the earth's springs keep my eyes replenished with tears, so that when the tide is high in the ocean of my weeping, I can drown the world. Ah, for my husband, my dear lord Edward!
response: Ah, for our father, for our dear lord Clarence!

instruction: My life, sir! What do you mean? That sounds serious indeed.
response: 'Tis death for anyone in Mantua To come to Padua.

instruction: What an annoying fool this man is!

instruction: Lord Northumberland should be more respectful and say "King Richard"; God forbid such a sacred king should have to hide.

instruction: You haven't offended usyou offended the king.
response: I shall be reconciled to him again.

instruction: Oh generous sun, suck all of this rotten dampness from the ground into the air below the moon! In the case of twin brothers, who were identically conceived, housed, and born out of the same womb into a world with different fortunes, it is the one with more who scorns the one with less. Human nature is subject to many evils, and cannot bear great riches without reserving contempt for those without such luxuries. I will become a beggar and restrain the lord within me, for the senator will be scorned, the beggar honored. Whether or not one is wealthy is only a matter of luck: if an ox is born into abundant pastures, he will grow fat, whereas if he is born into scarcity, he will grow thin. Who? Who will dare to stand up for what's right and call a man a flatterer? After all, if one man is a flatterer, so is everyone, because every level in a hierarchy is flattered by the one below it. Smart men bow to rich fools. Everything is ridiculous, because we have nothing rational within our nature, just straight villainy. Thus I hate all feasts, society, and groups of people! Timon hates anything that resemblesor ishimself. All men go to hell! Earth, where are your roots?
response: Who seeks for better of thee, sauce his palate With thy most operant poison!

instruction: I can't believe it. Wait, what's that noise?
response: Ah, who shall hinder me to wail and weep, To chide my fortune and torment myself?

instruction: A bridegroom, you say? More like a groom who cleans stables, a grumbling groom, as that girl will soon discover.

instruction: Well, you might miss your chance if you keep talking.

instruction: The Lord of York is always argumentative. Uncle, you know how to bear with him.

instruction: By repeating what Ive said before. My child is still extremely young. Shes not even fourteen years old. Lets allow two more summers to pass before we consider her ready for marriage.

instruction: And he died on the day that Viola turned thirteen.
response: Oh, that record is lively in my soul!

instruction: But what does he look like, and how old is he?
response: Not yet old enough for a man, nor young enough for a boy, as a squash is before tis a peascod, or a codling when tis almost an apple.

instruction: Any assistant to a money-lender is a fool. My girlfriend is a fool, and I am her fool. When people come to borrow from your bosses, they come with sad faces and leave with happy ones, but when they come to my girlfriend's whorehouse, they come with happy faces and leave with sad ones. What's the reason for this?
response: I could render one.

What news do you have?
response: The best news is that we have safely found Our king and company.

instruction: [Whispering] Oh, quiet! I hope the mood strikes him to read it out loud!

instruction: All I want you to think about is having a good time! You know, the gods turned themselves into animals for the sake of love: Jupiter became a bull, Neptune became a ram, and the sun god, Apollo, became a shepherd just like I am now. And their transformations weren't for girls as beautiful as you. Or as puresince, you know, I'm not trying to move too quickly here. My commitment to you goes beyond physical desire.
response: O, but, sir, Your resolution cannot hold, when 'tis Opposed, as it must be, by the power of the king: One of these two must be necessities, Which then will speak, that you must change this purpose, Or I my life.

instruction: No way! Ventidius and Lucullus denied him? Has he approached me for a loan? It shows little Timon's friends loved him that all three of these men refused him, and now I must be his last hope! All his friends benefitted from the charity that leaves him without money, and now leave him for broke like doctor does a case he has deemed helpless. Must I now try to cure him of his debts? What a disgrace and an unenviable position for me! I cannot understand why he did not come to me firstI was the first to receive a gift from him, after all. Does he think so poorly of me as to believe I would be the last to repay him? No, and that way I'll have reason to laugh at him and all the others, who have called me an idiot. If Timon had approached me first, I would have three times the amount he asks for. But now, servant, go back to him and tell him this: whoever scorns me this way will never get my money.
response: Excellent!

instruction: Oh sir, I will, and I'll always consider you the savior of my life and liberty.

instruction: Mistress! Hey, mistress! Juliet! Fast asleep, I bet. Hey, lamb! Hey, lady! Hey, you sleepyhead! Hey, love, I say! Madam! Sweetheart! Hey, bride! What, not a single word to say? Enjoy this last bit of sleep now. Get a weeks worth of sleep, because tonight, I bet, Count Paris will make sure that you dont get much rest. God forgive me. Indeed, and amen. How sound asleep she is! I have to wake her. Madam, madam, madam! Yes, let the count take you in your bed. Hell wake you up, no doubt. Wont he? [Opens the bed curtains] What? Still dressed in your clothes but asleep. I must wake you. Lady, lady, lady! No, no! Help, help! My ladys dead! Oh curse the day I was born! Hey! Get me some brandy! My lord! My lady!

instruction: I went to find another poor friar from our order to accompany me. He was in this city visiting the sick. I found him, but the town health officials suspected that we had both been in a house where people were infected with the plague. They sealed up the house and refused to let us out. So I was stuck, and couldnt go to Mantua.

instruction: My lord, I've been considering the request you just asked me about.

instruction: Oh, why does the new king bring me here before I have shook off my own regal thoughts? I havent yet learned to flatter, bow, and bend my limbs: give me some time to learn how to submit. And yet I remember the tokens of respect from these men: were they not my subjects? Did they not sometimes shout all hail to me? So Judas did to Christ: but he, in twelve disciples, found that they were all truthful except for one: I, in twelve thousand, dont have one true friend. God save the king! Why doesnt anyone say amen? Do I have to be the priest and the clerk? Well then, amen. God save the king! Although Im not him: and yet amen, if heaven thinks its me. What can I do for you?
response: To do that office of thine own good willWhich tired majesty did make thee offer,The resignation of thy state and crownTo Henry Bolingbroke.

instruction: I'm contagious, even though I'm not sick? You have to explain. Listen, Camillo, I demand, if you're honorable and you believe me to be, too, that you tell me what horrible things are coming my way. Tell me how far off they are (or how close at hand). Tell me how to avoid it or, if I can't, how to deal with it.

instruction: Here, stand behind this wall. He'll come soon. Keep your sword unsheathed, and then drive it into him. Quick, quick! Don't be scared. I'll be at your side. We win or lose everything with this. Think about that, and be firmly resolved for the task.

instruction: [Approaching the tomb] Romeo! Oh no! Whats this blood staining the stony entrance of this tomb? Why are these swordsdiscolored by gore and bloodlying abandoned here, in this place of peace? [He looks inside the tomb] Romeo! Oh, hes pale! Who else? What, Paris too? And covered in blood? Ah, during what cruel hour did this sad turn of events occur? The lady moves.

instruction: What can you see out on the sea?
response: Nothing at all.

instruction: [To himself] Poor little thing, youre overwhelmed by love! These lovesick words prove it.
response: You look wearily.

instruction: Are you a register for gentlemen, Kate? Oh, put me in your good books!
response: What is your crest?

instruction: What kind of a devil are you to torment me in this way? This sort of torture is fit only for hell. Has Romeo killed himself? Say yes and that single word will poison me more terribly than could even the deadly gaze of the cockatrice. I will cease to be myself if you say that Romeo killed himself. If hes dead, say yes. If not, say no. Those little words will determine my joy or pain.
response: I saw the wound, I saw it with mine eyes God save the mark!here on his manly breast.

instruction: She may deny it, my lord, for
response: She may, Lord Rivers.

instruction: I promise you, Timon, you have moved me greatly.
response: Much!

instruction: Bad news, my lord. The Bishop of Ely has fled to Richmond. And Buckingham, backed by his army of hardy Welshmen, is on the march, his power still growing.
response: Ely with Richmond troubles me more near Than Buckingham and his rash-levied strength.

instruction: The good King Simonides, huh?
response: Ay, sir; and he deserves so to be called for hispeaceable reign and good government.

instruction: She looks something like you.
response: She is not worth thee, then.

instruction: Thank the Lord for my recovery!
response: Amen.

instruction: Cesario is your servant's name, fair princess.
response: My servant, sir!

instruction: Yes, its true. And the Kings lords were killed, as well as the Duke of Milan and his brave son, too.
response: [aside] The Duke of Milan And his more braver daughter could control thee If now twere fit to do t!

instruction: If you show me a thousand people who have wronged you, I'll take revenge on all of them.
response: Look round about the wicked streets of Rome; And when thou find'st a man that's like thyself.

instruction: Whats all this, nephew? Why are you so furious?
response: Uncle, this is a Montague, our foe,A villain that is hither come in spiteTo scorn at our solemnity this night.

instruction: All our receipts.
response: Knock me down with 'em: cleave me to the girdle.

instruction: Me, too, son.
response: So you have: but I was a gentleman born before my father; for the king's son took me by the hand, and called me brother; and then the two kings called my father brother; and then the prince my brother and the princess my sister called my fa

instruction: Then plainly tell her my loving tale.
response: Plain and not honest is too harsh a style.

instruction: Then I swear by myself
response: Thyself is self-misused.

instruction: What's the trumpet for?
response: 'Tis Alcibiades, and some twenty horse,All of companionship.

instruction: Rip pieces of my heart out.
response: Mine, fifty talents.

instruction: If you don't tell the truth because you're partial to Cassio, then you don't deserve the title of soldier.
response: Touch me not so near.

instruction: I can't wait to hear the story of your life, which must be an extraordinary thing to hear.
response: Ill deliver all, And promise you calm seas, auspicious gales, And sail so expeditious that shall catch Your royal fleet far off.

instruction: I fear that both your heart and your words are false.
response: Then never man was man true.

instruction: And hello to you, sir.
response: That defense thou hast, betake thee to t .

instruction: They say I'm like you.
response: Why that's some comfort.

instruction: I'll wear boots to make my legs look a bit thicker.
response: [Aside] But love will not be spurr'd to whatit loathes.

instruction: Is it that insulting?
response: Ay, is t, I warrant him.

instruction: Wait, Petruchio. I must go with you, for my own treasure is in Baptista's keeping too. He has my precious jewel hidden away in his fortress: his youngest daughter, the beautiful Bianca. He keeps her away from me and her other suitors, my rivals for her love, as he assumes it will be impossiblebecause of those character defects I already describedfor Katherina to ever find a husband. Baptista has therefore set down this rule: no one will have access to Bianca until Katherine the shrew gets a husband.
response: Katherine the curst!A title for a maid of all titles the worst.

instruction: No, I swear on my Christianity. If the definition of not being a whore is to preserve my virginity for my husband and not let any other foul man unlawfully touch me, then I am not one.
response: What, not a whore?

instruction: Cousin Buckingham and you wise, solemn men, since you intend to force the crown onto my headto bear its burden whether I want to or notthen I must have the patience to endure the load. But if any foul scandal or ugly criticism comes of this, the mere fact that you forced me to accept must clear me from any future blame. For God knows, and you can see, how reluctant I am to accept this responsibility.
response: God bless your Grace!

instruction: We have heard that. But that is not why we've come.
response: Good honest men!

instruction: Arm yourself, my lord. The enemy is on the battlefield.
response: Come, bustle, bustle.

instruction: With the help of God. A nobleman from Naples, Gonzalo, had been put in charge of the task of abandoning us at sea. Out of charity, he gave us some food and fresh water, as well as clothes, linens, supplies, and other necessities that have over the years been so useful. Also, he was so noble and kind, that, knowing how much I loved my books, he gave me some books from my library that I value more than my dukedom.
response: Would I mightBut ever see that man!

instruction: Send for more money, knight. If you don't end up with her in the end, then I'm a fool.
response: If I do not, never trust me, take it how you will.

instruction: Something about Cyprus, I would guess. It's an urgent matter. The warships have sent a dozen successive messengers this very night, one after the other. Many of the senators have woken up and met, and are now already at the Duke's. You've been urgently called for. When you couldn't be found at your home, the Duke sent three separate search parties to look for you.
response: 'Tis well I am found by you.I will but spend a word here in the houseAnd go with you.

instruction: I sweardamn the king's crazy delusions! We have to tell him about the baby. We will. It's a woman's job and I'll do it myself. I won't have many nice things to say to him, I can guarantee you. Emilia, please tell the queen that I'm completely at her service. If she'll trust me with her tiny newborn, I'll show it to the king and will advocate for her to the best of my ability. It's hard to say how he'll reacthe may be touched when he sees her. Sometimes the silent testimony of pure innocence can persuade when words fail.
response: Most worthy madam, Your honour and your goodness is so evident That your free undertaking cannot miss A thriving issue: there is no lady living So meet for this great errand.

instruction: Madam, Im not feeling well.
response: Evermore weeping for your cousins death?

instruction: Why, then it's time to arm myself and direct my troops.
response: What said Northumberland as touching Richmond?

instruction: You're speaking a language that I don't understand. It's as if my life were being made up by your dreams; I'll lay down what life I have now.
response: Your actions are my dreams; You had a bastard by Polixenes, And I but dream'd it.

instruction: I'm thankful to my liege, that out of kindness to me he shortens four years of my son's exile: but little good it will do me. For before six years have passed, the lamp of my life will have gone out with age; my candle will have burned down, and death's blindfold will stop me from seeing my son.
response: Why uncle, thou hast many years to live.

instruction: Sir, this chest washed up on the shore from a shipwreck.
response: Set 't down, let's look upon't.

instruction: Why, you're right. It is a puny little cap, a tart crust, a plaything, a silken pie. I love you more for not liking it.
response: Love me or love me not, I like the cap, And it I will have, or I will have none.

instruction: Master, if I ever said "loose-bodied gown," you can sew me into the skirts of it and beat me to death with a ball of brown thread. I said "a gown."
response: Proceed.

instruction: Well, theres a chance he may do her some good. Shes a stubborn good-for-nothing little whore.
response: See where she comes from shrift with merry look.

instruction: Look, here comes my girlfriend's little man.
response: [To the Fool] Why, how now, captain!

instruction: Here, my good lord.
response: Catesby, fly to the duke.

instruction: Here it is.
response: How!

instruction: I told him that your father was in Venice, and that you expected him in Padua today.
response: [as LUCENTIO] Thou'rt a tall fellow.

instruction: I don't have any great dedication to do this deed, but Iago has given me satisfactory reasons to do it. It's just one man to kill. Go forth, my sword: he will die.
response: (aside) I have rubbed this young quat almost to the sense, And he grows angry.

instruction: I wont be a part of this. Well miss our opportunity and we'll all get turned into geese or apes with wretchedly low foreheads.
response: Monster, lay to your fingers.

instruction: But how long will her sweet life last?
response: As long as heaven and nature lengthens it.

instruction: You, old manwho, like Adam, are commanded to tend this gardenhow dare you talk about this sad news so rudely? What Eve, what serpent, has persuaded you to make man fall a second time? Why do you say King Richard is deposed? Do you daresince you're little better than dustto predict his downfall? Say, where, when, and how you heard this news? Speak, you fool.
response: Pardon me, madam: little joy have I To breathe this news; yet what I say is true.

instruction: Alas, sir, how did you lose your sanity?
response: Fool, there was never a man so notoriously abused: I am as well in my wits, Fool, as thou art.

instruction: Ah, mistress bride, have we woken you up?
response: Ay, but not frighted me.

instruction: Ma'am, please stop. Anything you could possibly say would be better than that.
response: You are one of thoseWould have him wed again.

instruction: Accost her, Sir Andrew, accost her.
response: Whats that?

instruction: Now, Catesby, what does his Grace say?
response: He wonders to what end you have assembled Such troops of citizens to come to him, His grace not being warned thereof before.

instruction: I have heard a bit about your bad luck.
response: Thou saw'st them, when I had prosperity.

instruction: Hed grow useless, stinging nettle plants all over it.
response: Or docks, or mallows.

instruction: But what if it's not true, son?
response: If it be ne'er so false, a true gentleman may swear it in the behalf of his friend: and I'll swear to the prince thou art a tall fellow of thy hands and that thou wilt not be drunk; but I know thou art no tall fellow of thy hands and that t

instruction: Do you have any sense?
response: What, is he angry?

instruction: An offer, uncle, that we will accept: but we must persuade your grace to go with usto Bristol castle, which they say is held by Bushy, Bagot and their accomplicesthe caterpillars of the commonwealth, which I have sworn to weed and pluck away.
response: It may be I will go with you: but yet I'll pause; For I am loath to break our country's laws.

instruction: I'm bound for your niece, sir. I mean, she's the destination of my voyage.
response: Taste your legs, sir.

instruction: The heads of the maids or their maidenheads. Interpret my comment in whichever sense you prefer.
response: They must take it in sense that feel it.

instruction: He's a madman, and his insanity is what drives him. He gave me a jewel the other day, and now he has beaten it out of my hat. Have you seen the jewel?
response: Did you see my cap?

instruction: Oh, sweet England![Singing]King Stephen was a good fellow,He paid just a dollar for his pants,But still thought he'd been overcharged,So he called the tailor a rogue.He was a man with a good reputation,And you're just a lowly man,It's pride that brings the country down,So wrap yourself up in your old cloak.Some more wine!
response: Why, this is a more exquisite song than the other.

instruction: Isn't this strange?
response: Most rare.

instruction: A stool.
response: Thou hast hit it.

instruction: And I say, "Cousin Toby, since fortune has allowed me to marry your niece, I have the right to say this"
response: ( aside ) What, what?

instruction: [Kneeling] I kneel to add my pleas to my mother's.
response: Against them both my true joints bended be.Ill mayst thou thrive, if thou grant any grace!

instruction: So may I prosper, as I swear the same thing.
response: Take heed you dally not before your king, Lest He that is the supreme King of kings Confound your hidden falsehood, and award Either of you to be the others end.

instruction: He means, my lord, that we should be doing more, since Bolingbroke grows stronger in power and arms through our lack of opposition.
response: Discomfortable cousin!

instruction: My heart is ten times lighter than my appearance.
response: My Lord of Norfolk

instruction: My leg has been cut in half.
response: Marry, heaven forbid!

instruction: Why should this catastrophe be accompanied by so many words?
response: Windy attorneys to their clients' woes, Airy succeeders of intestate joys, Poor breathing orators of miseries, Let them have scope, though what they will impart Help nothing else, yet do they ease the heart.

instruction: I'll listen. You have no idea how much you've startled me by calling yourself "Marina."
response: The nameWas given me by one that had some power,My father, and a king.

instruction: If that's true, then I think the same thing of you.
response: Then think you right: I am not what I am.

instruction: That's good. And I have met a gentleman who has promised to help find a fine musician to teach our lady. So I won't fall even a step behind in my duty to fair Bianca, my beloved.
response: Beloved of me, and that my deeds shall prove.

instruction: It's really true, if we can believe the circumstances. You might have to see the evidence to believe it: Hermione's scarf, her necklace, letters in Antigonus's handwriting, the girl's resemblance to her mother, her obvious nobility which proves she's not a shepherdess . . . all this and more proves that she's the king's daughter. Did you see the meeting of the two kings?
response: No.

instruction: Sir, you can thank yourself for this great loss, because rather than give your daughter to a husband in Europe you instead threw her to some African. It's a good thing you'll never see her again, since then she won't be around to remind you of this awful thing you've done to her.
response: Prithee, peace.

instruction: He was a good man until the disaster that destroyed him in a single night.
response: Sir king, all hail!

instruction: Go, fellow, take them to the pantry and make them all welcome. See that they have whatever they need.
response: Sirrah, go you to Bartholmew, my page, And see him dressed in all suits like a lady.

instruction: [Whispering] Such a clever girl, I say.
response: M.O.A.I.

instruction: I don't know.
response: Is t possible?

instruction: Yes, it is still perfect now. But Im afraid it will never be perfect again.
response: Nay, gentlemen, prepare not to be gone.

instruction: Then who took my letter to Romeo?
response: I could not send ithere it is again [Gives FRIAR LAWRENCE a letter] Nor get a messenger to bring it thee,So fearful were they of infection.

instruction: Ask Desdemona to help you, and you'll surely get it back. [To CASSIO so only he can hear] Now, if it were Bianca who had the power to help you, I imagine you'd be running off to her as fast as you could!
response: Alas, poor caitiff!

instruction: [To RICHMOND] Wake up, and believe that Richard's guilty conscience will be his downfall! Wake up, and win the day!
response: [to RICHARD] Dream on thy cousins smothered in the Tower.

instruction: Fifteen years! By God, that's quite a nap. But did I not speak that entire time?
response: O, yes, my lord, but very idle words.

instruction: Please, explain them.
response: Then thus: Baptista is safe, talking with the deceivingfather of a deceitful son.

instruction: Who's there? Whose voice is it that keeps saying murder?
response: We do not know.

instruction: May they live on forever.
response: Ah, Buckingham, now do I play the touch, To try if thou be current gold indeed.Young Edward lives; think now what I would speak.

instruction: If you're just going to make fun of me, I want nothing to do with it. But wait, here's a coin for you.
response: Now Jove, in his next commodity of hair, send thee a beard!

instruction: But you give me part of your cares with your crown.
response: Your cares set up do not pluck my cares down.

instruction: What's going on? What's wrong with you, that you didn't help me? By God, the duke will hear about how you've neglected your duty.
response: I would he knew that I had saved his brother.

instruction: [Calling offstage] Hey, do you hear that? You must come greet the master and countenance the mistress.
response: Why, she hath a face of her own.

instruction: Twenty crowns.
response: Twenty crowns?Ill venture so much of my hawk or hound, But twenty times so much upon my wife.

instruction: But if she cannot love you, sir?
response: I cannot be so answerd.

instruction: Yes, she saw me as plainly as I see you now.
response: This was a great argument of love in her toward you.

instruction: What's going on here?
response: O sir, I shall be hated to report it!The prince your son, with mere conceit and fearOf the queen's speed, is gone.

instruction: Sir, very closely.
response: Being once perfected how to grant suits, How to deny them, who t' advance and who To trash for overtopping, new created The creatures that were mine, I say or changed 'em, Or else new formed 'emhaving both the key Of officer and office, set

instruction: That they are borrowed or rented and not entirely in your possession.
response: Here comes the duke.

instruction: Oh, then teach me to forget how to think!
response: By giving liberty unto thine eyes.Examine other beauties.

instruction: [As LUCENTIO] Sir Hortensio, I've often heard of your sincere affection for Bianca, and now that I've seen with my own eyes that she is unfaithful, I will join you, if you like, in rejecting Bianca and her love forever.
response: See how they kiss and court!

instruction: Now I will stand up. [He stands up and puts on his magic cloak] Sit still, and listen to the rest of the story of our sad times at sea. We arrived here on this island. I, as your teacher here, have given you a better education than other princesses get, because they have so many opportunities to spend their time more foolishly and do not pay as close attention to their teachers.
response: Heavens thank you for t!

instruction: Madam, your majesty is sad too often: you promised, when you parted with the king, to lay aside depression and be cheerful.
response: To please the king I did; to please myself I cannot do it; yet I know no cause Why I should welcome such a guest as grief, Save bidding farewell to so sweet a guest As my sweet Richard : yet again, methinks, Some unborn sorrow, ripe in fort

instruction: Have you come to make confession to Father Lawrence?
response: To answer that, I should confess to you.

instruction: Who said she didn't?
response: Thou, it seems, that calls for company to countenance her.

instruction: Will you betray your noble mistress like this?
response: My mistress is my mistress; this myself, The vigour and the picture of my youth: This before all the world do I prefer; This maugre all the world will I keep safe, Or some of you shall smoke for it in Rome.

instruction: If only I could meet that man someday.
response: Now I arise.

instruction: Well, sir, sometimes he acts like a Puritanopposed to anything fun.
response: O, if I thought that, Id beat him like a dog!

instruction: Pardon me, sir! My eyes were so blinded by the sun that everything I see looks young and fresh. But now I can see that you're a respectable old gentleman. Pardon me, please, for my crazy mistake.
response: Do, good old grandsire, and withal make knownWhich way thou travellest.

instruction: Yes, you are.
response: Oh, help, ho!

instruction: Forgive me, dear father.
response: How hast thou offended?

instruction: Oh please, let's see it. Is it for the Lord Timon?
response: If he will touch the estimate: but, for that

instruction: Rosaline whom you love so much is going to attend Capulet's traditional feast, along with all the beautiful woman of Verona. Go there and, without bias, compare her to some of the girls Ill point out to you. Ill show you that the woman you think is as beautiful as a swan is in fact as ugly as a crow.
response: When the devout religion of mine eye Maintains such falsehood, then turn tears to fires, And these, who, often drowned, could never die, Transparent heretics, be burnt for liars!

instruction: [Interrupting the song] Well, we can finish this song by ourselves later on. My father and the gentlemen are having a serious discussion and we won't bother them.[To AUTOLYCUS] Come on, bring your merchandise and follow me. Ladies, I'll buy something for both of you. Give them their first choice. Follow me, girls.
response: And you shall pay well for 'em.

instruction: And I swear by innocence and by my own youth that I have only one heart and one love to give, and no woman has ever ruled them, and never willexcept for myself. And so I'll say farewell, good madam. I'll never again try to make you pity my master's passion.
response: Yet come again, for thou perhaps mayst move That heart, which now abhors, to like his love.

instruction: And yet, one can act against one's nature
response: Ay, theres the point.

instruction: But what does Jupiter say, I ask you?
response: Alas, sir, I know not Jupiter; I never drank with himin all my life.

instruction: Iago, give these letters to the captain of my ship, and tell him to extend my greetings to the senate back in Venice. Once that is done, come find me where I will be walking atop the walls.
response: Well, my good lord, Ill do t.

instruction: [Singing] And what if you do?
response: (sings) Shall I bid him go, and spare not?

instruction: Isn't it strange to hear such godly preaching there? Did you ever dream of such a thing?
response: No, no.

instruction: But his actions suggests something he had already done.
response: 'Tis a shrewd doubt, though it be but a dream.

instruction: What kind of guy was it that robbed you?
response: A fellow, sir, that I have known to go about withtroll-my-dames; I knew him once a servant of theprince: I cannot tell, good sir, for which of hisvirtues it was, but he was certainly whipped out of thecourt.

instruction: Oh Lord!
response: [t o MARIA ] Prithee, hold thy peace.

instruction: Forgive me, sweet father.
response: Lives my sweet son?

instruction: Then Ill call you a lowly servant.
response: Then will I lay the serving creatures dagger on your pate.

instruction: Don't worry; you're in no danger here.
response: I hope so, sir; for I have about me many parcels of charge.

instruction: I am biting my thumb.
response: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?

instruction: Go see what's going on.
response: Good ancient, you are welcome.Welcome, mistress.

instruction: All you bottom-feeders, water and steam is the perfect meal for you, and I hope you never eat a better feast than this for the rest of your lives. I, who endured all your flattery, wash myself of it and return to you your wickedness.
response: Live loathed and long, Most smiling, smooth, detested parasites, Courteous destroyers, affable wolves, meek bears, You fools of fortune, trencher-friends, time's flies, Cap and knee slaves, vapours, and minute-jacks!

instruction: I'll do my best.
response: Who is the first that doth prefer himself?

instruction: Whatever you say.
response: [Aside] Lord Lucius and Lucullus?

instruction: No, indeed, I do worry about you.
response: Let us take the law of our sides.

instruction: Give up? No. That's cowardly and womanish.
response: Not to relent is beastly, savage, devilish.

instruction: There's Silvia, and Silvia is mine.
response: Turio, give back, or else embrace thy death; Come not within the measure of my wrath; Do not name Silvia thine; if once again, Verona shall not hold thee.

instruction: Oh! There he is, and we're ruined! Deny him, swear that you don't know him, or else we're completely undone.
response: Pardon, sweet father.

instruction: He doesn't and he never will.
response: Methinks a father Is at the nuptial of his son a guest That best becomes the table.

instruction: Who? Petruchio?
response: Ay, that Petruchio came.

instruction: Who is it that is knocking so hard? Where do you come from? What do you want?
response: [From within] Let me come in, and you shall know my errand.

instruction: Oh, the part of me that shared Woodstock's blood makes me long for revenge on his butchers even more than your cries of pain! But since the power to take vengeance lies in the hands of the person who's responsible (and we have no hope of getting revenge on him), we have to take it up with heaven, which, when the time comes, will make everything right again.
response: Finds brotherhood in thee no sharper spur?

instruction: [Whispering] An elaborate riddle!
response: ( aside ) Excellent wench, say I.

instruction: That Julius Caesar was a famous man. His courage aided his intelligence, and his intelligence helped him make sure that his reputation for courage outlived him. Death didn't conquer that conqueror. Now he lives on in fame, though not in life. I'll tell you what, my cousin Buckingham
response: What, my gracious lord?

instruction: Yes, but we had decided that he shouldn't die until you, Lord Mayor, were able to come and witness his execution. But this was prevented by the loving haste of our friends, Lovell and Ratcliffe, who went slightly against our intentions by executing him so soon. My lord, if you could have heard the traitor speakand fearfully confess his plots of treasonthen you could have told the citizens what you heard. However, as it is now, they're likely to misunderstand our methods of dealing with Hastings, and mourn his death.
response: But, my good lord, your Graces' words shall serve As well as I had seen and heard him speak; And do not doubt, right noble princes both, But Ill acquaint our duteous citizens With all your just proceedings in this case.

instruction: who has every intention of being your son-in-law
response: Before thee stands this fair Hesperides, With golden fruit, but dangerous to be touch'd; For death-like dragons here affright thee hard: Her face, like heaven, enticeth thee to view Her countless glory, which desert must gain; And which, wi

instruction: Ha, ha! Honest men are idiots, and people who trust me are just plain stupid. I've sold all my junk. I don't have a single fake gem, ribbon, mirror, perfume, jewelry, book, ballad, knife, belt, glove, shoelace, bracelet, or ring left in my bag. They all swarmed to be the first to buy, as if my stuff were some kind of holy charm. I took note of where they kept their wallets and remembered that for later. The shepherd's son (he's not all that bright, by the way) was so impressed with the girls' song that he wouldn't budge until he learned the tune and the words. That was the best advertisement, since it sent all the others running to me to get the song for themselves. There was nothing you could do; everyone was singing this god-awful song, non-stop. While they were all lying around, I took the opportunity to pick their pockets and rifled through most of their purses. If that old man hadn't come in and raised a ruckus about the shepherd's daughter and the prince, scaring everyone away, I wouldn't have left a single penny in anyone's wallet.
response: Nay, but my letters, by this means being thereSo soon as you arrive, shall clear that doubt.

instruction: Here comes a fresh flower. Never been picked, I can assure you.
response: Is she not a fair creature?

instruction: He and Thomas, the Earl of Surrey, were moving from troop to troop around twilight, and cheering up the soldiers.
response: So, I am satisfied.

instruction: [Offering him the crown] Courageous Richmond, you fought well. See, I took this long-stolen crown from the dead forehead of that bloody wretch. Now let it grace your brows. Wear it, enjoy it, and do much with it.
response: Great God of heaven, say amen to all!But tell me, is young George Stanley living?

instruction: If music feeds love and makes it stronger, then keep playing music. Give me too much of it, so much that it kills my longing for love and makes it go away. Play that part againit sounded melancholy. Oh, it sounded to me like a sweet breeze blowing over a bank of violets, stealing their scent and distributing it to everyone. That's enough now, no more music. It doesn't sound as sweet as it did before. Oh spirit of love, how restless you are! You make me want to accept everything, like the sea does, but then the next minute everything seems worthless, no matter how valuable it is. Love is like a hallucinationnothing else is so imaginative and extravagant.
response: Will you go hunt, my lord?

instruction: Good lords, go as quickly as you can.
response: Say, uncle Gloucester, if our brother come,Where shall we sojourn till our coronation?

instruction: Sir?
response: My purpose was for Tarsus, there to strike The inhospitable Cleon; but I am For other service first: toward Ephesus Turn our blown sails; eftsoons I'll tell thee why.

instruction: Noble Sebastian, by not seizing this opportunity youre letting this chance sleepno, dieeven while you are wide awake.
response: Thou dost snore distinctly.Theres meaning in thy snores.

instruction: Go kill yourself!
response: No, I will do nothing at thy bidding: make thyrequests to thy friend.

instruction: Oh, Rosaline knew that you were play-acting at love but did not actually understand what love means. But come with me, my young unreliable friend. Ill help you, because its possible that this marriage may transform your two families hatred into pure love.
response: Oh, let us hence.

instruction: My lord, great Buckingham's army
response: Out on you, owls!

instruction: My lord, Buckingham's supportersthe Guilfordsare armed and gathering in Kent. Every hour more men flock to join the rebels, and their army grows strong.
response: My lord, the army of great Buckingham

instruction: Your servants were fighting Capulet's servants when I arrived. I drew my sword to try to stop them. Just then, the reckless Tybalt showed up with his sword drawn. He taunted me while swinging his sword through the air, which made a hissing sound. As we fought, more and more Capulets and Montagues showed up to join the battle. Finally, the Prince came and stopped the fighting.
response: Oh, where is Romeo?
