instruction: Ha! Is that his assistant wrapped up like that? Get him, he's trying to sneak away under cover.
response: Do you hear, sir?

instruction: It echoes poignantly in the heart.
response: Thou dost speak masterly.

instruction: Sir, my mistress says to tell you that she's busy, and she cannot come.
response: How!

instruction: Come, come, give me your hands. Let me be blessed to make a happy end to this. It would be a pity if two friends like you should be enemies.
response: Bear witness, Heaven, I have my wish for ever.

instruction: My lords, since you last left me, I've had the sweetest sleep and the most hopeful dreams that ever entered someone's drowsy head. It seemed like the souls of those Richard had murdered came to my tent and encouraged me to victory. I promise you, my soul is very joyful now, remembering that beautiful dream. How late in the morning is it, lords?
response: Upon the stroke of four.

instruction: Well, sir, I could do that, but I won't right now. You're trying to trick me so I forget about persuading you regarding Cassio. Please, let Cassio be your lieutenant again.
response: Fetch me the handkerchiefmy mind misgives.

instruction: I fear that he will. Here comes Catesby again.
response: Now, Catesby, what says his grace?

instruction: Yes, both sweet and catchy, truly.
response: To hear by the nose, it is dulcet in contagion.

instruction: I won't allow it.
response: Nor I.

instruction: But pearls are white. And the old saying goes that tan men are pearls in the eyes of beautiful ladies.
response: [Aside] 'Tis true; such pearls as put outladies' eyes;For I had rather wink than look on them.

instruction: No, truly, sir. I wont take your money.
response: Go to.

instruction: It appears not, based on his message. First, he sends his regards to your noble self.
response: What then?

instruction: I see.
response: Each man to his stool, with that spur as he would to the lip of his mistress: your diet shall be in all places alike.

instruction: The grass looks so rich and healthy! It is so green!
response: The ground indeed is tawny.

instruction: Only me to state his current state of affairs, and to ask you to lend him some money.
response: I know his lordship is but merry with me;He cannot want fifty five hundred talents.

instruction: But she doesn't.
response: For what reason, I beseech you?

instruction: There you are, my lord, I've been look all over for you. My lord
response: Servilius!

instruction: You rebels and enemies of the peace, who curse your own weapons by turning them on your neighbors.
response: Who set this ancient quarrel new abroach?

instruction: Good morning to my sovereign king and queen. And I'm happy to see you too, my princely peers.
response: Happy indeed, as we have spent the day.

instruction: Oh yes, as honest as a swarm of flies all reproducing together in the blowing wind. Oh, you weed, you are so lovely and smell so sweet that it hurts to look at you. I wish you had never been born!
response: Alas, what ignorant sin have I committed?

instruction: You're exactly right, sir.
response: Well, call forth, call forth.

instruction: Leave and give us a moment.
response: Draw nearer, honest Flaminius.

instruction: Sir Lodovico?
response: He, sir.

instruction: No, for then she has no choice but to hate you, as you tried to buy her love with murder.
response: Look what is done cannot be now amended.

instruction: Truly, madam, he keeps the devil away as well as a man in his situation can. He's written a letter to you here. I should have given it to you this morning, but a madman's letters aren't gospel truth, so it doesn't matter too much when they're delivered.
response: Open t, and read it.

instruction: What, bishop, is Norfolk dead?
response: As surely as I live, my lord.

instruction: Well, behave yourself in this new spring, lest you be cropped before your time. Whats the news from Oxford? Did they hold the jousts?
response: For aught I know, my lord, they do.

instruction: Yes, I'll grant you that.
response: Dost grant me, hedgehog?

instruction: What do you mean, sir?
response: Are these, I pray you, wind instruments?

instruction: He did.
response: And speaking it, he wistly look'd on me, And who should say, 'I would thou wert the man' That would divorce this terror from my heart;' Meaning the king at Pomfret.

instruction: The devil of drunkenness decided to give up his place to the devil of anger. One vice leads to another, and now I hate myself.
response: Come, you are too severe a moraler.

instruction: What horrible things are you imagining?
response: (to EMILIA) Some of your function, mistress, Leave procreants alone and shut the door.

instruction: Why not, little man?
response: You'll kiss me hard and speak to me as ifI were a baby still.

instruction: And I now make the same oath, never to marry her even if she begs me. Damn her! See how lustfully she flirts with him!
response: Would all the world but he had quite forsworn!

instruction: Bear with me. I am hungry for revenge, and now I'm almost sick from gorging myself upon it. Your son Edwardwho killed my son Edwardis dead. Your grandson Edward is also dead, with young York thrown in as an extra, because both your grandsons didn't equal my lost son. Your Clarencewho stabbed my son Edwardis dead. And the audience to this frantic playthe adulterer Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, and Greyhave all been smothered in early graves. Richard still lives as hell's dark spy, only allowed to remain long enough to buy souls and send them down below. But soon, soon his pitiful and well-deserved end will come. The earth gapes open, hell burns, devils roar, and saints pray that he might be quickly sent from this earth. Dear God, end his life soon, so that I may live to say, "The dog is dead!"
response: O, thou didst prophesy the time would come That I should wish for thee to help me curseThat bottled spider, that foul bunch-backed toad!

instruction: Yes, I'm sorry that I didn't do a thousand more. Even now I curse the dayalthough there haven't been many such days, I admitwhen I didn't do some horrible thing like kill a man (or else plot his death), rape a girl (or plot some way to do it), accuse some innocent person, swear, make two friends hate each other, break the neck of poor cattle, or set barns and hay-stacks on fire and tell the owners to put out the flames with their tears. I've often dug up dead men from their graves and set them standing up at the doors of their dear friendswho had begun to get over their griefand used my knife to write on their skins, as on the bark of trees, "Don't let your sorrow die, although I'm dead." Ha, I've done a thousand awful things as easily as one would kill a fly, and nothing makes me sadder than not being able to do ten thousand more.
response: Bring down the devil; for he must not dieSo sweet a death as hanging presently.

instruction: Well then, just do this, noble Catesby: go and sound out Lord Hastings regarding our cause. But make it seem like a vague plan for the distant future. Find out how he feels, and summon him to the Tower tomorrow for the coronation. If he seems like he could be convinced to join us, then encourage him and explain all our reasons to him. If he's surly, cold, or unwilling, then you should act like that too, and break off the conversation. Let us know how he responds, for tomorrow we will hold two separate council meetingsone public, and one in secret, only for our supportersand you'll have lots of work to do at them.
response: Commend me to Lord William.

instruction: How does she like my conversation?
response: Ill, when you talk of war.

instruction: But you killed my children.
response: But in your daughters womb I bury them,Where, in that nest of spicery, they will breedSelves of themselves, to your recomforture.

instruction: Amen!
response: What?

instruction: Youd be a lost monster.
response: Good my lord, give me thy favor still.

instruction: Oh, no doubt it is the Bishop of Carlisle.
response: Noble lords, Go to the rude ribs of that ancient castle; Through brazen trumpet send the breath of parley Into his ruin'd ears, and thus deliver: Henry Bolingbroke On both his knees doth kiss King Richard's hand And sends allegiance and tru

instruction: If only it were so! But not until I am dead. I'll say to gold that it will be rushed to before long.
response: Throng'd to!

instruction: First, let heaven witness my speech! I swear that I make this accusation as a devoted subject, concerned for the precious safety of my prince, and free from any other grudge or personal motive. Now, Thomas Mowbray, I turn to you, and listen closely; for what I speak, I'll prove true while I live, or my soul will answer for it in heaven. You are a traitor and a villain, too good to be so and too bad to live, since the brighter and clearer the sky, the uglier it looks when clouds fill it. Once more (the more to make my point), I throw the name of "foul traitor" back down your throat; and wishif it pleased my sovereignthat before I go, I might prove what I say with my sword.
response: Let not my cold words here accuse my zeal: 'Tis not the trial of a woman's war, The bitter clamour of two eager tongues, Can arbitrate this cause betwixt us twain; The blood is hot that must be cool'd for this: Yet can I not of such tame pa

instruction: That really was not so good. But I wish I could say that was the worst he'll do.
response: Is it his use?Or did the letters work upon his bloodAnd new-create his fault?

instruction: Let's test that. If he doesn't care about it, he'll give it to us without a care. If he covets it, how will we get it?
response: True; for he bears it not about him, 'tis hid.

instruction: Right, you speak true. He loves me just as much as Hereford does. And as they love me, I love them: that's how we got here.
response: My liege, old Gaunt commends him to your majesty.

instruction: Why?
response: That I had no angry wit to be a lord.Art not thou a merchant?

instruction: Your words are so dark and threatening! Your eyes menace me. Why do you look so pale? Who sent you here? Why have you come?
response: To, to, to

instruction: Write him a letter from us. Right away, hurry now.
response: Here comes Brabantio and the valiant Moor.

instruction: Oh, barbaric animals, just like you!
response: Indeed, I was their tutor to instruct them: That codding spirit had they from their mother, As sure a card as ever won the set; That bloody mind, I think, they learn'd of me, As true a dog as ever fought at head.

instruction: Then she is well, and nothing is bad. Her body sleeps in the Capulet crypt, and her immortal soul lives with the angels. I saw her buried in her familys tomb, and rushed here to tell you the news. Oh, pardon me for bringing this bad news, but you told me it was my duty to do so, sir.
response: Is it een so?

instruction: I hear a noise from inside. Dear love, goodbyeJust a second, Nurse!Sweet Montague, be true. Stay for a moment. Ill come right back.
response: O blessèd, blessèd night!

instruction: I'll give my nephew a greater gift than that.
response: A greater gift?

instruction: First, I wish you all happiness in your sacred position. The next news is that I've sent the decapitated heads of Oxford, Salisbury, Blunt, and Kent to London; how I captured them is described in this paper.
response: We thank thee, gentle Percy, for thy pains;And to thy worth will add right worthy gains.

instruction: Then it's more likely to be fake. Please, keep it to yourself. I heard you were rude at my gates, and I let you in because I was curious about you, not to hear your message. If you're not crazy, then go. If you're sane, be quick. I am not in the mood for lively conversation.
response: Will you hoist sail, sir?

instruction: The captain who first brought me to shore has my woman's clothing. He has some legal charge against him, and is in prison because he's been sued by Malvolioa gentleman and a servant of my lady's.
response: He shall enlarge him.

instruction: Would you fall with the rest of the men and remain an animal?
response: Ay, Timon.

instruction: [Whispering] Curse him, wicked Jezebel!
response: [aside] O, peace!

instruction: Oh, let me speak!
response: Do then, but Ill not hear.

instruction: Well, then I might as well be dying of cancer and be named Judas Iscariot. My reputation is ruined. From now on, I'll stink of this. I'll walk into a room and everyone will complain about the stench. I'll be shunned and hated more than the worst epidemic in the history of the world.
response: Swear his thought over By each particular star in heaven and By all their influences, you may as well Forbid the sea for to obey the moon As or by oath remove or counsel shake The fabric of his folly, whose foundation Is piled upon his fait

instruction: Move away, here comes Lord Timon.
response: Come with me, fool, come.

instruction: I haven't been home in fifteen years. I've been away for so long, but I do want to die and be buried there. Besides, the remorseful king, my former boss, has asked me to come. I might be able to ease his suffering, which is just another reason I want to go.
response: As thou lovest me, Camillo, wipe not out the rest of thy services by leaving me now: the need I have of thee thine own goodness hath made; better not to have had thee than thus to want thee: thou, having made me businesses which none withou

instruction: But your loving advances make me very unhappy.
response: [Aside] And me, when he approacheth to your presence.

instruction: You are firm in your resolve, then?
response: Not so, neither, but I am resolved on two points.

instruction: "And another thingyou're wasting your valuable time with that foolish knight"
response: ( aside ) Thats me, I warrant you.

instruction: Whoever works to rise in the world ought to poison himself! What do we have here? Gold? Shiny yellow gold? No, I am not a false man[He keeps digging] Where are you, roots?![Looking at the gold] Just this much gold will turn the world upside down, making black white, foul fair, wrong right, low high, old young, cowardice valor. Ha, gods! Why this little thing? What is it, even? Why does this steal from you your loyal priests and servants, and steal the pillow from beneath a man's head? This yellow fiend will make and break religions, bless the lowly, and even make the leper liked, the thief as great as a senator! This little thing makes a widow get married a second time, and rejuvenates a woman so ugly that even the grossest men plagued with sores would have rejected her.[Still digging] Come on, stupid earth, whoring around beneath the feet of different nations, I will lower myself to your level and take my revenge.
response: Ha!

instruction: Stop, stop, I say! It is my lord, the Duke. It is I, a dishonored manthe banished Valentinewho welcomes Your Grace.
response: Sir Valentine!

instruction: And just in time, here comes the sweating lord.
response: Welcome, my lord.

instruction: Why, what's going on, man? What is the matter with you?
response: Not black in my mind, though yellow in my legs.

instruction: If they're still alive, I should hope that I don't need to fear them.
response: Think you, my lord, this little prating YorkWas not incensèd by his subtle motherTo taunt and scorn you thus opprobriously?

instruction: Marshal, ask that champion why he's come here bearing arms: have him state his name and swear that his cause is just.
response: In God's name and the king's, say who thou art And why thou comest thus knightly clad in arms, Against what man thou comest, and what thy quarrel: Speak truly, on thy knighthood and thy oath; As so defend thee heaven and thy valour!

instruction: This show is an incredible illusion, with enchantingly harmonious music. Am I right to think that these are spirits that we're watching?
response: Spirits, which by mine artI have from their confines called to enactMy present fancies.

instruction: [As CAMBIO] Ridiculous ass! You are not even educated enough to know why music was created in the first place. Wasn't it to refresh the mind of man after his studies and daily labor? So let me read philosophy with her, and when I take a break, you can come in with your harmony.
response: [as LITIO] Sirrah, I will not bear these braves of thine.

instruction: Kinsmen, shoot all your arrows at the palace; well annoy the prideful emperor.
response: Now, masters, draw.

instruction: Where then can I go for help, if not to you?
response: To God, the widow's champion and defence.

instruction: I'll go back to the Duke of Gloucester and tell him so.
response: Nay, I prithee stay a little.

instruction: Northumberlandthe ladder with which Bolingbroke climbs to the throneit wont be long until things go bad between you two: if he gives you half the kingdom, you wont think its enough, since you helped give him everything. And hell be suspicious of you; since you know how to depose kings and put someone else in their place, whats to stop you from doing it again? The love of wicked men turns to fear, that fear to hate, and hate to danger and deserved death.
response: My guilt be on my head, and there an end.Take leave and part; for you must part forthwith.

instruction: What is it? A spirit? Lord, its looking all around! Believe me, sir, it is very good-looking. But it must be a spirit.
response: No, wench!

instruction: No, don't say "stand up"; say "pardon" first, and "stand up" afterwards. If I were your nurse teaching you your first words, "pardon" would be the first word you knew. I never wanted to hear any word so much; say "pardon," king, and let pity teach you how: the word is short, but short is sweet, and no word is better to hear from a king.
response: Speak it in French, king; say, 'pardonne moi.'

instruction: Oh, I've been killed!
response: I am maimed for ever.

instruction: Whatever you want, enforce it with mercy and not with violence.
response: Set but thy foot Against our rampired gates, and they shall ope; So thou wilt send thy gentle heart before, To say thou'lt enter friendly.

instruction: I think you're right, my lord.
response: Then let thy love be younger than thyself, Or thy affection cannot hold the bent.

instruction: Know, then, that it is your fault that you've given up the supreme seat, the majestic throne, the powerful office of your ancestors, your position of greatness, and the glory of your royal familyall of which are yours by birth. And instead you've handed it over to a corrupted, impure usurper. You have been lost in prayer and dreamy contemplation, but now we've come to alert you of your country's needs. Our noble island wants her true self backher face has been scarred by Edward's infamous deeds, and her royal family has been corrupted by ignoble outsiders. Its majesty is almost lost in an abyss of dark forgetfulness and deep oblivion. To fix this situation, we beg your Grace to take charge and become king of this landnot Lord Protector, steward, substitute, or lowly agent to another ruler, but king, the successor of a noble bloodline. This is your right by birth, your empire, your own. It's for this purpose that I have come with these citizenswho are your devoted and loving friends, and vehemently begged me to do thisto try and convince your Grace to accept our plea.
response: I cannot tell if to depart in silence Or bitterly to speak in your reproof Best fitteth my degree or your condition.

instruction: Do your worst. This deed you have done is not justified. It is no more worthy of heaven than you were worthy of her.
response: Peace, you were best.

instruction: What, what! The lustful sons of Tamora did this horrible, bloody crime?
response: Magni Dominator poli,Tam lentus audis scelera?

instruction: No, I believe that they rise up to heaven and awaken God from his gentle, peaceful sleep.
response: What doth she say, my lord of Buckingham?

instruction: Just because you have more cares doesnt mean I have fewer. Im sad because Ive lost my cares; youre sad because youve gained cares. I still have my cares, although Ive given them away; they go along with the crown, but still they stay with me.
response: Are you contented to resign the crown?

instruction: This isn't a great favor you're doing me. It's as if I'm trying to persuade you to put on gloves when it's cold out, or to eat healthy food, or to keep yourself warm, or to do anything that's good for you. No, when I have something to ask of you that will really test your love, it will be a difficult, serious thing, one that you wouldn't grant easily.
response: I will deny thee nothing!

instruction: A very handsome man.
response: He speaks well.

instruction: Oh, Dionyza, how can someone who's starving not beg for food? Can he pretend he's not hungry until he dies? We should proclaim our grief loudly, cry out, weep, then shout even louder. Then maybe the gods will wake up from their sleep, take notice of how their creatures are suffering, and help us. I'll start by telling our sad story of the last few years, and you can help me by crying during the pauses.
response: I'll do my best, sir.

instruction: My lord, I will leave now. [He starts to leave.]
response: [aside] Why did I marry?

instruction: Because your lordship was proclaimed a traitor. But he, my lord, is gone to Ravenspurgh, to offer his service to the Duke of Hereford, and sent me over here to Berkeley, to find out how large an army the Duke of York had raised there; then he told me to meet him in Ravenspurgh.
response: Have you forgot the Duke of Hereford, boy?

instruction: [To SEBASTIAN] But the visitor trying to bring comfort to the sick wont give up on him.
response: Look hes winding up the watch of his wit.

instruction: Ignore it, you fool. Its trash.
response: Oh, ho, monster, we know what belongs to a frippery.

instruction: I promise you, sir, the pure love I feel in my heart holds back the passion I feel elsewhere.
response: Well.

instruction: And I'll tell you something funny. [To HORTENSIUS] Your lord sent you to get money, right?
response: Most true, he does.

instruction: Why, that's because you're white: your treacherous color so easily betrays what you're thinking, since you blush so easily! But this young boy has another kind of complexion. Look how the black slave smiles on his father, as if to say "old boy, I'm yours." He's your brother, lords, fed from the same blood that first gave you life, and from the womb where you were imprisoned he has emerged, too, and come to the light. No, he is your brother, certainly, although he looks like me.
response: Aaron, what shall I say unto the empress?

instruction: There arent any bushes or shrubs here to offer me even a little protection from the weather. And another storm is coming. I can hear it in the sound of the wind. That black cloud over therethe huge onelooks like a dirty leather canteen thats about to drop the liquid it contains. If it storms like it did earlier, I dont know where Ill hide. That cloud is going to drop buckets of rain. [He sees CALIBAN] What do we have here? Is it a man or a fish? Is it dead or alive? It must be a fish. He smells like a fish, an old fish, like old cheap dried fish. What a strange fish! If I were in England now, as I was once before, and had a painting that showed this fish, every single fool there would give me a silver coin just to look at it. In England, this monster would make a man rich. But, then again, any strange beast there is just like a man. English people wont give a penny to help a lame beggar, but theyll give ten to see a dead Indian. This monster here has legs like a man but fins for arms! Hes still warm, too, by my faith. I no longer think this is a fish. I think now that its a native of the island whos been struck by a lightning bolt.
response: Alas, the storm is come again!

instruction: If he'd really do anything, I'd ask him to give me your girlfriend, who he clearly doesn't care for.
response: Sir, my liege,Your eye hath too much youth in't: not a month'Fore your queen died, she was more worth such gazesThan what you look on now.

instruction: Bring in my daughter. Put her in a wedding dress good enough for the king of the gods himself. From the time she was conceived to the time she was born, Nature worked to make her beautiful specifically for this moment of marriage, and the whole universe decided to make her as perfect as possible.
response: See where she comes, apparell'd like the spring, Graces her subjects, and her thoughts the king Of every virtue gives renown to men!

instruction: That's me, sir.
response: How often have I told you 'twould be thus!How often said, my dignity would lastBut till 'twere known!

instruction: [To BRAKENBURY] Ah, jailer, jailer, I did all those things that the ghosts accused me ofand my crimes are now giving evidence against my soul. I did them all for King Edward's sake, and now see how he thanks me.
response: I will, my lord.

instruction: ArielI call you with a thought. I thank you, Ariel. Come.
response: Thy thoughts I cleave to.

instruction: Sir Topas, Sir Topas, good Sir Topas, please go to my lady
response: Out, hyperbolical fiend!

instruction: He would be rich in both, if justice had its way.
response: My heart is great; but it must break with silence,Ere't be disburden'd with a liberal tongue.

instruction: No? Why not? Richardwho is now my husbandfirst came to me when he'd hardly washed all the blood off his hands from killing both my first, angelic husband and my husband's fatherthat dear saint Henrywhose corpse I was tearfully following. Oh, I tell you, when I looked at Richard's face then, my only wish was this: "May you be cursed for making me a widow so young. When you get married, let sorrow haunt your bed, and may your wifeif any woman is crazy enough to marry yoube made more miserable by your life than you've made me by my dear husband's death." But alas! Before I could even repeat my curse again, my woman's heart stupidly fell prey to his honeyed words. I then proved the victim of my own soul's curse. From then on, I haven't had one hour of precious sleep in his bed without being awakened by the sounds of his nightmares. It doesn't matter, thoughRichard hates me because of my father, Warwick, who was his enemy. He'll soon get rid of me, no doubt.
response: Poor heart, adieu.

instruction: The only way Ill hide is if my heartsick groans produce a mist that covers me from peoples searching eyes.
response: Hark, how they knock!Whos there?Romeo, arise.

instruction: And I could sing, if crying did me any good, and you wouldn't need to cry at all.
response: But stay, here come the gardeners: Let's step into the shadow of these trees.

instruction: Dont saints have lips? And pilgrims, too?
response: Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.

instruction: I dare say, sir, that it's almost two, and it will be dinnertime before we get there.
response: It shall be seven ere I go to horse.

instruction: Why do you hope so? One had better hope he is, for he's in a hurry, and his success against the rebels requires speedso why do you hope he isn't gone yet?
response: That he, our hope, might have retired his power, And driven into despair an enemy's hope, Who strongly hath set footing in this land: The banish'd Bolingbroke repeals himself, And with uplifted arms is safe arrived At Ravenspurgh.

instruction: Oh Lord, I could stay here all night listening to good advice like yours. Education is amazing!
response: Do so, and bid my sweet prepare to chide.

instruction: First, as you know, my house in the city, which is richly furnished with gold and china, and basins and jugs for her to wash her dainty hands. My wall hangings are of purple tapestry, my ivory chests are stuffed with gold, and my cypress-wood chests are filled with quilted bedspreads, expensive clothes, bed curtains and canopies, fine linen, Turkish cushions embossed with pearl, gold Venetian draperies, pewter and brass, and everything else you could want for a house or housekeeping. Then, at my farm I have a hundred milk cows and a hundred and twenty fat oxen in my stables. Everything else I own is of a similar high value. I myself am getting on in years, I must confess, and if I should die tomorrow, all this will belong to Biancaso long as while I live she will be only mine.
response: (as LUCENTIO] That only came well in.

instruction: Aha, my lord, this prince is not an Edward! He's not lolling about in a lustful bed, but on his knees in prayer; not enjoying himself with a few prostitutes, but praying with two learned priests; not sleeping to fatten up his lazy body, but praying to enrich his attentive soul. England would be blessed to have this virtuous prince wearing its crown. But I'm afraid he won't agree to it.
response: Marry, God defend his grace should say us nay!

instruction: For reasons unknown to me, King Antiochus got angry at him (or at least Pericles thought so). Pericles, worried that he had offended the king, to show his remorse until he could rectify the situation, decided to sail away, despite it being dangerous on the seas.
response: [Aside] Well, I perceive I shall not be hang'd now, although I would; But since he's gone, the king's seas must please: He 'scaped the land, to perish at the sea.

instruction: In God's name, I'll ascend the royal throne.
response: Marry.

instruction: A bloody deed, and desperately done. I wish I could wash my hands of this sad murder, as Pontius Pilate did.
response: How now?

instruction: Who is it that cried out?
response: Oh, my dear Cassio!My sweet Cassio!

instruction: May his soul rest in peace with good old Abraham in heaven! Lords, your challenges will wait until we assign a day for the duel.
response: Great Duke of Lancaster, I come to thee From plume-pluck'd Richard; who with willing soul Adopts thee heir, and his high sceptre yields To the possession of thy royal hand: Ascend his throne, descending now from him; And long live Henry, fo

instruction: And yet you aren't limping.
response: [as LUCENTIO] Not so well appareled as I wish you were.

instruction: I say she will.And first begin with her.
response: Fie, fie!

instruction: And I'll followbecause I love Silvia more than I hate Eglamour, who accompanies her.
response: And I will follow, more to cross that loveThan hate for Silvia that is gone for love.

instruction: And the letters you'll get from King Leontes
response: Shall satisfy your father.

instruction: In a second, Im coming!
response: So thrive my soul

instruction: Health to everyone!
response: Let it flow this way, my good lord.

instruction: My masters house.
response: Indeed, I should have asked thee that before.

instruction: Oh Kate, calm down. Please, don't be angry.
response: I will be angry.

instruction: Armor? Let me see that. After all the bad luck I've had, finally, something to help me fix myself, though it is my own, and part of my heritage: this is my armor, given to me by my dead father. Just before he died he told me, "Keep it, Pericles. It's kept me safe all my life," and he pointed to this brace, "It saved me. Keep it. When you need it, though I hope the gods will protect you from such a situation, it will defend you." I've always had it with me and have always loved it. I'd never been separated from it until the storm, which doesn't spare anyone, took it in its rage. Now that it's calmed, it's given it back again. I thank you for it. I didn't lose much after all in the shipwreck, since I have my father's gift now.
response: What mean you, sir?

instruction: The Duke of Norfolk, filled with rage, is awaiting the sound of the trumpet to summon him to battle.
response: Why, then, the champions are prepared, and stayFor nothing but his majesty's approach.

instruction: With all my heart I pardon him.
response: A god on earth thou art.

instruction: Yes, though I'm also suited for one other place, if you'll let me name it.
response: Some dungeon.

instruction: Let it be mine, my most noble lord, only as my true service deserves your love.
response: Well you deserve: they well deserve to have, That know the strong'st and surest way to get.

instruction: Get down, whore!
response: Kill me tomorrowlet me live tonight!

instruction: Certainly. One of them looks exactly like a fish, and must therefore be marketable.
response: Mark but the badges of these men, my lords, Then say if they be true.

instruction: What?
response: I say, it is not lost.

instruction: I beg you, sir, have patience. You look pale and wild, as if youre about to do something reckless.
response: Tush, thou art deceived.Leave me and do the thing I bid thee do.Hast thou no letters to me from the friar?

instruction: Did you really have so much time to examine the secrets of the deep while you were dying?
response: Methought I had, and often did I strive To yield the ghost, but still the envious flood Stopped in my soul and would not let it forth To find the empty, vast, and wand'ring air, But smothered it within my panting bulk, Who almost burst to b

instruction: It is not everyone's fault that you are offended. It is not fair to avenge yourself on those that are here now for those who offended you then. Crimes should not be inherited like the land. Dear countrymen, bring in your army, but leave without your anger. Spare your hometown of Athens and those people who in your wrath you might otherwise kill. Be like a shepherd and approach the herd and separate the infected parts of it. Do not kill everyone.
response: What thou wilt,Thou rather shalt enforce it with thy smileThan hew to't with thy sword.

instruction: Indeed, it is inconsistent. My letters say a hundred and seven ships.
response: And mine a hundred and forty.

instruction: You cast a spell on me. You've beaten me to the brink of tears, giving me a fool's heart and a woman's eyes, crying before these comforting words.
response: Therefore, so please thee to return with us And of our Athens, thine and ours, to take The captainship, thou shalt be met with thanks, Allow'd with absolute power and thy good name Live with authority: so soon we shall drive back Of Alcibia

instruction: I do, so I can thank you for what you called me.
response: How?

instruction: What? I'm contagious? Don't talk about me like I'm a basilisk; I've looked at thousands of people, and they've been fine. I've never killed anyone just by sight. Camillo, I know you're a good guy, and experienced in your job, which is as much a credit to you as a fancy last name is to royalty. I'm begging you, if you know anything that I should know, please don't keep it from me.
response: I may not answer.

instruction: I understand what you are saying, but do not know how you have arrived at these conclusions.
response: I know thee too; and more than that I know thee, I not desire to know.

instruction: Oh master, master, I've been watching for so long that I'm dog-tired, but at last I spied a good old fellow coming down the hill. He'll work for our needs.
response: What is he, Biondello?

instruction: Well, sir, it's half a day's journey. And, by the way, he has a beautiful daughter and tomorrow is her birthday. Princes and knights from all over the world have come to fight in a tournament for her love.
response: Were my fortunes equal to my desires, I could wishto make one there.

instruction: Masters, are you crazy? What's wrong with you? Have you no wit, manners, or honesty, that you're making such a racket at this time of night? Are you trying to turn my lady's house into a noisy tavern by singing these rowdy songs without bothering to lower your voices at all? Do you have no respect for people, this place, or this time of night?
response: We did keep time, sir, in our catches.

instruction: The sun begins to tinge the western sky with gold. And now it's time for Silva to meet me at Friar Patrick's place. She won't be late. Lovers never miss the time they're supposed to meet upunless they arrive early if they really can't wait to see each other. Here she comes.
response: Lady, a happy evening!

instruction: Why don't you care for them?
response: For I have heard it saidThere is an art which in their piedness sharesWith great creating nature.

instruction: By Saint Anne, we'll have spiced ale too.
response: Thou'rt i' the right.

instruction: I beg you, don't get upset. Othello is just in a bad mood. State business has angered him, and he's just taking out his anger on you.
response: If twere no other

instruction: Good afternoon, beautiful lady.
response: Is it good een?

instruction: Well, sure it is.
response: [to ALONSO] Sir, we were talking that our garments seemnow as fresh as when we were at Tunis at the marriage of your daughter, who is now queen.

instruction: Oh, sir, I think she is more gracious than she was before. And yet, she is not so sure about your physical appearance.
response: What, that my leg is too long?

instruction: Come on, dun is the color of a timid mouse. Youre being as timid as a patrolman on night duty. If youre a stick stuck in the mud, well pull you outpardon me for being rude out of the love in which youre stuck up to your ears. Come on, were wasting daylight.
response: Nay, thats not so.

instruction: Thank you very much, fellow. Here, have a drink on me.
response: I thank your Honor.

instruction: Here, most gracious lord.
response: Norfolk, we must have knocks, ha, must we not?

instruction: You took what I said more seriously than I meant it.
response: [to ALONSO] Therefore, my lord

instruction: You foul, wrinkled witch, what are you doing here?
response: But repetition of what thou hast marred.That will I make before I let thee go.

instruction: I'll take care of it.
response: Alack that Leonine was so slack, so slow!

instruction: You may do that, sir. It's a wise idea. Farewell.
response: What, shall I stab him as he sleeps?

instruction: [Offstage] God have mercy on us! The ships splitting apart; the ship's splitting! Goodbye, my wife and children! Goodbye, brother! The ship's splitting, splitting, splitting!
response: Lets all sink wi' th' king.

instruction: Youre not taking one step to try to fight an enemy.
response: Rebellious subjects, enemies to peace, Profaners of this neighbor-stainèd steel!

instruction: She is awake, sir. If she happens to come this way, I'll tell her.
response: In happy time, Iago.

instruction: My lord, I won't leave you now: I'll ride to the sea with you.
response: O, to what purpose dost thou hoard thy words,That thou return'st no greeting to thy friends?

instruction: I was born in Verona. I'm old Antonio's son. My father is dead, and his fortune is mine now. I hope to see many long, good days.
response: O sir, such a life with such a wife were strange!

instruction: Well, what would you do if you were your master?
response: Make me a willow cabin at your gate And call upon my soul within the house.

instruction: You might have done this without the robe and beard. He never saw you.
response: To him in thine own voice, and bring me word how thou findest him.

instruction: Nurse!
response: Ah sir, ah sir.

instruction: Do you think it's true?
response: Very true, and but a month old.

instruction: Who's stopping you?[To MARINA] Cheer up, missy. I like your clothes.
response: Ay, by my faith, they shall not be changed yet.

instruction: If Iago said this, then let his malicious soul rot slowly day after day! He lies down to his heart. She was too attached to her filthy marriage to you to be unfaithful.
response: Ha!

instruction: Its young Romeo, right?
response: Tis he, that villain Romeo.

instruction: Then you must be a weakling, because its the weak one who gets shoved up against a wall.
response: Tis true, and therefore women, being the weaker vessels, are ever thrust to the wall.

instruction: Then learn to know him now; this is the duke.
response: My gracious lord, I tender you my service, Such as it is, being tender, raw and young: Which elder days shall ripen and confirm To more approved service and desert.

instruction: I'm the empress, but the emperor is there.
response: 'Tis he.

instruction: I think the boy is charming. He blushes.
response: I warrant you, my lord, more grace than boy.

instruction: Come, come. Let's go. Do you know what, my lord? Those lords you just mentionedRivers and Greywill be beheaded today.
response: They, for their truth, might better wear their headsThan some that have accused them wear their hats.

instruction: It's nothing but your imagination, my gracious lady.
response: 'Tis nothing less: conceit is still derived From some forefather grief; mine is not so, For nothing had begot my something grief; Or something hath the nothing that I grieve: 'Tis in reversion that I do possess; But what it is, that is not

instruction: His nurse, grandmother.
response: His nurse?

instruction: [Giving money to the FOOL] There's money from me too. If one knight gives a
response: Would you have a love song or a song of good life?

instruction: Carlisle, this is my sentence. Find some secret place, some little monastery, and enjoy your life there. So long as you live in peace, die free from conflict; for though you've always been my enemy, I know you're an honorable man.
response: Great king, within this coffin I present Thy buried fear: herein all breathless lies The mightiest of thy greatest enemies, Richard of Bordeaux, by me hither brought.

instruction: Well then, improve your fortunes through your bravery. Challenge the duke's young servant to a fight. Hurt him in eleven places. My niece will notice this, and let me assure you, no matchmaker in the world can win you a woman's love like a reputation for bravery can.
response: There is no way but this, Sir Andrew.

instruction: Which symbolizes that his love of beauty could as easily lead him to do great things as evil ones.
response: The fifth, an hand environed with clouds,Holding out gold that's by the touchstone tried;The motto thus, 'Sic spectanda fides.'

instruction: What is going on? What is the reason for this fight? Have we become Turks? Are we attacking ourselves since fate stopped the Turks from attacking us? You are Christians; stop this barbarous brawl. The next one of you to raise a fist must not value his life very much, for I'll kill whoever moves. Silence that annoying bell. It will worry everyone on the island. What is the matter, gentlemen? Honest Iago, you look sick with worry. Tell me, who started this? I command you to tell me, if you care for me.
response: I do not know.

instruction: May the gods forgive you!
response: And as for Pericles, What should he say?

instruction: Whats this? Whats this?
response: A rhyme I learned even nowOf one I danced withal.

instruction: Think about this pact he made with King Alonso, and about what happened as a consequence of it. Then tell me if Antonio can really be thought of as a brother.
response: I should sinTo think but nobly of my grandmother.Good wombs have borne bad sons.

instruction: Your grace is responsible for seeing justice done.
response: Base men by his endowments are made great.

instruction: My father had a mole on his forehead.
response: And so had mine.

instruction: Give me the mirror, and Ill read from that. No deeper wrinkles yet? Has sorrow struck so many blows against my face and not left any deeper wounds? Oh, the mirror flatters me, like my old courtiers, lying to me! Was this the face that every day under his household roof kept ten thousand servants? Was this the face that, like the sun, blinded people who looked at it? Was this the face that faced so many follies, and was at last out-faced by Bolingbroke? I see a fragile glory shining in this face, and the face is fragile too.
response: For there it is, crack'd in a hundred shivers.

instruction: I'm a virgin, although bad luck has landed me in this dump where, since I came people have paid more to get diseases than they would for medicine. Oh, may the gods set me free from this hellish place, even if it means changing me into a bird that flies through the pure air!
response: I did not think Thou couldst have spoke so well; ne'er dream'd thou couldst.

instruction: And as we walk along, I will dare to be bold with our conversationso I can make your Grace smile. [Referring to JULIA] What do you think of this boy, my lord?
response: I think the boy hath grace in him; he blushes.

instruction: She's a most beautiful lady.
response: And, Ill warrant her, full of game.

instruction: Her story is blank, my lord. She never spoke of her love, but kept her passion concealed. It tormented her from the inside, like a worm trapped inside a closed flower bud, and fed on her outer beauty until it faded. She pined away quietly and sadly, and sat like a sculpture of patience itself, smiling despite her grief. Now wasn't this true love? We men might say more and promise more, but indeed our words are stronger than our passions. We are good at making vows of love, but worse at keeping them.
response: But died thy sister of her love, my boy?

instruction: [To Bolingbroke] My gracious lord, I offer you my service, such as it is, being tender, raw and young: when I'm older, I'll be more worthy of it.
response: I thank thee, gentle Percy; and be sure I count myself in nothing else so happy As in a soul remembering my good friends; And, as my fortune ripens with thy love, It shall be still thy true love's recompense: My heart this covenant makes, m

instruction: Yes.
response: Who brought it?

instruction: I'll come and hear what reasons you have for doing this.
response: And you shall be satisfied.

instruction: Lady, I swear by the sacred moon, which outlines in silver the tops of these fruit trees
response: O, swear not by the moon, th inconstant moon, That monthly changes in her circle orb,Lest that thy love prove likewise variable.

instruction: I'm thankful for the day my falcon landed on your father's farm.
response: Now Jove afford you cause!

instruction: Well, we may meet again.
response: I fear me, never.

instruction: Urgent! Let's do it another time. Please, let's get ready to entertain these new guests.
response: [Aside] I scarce know how.

instruction: And you have to take care of the funeral; bury her in the fields nearby, for you're noble gentlemen. Once you're done with that, hurry up and send the midwife to me. Once I've taken care of the midwife and the nurse, then the ladies can gossip all they want.
response: Aaron, I see thou wilt not trust the airWith secrets.

instruction: I have such deadly poisons. But those who sell poison receive the death penalty in Mantua.
response: Art thou so bare and full of wretchedness, And fearst to die?

instruction: Then think of this hard journey as a jewel box where you can set the precious stone of your return home.
response: All places that the eye of heaven visits Are to a wise man ports and happy havens.

instruction: Tell me, furthermore: have you asked him whether he accuses the duke because he has a grudge against him, or becauselike a good subjecthe has reason to suspect him of disloyalty?
response: As near as I could sift him on that argument, On some apparent danger seen in him Aim'd at your highness, no inveterate malice.

instruction: Because I'm pretty.
response: Come, the gods have done their part in you.

instruction: [To LUCENTIO] Oh, very well, I've read the list of books for Bianca. Now listen, sir: I want them very handsomely bound, and I want them to be books of love. No matter what, don't teach her any other lessons. Do you understand me? Above and beyond what Sir Baptista pays you, I'll add on a hefty bonus. Take your book list too. And have all the books well perfumed too, for the lady they're going to is sweeter than perfume itself. What will you teach her?
response: [as CAMBIO] Whate'er I read to her, Ill plead for you As for my patron, stand you so assured, As firmly as yourself were still in place, Yea, and perhaps with more successful wordsThan you, unless you were a scholar, sir.

instruction: Both on one horse?
response: Whats that to thee?

instruction: And God bless you for that! I'll go to the queen. But please, come closer.
response: Madam, if't please the queen to send the babe,I know not what I shall incur to pass it,Having no warrant.

instruction: You speak well. I'd bet my life that, young as you are, you've fallen in love with a woman before. Am I right, boy?
response: A little, by your favor.

instruction: [As LUCENTIO] But tell us, what is your old news?
response: Why, Petruchio is coming in a new hat and an old jerkin, a pair of old breeches thrice turned, a pair of boots that have been candle cases, one buckled, another laced; an old rusty sword ta'en out of the town armory, with a broken hilt and

instruction: Oh, it will be possible. Swear by my sword that you'll do what I say.
response: I will, my lord.

instruction: No.
response: I will then give it you soundly.

instruction: [As LITIO] The bass string is fineit's this base villain that's out of tune.
response: [To LUCENTIO] In time I may believe, yet I mistrust.

instruction: The ugly, foolish women play the same tricks the pretty, wise ones do.
response: Oh, heavy ignorance!

instruction: Please come to the diner, then. Will you?
response: Go to!

instruction: [Whispering] And this will all end in an "O" as well, I hopethe "O" of a hangman's noose.
response: ( aside ) Ay, or Ill cudgel him and make him cry O!

instruction: Where is everyone?
response: Here, my lord, in readiness.

instruction: Oh! Oh! Oh!
response: Nay, lay thee down and roar,For thou hast killed the sweetest innocentThat e'er did lift up eye.

instruction: Like standing water, I'm not moving at all.
response: Ill teach you how to flow.

instruction: Five judges verified it, and there were countless witnesses.
response: Lay it by too: another.

instruction: We hope you find some peace.
response: Come with a thought.

instruction: We're soldiers, not thieves.
response: Both too; and women's sons.

instruction: "That Sir Andrew"
response: ( aside ) I knew twas I, for many do call me fool.

instruction: [Waking up and seeing them] Angels above protect the king!
response: [waking] Why, how now?

instruction: No he's not.
response: We attend his lordship; pray, signify so much.

instruction: We certainly would, then wed go hunting birds at night by luring them to us with a lantern and smacking them out of the sky with a stick.
response: [to GONZALO] Nay, good my lord, be not angry.

instruction: Ah, who can stop me from wailing and weeping, cursing my bad luck, and tormenting myself? I'll ally myself with the black despair that threatens my soul, and become my own enemy.
response: What means this scene of rude impatience?

instruction: I have no husband. Do not talk to me, Emilia. I cannot weep, and I have nothing to say besides what could be expressed by tears. Please, make my bed tonight with the sheets from my wedding night. Remember to do this, and call your husband here.
response: Heres a change indeed!

instruction: Heres a friar whos trembling, sighing, and weeping. We took this pickax and this shovel from him as he was leaving the graveyard.
response: A great suspicion.

instruction: Did you hear it, Gonzalo?
response: Upon mine honor, sir, I heard a humming, And that a strange one too, which did awake me.

instruction: If I weren't a thief, I'd be getting a promotion right about now. I brought the old man and his son onboard the prince's ship. I told him what I'd heard about the bag and whatnot, but he was too busy worrying about the shepherd's daughter (as he thought she was then), who was sea-sick, and then he got sea-sick, too because of the storm. So the mystery remained unsolved. But it's all the same to me; if I'd figured out this secret, it wouldn't have matched up very well with my other crimes. [The SHEPEHERD and the SHEPHERD'S SON come in] Here come the guys I helped against my will, already decked out in their new, fancy clothes.
response: Come, boy; I am past moe children, but thy sons anddaughters will be all gentlemen born.

instruction: No, I'll slit the nose of that villain who tried to send me to jail.
response: But do you hear, sir, have you married my daughter without asking my goodwill?

instruction: To satisfy you and because of your lovely wife's invitation.
response: Satisfy!

instruction: [To QUEEN ELIZABETH] Poor Clarence abandoned his father-in-law Warwick, yes, and broke his own oathmay Jesus pardon him!
response: [aside] Which God revenge!

instruction: Oh, its awful, awful. I thought the clouds spoke to me; the winds sang to me; and the thunder roared like the deep and terrible sound of an organall of them said the name of Prospero. Singing in a deep note, the voice spoke of the bad things I've done, and told me that, because of what I did, my son now sleeps on the ocean floor. Now I'll go search for him deeper than an anchor has ever sank, and lie with him in the mud.
response: But one fiend at a time,Ill fight their legions o'er.

instruction: I'll take you up on that promise, your Grace.
response: And look to have it yielded with all kindness.Come, let us sup betimes, that afterwardsWe may digest our complots in some form.

instruction: I think such a story would win over my daughter, too. Good Brabantio, try to make the best of a bad situation. As they say, a broken weapon is better than none at all.
response: I pray you, hear her speak.

instruction: Think what, Iago?
response: What,To kiss in private?

instruction: Oh, sir, she has no doubt of that.
response: [Aside] She needs not, when she knows it cowardice.

instruction: If I don't hate him, you can hate me. Three noblemen of the city tipped their hats to him, making a personal plea for him to make me his lieutenant. And, truly, I know my value, and I'm worthy of that position. But of course Othello is too proud to listen and wants to do things his own way, so he speaks in circles with empty talk about war-related titles. And in the end he declines their proposal and says, "Certainly, I have already chosen my lieutenant." And who did he choose? A guy who's basically a mathematician, some Michael Cassio, from Florence. A man practically cursed with a wife too beautiful (whom he can't control). A man who has never commanded a squadron on the battlefield, who knows no more about battle than an old lady. He knows only theory from books, full of the talk of old geezers in togas. His military experience is all ideas, with no real action! But, sir, Othello chose this Cassio for lieutenant, not meeven though he's seen proof of my military prowess with his own eyes at Rhodes, at Cyprus, and on all sorts of battlefields in Christian and Pagan lands. Now, my career's stalled and I'm overtaken by some number cruncheran accountant! That bean-counter will be his lieutenant before too long, and meanwhile I'll be carrying around his Moorship's flag, thank you very much.
response: By heaven, I rather would have been his hangman.

instruction: She has become a jealous woman, a jealous woman!
response: Now, fellow,What is there?

instruction: [To FERDINAND and MIRANDA] Give me your hands. May grief and sorrow always grip the heart of anyone who does not wish you joy.
response: Be it so.

instruction: I can see this has upset you a little.
response: Not a jot, not a jot.

instruction: Let me stay and comfort you, master.
response: If thou hatest curses,Stay not; fly, whilst thou art blest and free:Ne'er see thou man, and let me ne'er see thee.

instruction: Well, there's nothing I can do. That's the price of military service. Promotions are a matter of favoritismbased on whoever the leader likesnot based on rank, with a second officer stepping up to become a first officer, and so on. So now , sir, you be the judge and tell me: do I have any reason at all to love that Moor?
response: I would not follow him then.

instruction: [Waking up] The strangeness of your story made me drowsy.
response: Shake it off.

instruction: My mother had a maid named Barbary. She was in love, and the man she loved turned out to be crazy and abandoned her. She had a song called "Willow," an old song that expressed what she had experienced, and she died singing it. I can't stop thinking of that song tonight. I almost can't help but droop my head and sing it just like poor Barbary. Please, hurry.
response: Shall I go fetch your nightgown?

instruction: Oh, princely Buckingham, I'll kiss your hand as a sign of my support and friendship. May only good things come to you and your noble family! Your clothes are not stained with my family's blood, and so you don't fall under my curse.
response: Nor no one here, for curses never passThe lips of those that breathe them in the air.

instruction: Don't worry, sir, you don't need to worry about being my husband. Indeed, marriage doesn't appeal to my heart. But even if it did, the only thing I'd want to do with you is knock you on the head with a three-legged stool, scratch up your face, and make you my fool.
response: From all such devils, good Lord, deliver us!

instruction: Enough, whore! Do you dare to weep for him in front of me?
response: Oh, banish me, my lord, but kill me not!

instruction: Yes, and even more so. But I was born at that high social rank. My family lives like eagles at the top of the tallest cedar tree, playing in the wind and looking fearlessly at the sun.
response: And turns the sun to shade.

instruction: Come on, let's go to the castle. I have good news, friends! The war is over, and the Turks are all drowned. How is my old friend on this island doing? [To DESDEMONA] Honey, you will be well loved in Cyprus. They've shown nothing but love to me. Oh, my sweet lady, I keep on chattering on and going on and on about my happiness. [To IAGO] Iago, if you don't mind, go to the bay and unload my chests from the ship. Bring the ship captain to the castle. He's a good man, and his virtue demands respect. [To DESDEMONA] Come with me Desdemona. One more time: it's so nice to see you at Cyprus.
response: (to the attendant) Do thou meet me presently at the harbor.

instruction: Your assistant keeps ignoring me, and now I've been told to speak only to you.
response: Give me breath.I do beseech you, good my lords, keep on;I'll wait upon you instantly.

instruction: If we could hear with our noses, his plague-breath would be sweet indeed. But will we make the sky dance with our antics? Will we wake up the night owl and sing loud enough to make people pray? Will we?
response: An you love me, lets do t.

instruction: He's run off, and his wife has been killed.
response: 'Tis a notorious villain.

instruction: What did you say, uncle?
response: I say, without characters fame lives long.

instruction: How and why did you come here? The orchard walls are high and difficult to climb. And it will mean your death, because of who you are, if any of my family members find you here.
response: With loves light wings did I oerperch these walls, For stony limits cannot hold love out, And what love can do, that dares love attempt.

instruction: Well, I saw your niece Olivia treating the Duke's messenger better than she has ever treated me. I saw it in the garden.
response: Did she see thee the while, old boy?

instruction: We know your orders, Brakenbury. And we'll obey.
response: We are the queens abjects and must obey.

instruction: [To SAMPSON so that only he can hear] Say better. One of our masters kinsmen has just arrived.
response: [To ABRAHAM] Yes, better, sir.

instruction: They are welcome.
response: I beseech your honor,Vouchsafe me a word; it does concern you near.

instruction: May fortune and victory be yours!
response: All comfort that the dark night can affordBe to thy person, noble father-in-law.

instruction: [To RICHARD] I was, but banishment is more painful to me than dying here at home. You owe me a husband and a son.
response: The curse my noble father laid on thee When thou didst crown his warlike brows with paper, And with thy scorns drewst rivers from his eyes, And then, to dry them, gavst the duke a clout Steeped in the faultless blood of pretty Rutland His c

instruction: She's hugging him.
response: She hangs about his neck:If she pertain to life let her speak too.

instruction: Miranda. Oh, Father, Ive broken your command to me by telling him that!
response: Admired Miranda!

instruction: Ah, don't change them yet.
response: Boult, spend thou that in the town: report what a sojourner we have; you'll lose nothing by custom.

instruction: She's a noble lady.
response: She's such a one, that, were I well assured Came of a gentle kind and noble stock, I'ld wish no better choice, and think me rarely wed.

instruction: A woman, and your aunt, great king: it's me. Speak with me, take pity on me, open the door. I'm a beggar that's never begged before.
response: Our scene is alter'd from a serious thing,And now changed to 'The Beggar and the King.'My dangerous cousin, let your mother in:I know she is come to pray for your foul sin.

instruction: But to not give up, and murder me, is beastly, savage, and devilish.
response: Look behind you, my lord.

instruction: So they are. It's too bad that this is how it isbeauty starts to die just as it reaches its perfection!
response: O, fellow, come, the song we had last night.

instruction: Yes, sir, and he deserves it. He rules with peace and good government.
response: He is a happy king, since he gains from his subjectsthe name of good by his government.

instruction: How did you sleep, my lord?
response: The sweetest sleep and fairest-boding dreams That ever entered in a drowsy head Have I since your departure had, my lords.

instruction: Here comes Romeo, here comes Romeo.
response: Without his roe, like a dried herring.

instruction: Obviously that was when, after three long, bitter months, I convinced you to give me your hand in marriage. At that moment, you said, "I am yours forever."
response: 'Tis grace indeed.Why, lo you now, I have spoke to the purpose twice:The one for ever earn'd a royal husband;The other for some while a friend.

instruction: Madam, Duke Orsino's young gentleman has returned. I had to beg him to come back, but he is here now and ready to see you when you're ready.
response: Ill come to him.

instruction: Taste it first, as you always do.
response: My lord, I dare not: Sir Pierce of Exton, wholately came from the king, commands the contrary.

instruction: Now, before God, it is a shame that he, a royal prince, is wronged in this way, as are so many more of noble blood in this declining land. The king is not himself, but directed by flatterers; and they will tell him lies about us to make him enemies to us, our lives, our children, and our heirs.
response: The commons hath he pill'd with grievous taxes, And quite lost their hearts: the nobles hath he fined For ancient quarrels, and quite lost their hearts.

instruction: If you do want to fight, sir, then Im up for it. My master is as good as yours.
response: No better.

instruction: What? You're a king's daughter named Marina?
response: You said you would believe me;But, not to be a troubler of your peace,I will end here.

instruction: No, master, in whom doubt and suspicion have taken hold too late. You should have feared lies when you threw feasts with your wealth, but your suspicion comes when you are most poor. What I show you is true love, duty, and enthusiasm for your outstanding mind, along with care for your wellbeing. Believe me, my lord, that any advantage I could gain now I would exchange for one wish: that you had the power and wealth to make yourself rich. That would be the return for my admiration.
response: Look thee, 'tis so!

instruction: [To himself] Its working![To FERDINAND] Come on.[To himself] Youve done well, Ariel.[To FERDINAND] Follow me.[To ARIEL] Listen to what else you should do for me.
response: [to FERDINAND] Be of comfort.

instruction: Yes, my good lord. Everyone here in the king's presence has gone totally pale.
response: Is Clarence dead?

instruction: Dont tell me that. When the wine barrel is empty, well drink water. But we won't drink even a drop of water before then. Therefore, raise the bottle and drink. [To CALIBAN] Servant-monster, drink a toast to me.
response: Servant-monster?

instruction: Spoken like a brave man who values his reputation. Come, shall we get to work?
response: Take him on the costard with the hilts of thy sword, and then throw him into the malmsey butt in the next room.

instruction: Where is he?
response: Here.

instruction: You won't win any more money from me with this third roll of the dice. But if you'll tell your lady that I'm here to speak with her, and bring her along with you when you return, then you might wake up my generosity.
response: Marry, sir, lullaby to your bounty till I come again.

instruction: Oh, Paulina, you know I'd do anything for you. But I came to see the statue of my queen. But I've passed through your entire gallerywhich was great, and allwithout my daughter seeing the statue of her mother that she came to see.
response: As she lived peerless, So her dead likeness, I do well believe, Excels whatever yet you look'd upon Or hand of man hath done; therefore I keep it Lonely, apart.

instruction: Then you lie: look at your last poem, in which you pretended that you think Timon is a worthy man.
response: That's not feigned; he is so.

instruction: Bring us to the cave. We promised the Athenians we would speak to Timon.
response: At all times alike Men are not still the same: 'twas time and griefs That framed him thus: time, with his fairer hand, Offering the fortunes of his former days, The former man may make him.

instruction: Oh, deadly sin! Oh, you rude, unthankful child! Your crime is punishable by death, but the Prince in his kindness defended you, and bypassed the law by replacing death with banishment. This is mercy, but you cant see it.
response: Tis torture and not mercy.

instruction: And I can cut the meat to go with your capers.
response: And I think I have the back-trick simply as strong as any man in Illyria.

instruction: [As LUCENTIO] Of all the craziest pairings, I've never seen one like this.
response: [as CAMBIO] Mistress, whats your opinion of your sister?

instruction: A happy story, or a sad story?
response: As merry as you will.

instruction: Most likely, sir.
response: Nay, certainly to-night; For look how fresh she looks!

instruction: No, we wont play a sad song. Now is not the time for it.
response: You will not then?

instruction: What in the world?
response: O, help me, help me!

instruction: What, so you think the king will be deposed, then?
response: Depress'd he is already, and deposed 'Tis doubt he will be: letters came last night To a dear friend of the good Duke of York's, That tell black tidings.

instruction: Where is this impulsive and most unfortunate man?
response: Thats he that was Othello.

instruction: Not so, sir, I do care for something. But honestly, sir, I don't care for you. If that means that I care for nothing, sir, then you should become invisible right nowas you're nothing.
response: Art not thou the Lady Olivias fool?

instruction: I know that trumpet! It's the Moor.
response: 'Tis truly so.

instruction: Hey! Stop right there!
response: Signior, it is the Moor.

instruction: I have a tree that grows around here that I need to cut down, and I need to do that soon. Tell my friends in Athens of all stations that whoever wants to stop these pains should hurry here before my my axe touches the tree, so that they might hang themselves. Please, send those regards.
response: Trouble him no further; thus you still shall find him.

instruction: I may?
response: Who should deny it?

instruction: And why's that, sir?
response: Not for becauseYour brows are blacker; yet black brows, they say,Become some women best, so that there be notToo much hair there, but in a semicircleOr a half-moon made with a pen.

instruction: What should I say to her? Her father's brother wants to be her husband? Or should I say it's her uncle? Or should I say it's the man who killed her brothers and uncles? Under what name should I go wooing on your behalf? What name can please God, the law, and my honor, and also seem appealing to such a young woman?
response: Infer fair Englands peace by this alliance.

instruction: Whose house?
response: My masters.

instruction: Your highness? We just got news that the messengers you sent to Delphos are almost back. Cleomenes and Dion just got to the shore and are on their way to court.
response: So please you, sir, their speedHath been beyond account.

instruction: [As CAMBIO] Are you so strict, sir? Well, I guess I have to wait then.
response: [as LITIO] Madam, before you touch the instrument, To learn the order of my fingering I must begin with rudiments of art, To teach you gamut in a briefer sort, More pleasant, pithy, and effectual Than hath been taught by any of my trade.

instruction: Joy has the same effect on our eyes, and suddenly tears spring up from them like a baby.
response: Ho, ho!

instruction: She can have all this at her father's house.
response: Ill not have it so.

instruction: Oh, something that I would hide from the eye of heaventhe shame of our empress and the disgrace of noble Rome! She is delivered, lords; she's delivered.
response: To whom?

instruction: A daughter. She's beautiful, healthy, and will probably live. The queen takes a lot of comfort from the baby. She keeps saying, "My poor prisoner, I am as innocent as you."
response: I dare be sworn These dangerous unsafe lunes i' the king, beshrew them!

instruction: [To CALIBAN] You vicious slave, fathered by the devil himself with your wicked mother, come here!
response: As wicked dew as e'er my mother brushed With ravens feather from unwholesome fen Drop on you both!

instruction: Do you know how to catch fish?
response: I never practised it.

instruction: He's taxed the common people so much that he has quite lost their love; he's fined the nobles too, for old quarrels, and quite lost their hearts.
response: And daily new exactions are devised, As blanks, benevolences, and I wot not what: But what, o' God's name, doth become of this?

instruction: Have I, Malvolio? No.
response: (handing a paper) Lady, you have.

instruction: Just the prostitute we were talking about. And she's wearing perfume. Why are you following me around like this?
response: Let the devil and his dam haunt you!

instruction: Do they call this place Barkloughly castle?
response: Yea, my lord.

instruction: I'll see you hanged on Sunday first!
response: Hark, Petruchio: she says shell see thee hanged first.

instruction: The most powerful queen, Great Juno, comes. I know her by her walk.
response: How does my bounteous sister?

instruction: Madam, I'll happily accept your offer. [To VIOLA] Your master releases you from his service. Because you served me so well, doing things that no woman, especially one of your noble birth, should be expected to do, and because you called me "master" for so long, I will offer you my hand in marriage. From now on you'll be your master's mistress.
response: [To VIOLA] A sister!

instruction: Tomorrow, then. We will wait on your Grace. And now we joyfully bid you farewell.
response: [to the bishops] Come, let us to our holy task again.Farewell, my cousin.

instruction: She returns this ring to you, sir. You might have saved me the trouble and taken it with you. She also adds that you should make it clear to your lord that there is no hopeshe wants nothing to do with him. And one thing more: you should never return here as Orsino's messenger again, unless it is to report how he takes the bad news. Take the ring now.
response: She took the ring of me.

instruction: What do you think it's worth?
response: Not worth my thinking.

instruction: No, good Sir Toby.
response: ( sings ) His eyes do show his days are almost done.

instruction: Cornelia the midwife, me, and no one else but the empress.
response: The empress, the midwife, and yourself:Two may keep counsel when the third's away:Go to the empress, tell her this I said.

instruction: I've changed my mind.
response: Stanley, what news with you?

instruction: [Whispering] This is winning him over, heart and all.
response: [reads] Jove knows I love,But who?Lips, do not move; No man must know.No man must know.

instruction: Hell torture me to death.
response: Is not this Stephano, my drunken butler?

instruction: Perdita, do you feel the same way about him?
response: I cannot speakSo well, nothing so well; no, nor mean better:By the pattern of mine own thoughts I cut outThe purity of his.

instruction: Yes, sir, it's too true, God help us.
response: Then, masters, look to see a troublous world.

instruction: Oh come on! You're just saying that.
response: My mother had a maid called Barbary, She was in love, and he she loved proved mad And did forsake her.

instruction: Isn't she pretty?
response: 'Faith, she would serve after a long voyage at sea.Well, there's for you: leave us.

instruction: That'll be the worse for me, and an end to the matter.
response: Now, by my holidam, here comes Katherina!

instruction: They sit talking by the fire in the parlor.
response: Go fetch them hither.

instruction: I assure you, father, it's true.
response: Come, go along and see the truth hereof,For our first merriment hath made thee jealous.

instruction: Next hell say but
response: Yet

instruction: A painting, which I'm begging you to accept as a gift from me.
response: Painting is welcome.

instruction: [As LITIO] Madam, my instrument's in tune.
response: Lets hear.

instruction: The moment Fortune changes her mind and spurns this newly chosen man, all of those who depended on him and who helped him on their hands and knees to reach the mountain top, they let him slip without even trying to save him.
response: 'Tis common: A thousand moral paintings I can show That shall demonstrate these quick blows of Fortune's More pregnantly than words.

instruction: Yes, indeed they are, sir.
response: Oh, thereby hangs a tail.

instruction: It's useless.
response: But yet I love my country, and am notOne that rejoices in the common wreck,As common bruit doth put it.

instruction: Begs her to do what God, the King of Kings, forbidsmarriage between an uncle and a niece.
response: Say she shall be a high and mighty queen.

instruction: Northumberland returns with a message from Bolingbroke.
response: What must the king do now?

instruction: Ill confess to you that I love him.
response: So will ye, I am sure, that you love me.

instruction: It's off-the-cuff. It comes from my natural intelligence.
response: A witty mother!

instruction: I should be wise, because being honest is foolish and causes someone to lose all that he works for.
response: By the world, I think my wife be honest and think she is not.

instruction: Who is he, Biondello?
response: Master, a marcantant, or a pedant, I know not what, but formal in apparel,In gait and countenance surely like a father.

instruction: It's a good thing I was found by you. I'll just go say one thing inside, and then I'll go with you.
response: Ancient, what makes he here?

instruction: Leave you! Why?
response: I do attend here on the generalAnd think it no addition, nor my wish,To have him see me womaned.

instruction: I wouldn't tell him, not if you gave me this beautiful island in return. I love Cassio, and would do anything to cure him of his alcoholism
response: But, hark!

instruction: [To QUEEN ELIZABETH] Oh, Aunt, you didn't weep for our father's death. So why would we help you with our tears?
response: Our fatherless distress was left unmoaned.

instruction: I would, sir, if I were human.
response: And mine shall.

instruction: Hey, come bring the nets in!
response: What, Patch-breech, I say!

instruction: Here's more material for our comedy.
response: [presenting a paper] Heres the challenge, read it.

instruction: That, being mad herself, she has now married a madman.
response: I warrant him, Petruchio is Kated.

instruction: Tut, tut! Don't "grace" me or "uncle" me: I am no traitor's uncle; and the word "grace" in an ungracious mouth is just profanity. Why have those banished and forbidden feet dared once to touch a dust of England's ground? But then more "why?" Why have they dared to march so many miles upon this peaceful land, frightening her pale-faced villages with war and display of arms? Do you come because the anointed king isn't here? Why, foolish boy, the king is here; he appointed me his representative. If only I were the young lord I was when brave Gaunt, your father, and myself rescued the Black Prince, that young Mars of men, from many thousand French soldiers, oh, then how quickly should my hand (now prisoner to the palsy) punish you for your offence!
response: My gracious uncle, let me know my fault:On what condition stands it and wherein?

instruction: [To himself] Everything is happening, I see, just as my soul hoped it would. [To ARIEL] Spirit, you wonderful spirit, Ill set you free in two days for doing your work so well.
response: [seeing MIRANDA] Most sure, the goddess On whom these airs attend!

instruction: Captain Alcibiades, you seem to long for battle now.
response: My heart is ever at your service, my lord.

instruction: Well, what do you know, old boy, you've done it.
response: 'Tis a good hearing when children are toward.

instruction: Will he woo her? Yes, or I'll hang her.
response: Why came I hither but to that intent?

instruction: No, thats wrongits night.
response: I mean, sir, in delay.

instruction: [To SECOND SERVINGMAN] Go hire twenty skilled cooks.
response: You shall have none ill, sir, for Ill try if they can lick their fingers.

instruction: I'm well, my sovereign lordfor that's what I must call you now.
response: Ay, brother, to our grief, as it is yours.Too late he died that might have kept that title, Which by his death hath lost much majesty.

instruction: Yes, but this case at least can be mended.
response: Musicians, O musicians, Hearts Ease, Hearts Ease.O, an you will have me live, play Hearts Ease.

instruction: Tell them to go away! We won't have it. There's been enough shenanigans here already.[To POLIXENES] Sir, I know you're getting tired of us.
response: You weary those that refresh us: pray, let's seethese four threes of herdsmen.

instruction: We thank your Honor.
response: Do you intend to stay with me tonight?

instruction: I will not be quiet. What is the matter, Aumerle?
response: Good mother, be content; it is no moreThan my poor life must answer.

instruction: Here comes my son Aumerle.
response: Aumerle that was; But that is lost for being Richard's friend, And, madam, you must call him Rutland now: I am in parliament pledge for his truth And lasting fealty to the new-made king.

instruction: Not one person that I care about more than myself. Youre a kings advisor. If you can order the storm to stop, or negotiate a peace with it, we sailors will all stop working with our ropes and take a rest. Use your authority and do it. If you cant, be thankful that youve lived as long as you have, and go to your cabin and prepare yourself to face death, should the worst happen. [To SAILORS] Work, my boys! [To GONZALO] Now, Im telling you, get out of our way.
response: I have great comfort from this fellow.

instruction: "You must give up your drinking."
response: ( aside ) Out, scab!

instruction: If you had suffered for him in childbirth as I have, you would be more sympathetic. But now I see: you suspect that Ive been disloyal to your bed, and that hes a bastard, not your son. Sweet York, sweet husband, dont think that: he looks as much like you as any man could, not like me or my family, and yet I love him.
