response: Make way, unruly woman!

instruction: Apemantus, you (and your humor) are welcome here.
response: No;You shall not make me welcome:I come to have thee thrust me out of doors.

instruction: I stand before you virtuous men to ask a favor. The law is a merciful thing, which only a tyrant could use for cruel purposes. Time and hard luck have worked against a friend of mine who recently broke the law in a fit of rage, a state which unfortunately the law does not consider when men break it. My friend, this action aside, is a good man, who in the moment actually acted without cowardicesomething which ought to be held against his crimeby bravely identifying and responding to one who had ruined his reputation. He opposed this enemy with a clearheaded and calculating passion, expressing his anger with a certain coldness, almost as if he were proving a point.
response: You undergo too strict a paradox, Striving to make an ugly deed look fair: Your words have took such pains as if they labour'd To bring manslaughter into form and set quarrelling Upon the head of valour; which indeed Is valour misbegot and

instruction: Wait a moment! I will not read your master's lines. I know they are full of declarations of love and recently-invented oathswhich he will break as easily as I tear his letter apart.
response: Madam, he sends your ladyship this ring.

instruction: Tell me who your parents were. I think you said you'd been wronged and hurt in the past, and that you thought you had suffered as much as I had (if the stories were both told).
response: Some such thingI said, and said no more but what my thoughtsDid warrant me was likely.

instruction: We'll show you one of Io as a maid, just as Jupiter tricks and surprises her. The painting seems alive, it's so realistic.
response: Or Daphne roaming through a thorny wood, Scratching her legs that one shall swear she bleeds, And at that sight shall sad Apollo weep, So workmanly the blood and tears are drawn.

instruction: And living too; for now his son is duke.
response: Barely in title, not in revenue.

instruction: Welcome, you jackass. Now sing us a song.
response: By my troth, the fool has an excellent breast.

instruction: My gracious sovereign.
response: Give me thy hand.

instruction: "Naught" to do with Miss Shore? I tell you, fellow, there's only one man who can do "naught" with her. And if anyone else is doing it, he'd best do it secretly.
response: What one, my lord?

instruction: Oh, grace! Oh, heaven forgive me! Are you human? Do you have any sense, or a soul? Goodbye, I resign as flag-bearer. Oh what a fool I am for being honest to a fault! Oh this monstrous world! Take note, take note, everyone: it is not safe to be direct and honest. Thank you for teaching me this lesson. From here on out, I'll love no friend, since showing love for your friends causes such hate.
response: Nay, stay.

instruction: I've been beaten and robbed. My money and clothes were stolen, and then they threw these rags on me.
response: What, by a horseman, or a footman?

instruction: You are captivated by some task, writing a poetic dedication to Lord Timon.
response: A thing slipp'd idly from me.

instruction: For this favor to our mother, we're very grateful to you.
response: Now to the Goths, as swift as swallow flies; There to dispose this treasure in mine arms, And secretly to greet the empress' friends.

instruction: Our horses!
response: O my friends, I have one word to say to you: look you, my good lord, I must entreat you, honour me so much As to advance this jewel; accept it and wear it, Kind my lord.

instruction: Dont you hear me speaking?
response: I do, and surely It is a sleepy language, and thou speakst Out of thy sleep.

instruction: I'm here in Sicily by his command. He's asked me to greet you not just as a king, but as a friend and brother. Though he wanted to come, he was held back by some unavoidable issues at home. He asked me to tell you that he loves you more than all the thrones and all the kings in the world.
response: O my brother, Good gentleman!

instruction: Indeed, Im sorry youre in pain. Sweet, sweet, sweet Nurse, tell me, what does my love say?
response: Your love says, like an honest gentleman, and a courteous, and a kind, and a handsome, and, I warrant, avirtuous Where is your mother?

instruction: Do you know what you're saying?
response: [t o SIR TOBY BELCH ] La you, an you speak ill of the devil, how he takes it at heart!

instruction: [As LUCENTIO] Can you at least stay until after dinner?
response: It may not be.

instruction: Please, don't spin me around. My stomachs not feeling well.
response: [aside] These be fine things, an if they be not sprites.

instruction: Yes, but I know
response: What dost thou know?

instruction: But my noble lord, if she is really as brokenhearted as they say, she is sure to deny me an audience.
response: Be clamorous, and leap all civil bounds, Rather than make unprofited return.

instruction: Here come our fellow Senators.
response: No talk of Timon, nothing of him expect.

instruction: Go on, my loving lord.
response: Why, Buckingham, I say I would be king,

instruction: So they say. But how weird is thishave you ever seen anything like it? Look at how amazing wealth and generosity are, how they can summon all these people to attend to them. I know this merchant.
response: I know them both; th' other's a jeweller.

instruction: Im glad! This is good. Stand up.
response: This is as t should be.Let me see the county.

instruction: But only in title, not in income.
response: Richly in both, if justice had her right.

instruction: My lord has fallen into a seizure. This is the second time he's had one of these fits. He had one yesterday.
response: Rub him about the temples.

instruction: Oh awful time!
response: Death, that hath taen her hence to make me wail,Ties up my tongue and will not let me speak.

instruction: With her, on her, however you want to say it.
response: Lie with her?

instruction: "What rank are your parents?" "I was born to a higher rank than I have now, but I'm still well-off. I am a gentleman." Yes, I'll swear that you are; your words, your face, your body, your actions, and your spirit all seem like a coat of arms for a lord. But not so fast! Calm down, calm down! If only Orsino were Cesario. But what's going on? Can someone catch the plague of love this quickly? I think I can feel this youth's perfection creeping stealthily and invisibly in through my eyes. Well, let it happen. [Calling out to MALVOLIO] Come, Malvolio!
response: Here, madam, at your service.

instruction: Let them both set down their helmets and their spears, return back to their chairs again, and come inside with us. And sound the trumpets while we tell the dukes what we've decided.
response: Draw near, And list what with our council we have done.

instruction: What do you believe?
response: That thou dost love my daughter from thy soul.

instruction: I learned it in England, where they really are strong drinkers. The Danes, the Germans, and the pot-bellied Dutchdrink, everybody!can't compare to the English in drinking.
response: Is your Englishman so expert in his drinking?

instruction: The story is too long to repeat, but the short version is that he lost his beloved daughter and his wife.
response: May we not see him?

instruction: Indeed, I'm not sorry to hear that news, for they have always been my enemies. But as for the idea that I'd support Richard's side in keeping my master's true heirs from the throneGod knows I'll never do it. I'd rather die.
response: God keep your Lordship in that gracious mind.

instruction: Calm down, sirs. If you're gentleman, then be polite and hear me out. Baptista is a noble gentlemanone who knows my fatherand even if his daughter was more beautiful than she already is, she would still be entitled to more than one suitorand I will be one of them. Helen of Troy had a thousand suitors, so let fair Bianca have one more. And so she does. Lucentio will woo her, even if Paris himself should come to try and win her.
response: What!

instruction: And you want me to do that!
response: Ay, if you dare do yourself a profit and a right.

instruction: Its wrong to make me wait. Ill dive into the burning lake in the underworld, and pull her out of Acheron by the heels. Marcus, were just shrubs, not cedars, not big-boned men like the cyclops. Were just metal and steel, Marcus, and yet weve had more wrongs done to us than our backs can bear. And, since theres no justice in earth or hell, well pray to heaven and move the gods to send down Justice to right our wrongs. Come, lets do it. You are a good archer, Marcus.
response: 'Ad Jovem,' that's for you: here, 'Ad Apollinem:' 'Ad Martem,' that's for myself: Here, boy, to Pallas: here, to Mercury: To Saturn, Caius, not to Saturnine; You were as good to shoot against the wind.

instruction: Turio, move back, or else accept your death. Don't come close to the range of my anger. Do not call Silvia yours. If you do that once more, Verona won't protect you. Here she is. Go ahead, try to only touch her and take her as your own; I dare you to do so much as breathe on my love.
response: Sir Valentine, I care not for her, I; I hold him but a fool that will endanger His body for a girl that loves him not: I claim her not, and therefore she is thine.

instruction: By Saint Paul, tonight shadows have struck more terror in my soul than ten thousand soldiers could, even if they were dressed in impenetrable armor and led by that fool Richmond. It's not yet daytime. Come with me; I'll eavesdrop under our tents to see if anyone plans to desert me.
response: Good morrow, Richmond.

instruction: Yes, of course, sir.
response: Thou want'st a rough pash and the shoots that I have, To be full like me: yet they say we are Almost as like as eggs; women say so, That will say anything but were they false As o'er-dyed blacks, as wind, as waters, false As dice are to be

instruction: Someone once adored me, too.
response: Lets to bed, knight.

instruction: I shall accept them, and let the rest of those present be well entertained.
response: How now!

instruction: Go kill yourself you monster!
response: Pardon him, sweet Timandra; for his wits Are drown'd and lost in his calamities.

instruction: and with that shame, may your father's grief die as well!
response: What hast thou done, unnatural and unkind?

instruction: Cousin, there's a rift now between my husband and him. But you can mend it.
response: Are you sure of that?

instruction: Sir, I came to ask you to listen to me as your loyal servant, your doctor, your obedient advisor. I came because I'm bold enough (unlike your other servants, doctors, and advisors) to call you out on your evil actions. I come on behalf of your good queen.
response: Good queen!

instruction: Cousin, farewell; and, uncle, say goodbye: he's banished six years, and he shall go.
response: Cousin, farewell: what presence must not know,From where you do remain let paper show.

instruction: Monday! Ha, ha! Well, Wednesday is too soon. Make it Thursday. Tell her that on Thursday shell be married to this noble earl. Will you be ready, Paris? Are you opposed to rushing in this way? We wont have a big party, and just invite a friend or two. Because Tybalt was just killed, people might think that we didnt care enough about our cousin if celebrate too much. Therefore well invite just a half dozen friends to the wedding, and no more. So, what do you say to Thursday?
response: My lord, I would that Thursday were tomorrow.

instruction: Right.
response: Why, then is my pump well flowered.

instruction: To avoid marrying Paris Id jump from the top of a tower; or walk down thief-infested alleys; or sit among a nest of serpents; or be chained up with wild bears; or be shut up every night in a crypt full of rattling bones, stinking flesh, and skulls without jawbones; or climb into a freshly dug grave and hide beneath the shroud of a dead man. All those things make me tremble when I hear them said, but Ill do them without fear or dread in order to be a pure wife to my sweet love.
response: Hold, then.

instruction: Meaning make a curtsy?
response: Thou hast most kindly hit it.

instruction: If you hang all the husbands who can't keep their wives quiet, you won't have any subjects left.
response: Once more, take her hence.

instruction: Come, Montague. Youre up early to see your son and heir killed at too young an age.
response: Alas, my liege, my wife is dead tonight.

instruction: [Singing]Ill never again go to sea, to sea,Ill die here on the shoreThis is a terrible song to sing at a mans funeral. Well, heres something to give me a bit of comfort. [He lifts a bottle of alcohol to his mouth, drinks, and sings again]The master, the deck-cleaner, the boatswain, and I,The gunman and his crewmate,All loved Molly, Meg, Marian, and MargeryBut none of us much liked Kate,Because she spoke so cruelly,And would shout to sailors, Go hang!She did not like the smell of tar or pitch,But would sleep with a tailor when she was in the mood.So go to sea, boys, and let her go to hang!Thats a wretched song too. But heres my comfort. [He drinks]
response: Do not torment me.

instruction: No; I swear on my life. There was nothing to know. You'll regret this when you come to your sensesyou'll regret the things you've said about me! Sweetheart, you can almost totally fix this now if you admit you made a mistake.
response: No; if I mistakeIn those foundations which I build upon,The centre is not big enough to bearA school-boy's top.

instruction: How good are you at the fast dances, knight?
response: Faith, I can cut a caper.

instruction: Don't preach about kindness or shame to me.
response: Have done, have done.

instruction: Good night. Go to bed and get your rest. You'll need it.
response: Farewell.

instruction: But, my good lord, your Graces' words are just as trustworthy as if I had seen him and heard him myself. And don't worry, you noble princes. I'll tell our citizens about how fairly you dealt with this case.
response: And to that end we wished your Lordship hereT' avoid the censures of the carping world.

instruction: Does she consider my possessions?
response: O, ay; and pities them.

instruction: Girls who marry that young grow up too quickly. All of my other children are dead and buried in the earth, so all hopes on this earth rest in her. But you may woo her, kind Paris. Win her love. My permission for you to marry her is only part of the bargain; she must also agree to marry you. Then my blessing on the marriage will confirm her choice. This very night Im throwing a party that Ive hosted for many years. Ive invited many guests, many close friends. Id like to invite you as a most welcome guest. At my humble home tonight, youll see see young women like stars that walk the earth and light the sky from below. Like all lusty young men, youll be delighted by the young women who are as fresh as spring flowers. Look at them all, and choose whichever woman you like best. Amidst all these girls, you may no longer think that my daughters the most beautiful. Come with me.
response: Find them out whose names are written here?

instruction: How is the prince?
response: Well, madam, and in health.

instruction: As by definition most unbelievable things are.
response: That our garments, being, as they were, drenched in thesea, hold notwithstanding their freshness and glosses, being rather new-dyed than stained with salt water.

instruction: Help, my lord of Norfolk, help, help! The king has performed more wonders than seems humanly possible, facing down every dangerous enemy himself. His horse is killed, and now he's fighting on foot, searching for Richmond even in the face of death. Help, honorable lord, or else the battle is lost!
response: A horse, a horse, my kingdom for a horse!

instruction: Oh, woe is me! My heart is about to break!
response: What fit is this, good lady?

instruction: Let it be so. Good night to everyone. [To BRABANTIO] And, noble sir, if virtue is a beautiful thing, then your son-in-law is much more fair than he is black.
response: Adieu, brave Moor.

instruction: Give me a second. Please wait a bit and I'll be with you as soon as I can.
response: Come hither: pray you, How goes the world, that I am thus encounter'd With clamourous demands of date-broke bonds, And the detention of long-since-due debts, Against my honour?

instruction: Read it.
response: The note lies in s throat, if he say I said so.

instruction: Thats true; you were there, and can testify that what I say is true.
response: As false, by heaven, as heaven itself is true.

instruction: Down, down I come, like glittering Phaethon, unable to manage his unruly horses. In the lower courtyard? Lower courtyard, where kings are made low, coming when a traitor calls and acting respectful to him. In the lower courtyard? Come down? Down, court! Down, king! For it's night when it should be day.
response: What says his majesty?

instruction: But he won't beg his son to stop the attack.
response: If Tamora entreat him, then he will: For I can smooth and fill his aged ear With golden promises; that, were his heart Almost impregnable, his old ears deaf, Yet should both ear and heart obey my tongue.

instruction: You're annoying me. I'm not in the mood.
response: And is it thus?

instruction: Why then, the mustard without the beef.
response: Go, get thee gone, thou false deluding slave, (Beats him) That feedst me with the very name of meat.

instruction: Mistress, your father asks that you leave your books and help decorate your sister's room. You know tomorrow is the wedding day.
response: Farewell, sweet masters both.

instruction: I'm afraid that no matter what you do, sir, your wife won't let herself be asked for anything.
response: Now, wheres my wife?

instruction: For the love of God, be quiet!
response: My masters, are you mad?

instruction: How is your master Timon? He's so honest and generous.
response: His health is well sir.

instruction: By God, you whore! Is black so terrible a color?[To the baby] Sweetheart, you are a beautiful flower, you are.
response: Villain, what hast thou done?

instruction: You're really provoking me? Then lets fight, boy!
response: O Lord, they fight!

instruction: I say a husband.
response: I say a devil.

instruction: I have toprinces are as vain as the gods. Just like jewels lose their shine if they're not polished, princes lose their reputations if they're not respected. Now, daughter, it's your job to explain what each knight's emblem means.
response: Which, to preserve mine honour, I'll perform.

instruction: Besides, the king's enemies hate us because he loves us.
response: And that's the wavering commons: for their love Lies in their purses, and whoso empties them By so much fills their hearts with deadly hate.

instruction: Yours, if we're telling tall tales of tails. Farewell then.
response: What, with my tongue in your tail?

instruction: No, don't pause. For I did kill King Henrythough your beauty provoked me to do it. Now go ahead. I was the one who stabbed young Edwardthough your heavenly face that drove me to it.
response: Take up the sword again, or take up me.

instruction: We would like nothing more.
response: I take all and your several visitations So kind to heart, 'tis not enough to give; Methinks, I could deal kingdoms to my friends, And ne'er be weary.

instruction: Don't argue, sir. We gentlemen don't get jealous of others with our eyes or our hearts. We neither envy the powerful nor hate the weak.
response: You are right courteous knights.

instruction: I do not worry about your insults. You are an Athenian and therefore welcome. I myself would have no power to silence you, so please, just let my food keep you quiet.
response: I scorn thy meat; 'twould choke me, for I should ne'er flatter thee.

instruction: Tricks? I hate tricks. There's a man at the gate.
response: Ay, marry, what is he?

instruction: It's hard to see him like this! He got sick when he realized his mother is disgraced. He took it hard, as if her shame were his own personal burden. He stopped smiling, eating, and sleeping and then became bedridden. Leave me alone; go see how he's doing. [The SERVANT leaves][To himself] Shame on you! Don't think about Polixenesyou can't take revenge on him now without putting yourself in danger. He's too powerful; he has too many friends and allies. Leave him alone until the right moment. Right now, just take your revenge on Hermione. Camillo and Polixenes are laughing at me; my suffering is a huge joke to them. They wouldn't be laughing if I could get to themand she definitely won't, since she's within my power.
response: You must not enter.

instruction: Bring them in; I'm ready. Since this whole thing is in honor of her birthday, my beautiful daughter, whom Nature made for men to see, will sit here, where everyone can marvel at her.
response: It pleaseth you, my royal father, to expressMy commendations great, whose merit's less.

instruction: Is this the madman?
response: Ay, my lord, this same.How now, Malvolio!

instruction: Not as much as I value telling the truth, which doesn't cost a penny.
response: What dost thou think 'tis worth?

instruction: Oh, don't promise! Keep a little faithyour faith in meeven though you're so afraid.
response: For the love of God, a surgeon!

instruction: Yes, madam, I was born and raised less than three hours' travel from here.
response: Who governs here?

instruction: What does my niece Lavinia mean by this sign language?
response: Fear her not, Lucius: somewhat doth she mean: See, Lucius, see how much she makes of thee: Somewhither would she have thee go with her.

instruction: I would cry, madam, if it would do you good.
response: And I could sing, would weeping do me good,And never borrow any tear of thee.

instruction: Too light for a bumpkin like you to catchand yet just as heavy as I should be.
response: Should beshould buzz!

instruction: Northumberland, tell him that the king says this: his noble cousin is very welcome here, and all his fair demands will be accepted without contradiction. Say this to him as graciously as you can.
response: No, good my lord; let's fight with gentle wordsTill time lend friends and friends their helpful swords.

instruction: Why, sir, you know this is your wedding day. First we were sad because we feared you wouldn't come, but now we're sadder to see that you've come so unprepared. For God's sake, take off this costume. It's a disgrace to your social rank and an eyesore in the middle of our solemn ceremony.
response: And tell us what occasion of importHath all so long detained you from your wifeAnd sent you hither so unlike yourself.

instruction: Can God be so cruel?
response: Romeo can,Though heaven cannot.

instruction: You do yourselves much wrong and undervalue yourselves too much. Here, my lord, a small sign of my love.
response: With more than common thanks I will receive it.

instruction: Dionyza, should we sit down here and tell each other sad stories? Maybe that way we'll forget our own sad lives.
response: That were to blow at fire in hope to quench it; For who digs hills because they do aspire Throws down one mountain to cast up a higher.

instruction: You mock me, madam. This is not the way to win your daughter.
response: There is no other way,Unless thou couldst put on some other shape And not be Richard, that hath done all this.

instruction: Excuse me?
response: That you ask me what you are, and do not knowyourselves.

instruction: March on, march on, since we're already prepared for battle. Even if we don't have to fight foreign enemies, we'll still beat down these rebels here at home.
response: My liege, the duke of Buckingham is taken.

instruction: Yes, Mother, but I wish it weren't so.
response: Why, my young cousin?

instruction: [As CAMBIO] Mistress, what's your opinion of your sister?
response: That, being mad herself, shes madly mated.

instruction: Now, Camillo: I've been so caught up with all this that I've been rude.
response: Sir, I thinkYou have heard of my poor services, i' the loveThat I have borne your father?

instruction: Norfolk, throw down, we command you; there's no point refusing.
response: Myself I throw, dread sovereign, at thy foot.

instruction: Indeed, I'm as bad as can be.
response: Pluck up thy spirits.

instruction: Sir Toby Belch! How are you, Sir Toby Belch?
response: Sweet Sir Andrew!

instruction: I'll go now. At around three or four o'clock you should expect the news from the town hall.
response: Go, Lovell, with all speed to Doctor Shaw.

instruction: Rest assured, good Cassio, I will do all I can for you.
response: Good madam, do.

instruction: Look, he's coming!
response: Oh my fair warrior!

instruction: Yes, it is Emilia. [To EMILIA] One minute. [To himself] She's dead. Emilia is likely coming to tell me about Cassio's death. There was a lot of noise outside. Ha! Not moving anymore, Desdemona? Still as the grave. Should Emilia come in here? Would that be good? Is Desdemona moving again? No. What should I do? If she comes in, she'll definitely want to speak to my wife. My wife! My wife! What wife? I have no wife. Oh, this is unbearable! Oh, what a terrible time! I think there should be a huge eclipse now of both the sun and the moon, and the ground itself should break open at what has happened.
response: [within] I do beseech youThat I may speak with you, O good my lord!

instruction: We see the shipwreck that will come to us; there's no avoiding the danger now, for we will suffer the same.
response: Not so; even through the hollow eyes of death I spy life peering; but I dare not say How near the tidings of our comfort is.

instruction: Tell me your idea first.
response: You will be schoolmasterAnd undertake the teaching of the maid:Thats your device.

instruction: He almost makes me want to give up my profession by talking me into it.
response: 'Tis in the malice of mankind that he thus advisesus; not to have us thrive in our mystery.

instruction: Our fight will decide who goes to heaven.
response: Romeo, away, be gone!

instruction: Maybe the letter upset him. I think they've ordered him to return home and leave Cassio in charge here.
response: By my troth, I am glad on t.

instruction: Then tell the Lord Aumerle to look me in the face.
response: Cousin, stand forth, and look upon that man.

instruction: Oh slow-winged turtledove, will you let a buzzard catch you?
response: Ay, for a turtle, as he takes a buzzard.

instruction: No, hold on. We have to let the fit run its course. Otherwise he'll foam at the mouth and break out in a fit of savage madness. Look, he's moving. Stay away for a bit. He'll recover soon. When he is gone, I would really like to talk to you in private.
response: How is it, general?

instruction: It was flirtation, the sort of thing that leads to foul thoughts and lust. Their faces were so close to each other that they almost breathed the same breath. It's horrible to think about, Roderigo! When this kind of behavior happens, the main event isn't far awaythe physical consummation. Psh! But, sir, let me tell you what to do. I've brought you here from Venice. Wait for my command tonight. Cassio doesn't know who you are. I won't be far away from you. Find some excuse to make Cassio angry, either by speaking too loudly, or mocking his discipline, or whatever way you want that seems like a good idea at the time.
response: Well.

instruction: Read the indictment.
response: [Reads] Hermione, queen to the worthy Leontes, king of Sicilia, thou art here accused and arraigned of high treason, in committing adultery with Polixenes, king of Bohemia, and conspiring with Camillo to take away the life of our sovereign

instruction: Come on, the gods have blessed you.
response: I accuse them not.

instruction: What, captain?
response: I am an humble suitor to your virtues; For pity is the virtue of the law, And none but tyrants use it cruelly.

instruction: Yes, sir?
response: How does the boy?

instruction: It is, my lord.
response: Bid my guard watch.

instruction: Welcome, my lord! How far away is your army?
response: Nor near nor farther off, my gracious lord, Than this weak arm: discomfort guides my tongue And bids me speak of nothing but despair.

instruction: I can, sir. But first, let's go into my house, where I can show you everything we found with her. We'll explain how she came here to the temple, and we won't leave anything out.
response: Pure Dian, bless thee for thy vision!

instruction: Be patient, gentlemen. I choose her for myself. If she and I are happy, then what's it to you? When we were alone, we agreed that she would go on being a shrew in public. I tell you, it's incredible how much she loves me, though. Oh, the kindest Kate! She threw her arms around my neck, giving me kiss after kiss and swearing vows of love, and in an instant she had won my heart. Oh, you are all just beginners! It's amazing to seeeven a cowardly wretch can tame the fiercest shrew when a man and a woman are left alone together.Give me your hand, Kate. I'll now go to Venice to buy clothes for the wedding. You plan the feast, father, and invite the guests. I'll make sure my Katherine will be beautifully dressed.
response: I know not what to say, but give me your hands.God send you joy, Petruchio.

instruction: What a happy coincidence, and even happier for your son. I can now call you "father" legally, and not just as a term of respect for your age. This gentlewoman here is my wife, and her sister is now married to your son. Don't be amazed or upset. His wife has a good reputation, a wealthy dowry, and a noble bloodline. She has all the qualities that would make her a worthy spouse for any noble gentleman. Now let me embrace you, Vincentio, and then we'll go out of our way to see your honest son. He'll be overjoyed at your coming.
response: But is this true, or is it else your pleasure,Like pleasant travelers, to break a jestUpon the company you overtake?

instruction: I'll test that out.
response: I swear Ill cuff you if you strike again.

instruction: May all the sicknesses that grow in swamps, marshes, and wetlands strike Prospero so that, little by little, he becomes nothing more than a disease! His spirits are spying on me, but I just have to curse him. Unless he tells the spirits to, they wont pinch me; frighten me by appearing as hedgehog-shaped goblins; push me in the mud; or lead me the wrong way like a false guide in the night. But he does send them after me for every little thing I do. Sometimes his spirits come after me in the form of apes, chattering and making faces at me and then biting me. Sometimes they come in the shape of porcupines, lying curled up on the paths where I walk barefoot and pricking me when I step down. Sometimes poisonous snakes wrap around me, hissing with their forked tongues until I go crazy.
response: Lo, now, lo!

instruction: Are you good at such trifles, knight?
response: As any man in Illyria, whatsoever he be, under the degree of my betters.

instruction: By heaven, that's my handkerchief!
response: If youll come to supper tonight, you may.

instruction: If this were being acted out on a stage, I would complain that it was unrealistic.
response: His very genius hath taken the infection of the device,man.

instruction: The only way to deal with him is gently, gently. The demon in him is rough, but we can't treat it roughly.
response: [t o MALVOLIO ] Why, how now, my bawcock!

instruction: I think it is my Lord of Berkeley.
response: My Lord of Hereford, my message is to you.

instruction: [To herself] And when he makes those advances to you, Silvia, it makes me unhappy.
response: Had I been seized by a hungry lion, I would have been a breakfast to the beast, Rather than have false Proteus rescue me.

instruction: [To himself] I'm not sure how this will get in the way of Florizel's departure.
response: Pray heartily he be at palace.

instruction: Your speech is useless.
response: In vain!

instruction: Whats with all the noise?
response: O lamentable day!

instruction: Miss Bianca, may you be blessed with all the good fortune you deserve! No, I've caught you napping, my dear. Both Hortensio and I have rejected you.
response: Tranio, you jest.

instruction: I saw you at Duke Orsino's recently.
response: Foolery, sir, does walk about the orb like the sun.

instruction: You're talking about Timon? He is my friend and a good guy.
response: We know him for no less, though we are but strangers to him.

instruction: Way too much. It seems your master is more brazen even than mine, otherwise mine would have asked for as much.
response: One of Lord Timon's men.

instruction: Sir, we have a chest ready, waterproofed and sealed.
response: I thank thee.

instruction: He moved quickly and lightly, so he outran us. But Moyses and Valerius are following him. Go with her to the west end of the forestthat's where our captain is. We'll follow the one who ran away. The bushes surround him; he can't escape.
response: Come, I must bring you to our captain's cave:Fear not; he bears an honourable mind,And will not use a woman lawlessly.

instruction: Ah, madam, it's too true. And what's worse, the Lord Northumberland, his son young Henry Percy, and the Lords of Ross, Beaumond, and Willoughby, with all their powerful friends, have gone to fight with them.
response: Why have you not proclaim'd NorthumberlandAnd all the rest revolted faction traitors?

instruction: Good night, queen of the Amazons.
response: Before me, shes a good wench.

instruction: Cassio, my lord? No, surely not. I can't imagine he would slink away looking so guilty after seeing you coming.
response: I do believe twas he.

instruction: Please, come inside. I will give you a chance to talk to her freely.
response: I am much bound to you.

instruction: If I had a pair of these coins, sir, do you think they'd have children?
response: Yes, being kept together and put to use.

instruction: Hello! How much for a dozen virginities?
response: Now, the gods to-bless your honour!

instruction: Go and write it down, in fierce handwriting. Be rude and brief. It doesn't need to be witty, as long as it's eloquent and original. Taunt him with all the possibilities of writing. Refer to him familiarly three times at least, which will insult his pride as a nobleman. As many lies as you can fit on a piece of papereven if the paper's as big as a royal bedwrite 'em all down. Go, get started now. Even if you're using an ordinary pen, you can still fill it with bitter, venomous ink. Now go ahead.
response: Where shall I find you?

instruction: He's a stupid, blockheaded, flap-eared son of a bitch!Come, Kate, sit down. I know you must be hungry. Will you say grace, sweet Kate, or should I?What's this? Mutton?
response: Ay.

instruction: Or should I?
response: Shall I play my freedom at tray-trip, and become thy bondslave?

instruction: My lord, you are too kind.
response: 'Faith, for the worst is filthy; and would not holdtaking, I doubt me.

instruction: By God, Here come the Capulets.
response: By my heel, I care not.

instruction: Nurse, will you come with me to my room and help me pick out the clothes and jewelry that I should wear tomorrow?
response: No, not till Thursday.

instruction: Oh you sweet little king-killer, which can set even a son and father at odds! You that can defile the bed of Hymen like Mars! You forever young, fresh, beloved, and delicate wooer, that can ruin the chastity of Diana with just a blush! You beautiful god, which can sew together impossible events and make them kiss! That can speak in every language and for any purpose! You tester of hearts, that think your slave man rebels against you and, with your power, set him at odds with himself so that beasts may rule the world!
response: Would 'twere so!But not till I am dead.

instruction: Indeed. God forbid! I know my words may not be welcome, but I must speak the truth. Who among us is noble enough to judge our king? If there were such a person, he would know not to commit such a foul crime. What subject can pass sentence on his king? And who sits here that is not Richards subject? We dont judge thieves without hearing what they have to say, even if they look guilty: so will the symbol of God's majesty, His captain, steward, and deputy-elect, who was anointed and crowned by Him and reigned over us many yearswill he be judged by subjects, and without his even being present? Oh, God forbid that in a Christian climate refined souls should be guilty of such a terrible deed! I speak to subjects, and I speak as a subject, inspired by God to advocate for whats right: my Lord of Hereford here, whom you call king, is a foul traitor to the true king. And if you crown him, let me warn you: the blood of the English will water the ground, and our future children will suffer: well have nothing but war, never peace, as families turn against each other; horror and civil war will come to live in this land, which will be called the field of Golgotha and dead men's skulls. Oh, if you pit families against each other, it will be the saddest war that ever struck this earth. Prevent it, resist it, let this not happenor your children and your childrens children will blame you for their suffering.
response: Well have you argued, sir; and, for your pains, Of capital treason we arrest you here.

instruction: This is what you get from whoring around. Please, Emilia, go ask Cassio where he had dinner tonight. [To BIANCA] Why do you shake with worry at that?
response: He supped at my house, but I therefore shake not.

instruction: What is your will, sir, that you sent for me?
response: Where is your sister, and Hortensios wife?

instruction: I don't eat what I hate.
response: Dost hate a medlar?

instruction: Gold is useless here.
response: The best and truest;For here it sleeps, and does no hired harm.

instruction: I said that without written records, fame lives long.
response: That Julius Caesar was a famous man.

instruction: Call up Desdemona's father. Wake him up. We'll slander Othello in the streets, and ruin his happiness by getting his wife's family all riled up. And even if he's in a paradise right now, we'll fill it with flies. He may still be happy, but we'll douse him in so much irritation that his happiness will lose some of its luster.
response: Here is her fathers house, Ill call aloud.

instruction: What crime do you accuse Mowbray of, cousin? It must be very bad, if it can cause us to think any ill of him.
response: Look, what I speak, my life shall prove it true; That Mowbray hath received eight thousand nobles In name of lendings for your highness' soldiers, The which he hath detain'd for lewd employments, Like a false traitor and injurious villain.

instruction: Let me reveal myself. I am not Litio, and not a musician either. I refuse to continue with this disguise for the sake of a woman who would choose a low-class scoundrel over a gentleman like me. Know, sir, that I am called Hortensio.
response: [as LUCENTIO] Signior Hortensio, I have often heard Of your entire affection to Bianca, And since mine eyes are witness of her lightness, I will with you, if you be so contented, Forswear Bianca and her love for ever.

instruction: Good Michael, take care of the guard duties tonight. Let's show some self-restraint and not celebrate to the point of excess.
response: Iago hath direction what to do, But notwithstanding with my personal eyeWill I look to t.

instruction: I just want to get paid!
response: I fear it.

instruction: If I described this back in Naples, would they believe me? Would they believe it if I told them that I saw native islanders such as thesebecause they must certainly be natives of the islandwho despite their unnatural shape have more grace and better manners than you can find among manyactually, almost anyhuman beings?
response: [aside] Honest lord,Thou hast said well, for some of you there presentAre worse than devils.

instruction: Yes, if your memories of yourself only hurt you.
response: Yet thou didst kill my children.

instruction: My gracious lord, my lovely Saturnine, lord of my life, commander of my thoughts: calm yourself. Remember that Titus is old; his grief for his sons has pierced him deeply and scarred his heart. Comfort him in his distress instead of prosecuting the greatest or least member of his family for this. [To herself] Well, it's clever to pretend to defend him like this. But Titus, I've got you, and I've spilled your life-blood. if Aaron's plan goes smoothly, then we're almost there.
response: How now, good fellow!

instruction: Are you a woman?
response: What would you have me be, an I be not a woman?

instruction: I know a lady in Venice who would have walked barefoot to Palestine just to touch his lower lip.
response: ( singing) The poor soul sat sighing by a sycamore tree, Sing all a green willow.

instruction: Sister, let yourself be comforted. All of us have reason to mourn the dimming of the king, our shining star, but none of us can help anything by wailing.
response: God bless thee, and put meekness in thy breast,Love, charity, obedience, and true duty.

instruction: Yes, him.
response: Hes as tall a man as anys in Illyria.

instruction: Just stop there, and go to hell! Do you think I'm so crazy and confused that I would make this up? Do you think I would destroy my own reputation and my marriage, just to welcome all the pain and difficulty that will come of that? Do you really think I would just bastardize my son (who I think is mine and who I love as my own) without a good reason? Would I do that? Would any man have the guts to do that?
response: I must believe you, sir: I do; and will fetch off Bohemia for't; Provided that, when he's removed, your highness Will take again your queen as yours at first, Even for your son's sake; and thereby for sealing The injury of tongues in courts

instruction: Before the time of our deal is up? Stop right there!
response: I prithee, Remember I have done thee worthy service, Told thee no lies, made thee no mistakings, served Without or grudge or grumblings.

instruction: Have you seen my hat?
response: Here 'tis.

instruction: But sir, you would have given the entire world in one breath. Your holdings shrank so quickly!
response: You tell me true.

instruction: Camillo, if, in your duties as a servant to the king, you ever happen to visit Bohemia (as I'm visiting Sicily now), you'll see how different our two countries are.
response: I think, this coming summer, the King of Siciliameans to pay Bohemia the visitation which he justly owes him.

instruction: And Ill remain here, even if you keep forgetting. Ill forget that I have any other home but here.
response: Tis almost morning.

instruction: Yes, sir, I've often been to PisaPisa, famous for its serious citizens.
response: [as LUCENTIO] Among them know you one Vincentio?

instruction: Then God be blessed, it's the blessed sun. But it's not the sun when you say it isn't, and the moon changes with your mind. Whatever you name it, that's what the thing is, and so it will always be for Katherine.
response: Petruchio, go thy ways; the field is won.

instruction: No, be smart. We still haven't seen anything actually happen. She may still turn out to be honest. Just tell me this: have you occasionally seen a handkerchief decorated with strawberries in your wife's hand?
response: I gave her such a one, twas my first gift.

instruction: The gods know that there has never been an assistant racked with sadness for his lord the way I am looking at you.
response: What, dost thou weep?

instruction: Then quickly say what it is you want.
response: The forfeit, sovereign, of my servants life,Who slew today a riotous gentlemanLately attendant on the duke of Norfolk.

instruction: No, Ill summon him as I would a spirit. Romeo! Humors! Madman! Passion! Lover! Appear to me in the form of a sigh. Speak just a single rhyme, and Ill be satisfied. Cry out, Ah me! Say love and dove. Say one pretty word to my good gossiping friend Venus. Say the nickname of her blind son and heir, Cupid, who shot arrows so accurately and made King Cophetua fall in love with a beggar maid.Romeo doesnt hear me, stir, or move. The little monkey is dead, so I must conjure him to appear. By Rosalines bright eyes, by her high forehead and her red lips, by her fine feet, straight legs, and trembling thighs, and by parts of her that lie next to her thighs, I summon you to appear before us in your actual form.
response: An if he hear thee, thou wilt anger him.

instruction: You have a servant named Lucilius.
response: I have so: what of him?

instruction: Good sister, don't wrong both me and yourself by turning me into a slave. I won't stand for that. But if it's my jewelry and clothes you wantuntie my hands and I'll pull them off myself, yes, everything down to my underwear. Or I'll do anything else you command me to do, for I know that it is my duty is to obey my elders.
response: Of all thy suitors here I charge thee tellWhom thou lovest best.

instruction: Lie with her? Lie on her? To lie on someone is to tell lies about that person! To lie with herthat's obscene. First the handkerchief, and now this confession! Should he confess first and then be executed? No, I'll kill him first and let him confess later. I am trembling with anger, and nature wouldn't make my body do this without some reason. It must be more than a rumor if it's making me tremble like this. Ugh! Noses, ears, and lips. Could this be true? That he would admit to itand the handkerchief! Oh, devil!
response: Work on, My medicine, work!

instruction: These walls of ours were not built by the people who insulted you, nor were they people that deserve their work to fall for the faults of others.
response: Nor are they living Who were the motives that you first went out; Shame that they wanted cunning, in excess Hath broke their hearts.

instruction: He who is dizzy thinks the world spins round.
response: Roundly replied.

instruction: Call it whatever you want; the day is yours. And I hope no one here is jealous of you. Some artists are good, but according to the standards of art, some are excellent; you're clearly the best that art has to offer. [To THAISA] Come, daughter, queen of the feast (since that's what you are), take your place. Direct everyone to do what they're supposed to. [He seats THAISA at the high table]
response: We are honour'd much by good Simonides.

instruction: [To FLAVIUS] You go to the senators. I deserve an audience with them. Ask them to send me a thousand talents.
response: I have been bold For that I knew it the most general way To them to use your signet and your name; But they do shake their heads, and I am here No richer in return.

instruction: No, leave him be. I'll get him in a different way. I'll sue him for assault and battery, if there's any justice and law in Illyria. I struck him first, but that shouldn't matter.
response: [To SIR TOBY BELCH] Let go thy hand.

instruction: Why, that's what he didand now you'll be released from the prison of earth, to be free among the joys of heaven.
response: Make peace with God, for you must die, my lord.

instruction: Give her my true love's kiss. And so, farewell.
response: Relenting fool and shallow, changing woman!

instruction: It only concerns you. I'm not bringing a declaration of war or a demand for praise. I'm only bringing you an olive branch. My words are full of peace.
response: Yet you began rudely.

instruction: For treating your injured shin.
response: Why Romeo, art thou mad?

instruction: [Whispering] Yes, or else I'll beat him with a club and make him yell "O!"
response: And then I comes behind.

instruction: Monster, if you want to be a good monster, please say something.
response: How does thy honor?

instruction: Sir Christopher, bring this message to Richmond for me: my son George Stanley is locked up in the deadly boar's pen. If I revolt, off goes young George's head. My fear of that happening prevents me from helping right now. So go quickly, and give my regards to your lord. Also say that Queen Elizabeth has readily agreed that Richmond should marry her daughter Elizabeth. But tell me, where is princely Richmond now?
response: At Pembroke, or at Ha'rfordwest in Wales.

instruction: Tarsus, which I rule, was once wealthy. We had everything we wanted: the streets were strewn with riches, we built towers up to the skies, and every visitor who came here was amazed. Our men and women wore fine clothes and jewelry; they were like mirrors to each other's own riches. They had more than enough food on their tables. No one was poor. We were proud; we couldn't imagine needing help from anyone.
response: O, 'tis too true.

instruction: Is this a joke?
response: Bear the boy hence; he shall not come about her;Away with him!

instruction: A pretty spirit! My clever Ariel, listen closely. [He whispers to ARIEL]
response: My lord it shall be done.

instruction: I can find the logs without bothering Peter.
response: Mass, and well said!

instruction: Villain, not on your life! Take off my mistress's gown for your master's use!
response: Why, sir, whats your conceit in that?

instruction: Cousin, put down your gage. Don't you start as well
response: O, God defend my soul from such deep sin!

instruction: Have you read the truth?
response: Ay, my lord; even soAs it is here set down.

instruction: Now, if you're really my friend, let me see his letter.
response: Good Master Fabian, grant me another request.

instruction: The news is very favorable and good, my lord: Richard is hiding not far from here.
response: It would beseem the Lord Northumberland To say 'King Richard': alack the heavy day When such a sacred king should hide his head.

instruction: You must depart tonight.
response: With all my heart.

instruction: Away with this old fool! Take him to jail!
response: Thus strangers may be haled and abused.O monstrous villain!

instruction: It might, or it might not.
response: I have heard it said so.

instruction: Ah, Desdemona, go away, away, away!
response: Alas the heavy day, why do you weep?

instruction: The people who banished you are no longer living. Their shame at their actions broke their hearts. March into our city with your banners, Alcibiades, and if in an unnatural hunger for revenge you'd like to kill one tenth of the entire city, let those unfortunate enough to have gotten such a bad turn of the dice die for all the rest.
response: All have not offended; For those that were, it is not square to take On those that are, revenges: crimes, like lands, Are not inherited.

instruction: According to my nurse, my father wasn't afraid. He just called out to the sailors, "Good seamen!" and helped them, pulling the ropes with his own hands, and holding onto the mast to ride out the waves that almost broke the ship.
response: When was this?

instruction: You're trying to hide your evil with a show of hospitality, but it's hypocrisy; it only looks good from the outside! If I'd really gotten the answer wrong, then that would mean you weren't dirtying your soul by committing disgusting incest. But now, by sleeping with your daughter, you're both father and son, acting more like a husband than a father . . . and she's filling the role her mother should, taking her mother's place in your bed. They're both like snakes who eat pretty flowers but produce deadly poison.Goodbye, Antioch! I'm smart enough to know that a guy who's comfortable doing one evil thing won't hesitate to do another one if it'll keep him from being found out. One sin leads to another; murder is as close to lust as fire is to smoke. If I stick around, I'll be poisoned, or accused of treason, anything to keep me from exposing him. So, to save myself and not expose him, I'll leave here and escape the danger I'm afraid of.
response: He hath found the meaning, for which we mean To have his head.

instruction: What will you do with it? Why have you been so eager for me to steal it?
response: Why, what is that to you?

instruction: I can't speak; I can't think or wrap my head around what I know now. [To FLORIZEL] Sir, you've ruined an eighty-three-year-old man who only wanted to die in peace on the same bed where his father passed away, and to be buried near him. Now some executioner will bury me, alone.[To PERDITA] How dare you continue to play around with him, knowing he was the prince? Ruined! Ruined! If I die within the hour, I'll be glad to be out of my misery.
response: Why look you so upon me?

instruction: Don't refuse this love we offer you, mighty lord.
response: O, make them joyful.

instruction: What about the bag? What's in the bag? And why the box?
response: Sir, there lies such secrets in this fardel and box,which none must know but the king; and which heshall know within this hour, if I may come to thespeech of him.

instruction: Go ask him for his name.
response: If he be married.My grave is like to be my wedding bed.

instruction: It's a dish I love to eat.
response: Ay, but the mustard is too hot a little.

instruction: That's why it's a "sensitive" story. I was just knocking to see if your ear was listening. But now I'll begin: first of all, we came down a muddy hill, my master riding behind my mistress.
response: Both of one horse?

instruction: Holy father, it is there along with my master, whom you love.
response: Who is it?

instruction: Well then, sir, I'll sing a lullaby to your generosity while I'm gone, so it can nap until I return. I'll go now, sir, but don't think that I'm doing this just because I'm greedyI'm more interested in the art of begging than the actual money. But as you say, sir, let your generosity sleep, and I'll wake it up soon.
response: Here comes the man, sir, that did rescue me.

instruction: What? Let me see her. No! Shes cold. Her blood has stopped, and her joints are stiff. Life left her body a long while ago. Death rests on her like an unexpected frost that killed the most beautiful flower.
response: O lamentable day!

instruction: You should know this much: by a strange chance, the goddess of luck (whom I now love) has brought my old enemies to this island. And by my magic senses, I can tell that my opportunity for good fortune depends on this lucky circumstance. And if I do not act but instead do nothing, then I will never again have such an opportunity. No more questions now. You are sleepy. Its a good time for sleepiness, so give in to it. I know you have no choice.
response: Come away, servant, come.

instruction: Will we hear from you before we go to sleep, Catesby?
response: You shall, my lord.

instruction: The quicker the better.
response: I understand the business, I hear it: to have an open ear, a quick eye, and a nimble hand, is necessary for a cut-purse; a good nose is requisite also, to smell out work for the other senses.

instruction: Immortal Diana!
response: Now I know you better.When we with tears parted Pentapolis,The king my father gave you such a ring.

instruction: But you avoid getting motivated, so you dont ever have to hit.
response: A dog of the house of Montague moves me.

instruction: You hate medlar?
response: Ay, though it look like thee.

instruction: You should know, my loving lord: I've heard that the Marquess of Dorset has fled to Richmond in France.
response: Come hither, Catesby.

instruction: But listen, sir: we're the ones that pulled this armor out of the rough sea, so there are certain conditions, certain respects to paid. I hope, sir, if you're successful, that you'll remember where you got it from.
response: Believe 't, I will.

instruction: [He skims the letter] This letter corroborates the friars story. It describes the course of their love and how he heard of her death. Then he writes that he bought poison from a poor pharmacist and came to this tomb to die and lie with Juliet. Where are these enemies? Capulet! Montague! Do you see how your hate has cursed you? Heaven has in response conspired to kill your joys with love. And because I did not take a firm hand against your feud, Ive lost two of my family members as well. Everyone is punished.
response: O brother Montague, give me thy hand.This is my daughters jointure, for no moreCan I demand.

instruction: It can't be anything else. You'll see him high and mighty in Athens again, to be sure. For that reason it's not crazy to appeal to him in his supposed distress. It'll look good for us, and it is likely to end in us receiving what the others got, if it is in fact true that he has money.
response: What have you now to present unto him?

instruction: I mean to enter the house, sir.
response: I will answer you with gait and entrance.

instruction: What is this? What are you talking about? It's true that my brother's daughter is the Queen of Tunis as well as the heir to the throne of Naples, and that a great distance separates those two places.
response: A space whose every cubit Seems to cry out, How shall that Claribel Measure us back to Naples?

instruction: Blue, sir.
response: Nay, that's a mock: I have seen a lady's noseThat has been blue, but not her eyebrows.

instruction: My job isn't to debate the reason. It's just to do it.
response: You will not do't for all the world, I hope.

instruction: Never, my lord. So prepare to die.
response: Are you drawn forth among a world of men To slay the innocent?

instruction: You made an oath of eternal love, which was confirmed by joining hands, proved by a holy kiss, and strengthened by an exchange of rings. I witnessed and approved all this in my official capacity as a priest. All this took place only two hours ago.
response: O thou dissembling cub!

instruction: [Reading the oracle] Hermione is virtuous,Polixenes is blameless,Camillo is a loyal subject,Leontes is a jealous tyrant,The baby is his biological daughter,And the king will have no heirUntil he finds that which is lost.
response: Now blessed be the great Apollo!

instruction: I found it in my room, and Iago himself just confessed that he left it there on purpose as part of his plan.
response: O fool!

instruction: Good question, my dear girl. My story does indeed bring up that question. My dear, they didnt dare. Because I was so loved by the people of Milan, Antonio and Alonso had to keep any blood from staining their actions, and hide their evil goals behind a prettier picture. In short, they hurried us onto a ship and carried us a few miles out to sea. There, they had prepared a rotten shell of a boat that had no ropes, equipment, sails, or a mast. Even the rats had abandoned it when they sensed its likelihood to sink.They lowered us down into the water. We were left to cry out to the sea, which just roared back at us. We sighed in sadness to the wind, which sighed back in pity. And in doing so it buffeted us with winds thatno matter how lovingonly made us more uncomfortable.
response: Alack, what troubleWas I then to you!

instruction: I swore I would, so here we go . . . [He grabs MARINA]
response: Hold, villain!

instruction: Actually, it seems the "fool" goes with you.
response: No, thou stand'st single, thou'rt not on him yet.

instruction: Yes, she may, Lord Rivers. Why, everyone knows that she may. And she may do more than just denying that, sir. She may help you to many nice promotions and then deny that she aided you, claiming that you won those honors through your own merit. What may she not do? She may, yes, by God, she may
response: What, marry, may she?

instruction: Oh, I am a villain.
response: It is even so.

instruction: Your argument is contradictory, a forced attempt to make gross actions seem justifiable. Your rhetoric reaches almost to the point of labor as it tries to turn murder into a mere formality and feuding into an act of valor. Feuds actually prove to be valor in its most degenerate form, as they come from the formation of rivalries. A man is truly valiant only when he can endure the worst insults men can speak, and even wear them like clothing without a care in the world. True valor never takes injury to heart, or retaliates in violence. If acts of injustice are in fact evil and force us to kill others, how dumb it would be then to risk your life for such a cause!
response: My lord,

instruction: You can say it, but don't swear it.
response: Not swear it, now I am a gentleman?

instruction: I'm afraid that meat like that is choleric and will make you angry. What do you say to a fat cow stomach, well-broiled?
response: I like it well.

instruction: Look at this huge crowd of flooding visitors. I have in this draft of my poem drawn the outline of a man beloved and embraced by the earthly world. I do not mean to represent particular people, but work in generalities as if my tablet were an entire sea of wax. Personal grudges do not affect even the smallest details of my writing. My creative process flies forth, strong as an eagle in flight, and leaves no trace of its earthly inspirations.
response: How shall I understand you?

instruction: Holy lady, you've spoken so highly of us foolsit's almost as if your eldest son was going to be a fool. And may God cram his skull with brains, for here comes one of your relatives whose head is quite empty.
response: By mine honor, half-drunk.

instruction: [To GREMIO and HORTENSIO] Gentlemen, I want to make good on what I've saidso Bianca, go inside. And don't let this make you unhappy, good Bianca, for I'll never love you any less, my girl.
response: A pretty peat!

instruction: I already said that, you stupid thing. Caliban, who I now keep as a servant. You know better than anyone the pain you were in when I found you. Your groans made wolves howl, and made perpetually angry bears feel pity for you. The spell that Sycorax put on youand which she could not undowas something fit only for souls damned to hell. When I arrived on the island and heard you, it was my magic that made the pine tree open and let you out.
response: I thank thee, master.

instruction: What is your name? Has mankind been so awful to you? You are a man, after all.
response: I am Misanthropos, and hate mankind.For thy part, I do wish thou wert a dog,That I might love thee something.

instruction: Is she as fiery a shrew as she's reported to be?
response: She was, good Curtis, before this frost.

instruction: Oh, sir, I wish you would listen to my advice; you might need it.
response: Hark, Perdita [Drawing her aside] I'll hear you by and by.

instruction: Down to the last detail. I boarded the kings ship. And from the prow, to the middle of the ship, to the stern, and in every cabin, I took the form of a fire and sent everyone into a terror. Sometimes I would divide myself, and burn at many places at once. I burned on the main mast, the yards extending from the mastand, at the same time, split to burn the bowsprit extending from the prow. Then I joined back together to form a single flame. Not even Jove's lightningwhich precedes and then causes thundercould move as fast as I did. The fire and deafening cracks of my burning seemed to terrify even mighty Neptune, the god of the sea, and made his waves tremble and his weaponthe tridentshake.
response: My brave spirit!Who was so firm, so constant, that this coilWould not infect his reason?

instruction: What's this here? Is he dead or drunk? Check and see if he's breathing.
response: He breathes, my lord.

instruction: The hart.
response: Why, so I do, the noblest that I have.

instruction: What, are they dead?
response: They are; and Bolingbroke Hath seized the wasteful king.

instruction: Alas, he has been betrayed, and now I am ruined.
response: Out, strumpet!

instruction: What is the matter?
response: Behold, I have a weapon.

instruction: Youre a lover. Borrow Cupids wings and use them to soar higher than the average man.
response: I am too sore enpiercèd with his shaft To soar with his light feathers, and so bound, I cannot bound a pitch above dull woe.

instruction: You have undone our mother.
response: Villain, I have done thy mother.

instruction: [To STEPHANO] Ill swear on that wine bottle in order to become your loyal subject, because that wine must come from heaven.
response: [to TRINCULO] Here.

instruction: Flaminius! Can we talk for a second? Is Timon coming?
response: No, indeed, he is not.

instruction: He's well known to me. You are welcome for his sake.
response: Saving your tale, Petruchio, I prayLet us that are poor petitioners speak too.

instruction: I also said I needed to deal with some business matters, but he didn't care. I am not happy to say it, but when he asked me for money, I had no more left to give him.
response: I am sick of that grief too, as I understand how allthings go.

instruction: Quietly and quickly, sir. The priest is ready.
response: I fly, Biondello.

instruction: I am from Messaline. Sebastian was my father, and my brother was also named Sebastian. He was dressed just like you when he drowned. If ghosts can take on human forms and clothes, then you must be here to frighten us.
response: A spirit I am indeed, But am in that dimension grossly clad Which from the womb I did participate.

instruction: And what else?
response: His daughter is to be brought by you to the supper.

instruction: You weeping princes and sorrowful nobles who bear this mutual weight of grief, let us now cheer each other up with our love. Though we have lost our old, fruitful king, we will now reap the harvest of his son. Our former hatreds were only recently broken and then rejoined as friendship, and now we must gently preserve, cherish, and keep this new goodwill. It seems like a good idea that a small group of us should now set out for Ludlow Castle in Wales, to fetch the young prince and bring him here to London, where he will be crowned our king.
response: Why with some little train, my Lord of Buckingham?

instruction: If you will come have dinner with me tonight, then okay. If you don't come to dinner then just keep on waiting until I call for you nextwhich will be never.
response: After her, after her.

instruction: I'll do it with all my heart, and it pleases me to see how remorseful you've become.
response: Bid me farewell.

instruction: Yes, I did, sirand now I've got a plan!
response: I have it, Tranio!

instruction: Now, fellow, what are you carrying?
response: Things for the cook, sir, but I know not what.

instruction: Here, madam, at your service.
response: Run after that same peevish messenger, The countys man.

instruction: Go away, go on, you're a foolish fellow. Leave me alone.
response: Well held out, i' faith.

instruction: Madam, here comes my husband.
response: Madam, Ill take my leave.

instruction: It's so weird how Timon must pay out more than he owes, while your lord seems to get the privilege of wearing the jewels and getting to request the money paid for them.
response: I'm weary of this charge, the gods can witness:I know my lord hath spent of Timon's wealth,And now ingratitude makes it worse than stealth.

instruction: Fool!
response: (sings) My lady is unkind, perdy.

instruction: With all due respect, Petruchio, please let us poor petitioners get a word in too. Stand backyou're too forward.
response: Oh, pardon me, Signior Gremio, I would fain be doing.

instruction: That king is like a picture of my own father; looking at him reminds me of how glorious he once was. He used to have princes sit around his throne like stars, looking up to him like the sun. No one who saw him could hold a candle to his greatness; those smaller lights were outshone by his supremacy. I, his, son, am just a little firefly. You can see me at night, but I'm invisible in the day. From this, I can say that Time rules men. He raises men up and he puts them in their graves, and doesn't always give them what they want.
response: What, are you merry, knights?

instruction: Then I think it's time for me to smile again. Oh, how easy it is for the poor to be proud of something they don't have! But if I must be defeated, then better to be defeated by a noble enemy than a lowly one.
response: The clock upbraids me with the waste of time.

instruction: Why should you feel sorry for her?
response: Because methinks that she loved you as well As you do love your lady Silvia: She dreams of him that has forgot her love; You dote on her that cares not for your love.

instruction: [To himself] He'll make the man go crazy, pretending that he's a woman.
response: Young budding virgin, fair and fresh and sweet, Whither away, or where is thy abode?

instruction: No doubt, no doubt. Oh, he's a dangerous and cunning boybold, lively, ingenious, outspoken, and capable. He takes after his mother, from head to toe.
response: Well, let them rest.

instruction: Or even walk. Instead youll lie there like sleeping dogs and say nothing.
response: Mooncalf, speak once in thy life, if thou beest a good mooncalf.

instruction: Psst! Romeo! Psst! Oh, I wish I could cry out like a falconer, so I could call my little falcon to return to me. Stuck as I am in my familys house, I have to be quiet. Otherwise I would tear open the cave where Echo sleeps and make her call out my loves name until her voice grew more hoarse than mine by repeating, My Romeo!
response: It is my soul that calls upon my name.

instruction: My lord, it's Ratcliffe, it's me. The village rooster has already crowed twice to welcome the dawn. Your friends are up and putting on their armor.
response: O Ratcliffe, I have dreamed a fearful dream!

instruction: When I destroy Athens in war
response: Warr'st thou 'gainst Athens?

instruction: How well you've depicted the scene! This throne, this depiction of Fortune, and this hillwith one man beckoned from the rest below, bowing his head before the great mountain on which Fortune sits, the source of his happinessperfectly captures the human condition.
response: Nay, sir, but hear me on.

instruction: My legs can't keep time in delight, when my poor heart can't keep time in grief. Therefore, no dancing, girl; something else to pass the time.
response: Madam, we'll tell tales.

instruction: I will. Go, Biondello, and tell your mistress to come to me.
response: I go.

instruction: Right, because I mean you.
response: And I am mean indeed, respecting you.

instruction: If only Leonine hadn't been so slow! He should have killed me instead of talking so much. Or if only the pirates (as if they weren't barbarous enough) had thrown me overboard, to go after my mother!
response: Why lament you, pretty one?

instruction: Well, you have a father who cares for you, child. To help you escape your sadness, he has arranged a soon-to-come day of joy that you didnt expect and that I had not considered.
response: Madam, in happy time, what day is that?

instruction: You don't have enough strength to do me half as much harm as I can endure. Oh, you fool! You idiot! You are as ignorant as dirt! You've dome something so awful . . . I don't care about your sword. I'd spread the news of this even if I was killed twenty times. Help! Hey, help! The Moor has killed my mistress! Murder! Murder!
response: What is the matter?

instruction: And for me also. And so, I think, for all of us. But since our agreement is so fresh, we shouldn't risk putting it under too much stresswhich might happen if all of us go at once to fetch the prince. So I agree with noble Buckingham that it's best for only a few to go.
response: And so say I.

instruction: Hello, my lord. I'm glad to see you.
response: I thank thee, good Sir John, with all my heart.I am in your debt for your last exercise.Come the next sabbath, and I will content you.

instruction: To "fare well" is more than you deserve. But since you're now teaching me how to flatter you, pretend that I've said "farewell" already.
response: Sirs, take up the corse.

instruction: Where is the gentleman that was with her?
response: Being nimble-footed, he hath outrun us, But Moyses and Valerius follow him.

instruction: Should Timon really have to struggle for this? He could go to Lord Lucius or Lucullus for a loan, and he could also call on the rich Ventidius, who is free from prison thanks to Timon. All these men owe some of their wealth to Timon.
response: My lord,They have all been touch'd and found base metal, forThey have all denied him.

instruction: And did you see the handkerchief?
response: Was that mine?

instruction: She loves you too much to hurt you, boy.
response: Ay, when my father was in Rome she did.

instruction: I thank them, and would send them a disease if only I could catch it for them.
response: O, forget What we are sorry for ourselves in thee.

instruction: All the sooner because you asked, sweetheart.
response: Shall t be tonight at supper?

instruction: Come, rich Ceres, and entertain Juno.
response: Hail, many-colored messenger, that ne'er Dost disobey the wife of Jupiter; Who with thy saffron wings upon my flowers Diffusest honey drops, refreshing showers; And with each end of thy blue bow dost crown My bosky acres and my unshrubbed d

instruction: Aaron, what should I tell the empress?
response: Advise thee, Aaron, what is to be done,And we will all subscribe to thy advice:Save thou the child, so we may all be safe.

instruction: If God had decided to give me some affliction, if he had put all kinds of shameful sores on my bare head, had made me extremely poor, and made me a prisoner with no hope, I would have found a way to endure it. But, alas, to make me a laughing-stock forever, and an object of scorn! And yet, I could even endure that too, very well. But to do something to my heart, on which my life depends, which pumps all the blood through my veins, to dry it up and turn into a basin for foul toads to wallow and couple in! The very god of Patience could look at my heart with her young, rosy lips, and her complexion would turn grim as hell!
response: I hope my noble lord esteems me honest.

instruction: That you love my daughter from your soulfar from your soul. Just like you loved her brothers. And from my heart's same love I thank you for it.
response: Be not so hasty to confound my meaning.I mean that with my soul I love thy daughterAnd do intend to make her Queen of England.

instruction: Benvolio is a Montague. His loyalty compels him to lie. Hes lying. There must have been twenty Montagues fighting, and together all twenty of them could only kill one man. I beg for justice that only you, Prince, can give. Romeo killed Tybalt. Romeo must die.
response: Romeo slew him; he slew Mercutio.Who now the price of his dear blood doth owe?

instruction: If you want to see the real results of this joke, then watch him when he first approaches my lady. He'll come to her in yellow stockingsa color she hatesand with crossed laces on his legsa fashion she despises. And he'll smile constantly at her, which will go completely against her current mood, as she seems addicted to melancholy lately. All of it together will surely make her notice him and scorn him. If you want to see this, follow me.
response: To the gates of Tartar, thou most excellent devil of wit!

instruction: Then do it tomorrow night, or Tuesday morning. Or Tuesday at noon, or Tuesday night, or even Wednesday morning. You name the time, but please sometime within the next three days. Truly, he regrets what he's done, and his error wasn't really that seriousexcept that, as they say, military discipline requires that you be most strict with the best soldiersand should barely have even required a private scolding . When will Cassio come back? Tell me, Othello. If you asked me for something, I wouldn't just say no, or stand there hesitating. What do you say? Michael Cassio helped you when you were courting me, and whenever I criticized you he stood up for you. Why should it be so hard for him to get to talk with you? Trust me, I could do a lot
response: Prithee, no more.

instruction: Sir, if I knew my statue would make you so upsetsince it belongs to meI wouldn't have showed it to you.
response: Do not draw the curtain.

instruction: My weak arm, my gracious lord, is as close are you're going to get to an army: gloom guides my tongue and makes me speak of nothing but despair. Returning one day too late, I'm afraid, noble lord, has ruined all your happy days on earth: oh, call back yesterday, tell time to run backwards, and you would have had twelve thousand men to fight for you! But today, today, unhappy day, it's too late: your joys, friends, fortune and kingdom are lost. For all the Welshmen, hearing you were dead, have left and gone to fight for Bolingbroke.
response: Comfort, my liege; why looks your grace so pale?

instruction: It's reported that Sir Thomas Lovell and the Lord Marquess of Dorset are gathering an army in Yorkshire. But I bring your Highness this comfort: Richmond's navy has been dispersed by a storm. At Dorsetshire, Richmond sent a boat to shore to ask the men on the banks if they were his allies. They answered that they were with Buckingham. Richmond didn't trust them, and he hoisted sail and returned to Brittany.
response: March on, march on, since we are up in arms,If not to fight with foreign enemies,Yet to beat down these rebels here at home.

instruction: Ill fight their entire army of devils, one at a time.
response: Ill be thy second.

instruction: What?
response: Well, thou hast comforted me marvelous much.

instruction: I am watching, by God, I am. It's a good play, to be sure. Is there any more?
response: My lord, tis but begun.

instruction: Spiteful and intolerable treatment! How can I endure this monstrous behavior? I know where this came fromcan I bear this? He acts as if his traitorous sons, that died lawfully for murdering my brother, have been unjustly killed by me! Go, drag the villain here by his hair; I won't go any easier on him because he's old and honored in battle. For this proud mockery I'll kill him, the crafty, crazy bastard, who helped to give me the throne hoping he could take control of Rome and me.
response: What news with thee, AEmilius?

instruction: Kill me tomorrowlet me live tonight!
response: Nay, if you strive

instruction: Romeo will thank you, my girl, for both of us.
response: As much to him, else is his thanks too much.

instruction: Oh, but from that no hope arise amazing hopes for you! No hope for Ferdinand's survival is, for you, so high a hope that not even ambition for greatness could imagine anything higheror even entirely believe that this possibility exists. Do you agree with me that Ferdinand has drowned?
response: Hes gone.

instruction: Madam, there's a young gentleman at the gate who greatly desires to speak with you.
response: From the Count Orsino, is it?

instruction: [To FERDINAND] Wait, sir! I have one more thing to say.[To himself] Theyre in love with each other. But I have to put some obstacles in the way of this quick love, so that they dont undervalue their love because it came so easily.[To FERDINAND] Just one more thing to say. I demand that you listen to me. You are stealing a name for yourself that does not belong to you. Youve come to this island as a spy to try to take this island from me, its lord.
response: No, as I am a man!

instruction: Since I hope to enjoy quiet days, beautiful children, and a long life filled with the love that I have now, not even the greatest opportunity or strongest temptation will allow my worse instincts to overcome my honor, and let me give in to lust. Doing so would only remove the anticipation from that day's celebration, when I'll be so excited for my first night with Miranda that I'll wonder if the sun has stopped in the sky, or if night has been locked away somehow.
response: Fairly spoke.Sit then and talk with her.
