instruction: Do I look as pale as everyone else, Lord Dorset?
response: Ay, my good lord, and no one in the presenceBut his red color hath forsook his cheeks.

instruction: No sir, God forbid, but I am ashamed to kiss.
response: Why, then lets home again.

instruction: Father, whats the news? Did the Prince state how I am to be punished? What unknown suffering is coming for me?
response: Too familiarIs my dear son with such sour company.I bring thee tidings of the Princes doom.

instruction: But I have no pity, so I must not be a beast.
response: O, wonderful, when devils tell the truth!

instruction: If I do not consent to her marriage, with the gods as my witness, I will choose my heir from all the beggars of the world and deprive her of everything.
response: How shall she be endow'd,if she be mated with an equal husband?

instruction: The nobleman would have done with her what a nobleman does, but she sent him away as cold as a snowball, and saying his prayers, too.
response: Boult, take her away; use her at thy pleasure:crack the glass of her virginity, and make the rest malleable.

instruction: What is the matter, lady?
response: Alas, Iago, my lord hath so bewhored her,Thrown such despite and heavy terms upon her, That true hearts cannot bear it.

instruction: I can't admit to things that I haven't done. As far as Polixenes is concerned, I can only confess that I loved him as much as I should, with the kind of love that a woman in my position should givethe kind of love that you, yourself, commanded that I show. If I hadn't cared for him, I would have been disobedient to you and inhospitable toward your friend. I mean, you've loved Polixenes since before you could speak, since you were a baby, and he's always loved you back. As for conspiracy: I've never tasted it, despite the fact that you keep serving it to me on a plate. All I know is that Camillo was an honest man. God only knows why he left your court; I have no idea.
response: You knew of his departure, as you knowWhat you have underta'en to do in's absence.

instruction: I wouldve been a dreadful king, then.
response: [indicating CALIBAN] This is a strange thing as e'er I looked on.

instruction: I've told you all that I know. Why the nobles were arrested, and on what charges, is all unknown to me, my gracious lord.
response: Ay me!

instruction: [As LITIO] But this is not Katherine, that quarrelsome know-it-allthis is the goddess of heavenly harmony. So let me go first, and after we've spent an hour on music, you can have the same amount of time for your lesson.
response: [as CAMBIO] Preposterous ass, that never read so far To know the cause why music was ordained.

instruction: The same thing that was in my words.
response: I fear me both are false.

instruction: It is Alcibiades and twenty horsemen, all together.
response: Pray, entertain them; give them guide to us.

instruction: You flatter my misery.
response: I flatter not; but say thou art a caitiff.

instruction: May God protect me from false friendsbut my uncles weren't false.
response: My lord, the mayor of London comes to greet you.

instruction: A man calling himself Prince Florizel, son of Polixenes, is here with a beautiful princess. He's asked to see you.
response: What with him?

instruction: Yes, I'll do that. And from now on I'll be smart and always try to be good. What a magnificent jackass I was, to think this drunkard was a god and worship the dumb fool!
response: Go to, away.

instruction: For what reason, I ask you?
response: For this reason, if youll know:That shes the choice love of Signior Gremio.

instruction: If you had hated meddlers sooner, you would have loved your station better now. What wasteful man did you ever meet that was well-liked after his money was gone?
response: Who, without those means thou talkest of, didst thouever know beloved?

instruction: Whichever it is, it's a mistake.
response: Neither.

instruction: I wish they were basilisks, so they could strike you dead.
response: I would they were, that I might die at once, For now they kill me with a living death.

instruction: His clothes are fancy, but he's not wearing them elegantly.
response: He seems to be the more noble in being fantastical:a great man, I'll warrant; I know by the pickingon's teeth.

instruction: That will make me think the world is full of rubs, and that the ball is weighted against me.
response: Madam, we'll dance.

instruction: I am Christopher Sly. Don't call me your "Honor" or your "Lordship." I've never drunk Spanish wine in my life. And if you give me anything "preserved," give me some salted beef. Don't bother asking what "outfit" I'll wear, for I have no more jackets than I do backs, no more stockings than I have legs, and no more shoes than I have feet. Sometimes I even have more feet than shoes, unless the ones where my toes stick out count as shoes.
response: Heaven cease this idle humor in your Honor!

instruction: I will not rise until your Highness hears my request.
response: Then say at once what is it thou requests.

instruction: Why does it have to be this way? It cannot be. Please, my lords, I beg you to trust me.
response: How!

instruction: Are you biting your thumb at us, sir?
response: I do bite my thumb, sir.

instruction: What now? We'll have to try a different tactic with you. Your worthless virginitywhich isn't worth a cheap breakfast eaten in the nightisn't about to ruin this place; I'd rather be neutered like a dog than see that happen. Come with me.
response: Whither would you have me?

instruction: [To himself] I am almost afraid to stand here alone in the graveyard, but Ill do it.
response: [Scatters flowers around JULIETS closed tomb] Sweet flower, with flowers thy bridal bed I strew O woe!

instruction: Let me prove it, my gracious lord.
response: Darst thou resolve to kill a friend of mine?

instruction: That's a good one. But come on, begin.
response: What a caterwauling do you keep here!

instruction: Yes, ruined land, my lord.
response: We are so virtuously bound

instruction: What promise, dear?
response: I have sent to bid Cassio come speak with you.

instruction: What villain, madam?
response: That same villain, Romeo.

instruction: Why, what would you do there before I arrive?
response: Your Highness told me I should post before.

instruction: First improve my company and get away from me.
response: So I shall mend mine own, by the lack of thine.

instruction: I dont know, sir.
response: Oh, she doth teach the torches to burn bright!

instruction: That doesn't make any sense.
response: I know not where he lodges, and for me to devise a lodging and say he lies here, or he lies there, were to lie in mine own throat.

instruction: Please be calm, my good man.
response: When the sea is.

instruction: Do you know these two?
response: The empress' sons, I take them, Chiron and Demetrius.

instruction: Away! Get away from me! You have tortured me. I swear it's better to be horribly betrayed and not realize it than to know a bit about it.
response: How now, my lord!

instruction: Oh, my good lord, foul murders have been committed outside!
response: What, now?

instruction: Did you start that young? Were you a prostitute at the age of five or seven?
response: Earlier too, sir, if now I be one.

instruction: Where is he?
response: At Ely House.

instruction: Good job, that vagueness will keep you from being accused of slander.
response: (reads) Thou comest to the lady Olivia, and in my sight she uses thee kindly.

instruction: I will not go.
response: Fie!

instruction: For what crime?
response: The sum of all I can, I have disclosed.Why, or for what, the nobles were committedIs all unknown to me, my gracious lord.

instruction: Amen to that! Let's go, good Eglamour. Let's go out at the back gate by the abbey wall. I am afraid that some spies are following me.
response: Fear not: the forest is not three leagues off;If we recover that, we are sure enough.

instruction: God bless you, friend, and your music. Do you make your living by playing your drum?
response: No, sir, I live by the church.

instruction: If it would please your Lordship to have us.
response: With all my heart.

instruction: By heaven, you accuse me wrongly!
response: Are you not a strumpet?

instruction: Not at all, sir. I live by the church because I live in my house, and my house is by the church.
response: So thou mayst say the king lies by a beggar if a beggardwell near him, or the church stands by thy tabor, if thy tabor stand by the church.

instruction: Then why don't you tell the story! If you hadn't interrupted me, you would have heard about how her horse fell, with her under it. You would have heard about the swampy place she landed, and how she was covered in mud, and how my master left her with the horse on top of her, and beat me because her horse stumbled, and how she waded through the dirt to pull him off of me, and how he swore, and how she prayedshe who had never prayed beforeand how I yelled, and how the horses ran away, and how her bridle was broken, and how I lost my saddle strap, and many other things worth being remembered, but which will now be forgotten, and you'll go ignorant to your grave.
response: By this reck'ning he is more shrew than she.

instruction: Put away your sword. If this young gentleman has offended you, then let the blame pass to me. And if you've offended him, then I'll fight you on his behalf.
response: You, sir?

instruction: Oh please, woman. Throw your vile guesses back to hell, where they came from. You are jealous now and think that this handkerchief is from some mistress. No, in truth, it isn't, Bianca.
response: Why, whose is it?

instruction: Sir, you speak well, and you understand well. And since you declare yourself a suitor, you must do as we already have, and pay this gentleman to whom we all owe so much.
response: [as LUCENTIO] Sir, I shall not be slack; in sign whereof, Please ye we may contrive this afternoon And quaff carouses to our mistress' health And do as adversaries do in law, Strive mightily, but eat and drink as friends.

instruction: They're Senators of Athens. How lucky is he!
response: Look, more!

instruction: Then prove it.
response: I must catechise you for it, madonna.

instruction: Yes, if only they were our assistants!
response: So would I,as good a trick as ever hangman served thief.

instruction: You are all welcome; please let the ladies kindly enter. Music, play them in!
response: You see, my lord, how ample you're beloved.

instruction: [Giving a paper to the FIRST SERVINGMAN] Invite all the guests written on this list.
response: [To SECOND SERVINGMAN] Sirrah, go hire me twenty cunning cooks.

instruction: I'm worried we won't be.
response: Here comes the lord.

instruction: How are things, Roderigo?
response: I do not find that thou dealst justly with me.

instruction: I don't want a bigger one. This one agrees with the present fashion, and all gentlewomen wear caps like this.
response: When you are gentle, you shall have one too,And not till then.

instruction: Past noon.
response: At least two glasses.

instruction: Noble lord, I ask you to pardon me for another night or two, or at least wait until nightfall. Your doctors have expressly ordered me not to sleep with you, as otherwise you might be in danger of a relapse of your illness. I hope this reason will stand as my excuse.
response: Ay, it stands so that I may hardly tarry so long.

instruction: God, I'd rather be his executioner than his flag-bearer.
response: Why, theres no remedy.

instruction: My noble lord, he asks your Grace to please visit him tomorrow or the next day. He is inside with two priests, deep in prayer. He doesn't want to be disturbed from his holy labors by any worldly business.
response: Return, good Catesby, to the gracious duke.

instruction: If youre a man who's playing that music, show yourself. If youre a devil, then you can go to hell.
response: O, forgive me my sins!

instruction: Why, you are king, my glorious lord.
response: Ha!

instruction: Then no man has ever been an honest man.
response: Well, well, put up your sword.

instruction: A man, good lady, whom God has made for himself to ruin.
response: By my troth, it is well said.

instruction: Go, idiots, go, and fetch me my supper.
response: Singing Where is the life that late I led Where are those Sit down, Kate, and welcome.Soud, soud, soud, soud!

instruction: Let it go. Some men might be more optimistic. Your truthfulness, your being what you proclaim to be, make ungrateful men more noticeable.
response: He and myselfHave travail'd in the great shower of your gifts,And sweetly felt it.

instruction: I hope not, considering how much merchandise I have with me.
response: What hast here?

instruction: Hopefully the reading of the prophecy is as successful as our journey (for the queen's sake). It was a great, enjoyable, quick trip, but we can only hope it was worth the time.
response: Great ApolloTurn all to the best!

instruction: The truth will come out, the truth will come out. Me, be quiet? No, I will speak as freely as the north wind blows. I don't care if all angels and devils and humans cry out that I am shameful for disobeying my husband, I will still speak out.
response: Be wise, and get you home.

instruction: Give me your hand. It's moist, my lady.
response: It hath felt no age nor known no sorrow.

instruction: My little hawk?
response: What oclock tomorrowShall I send to thee?

instruction: Well, sir, its a bad cook who refuses to lick his own fingers. So I wont hire any cooks who wont lick their own fingers.
response: Go, be gone.

instruction: Am I that name, Iago?
response: What name, fair lady?

instruction: Well, give her that ring, and with it, this letter. That's her room there. Tell my lady that she should keep her promise and give me her heavenly picture. Once you deliver the message, go home to my room, where you will find me sad and alone.
response: How many women would do such a message?

instruction: None, sir. I have no pheasant, male or female.
response: How blessed are we that are not simple men!Yet nature might have made me as these are,Therefore I will not disdain.

instruction: All men do, except Proteus.
response: Nay, if the gentle spirit of moving words Can no way change you to a milder form, I'll woo you like a soldier, at arms' end, And love you 'gainst the nature of love,force ye.

instruction: A thousand thanks, Sir Gremio. Welcome, good Cambio.
response: [as LUCENTIO] Pardon me, sir, the boldness is mine own, That being a stranger in this city here Do make myself a suitor to your daughter, Unto Bianca, fair and virtuous.

instruction: Oh, it's going to be great!
response: Sport royal, I warrant you.

instruction: No eyes are as beautiful as hers were. Don't be afraid of me marrying a wife, Paulina; I won't marry a new wife.
response: Will you swearNever to marry but by my free leave?

instruction: The hand that kills me will burn in hell forever. Exton, you've stained the land with its own king's blood. Go up to heaven, my soul! Your place is up there, while my body sinks downward to die.
response: As full of valour as of royal blood: Both have I spill'd; O would the deed were good!

instruction: [Singing]It was the friar in robes of gray,Who walked along on his way:
response: One, Kate, that you must kiss and be acquainted with.Where are my slippers?

instruction: I think his soul is in hell, lady.
response: I know his soul is in heaven, fool.

instruction: It's a terrible thing to die when you're unprepared and not expecting it, my gracious lord.
response: O monstrous, monstrous!

instruction: I am a prince, MirandaI think I'm probably now a king, though I wish that were not trueand normally I wouldn't tolerate being forced to carry logs any more than Id let insects fly into my mouth. But listen to this, from the bottom of my soul. The moment that I saw you, my heart rushed to serve you, and it remains there as your servant. So, for your sake, I patiently carry these logs.
response: Do you love me?

instruction: Yes, for the worst of you is filthy, and I fear too rotten to hold.
response: Ladies, there is an idle banquet attends you:Please you to dispose yourselves.

instruction: Oh, I wish that my sovereign might turn away his face and be deaf for a little while, until I have told this villain how God and good men hate foul liars like him.
response: Mowbray, impartial are our eyes and ears: Were he my brother, nay, my kingdom's heir, As he is but my father's brother's son, Now, by my sceptre's awe, I make a vow, Such neighbour nearness to our sacred blood Should nothing privilege him,

instruction: A thousand misfortunes greater than this one have taught me how to endure this patiently.
response: Come, bring her away.

instruction: It's very suspicious, even though it's only a dream. And this may support and strengthen other, shakier evidence.
response: Ill tear her all to pieces!

instruction: Come, come, we're worrying about the worst possible outcome. I'm sure that everything will be all right.
response: When clouds are seen, wise men put on their cloaks; When great leaves fall, then winter is at hand; When the sun sets, who doth not look for night?

instruction: Hey, Mountain, hey!
response: Silver.

instruction: Ive seen you in the moon, and I love you. My mother showed you to me, as well as your dog and bundle of sticks.
response: Come, swear to that, kiss the book.

instruction: Here is Servilius. Now we'll know what is going on.
response: If I might beseech you, gentlemen, to repair some other hour, I should derive much from't; for, take't of my soul, my lord leans wondrously to discontent: his comfortable temper has forsook him; he's much out of health, and keeps his chambe

instruction: You saw my bad luck even when I had my wealth.
response: I see them now; then was a blessed time.

instruction: This sounds good. He will return soon enough.
response: I have a tree, which grows here in my close, That mine own use invites me to cut down, And shortly must I fell it: tell my friends, Tell Athens, in the sequence of degree From high to low throughout, that whoso please To stop affliction, le

instruction: Yes, just now, sir. I've only made it this far, walking at a moderate pace.
response: She returns this ring to you, sir.

instruction: What do you want with her, sir?
response: Who, I, my lord?

instruction: Absolutely not; she's locked in her room and it's impossible to get her out. She's sworn to remain a virgin for another year, and swears on her honor she won't go back on her promise.
response: Loath to bid farewell, we take our leaves.

instruction: You can rely on me. Go, get some money. I've said it before, and I'll say it again and again: I hate the Moor. My objective is set in my heart. And you are equally determined in yours. Let's work together to get our revenge on him. If you can get Desdemona to cheat on him with you, you'd get some pleasure and I'd get some amusement. There's still much that may happen. Now go, go and scrounge up your money. We can discuss this further tomorrow. Goodbye.
response: Where shall we meet i' th' morning?

instruction: They're the empress's sons, Chiron and Demetrius.
response: Fie, Publius, fie!

instruction: Woe, woe for England! I pity her fate, but save no pity for myself. I might have prevented this, but I was too foolish. Stanley dreamed that the boar cut off his head, and I laughed at him and refused to flee. Three times today my horse stumbled, and he bucked when he looked upon the Toweras if reluctant to carry me to the slaughterhouse. Oh, now I need that priest I spoke to earlier! And now I regret boasting to the pursuivant that my enemies were being butchered at Pomfret while I was safe and secure. Oh, Margaret, Margaret, now your heavy curse has fallen on poor Hastings' wretched head!
response: Come, come, dispatch.

instruction: For goodness' sake, have her hanged!
response: The nobleman would have dealt with her like anobleman, and she sent him away as cold as asnowball; saying his prayers too.

instruction: Why should madmen hear, when wise men cant see?
response: Let me dispute with thee of thy estate.

instruction: May you live long and miserable too, then die.
response: I am quit.Moe things like men!

instruction: Well, she cant be a prostitute unless shes so stale and old that shes only tasted when nothing else is available.[He sings]Old rabbit meat Old rabbit meatIs good meat if you cant get anything else,But old moldy rabbit,Is a waste of your coinIf it goes moldy before you can eat it[He speaks] Romeo, are you going to your fathers? Were having lunch there. Lets go.
response: I will follow you.

instruction: This will be remembered as a holy day. I wish to God that all troubles could end this well. But I must also ask your Highness to pardon your brother Clarence.
response: Why, madam, have I offered love for this,To be so flouted in this royal presence?

instruction: I swear.
response: And I, to keep all this.

instruction: Theres none of that, or just a little.
response: How lush and lusty the grass looks!

instruction: Who, Othello? I think he got so much sunlight where he was born that it burned the jealousy out of him.
response: Look where he comes.

instruction: What happened to his ship and his servants?
response: Wrecked the same instant of their master's death and in the view of the shepherd: so that all the instruments which aided to expose the child were even then lost when it was found.

instruction: The best news is that weve found our king and his men alive and safe. The next best news is that our shipwhich we thought had split in half just three hours agois as well-constructed, seaworthy, and well-supplied as it was when we first set sail.
response: [aside to PROSPERO] Sir, all this serviceHave I done since I went.

instruction: I salute you, my queen!
response: I know you not.

instruction: Truly, sir, I can't give you a reason without using words, and since words have become so false and unreliable, I'm hesitant to use them for my proof.
response: I warrant thou art a merry fellow and carest for nothing.

instruction: Put up my tent! I'll sleep here tonight. But where will I sleep tomorrow? Well, it makes no difference. Who has spied out the size of the traitor's army?
response: Six or seven thousand is their utmost power.

instruction: Will I really go win my daughter over for you?
response: And be a happy mother by the deed.

instruction: This doesn't sound much like madness.
response: See him delivered, Fabian; bring him hither.

instruction: Do whatever you want. I'll find you as long as you're underneath the sky.[To himself] I'm reeling them in now, even if you can't see my fishing line. Oh, come on! Look how she holds up her mouth, her lips to him! As confidently as if he were her own husband! [POLIXENES, HERMIONE, and their servants leave] There they go! I'm in thick and deep, over my head, and horns are sprouting above my ears! [To MAMILLIUS] Go play, boyplay! Your mother's playing, and I play such a horrible part that its reviews will put me in my grave; booing and hissing will be the last thing I hear.[To the audience] Unless I'm mistaken, plenty of men have been cheated on by their wives before now. There may even be a man here, as I'm speaking, holding his wife by the arm not knowing she slept with someone else while he was gone. Little does he know that his neighbor (you know the one, Mr. Smiley) stuck his fishing rod in that pond while he was out of town. It's actually comforting to know that I'm not alone in having something taken from me against my will. If all men who've been cheated on gave up on themselves, ten percent of the male population would hang themselves. There's no solution to it. We live on a raunchy planet and the raunchiness can strike at any time (and powerfully, believe you me) from the east, west, north, or south. It'll let the enemy in and out with bag and baggage. Thousands of us suffer from this and have no idea. [To MAMILLIUS] What's up, son?

instruction: This is really the air, and that's really the glorious sun. Here's the pearl she gave meI can feel it and see it. And though I'm full of amazement and confusion, I'm not crazy. But where's Antonio, then? I couldn't find him at the Elephant. But he had been there before me, and they told me that he was walking about the town and looking for me. His advice would be like gold to me right now. My soul makes the same strong argument as my senses, which is that all this is some mistake, but that I'm not crazy. Yet this mistake is such a sudden flood of good fortune, which exceeds all my expectations or possibility, that it makes me distrust my own eyes and wrestle with my reason, and suggests that maybe I am insaneor that the lady's insane. But if that were so, she wouldn't be able to run her house, command her servants, and take care of all her business affairs in the smooth, discreet, and stable way that she does. There's something deceptive going on here. But here comes the lady.

instruction: Then, Bolingbroke, I say that you lie from your heart through your throat. As for Gloucester's death, I didn't kill him; although I admit I let down my sworn duty in that case. As for you, my noble Lord of Lancaster, the honorable father to my enemy, I once tried to kill you, an offense that now grieves my soul greatly. But before I last received the sacrament, I confessed it and begged your grace's pardon, and I hope I had it. These are my crimes: as for the rest accused against me, it comes from the malice of a villain, a cowardly and violent traitorwhich I'll prove with my own strength, and throw down my gage upon this proud traitor's foot, to prove myself a loyal gentleman, even in the chamber of his body where all his "noble" blood flows. instruction: Answer me now. Can you love Paris?
response: Ill look to like if looking liking move.

instruction: Well, your brother's love; our duty; and your own crimes now provoke us to kill you.
response: If you do love my brother, hate not me.

instruction: Why do you cry, "Ah?"
response: I cannot chooseBut pity her.

instruction: Well, forget about that. Dorset has fled to join Richmond.
response: I hear the news, my lord.

instruction: Did you say he has his princess with him?
response: Ay, the most peerless piece of earth, I think,That e'er the sun shone bright on.

instruction: No, he cannot speak. Honest Iago has taken care of that.
response: Oh!

instruction: [Reading] "I am the scale, the foundation of all harmony:A re, to declare Hortensio's passion;B mi, Bianca, take him for your husband,C fa ut, he loves you with all affection;D sol re, I have one key but only two notes;E la mi, show me pity, or I'll die."You call this a scale? I don't like it. I prefer the old-fashioned way. I'm not so foolish as to want to replace the old, true methods.
response: Mistress, your father prays you leave your booksAnd help to dress your sisters chamber up.You know tomorrow is the wedding day.

instruction: Wait, madam. I must speak with you.
response: I have no more sons of the royal blood For thee to slaughter.

instruction: Get out, you damned doorman! Without this virgin keeping it up, this whole house would collapse and bury you! Away!
response: How's this?

instruction: I wasn't faking that. He is a worthy man.
response: Yes, he is worthy of thee, and to pay thee for thylabour: he that loves to be flattered is worthy o'the flatterer.

instruction: Man, these ugly rags hurt me more than the millions of punches and kicks I just received.
response: Alas, poor man!

instruction: And we also tried to reach out to Timon and express our city's love for him with a message of humility and promised riches. We were not unkind, and we do not deserve to fall to war.
response: These walls of ours Were not erected by their hands from whom You have received your griefs; nor are they such That these great towers, trophies and schools should fall For private faults in them.

instruction: This is a joke. Some angry god has sent you here to make the world laugh at me.
response: Patience, good sir,Or here I'll cease.

instruction: But how is it that you have this ring? I gave it to Julia when we said goodbye.
response: And Julia herself did give it me;And Julia herself hath brought it hither.

instruction: Now, where's my wife?
response: She says you have some goodly jest in hand.She will not come.

instruction: A tornado, if you could, and tell them that I have more gold here. Look, right here.
response: Here is no use for gold.

instruction: Good morning, neighbor. Where are you hurrying off to?
response: I promise you I scarcely know myself.Hear you the news abroad?

instruction: Only God knows.
response: I will be hanged, if some eternal villain, Some busy and insinuating rogue, Some cogging, cozening slave, to get some office, Have not devised this slander.

instruction: Do you want to go hunting, my lord?
response: What, Curio?

instruction: Whatever it is, it's very heavy. Open it up quick! If there's too much gold laying on the ocean floor, it's good luck that the sea has thrown it up to us.
response: 'Tis so, my lord.

instruction: Fine, just please wait until tomorrow morning.
response: Nay, good my lord,

instruction: Go on, man, you must be hanged.
response: Hanged!

instruction: Sir Proteus! How's it going? And Turio, how are you? Which of you saw Sir Eglamour recently?
response: Not I.

instruction: Lord, don't let me ever be brought to such a silly state of affairs where someone could treat me like that!
response: Fie!

instruction: You have little reason to say that.
response: Come on, come on.

instruction: I see that you don't intend to part with her, or else you don't like my company.
response: Mistake me not.

instruction: No, I am not. You will not let me be welcome, because I have come to remove you.
response: Fie, thou'rt a churl; ye've got a humour there Does not become a man: 'tis much to blame.

instruction: [To TIMON] Sir your presence has saved me from my longing, and I feed most hungrily at the sight of you.
response: Right welcome, sir!Ere we depart, we'll share a bounteous timeIn different pleasures.

instruction: No, she let it drop carelessly. And, since I happened to be here, I took the opportunity to pick it up. Look, here it is.
response: A good wench, give it me.

instruction: You already have thrown yourself away, being the madman you were, and now an idiot. Do you really think that this cold air will act like a manservant and put on a warm shirt for you? Do you really think that these mossy trees, which have outlived eagles, will follow your every step? That the cold brook crusted in ice will give you a warm drink to cure a hangover? Call out to the animals who live naked despite the fall of man, who expose their bodies to the harsh elements and contend with nature. Call them to flatter you and, oh, you will find
response: A fool of thee: depart.

instruction: My lord, what do you mean by that?
response: Well, do it, and be brief.

instruction: Continuing on would have made your tale too long.
response: Oh, thou art deceived.

instruction: Excellent! Why, this nonsense talk is the best kind of fooling when all's said and done. Now sing us a song.
response: [giving money to th e FOOL ] Come on.

instruction: Nothing but sit and sit, and eat and eat!
response: Padua affords this kindness, son Petruchio.

instruction: Miss Maria, if you care at all about Lady Olivia's approval, then you won't bring more wine and contribute to this boorish behavior. She'll hear about thisI'll tell her.
response: Go shake your ears!

instruction: Happy indeedthat's the way we've spent the day. Brother, we have done deeds of love, turning enmity to peace and hatred to love between these misguidedly angry nobles.
response: A blessèd labor, my most sovereign lord.

instruction: I hope sobecause then you'll never sleep.
response: I know so.

instruction: Here's mine.
response: And mine, my lord.

instruction: Oh Dorset, don't speak to me. Leave immediately. Death and destruction are snapping at your heels. Your mother's name has become a bad omen. If you want to outrun death, then go. Cross the seas to France, and live with Richmond, out of the reach of hell. Go, run away. Run away from this slaughterhouse, before you end up a body increasing the number of the dead, and make me die the slave of Margaret's curseneither wife, nor mother, nor England's queen.
response: Full of wise care is this your counsel, madam.

instruction: Where will I find you when I'm done?
response: Well call thee at the cubiculo.

instruction: We can, your majesty. It's not his fault that she came here.
response: You're liars all.

instruction: No, madam, no. I cannot do that. I am bound by oath, so you must forgive me.
response: Let me but meet you ladies one hour hence, And Ill salute your Grace of York as mother And reverend looker-on, of two fair queens.

instruction: Come on, then, and whisper it in my ear.
response: Was he met there?

instruction: Tell me, seriously, who is the one you love?
response: What, shall I groan and tell thee?

instruction: Oh, Eglamour, you are a gentleman. Don't think that I'm flattering you; I swear I'm not. You are brave, wise, compassionate, well-accomplished. You know how much I care about the banished Valentine, and how my father wants to force me to marry the foolish Turio, whom I hate with all my heart. You have been in love. And I have heard you say that you have never felt more grief in your heart than you did when your ladyyour true lovedied. And you have vowed pure chastity on her grave. Sir Eglamour, I want to go to Valentine in Mantua, where I heard he is. And since the journey is dangerous, I would like your worthy company, because I rely on your faith and honor. Don't encourage my father's anger, Eglamour. Just think about my griefa lady's griefand about the justice of my running away from here; and from a most unholy marriagewhich heaven and fortune would always make horrible. This is coming from a heart as full of sorrows as the sea is full of sand. I want you to keep me company and go with me. If you won't then keep secret what I have said to you so that I may go alone.
response: Madam, I pity much your grievances; Which since I know they virtuously are placed, I give consent to go along with you, Recking as little what betideth me As much I wish all good befortune you.

instruction: Generous madam, whatever happens to me, I'll always be your loyal servant.
response: I know t, I thank you.

instruction: Paulina, you've comforted me so much.
response: What, sovereign sir, I did not well I meant well.

instruction: The work would suit me as much as it suits you, and it would be easier for me because I want to do it, whereas you do not.
response: [aside] Poor worm, thou art infected!This visitation shows it.

instruction: Lets say goodbye to him.
response: Now would I give a thousand furlongs of sea for an acreof barren ground: long heath, brown furze, anything.

instruction: You are deceived. Your brother Richard hates you.
response: O, no, he loves me, and he holds me dear.Go you to him from me.

instruction: How far is it, my lord, to Berkeley now?
response: Believe me, noble lord, I am a stranger here in Gloucestershire: These high wild hills and rough uneven ways Draws out our miles, and makes them wearisome, And yet your fair discourse hath been as sugar, Making the hard way sweet and delect

instruction: Gonzalo's word is like the legendary harp of Amphion, which, when played, caused the walls of Thebes to rise. Now Gonzalojust by saying sohas created a whole new city.
response: What impossible matter will he make easy next?

instruction: Everyone knew that there would be revenge for it.
response: Northumberland, then present, wept to see it.

instruction: Sir Toby, madam, your uncle.
response: Fetch him off, I pray you.

instruction: Here comes another group of people looking for you.
response: It is Brabantio.

instruction: My lords of England, let me tell you this: I know my cousin has been wronged, and I've done all I could to do him right. But to come like this, with an army, to help himself to what he wants at the dinner table, to do right by doing a wrongit must not be. And you that help him do this are all damned rebels.
response: The noble duke hath sworn his coming is But for his own; and for the right of that We all have strongly sworn to give him aid; And let him ne'er see joy that breaks that oath!

instruction: My God! What crimes were committed against us that we ended up here? Or was our coming here a blessing?
response: Both, both, my girl.

instruction: Lots of people who stay in their rooms aren't sick, and if he's as sick as you say he is, all the more reason for him to pay off his debts before he dies.
response: Good gods!

instruction: He was kind to me, sir, and drew his sword to defend me, but then he said some strange things to me. I don't know what he meant, except that he might be insane.
response: Notable pirate!

instruction: Please do, beat him up well, but don't draw your sword.
response: An I do not

instruction: I said she's dead; I'll swear it. If you don't believe me, go and see for yourself. If you can bring the color back to her cheeks, open her eyes, or get her breathing again, it would be a miracle. You tyrant! Don't you dare repent what you've done. These crimes couldn't be offset even if you mustered every ounce of remorse in your body. From now on, your whole life should be nothing but misery. A thousand people praying naked and fasting on a mountain in a perpetual winter storm for ten thousand years could not convince the gods to have mercy on you.
response: Go on, go onThou canst not speak too much; I have deservedAll tongues to talk their bitterest.

instruction: Cheer up. Give me a smile. Here, love, see how diligent I amI've prepared your meat myself, and brought it to you. I am sure, sweet Kate, that this kindness deserves your thanks. What, not a word? Well, then I guess you don't like it, and all my work was for nothing. Here, take away this dish.
response: I pray you, let it stand.

instruction: But didn't you want to have it cut, too?
response: Thou hast faced many things.

instruction: Why not?
response: Every day thou daffst me with some device, Iago, and rather, as it seems to me now, keepst from me all conveniency than suppliest me with the least advantage of hope.

instruction: Yes, but now he can't be calmed down. Fabian can barely keep him from coming over here now.
response: Plague on t, an I thought he had been valiant and so cunning in fence, Id have seen him damned ere Id have challenged him.

instruction: Sir, I'm not holding your hand.
response: Marry, but you shall have, and heres my hand.

instruction: I couldn't be less like you in that way, Timon.
response: Whither art going?

instruction: He's as tall and brave as any man in Illyria.
response: Whats that to the purpose?

instruction: He has songs for men and women of all shapes and sizes. He can fit a song to a crowd better than a tailor can fit a suit to your body. He has love songs for the ladies (and they're not dirty, none of that funny business your average street musician puts into his songs).
response: This is a brave fellow.

instruction: True, madam. And let me comfort you: when our ship was wrecked, and you and the few other survivors hung onto our drifting lifeboat, I saw your brother tie himself to the mast that was floating on the wavesacting with courage and hope in the middle of great danger. For as long as I could see him, he safely rode upon the waves like Arion on the dolphin's back.
response: [giving him money] For saying so, theres gold.

instruction: He had dinner at my house, but that's not why I'm shaking.
response: Oh, did he so?

instruction: A kind and loving wish.
response: Here lacks but your mother for to say amen.

instruction: No.
response: I am sorry to find you thus.

instruction: Here is a friar, and dead Romeos servant. Theyre carrying tools for opening a tomb.
response: O heavens!

instruction: I've changed my mind about that.
response: Go to, farewell.

instruction: Beat him up some more. After a little while, Ill beat him up too.
response: Stand farther.Come, proceed.

instruction: Your mother is of the same species: what is she if I am a dog?
response: Wilt dine with me, Apemantus?

instruction: Well, sir, I have nothing better to do, so I'll go along with this.
response: Good madonna, why mournest thou?

instruction: A sail, a sail!
response: Two, twoa shirt and a smock.

instruction: That's the reason for this, that's the reason, my soul. I won't say the reason to the chaste stars in the sky, but it is the reason. But I won't shed her blood, or scar that skin of hers that is whiter than snow and as smooth as alabaster. Still, she must die or else she'll betray more men. Extinguish the light, and then extinguish her light. If I extinguish you, flame, I can light you again if I have second thoughts. But as for youyou most artfully, excellently fashioned womanonce I put out your light, I don't know of any magical fire that can bring your life back. When I have plucked the rose of your life, I can't re-plant it againit must wither. I'll smell you while you're still alive. Oh, your gentle breath almost persuades Justice herself to put away her sword! One more, one more kiss. If you look like this when you are dead, I will kill you and love you after. [He kisses DESDEMONA] One more, and that's the last. There was never anything so sweet and yet so deadly as you. I can't help but weep, but that is not a sign of pity. This sorrow is like that of God, who must strike down the creatures he loves. She's waking up.
response: Whos there?

instruction: Oh, make them joyful. Grant their request!
response: Alas, why would you heap this care on me?

instruction: Well said.
response: Commend me to my loving countrymen,

instruction: Good King of Cats, I want nothing more than one of your nine lives. Ill boldly take that one, and, depending on how you behave after that, I just may also beat the rest of the eight out of you too. Will you draw your sword from its sheath? Hurry, or mine will be at your ears before you have yours out.
response: I am for you.

instruction: May the gods protect me!
response: If it please the gods to defend you by men, then menmust comfort you, men must feed you, men must stiryou up.

instruction: Your words are sweet music. Come here, Tyrrel.
response: Go, by this token.

instruction: I'll rejoice, man. You know, he got me in trouble with my lady Olivia once, when I held a bear-baiting here.
response: To anger him, well have the bear again, and we will fool him black and blue.

instruction: Why, sweet Othello
response: Devil!

instruction: Sell all my land.
response: 'Tis all engaged, some forfeited and gone; And what remains will hardly stop the mouth Of present dues: the future comes apace: What shall defend the interim?

instruction: [To ALONSO] Noble sir, we all feel under the weather when youre feeling gloomy.
response: Foul weather?

instruction: There's nothing to worry about, sir. The baby was imprisoned in the womb, but she's been freed by natural law. She's not under any accusations from the king, and she can't possibly be guilty of anything the queen did.
response: I do believe it.

instruction: Your debt was owed six weeks ago.
response: Your steward puts me off, my lord;And I am sent expressly to your lordship.

instruction: But quiet! Here come the executioners I've hired.
response: We are, my lord, and come to have the warrantThat we may be admitted where he is.

instruction: Such honest men! How could I ever repay you? Can you eat roots or drink cold water? No.
response: What we can do, we'll do, to do you service.

instruction: You think I'll answer you? Noblemen don't answer servants!
response: Why appear you with this ridiculous boldness before my lady?

instruction: [To MIRANDA] What? Do you, my daughterwho owes me obediencedare to tell me what to do? [To FERDINAND] Sheathe your sword, traitor. You put on a nice show there, but you wouldnt dare to actually strike me because you feel too guilty. Step out of your defensive position. For, if I wanted to, I could use this magic wand to disarm you and make your sword drop.
response: Beseech you, father.

instruction: It was nine oclock when I sent the Nurse. She promised to be back in half an hour. Maybe she cant find him. No, that makes no sense. Oh, shes so slow! Loves messengers should be thoughts, which fly ten times faster than sunbeams and drive the shadows back over the dark and scowling hills. Thats how fast swift-winged doves carry the goddess of love in her chariot, and why Cupid has wings that propel him as quickly as the wind. Now the sun is at its highest point in the skyits noon. Three hours have passed since nine oclock, and yet she hasnt returned. If she were young and in love, shed move as fast as a struck tennis ball. My words would bounce her to my sweet love, and his words would bounce her back to me. But old people act as though theyre already deadawkward, slow, heavy, and pale as lead. Oh God, shes here! Sweet Nurse, whats your news? Did you meet with him? Send your servant away.
response: Peter, stay at the gate.

instruction: But why, my good man?
response: At thy good hearts oppression.

instruction: South-west.
response: When I was born, the wind was north.

instruction: On my way, sir.
response: Welcome is peace, if he on peace consist;If wars, we are unable to resist.

instruction: Now I'll go to old Andronicus and deal with him with all the cunning I have, to get him to bring proud Lucius here from the warrior Goths. And now, sweet emperor, be cheerful again, and don't be afraid, since I'm taking care of it.
response: Then go successantly, and plead to him.

instruction: After six frozen winters have passed, come home from banishmentwith my welcome.
response: How long a time lies in one little word!

instruction: [As LUCENTIO] It's some strange whim of his that inspires this fashionthough he does often dress casually.
response: I am glad hes come, howsoe'er he comes.

instruction: My love for your Grace makes me say forcefully among all these lords that the offenders should be executed. My lord, they deserve death.
response: Then be your eyes the witness of their evil.

instruction: Why, madam, have I offered you my love only to be mocked in front of the king? Who doesn't know that the gentle duke is dead?
response: You do him injury to scorn his corse.

instruction: It's someone named Iago, the general's flag-bearer.
response: Hes had most favorable and happy speed.

instruction: I was willing to condemn my own brother to death, and now you want me to pardon a servant? My brother Clarence didn't kill anyone. His only fault was his ideas, and yet he was punished with bitter death. Who pled on his behalf? When I was so angry, who kneeled at my feet and asked me to think about what I was doing? Who spoke to me about brotherhood? Who spoke about love? Who told me how the poor soul abandoned his father-in-lawthe mighty Earl of Warwickto come fight for me? Who told me of the battlefield at Tewkesbury, where Clarence rescued me when Oxford had me down, saying, "Dear brother, live, and be a king?" Who told me how, when we both lay in the field almost freezing to death, he wrapped me in his own clothes and left himself naked, exposed to the mercy of the numbingly cold night? All this seemed erased from my memory in my brutish rage, and not a man of you had the grace to remind me. But when your servants drunkenly kill someone and scorn the law of our dear Christ, you immediately get on your knees and beg, "pardon, pardon." And I, unfair as I am, must give it to you. [Stanley rises] But no one spoke on behalf my brother, and I didn't speak to myself on his behalf either, the poor soul. Even the proudest among you owed him something, and yet none of you would beg for his life. Oh God, I fear that your justice will punish me and all these gathered here, and our families as well, because of this!
response: This is the fruits of rashness.

instruction: Eternal thanks, my poor-man bankers; this richness must stand for my reward until my infant fortune inherits his due. But who comes here?
response: It is my Lord of Berkeley, as I guess.

instruction: Thanks, gentle Romans; I hope that I'll govern graciously, to heal Rome's wounds and suffering. But, gentle people, give me a moment to mourn my father. Everyone stand aside. But uncle, come closer, to cry with me on this body. Oh, take this warm kiss on your pale cold lips.
response: These sorrowful drops upon thy blood-stain'd face,The last true duties of thy noble son!

instruction: [To herself] Ah, no joy for that "queen" indeed. For I am the queen, and completely unhappy. I can no longer hold myself back.
response: Hear me, you wrangling pirates, that fall out In sharing that which you have pilled from me!

instruction: Truly, sir, I'm better because of my enemies, and worse because of my friends.
response: Just the contrary.

instruction: Much better than I was, my friend. I can stand and walk; I'll even say goodbye and make my way toward my uncle's house.
response: Shall I bring thee on the way?

instruction: Every man's clean conscience is like a thousand swords to fight against this guilty murderer.
response: I doubt not but his friends will turn to us.

instruction: Then show it to me.
response: Had I a glass, I would.

instruction: We can make you speak with torture.
response: Well, thou dost best.

instruction: Oh, stop it! You'd starve to death in that case. [To FLORIZEL] Now, my dear: if only I had some spring flowers for you and for my friends. Spring flowers are fitting for young virgins. I wish I had the flowers the spring goddess threw away when she was carted off to the underworld! I wish I had daffodils (the earliest spring flowers), violets (so dark and sweet), primroses (that die when kissed by the sun), oxlips (the royal flowers), and every kind of lily, including the fleur-de-lis! Unfortunately I don't have any of these to make a flower-crown for you, or to throw on top of you!
response: What, like a corse?

instruction: What, are you ashamed of me?
response: No, sir, God forbid, but ashamed to kiss.

instruction: Not even a hair was harmed on anyones head. The clothes that helped keep them afloat in the water not only didnt get stained, but are in fact cleaner than they were before the storm. And, as you told me to do, Ive scattered everyone from the ship in a few different groups around the island. I brought the kings son all by himself to the land, on a far corner of the island. Hes sitting there with his arms crossed like this in sadness [ARIEL crosses his arms], and cooling the air with his sighs.
response: Of the kings ship,The mariners, say how thou hast disposed,And all the rest o' th' fleet.

instruction: Such an act of despair would prove my guilt.
response: And by despairing shalt thou stand excusedFor doing worthy vengeance on thyselfThat didst unworthy slaughter upon others.

instruction: It seems you would rather be at a breakfast with your enemies than a dinner with your friends.
response: So the were bleeding-new, my lord, there's no meatlike 'em: I could wish my best friend at such a feast.

instruction: What, is he angry?
response: Maybe the letter moved him,For, as I think, they do command him home,Deputing Cassio in his government.

instruction: She's ruining the name of our profession.
response: Marry, hang her up for ever!

instruction: Aren't you the Lady Olivia's fool?
response: No, indeed, sir; the Lady Olivia has no folly.

instruction: I think I recognize that voice. It must be...But hes drowned, and I'm surrounded by devils. Oh, God protect me!
response: Four legs and two voicesa most delicate monster.His forward voice now is to speak well of his friend.

instruction: If he'll do as he says, then that's good. But Hortensio, have you told him about all her flaws?
response: I know she is an irksome brawling scold.If that be all, masters, I hear no harm.

instruction: I am forever in your debt.
response: I see this hath a little dashed your spirits.

instruction: I'm no traitor, sir, I swear.
response: Nor I, nor any But one that's here, and that's himself, for he The sacred honour of himself, his queen's, His hopeful son's, his babe's, betrays to slander, Whose sting is sharper than the sword's; and will not For, as the case now stands,

instruction: What would my mighty master like? I am here.
response: Thou and thy meaner fellows your last service Did worthily perform, and I must use you In such another trick.

instruction: Oh, it's this that makes your wife mourn!
response: O, this is it that makes your servants droop!

instruction: [To FERDINAND] Follow me.[To MIRANDA] Dont speak in his defense. Hes a traitor.[To FERDINAND] Come, Ill chain your neck and feet together. Youll have only sea water to drink. Your food will be fresh-water mussels, old roots, and empty acorn shells. Follow me.
response: No.I will resist such entertainment tillMine enemy has more power.

instruction: Did she reject so many noble suitors and turn her back on her father, her country, and her friends just to be called a whore? Wouldn't that make anyone weep?
response: It is my wretched fortune.

instruction: A thousand pieces!
response: What of you?
